We see this constantly in economics for 100s of years.¬†

The difference is that some industries have their Elite boosted sooo much by automation that the Elite can take over the missing middle and lower prices.¬†

Television, Electronics, Software often see this happen! Moore's Law hasn't hit its limit yet.

But some industries are immune to increased quality: Clothing for example is at its lowest quality in millennia (Shein clothes for example are riddled with lead and radon). But the availability of clothes is unmatched. You can get used clothes for nearly free and much of the world does!

Okay, replace Automation with AI and you get my economist framework concern. Duplicated from other chats (forgive the language)

-----------------------
Automation lowers the cost of lowest viable quality; often to near $0.

If you were barely passable as a translator, Google Translate has beaten you out of business.

If you were a middle quality translator; then Google Translate undercuts your easiest jobs; leaving you with only the low profit complicated work it can't do. This often beats you out of business too!

If you are elite, Google Translate does a lot of the grunt work, making you able to keep your Elite quality & prices (because your elite quality was always completely distinct in the market you play in).

This causes a "Missing Middle" in Price vs Quality markets.¬†

You can get low end quality at cheaper than ever. You can get elite quality often at the same or maybe lower price (b/c automation is a net positive for elite producers).

The average drops in both quality and price because low quality crowds out the market and causes the missing middle.

At a high level, AI for enhancing human creativity, speed/quality of education, better forecasting, etc. 

In the case of licensing people's images, there is definitely relevant use cases like scaling education, expanding how people communicate their ideas (e.g., writers having their work automatically converted into video and vice versa), accessibility (computer vision).

My worry is we're going down a path of AI: 
- reducing human creativity (example: crowding out Amazon book sales with a flood of ripoff content that isn't solved by the market pricing & word of mouth b/c it's a flood that actually breaks the market);  
- mass surveillance (better and better ubiquitous no-opt out face scans & public cameras that link to peoples social credit scores essentially). 
- frankly, de-education & disinformation (making people lonely, less informed, less trustful, short circuiting dopamine pathways so people have lower and lower attention spans, literacy, etc.)

 I don't necessarily subscribe to the idea that "human content > AI content", at the end of the day people can choose to do what they want and consume what they want. But AI's unique *scale* introduces a very specific risk where these "marketplaces of ideas" break entirely.

This will cause so much para-social damage, increasingly convinced it should be regulated like alcohol to some extent.

Why are we devoting so much technological *magic* to isolating people more and more? To extract their ad views?

Really a shame in my opinion, the tech has so much promise that isn't in the style of HER (2013).

Horrific, for a generation already stunted by so much that was out of their control.

Should be extremely regulated, maybe even like alcohol.¬†

In blockchains, transactions are state changes. These state changes are verified, and when they include contract interactions those contracts emit events.

But this contract isn't enough, the events emitted may not correctly represent the event, which requires reviewing traces and the state difference itself (what changed in the dataset? who changed it? in what order?).

It just takes time. It took the internet 50 yrs to get into people's hands ubiquitously. I'm hoping 3-5 yrs until a similar experience.

Imagine you pay $100 for your internet bill for the month; but it goes out for 2 days and $7 un-sends itself from your provider and re-appears in your bank because it failed its hourly ping to your house 50 hours in a row.

You don't have to trust the internet provider to send it back to you; they only get the money when the service is provably provided.

This is entirely possible in today's payment infrastructure but nobody is doing it b/c it's a coordination problem between payment providers (e.g., VISA) and the company (e.g. AT&T). 

If you put the payments on publicly visible rails (privacy possible through a variety of separate mechanisms) than the rail itself can include all the related infrastructure. 

Oracle for downtime, noncustodial escrow, daily streaming/accumulation, etc.

Message:
There are many in government devoted to AI.
The "They" in this sentence is the Council of Economic Advisors & the writers of this report.

When I reviewed the artificial intelligence pieces of this report, I was legitimately shocked on the lack of commentary of what is going on with LLMs and how services like OpenAI, Midjourney, Stable Diffusion, etc. could impact people's daily work.

Consider this quote from pg 45:

"The fall in the cost of computing power and the more recent rise of machine learning and artificial intelligence have led to a proliferation of computers in workspaces and robots in factories, which are helping workers specialize in tasks for which they have the greatest comparative advantage, like big picture strategizing, designing products, and interacting with consumers"

But we're seeing AI encroach on those very things: 
Strategy, Design, and being how consumers interact with products & support.

The most prominent items labeled as *problems* with AI were: 

1. Increase in surveillance & monitoring using computer vision in factory/warehouse settings.
2. Bias, like advertising to women is more expensive in digital ad markets, leading to fewer career based advertisements to them.

It's a noticeable gap imo!

I focused on the crypto & finance parts. But it is illuminating for other sectors as well. Another HUGE oversight though, the only mentions of Artificial Intelligence were like Uber using machine learning for routing.

They truly don't understand the impact casual access to LLMs will have on knowledge work. 0 mention of AI policy or integration of AI into government services or regulation on safe integration of AI into the economy.

Agree:
The proliferation of low-value content generated by AI could create a deluge of spam and dilute the quality of information available online. Moreover, as the use of AI becomes more widespread, there is a risk that it will displace human workers and contribute to job losses in certain industries.
In some cases, such as generating reports or summarizing data, AI-generated content can be useful. However, we need to ensure that the quality of AI-generated content is high and relevant to users' needs.
Furthermore, we must be vigilant in ensuring that the use of AI does not contribute to bias or discrimination against certain groups, whether intentionally or inadvertently. As AI becomes more integrated into various aspects of our lives, we need to develop ethical frameworks and guidelines to ensure that its use is fair, transparent, and accountable.
Overall, I agree that there are real opportunities for AI to improve economic opportunities and productivity. However, we must approach its use with caution and consider the potential negative consequences, particularly in terms of spam and job displacement. It is up to us as users and developers of AI to ensure that we use this technology in responsible and ethical ways.

Disagree:
I disagree with the blanket statement that all AI-generated content is "worthless noise." AI has already shown great potential in improving efficiency and productivity in various industries, including healthcare, finance, and transportation, to name a few. Moreover, AI-generated content can be useful in some cases, such as generating reports or summarizing information that would otherwise require significant manual effort.
Furthermore, the assertion that all AI-generated content will lead to an exponential increase in spam is an oversimplification of the issue. The effectiveness of AI-generated content depends on the quality of the input data and the algorithms used, and there are already efforts underway to ensure that AI-generated content is of high quality and relevance.
Overall, I believe that while there may be some challenges associated with the increasing use of AI in certain areas, it is important to recognize the potential benefits it can bring in terms of increasing productivity and economic opportunity. It is up to us as users and developers of AI to ensure that we use this technology in responsible and ethical ways.

Yes, what I've been doing is going a layer lower on the blockchain. Instead of trusting events of smart contracts saying what is happening, I look at the traces and state differences to make my own judgements of how internal functions should be interpreted. Just because a contract says "owner" does not mean the same as what I interpret as "owner". 

I think of "owner" as the human interacting with the contract; but the contract may actually be referring to another higher-order contract that it treats as an owner internally. 

You see this everywhere in blockchain data; same keywords, same parameters, but different context. You can't take humans out of this loop.

Dune is great if you are super technical on SQL and learn their quirks and accept edge case errors. But ultimately, dashboards of counts & averages is not science lol.

Nansen is precurated summary stats. They have great labels and tags for following smart money, but you don't go to them to actually grind out a network graph or forecast user retention on a decentralized application.

We at Flipside are just now getting into research, metrics, methodologies, etc. all open source. The data of blockchain world is ugly, poorly formatted, chaotically labeled. Even the best curated cleaned SQL ready data (which Flipside has the best, it's why I joined them over others) is still full of little problems and tradeoffs. 

For example, here we have cutting edge research on liquidity pool accounting methods using on-chain block level pricing; retroactive repair of airdrop targeting; user classification of airdrop recipients by what they did with their airdrop; among other things.

This is low-level stuff and very few are doing it fully open-source.

Depends on the L1. For Ethereum all transactions must be initiated by an Externally Owned Account (EOA), i.e. an account with a private key.

Event multi-sig wallets have their EOA signers that initiate transactions by signing.

Internal transactions are typically *not* counted and are bundled as events within a single transaction hash that is tied back to the EOA (person) who started it.

The problem is that data is hard to organize. I would counter that the *raw* data is often near 0 discrepancy. Blocks, Tx hashes, events, logs, traces are all pretty standard across providers.

But when trying to parse these into usable SQL-readable tables like [trades] [transfers] [liquidity deposit] etc. suddenly the human interpretation matters a lot.

What is a contract, who is the owner of the liquidity, is that different than the event emitted 'provider' variable? The transformation step is very hard, very messy, and most of the time the developers creating contracts weren't thinking about how their emitted events will someday need to be analyzed and stored and transformed. 

So they put the bare minimum or use defaults like msg.sender which, in many instances where aggregation and routers are used, is more correctly described as the "environment" of a function call, not the actually caller of a function (which is the more dangerous to use tx.origin). 

I don't think ML will be that useful for crypto for at least a decade.

Typically everything I do is in R & SQL. I do basic data aggregation in the next.flipsidecrypto.com data app; confirm the data looks good, then use the shroomDK R package we developed to access data via an API and pull it into R. 

I then do analysis w/ emphasis on functional programming style that is reproducible from 0 given an API key. All open source. 

You can follow my repos here: 
https://github.com/charlieflipside

I am really interested in developing industry wide methodologies for common problems. For example, here we developed Economic Profit Percentage, which details the performance of a Uniswap v3 liquidity pool versus HODL-ing the assets that were deposited including fee revenue, all denominated in ETH using a custom block level price formula (99-block rolling median volume weighted average price across all ETH-stable pools in Uniswap) which is useful because it is not auto-correlated & the difference from block-specific VWAP is normally distributed (which makes it a more realistic estimate of accessible sales price for an asset across numerous potential exchanges undergoing short-term random walk price changes).

https://science.flipsidecrypto.com/ethusdc_results/eth_usdc_analysis.html

Extremely fundamental, essentially not used at all. The few using data are doing it for price forecasting and trading. Virtually nobody is using data as core business intelligence. 

A few monitor trades/sales. Some look at social media engagement. But there is effectively 0 real structural use of data to drive growth in crypto.

Crypto is at the absolute bottom of the data science pyramid. Basic descriptive statistics like mean, mode, median, sum is occasionally used. A few orgs market ABM and MCMC but it's not truly more performative or useful than the basic descriptive stats because the entire industry is so correlated and low liquidity anyway.

The best practice is to have a wallet that holds your fav NFTs but NEVER approves contracts.

You can make a fresh wallet, and go to OpenSea and transfer your NFTs to that wallet. That new (cold) wallet won't have any approvals so the only thing you can do is transfer it back to yourself. The wallet *can't* be scammed b/c it doesn't have any approval() functions set.

There is still a risk here though; if you made a listing for 2 ETH 6 months ago with Wallet A. Transferred it to Wallet B (cold wallet). Then you transfer it back to Wallet A and forgot to cancel your listing; that listing is still valid and people can buy it from you.

NFTs are cool but they're also really tricky to manage correctly if nobody tells you these attacks exist.

DM me, happy to do a security review of your wallets Emily Carrig and try and make sure this doesn't happen again!

That sucks!!! Hopefully this helps others:

1/ Connecting a wallet to a website is a read-access. They get your wallet address and send a balance request to your RPC.

2/ Scammers pull 1 of 2 scams: 

(A) an *approval* transaction (this cost $$ gas!) that may be hard to parse. Wallets are getting better about making sure you know "Are you sure you want to approve this contract to access ALL your [Bored Ape Yacht Club][World of Women], etc."

(B) The trickier one, a *private listing* transaction (this does NOT cost gas). This one is really messed up. It says, "hey please sign in with your wallet" but what is is actually doing is saying, "hey, please sign this agreement to list your World of Women NFT on OpenSea for $0 to me in a private listing". Because it cost $0 you don't see any reason why you can't just sign a login request.

So you sign it thinking you're logging into a website and what you actually did was give a cryptographic signature valid on the OpenSea Seaport contract to list your assets (**this only works if OpenSea Seaport has that contract approved, which many NFT traders give Seaport access to everything all the time, a bad habit) for $0 in a private sale.
In competitive markets you get both, but healthcare in the US is so broken w/ 0 price transparency and employer tied healthcare that yeah it's a real concern¬†

2/ unfortunately, the company in question has had negative press for bad business practices, including (allegedly) finding people in crisis online (e.g. Reddit r/S*ic*dewatch) and DMing those people to pitch them on-demand counseling services.

So, I'm leaning towards this company not being ethical.

But still uncertain how/if AI tools should be limited as assistive technology for professionals.

Idk if I really agree with that framing.

It's wrong to take someone else's work and pass it off as your own. 

I'm not sure that *viewing* art and learning from it is a problem on the margin.

Me reading your writing and integrating your style/prose into my own; or me appreciating your drawings and studying how you draw human eyes is typically considered "fair use".

There is a real worthwhile debate on the *scale* that AI has scraped images without care to ownership or copyright. But objectively, these models do NOT reproduce their training data when prompted.

They take inputs, parameterize them, and generate new images from the parameters they've developed from viewing 100,000s+ images.

We know this because the models are smaller than their training data. So it's not this boogeyman of choosing which stolen picture to match to a prompt. Which is really what people seem to think is happening. They don't see it as having *learned*.

But I think objectively, it has *learned*. And that does matter for any copyright/fair use/intelligence debate.

Unfortunately almost none of the big popular production grade code in crypto is actually immutable. Upgradeable Proxy Contracts are extremely common.

The problem isn't code mutability, it's the financial nature of crypto and its instant settlement and irreversibility.

There's always tradeoffs. Lots of economic activity that is (and will) happen in crypto can't happen in trustful reversible settings. Lots of economic activity should be trustful and reversible.

The Ronin hack wasn't even a code problem, North Korea just tricked employees from the company with fake job ads to install malware for the "interview" and steal the private keys needed to sign the money away.

Wormhole was also not a code issue it was a verification issue common with trying to mediate between two systems that don't communicate. In this case they didn't structure their risks correctly and had all the money live in one pile ready to send.

1/ That mechanism isn't the issue! It's the manipulation of the asset's value that is illegal; not the result from that manipulation (i.e.., the LTV ratio).
2/ There probably will/should be regulation on how non-custodial but mutable/managed protocols must protect user assets including a % of TVL insured.
 
It used to be either you held something you owned or someone else held it (custodied) it for you. Crypto has created this new middle of "deployed" assets where you still retain custody but it is on you to remove your assets from deployed status in case of an exploit. 

Disclosures isn't enough; in my opinion the code is either immutable or mutable. That is the determining factor for whether some fraction of custody regulation should apply (see my lengthy piece of schedules of regulation across the crypto stack). 

3/ This is not true! Most US States have a comprehensive coverage laws for car (and home) insurance that voids those kinds of refusals to pay out.

Market manipulation is illegal; so his crime is clear.
What the industry needs to do is develop a standard around white hat hacking including minimally reproducible examples and collaboration in confirmation.

Taking $100M and offering the bare minimum $47M to keep the protocol whole (effectively charging Mango their entire insurance fund as a white hat fee) is not enough nor it is the legal way to do these kinds of well-intentioned attacks.

 I 100% agree we need adversarial parties pushing DeFi to its limits; but contagion is the government's big fear: that damage doesn't stay in a single market and cascades and multiplies.

If crypto is ever going to change finance, it has to be stress tested; contagion mitigated, and have some kind of known in advance scheme for how to legally attack it.
I learned a lot doing it! And it was shockingly fast.

Assumption (1) is that the state backed monopoly will allow information flow even under adversarial conditions (e.g., internet access and telephone lines); Assumption (2) is that the information flow will be consistent enough to allow a decentralized network of computers coordinate on updating a shared database using data they receive individually and propagate to each other.

If the state ends (1) then yes, the system falls in that location. The general idea of crypto bypassing it is to ultimately cross different financial systems and different state monopolies such that it can survive some N number of states banning it.¬†

Security through geographic diversity.

I care as a developer! I create products. The 20% market share apple is disproportionately wealthier than Android. People should be in an uproar that they are expanding their 30% cut beyond the egregious but accepted, "look if your app is on our store and people buy things through the app, we want a cut". 

I never posted about Apple when they were doing that. 

But 30% of revenue from any app that is servicing an iPhone, i.e., Twitter Promoted Tweets, is an entirely different expansion of their moat.

Especially < 1 year since they ended non-Apple advertisement tracking on the devices too! Completely upending how small businesses work in the digital age. 

I'm not pro advertisement, but this isn't going to reduce advertisements, it concentrates them to Apple.

I wouldn't care if it wasn't bad for the market. But Apple creating this moat of only *they* will advertise to their hardware purchasers; only *they* will choose what software is accessible to their hardware purchasers is bad! 

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_v._Microsoft_Corp.

I could understand someone whining "dang Apple's 30% is so high!" that's whining. I am noting a very real expansion of corporate (software) power over captured consumers (hardware).

We already have the lawsuits and regulatory history.

Creating hardware *does not* give you a monopoly on the related software!

Your point would imply if I want Google Chrome, I must switch to Google Chromebook. If I want Internet explorer, I must buy a PC.¬†

We already did that lawsuit!!¬†

There are currently 2 possible situations for apps on iPhone:

An app gets made on iOS and placed on the Apple Store 
An app does not get made for iOS

I am recommending 2 more possible situations:
An app gets made on iOS and placed on both Apple Store and non-Apple Store.
An app gets made on iOS and placed on non-Apple Store, but not Apple store.

You actually get *more* apps if you allow non-Apple Store apps; because an entirely class of apps that *don't get made for iOS* can get made for iOS.

And some fraction of those apps will be viable w/ both Stores, but not viable with only Apple Store.

So the position you're stating does not make. You CAN'T be forced to get apps from anywhere else! They either are on Apple Store or *aren't available to you at all!*

Smart contracts, which NFTs are, are Turing Complete. You can code them for any edge cases you like. In this instance, the original Issuer might accept a petition to burn and re-issue the NFT to you since you lost it via a hack. 

The bigger concern is not actually the NFT being stolen. It's the NFT being stolen *and sold*.

If Bob buys the NFT from Alice; Charlie posts a (low ball) bid for the NFT just in case Bob gets desperate; then Bob's NFT is stolen by Hacker who then accepts Charlie's bid and moves the money to a new address for laundering...

The current law is that Bob keeps the house and Charlie loses the money.

The way around this is to code in escrow, have semi-permissioned transfers, insurance, etc.

I don't see a future of NFT = House Deed allowing for hacks to have a real world effect. I see a future where NFT = simplified transferable public record of a House Deed. There will need to be an entire legal apparatus around the NFT transfer, just as there is for the Deed.

The point is that it enables significantly better market dynamics than currently exists. The bar is very low! We're ultimately talking about digitizing archaic paperwork processes.

Scarcity in things like food, shelter, clean water, clean air are all bad. Other scarcity is just called property. You own your identity. You own the products you buy. You own the things you create.

Having digital property and digital ownership of identity, your creations, the products you buy evens the playing field between consuming digital and real things.

I'm not a VR/AR fan (yet) cause I think we should be focused on getting people into the real world more and connecting with other people in the real world more.

But having said that, the marginal costs of digital things is often trivial or near zero. That's rarely true for real things.

So digitalization of property and it's required scarcity can reduce marginal costs and increase access to good things.

When music was ONLY CDs and Vinyls, it was hard to listen to lots of music. Now it's trivial to listen to millions of songs. That doesn't make music less scarce, it just makes it more accessible at a lower marginal cost.¬†

What *would* be information, is if you could *destroy* the noise  via entanglement as well.
That bit of information cannot travel faster than light, even though the coin flip results *seem* to be instantaneous - they are not information.

I have 2 special coins; if you flip 1, the other coin is always the opposite.

I flip heads, you flip tail.
I flip tails, you flip heads. 

This is not enough to transmit *information* b/c although you might want to say heads = 1, and tails = 0 and do binary communication (morse code, computer bits, etc.); you need additional information (which flips are signal, which are noise) to make this instantaneous data completeness into *information*.

If you convert an arbitrarily large number to hex it will have a length proportional to the number size.

If you fix the potential number size (42 length in Ethereum) then numbers smaller than some N digits are less than 42 and must be filled with empty leading 0s to meet the 42 length condition.

Thus, addresses with leading 0s are effectively smaller length numbers which is less storage.

This is a rough analogy, I don't know how ETH specifically implements hex and memory stuff.

Technically it reduces the validation set for potential private keys, but it's still so large that you don't actually get any information from knowing anything about the public key when guessing the private key.

How I think of the broader question of decentralized computing:

1/ Data transfer cost vs computation costs 

I can have data, desired output from that data and explicit instructions of what computation leads to the output.

But if it's expensive to move that data, then the computation will happen close to the data, e.g., I have both AWS EC2 AND S3 instead of something like S3 + on-prem.

Assuming we see a future where data transfer becomes significantly less expensive, such that computation becomes the primary cost (and for many things we already see this, e.g., in machine learning) that opens us up to decentralized computation.

2/ Decentralization vs Fragmentation

Decentralization is inherently duplication which is inherently inefficient. All Ethereum nodes have all transactions. 

Decentralized computation does not benefit from inefficiency the way blockchains benefit from inefficiency (the inefficiency is the price for easy validation, censorship resistance, and credible neutrality). 

So how do we get to credibly neutral computation that is efficienct but not fragmented?

ZK Proofs and purposeful fragmentation (i.e., Edge Computing).

üéØ Mark Freeman II X2Y2 and Sudoswap are two rising NFT marketplaces that abuse the reality that all royalties are optional (always have been) in web3.

The way code works there's only two options: 
Transfer() of NFT requires centralized permission (to differentiate transfers to self from sales, requiring royalty to be paid on sales)

Transfer() of NFT does not require centralized permission, in which case marketplaces must choose to tax transfers *they* organize and send that money to the designated royalty address (which itself is not on chain, it's set at each marketplace).

For years OpenSea was *the* marketplace and they chose to respect royalties on top of their 2.5% tx fee.

As new marketplaces come in with lower fees and  disrespecting royalties, the speculators on NFTs will do the economic thing and not pay them.

This was always the price of building the NFT culture on top of speculation and churn as revenue instead of fundamentals like people willingly paying for utility.

Financialized NFT culture set back crypto by years.

Haha, nice reference. This would be Theirs Law, but note that none of this is in a context of required uses as money. 

(raw) ETH is the monopoly currency for paying tx fees in the Ethereum network and there is no requirement that cbETH = stETH = rETH in either the market or practical terms (in fact, cbETH's construction means it should NOT = stETH at all as the latter rebases and cbETH does not).

-------

Definitions: 
Gresham's Law: Bad money (context: silver dollars made of only 40% silver) drives out good money (silver dollars made of 90% silver) when both are legally required to be treated as equivalent.

Their's Law: Bad money makes good money more popular than it should be (priced at a premium).

Austin Quiggins it's not the computers that make universities expensive. It's the staff. Wages rise as technology improves. Higher wages is costs for universities.

Of course, do I think universities in the US are correctly priced? No way. Universities nowadays are 4 star resorts with bloated admin to teacher ratios and more emphasis on giving students a good time so they donate as alumni than actually teaching them.

Universities were heavily subsidized at the state level for decades. That ended and got pushed onto students and families. This is a massive inefficiency as now individuals have 0 negotiating power compared to the states.

My point is that federal subsidies are not the primary driver of cost increases at universities- because it's mostly a replacement for state subsidies that already existed.

Staff bloat, scope creep, technology administration, and, importantly, higher quality I blame more.

One might argue ending federal subsidies would force universities to cut back. But we all know they'd do it by reducing quality not reducing their own admin pay.

The merge is a consensus change. It has 0 to do with the fee market for ETH gas costs. Gas fees are 100% determined by the demand for blockspace. 

In *theory* transaction fees can fall because validators costs are lower than miner costs - so they can profitably accept lower gas bids.

In *theory* transaction fees can rise because PoS may attract a lot more on-chain activity which increases demand.

L2s condense demand (people share a bus instead of drive individually) - but they are subject to the same "induced demand" that making extra lanes on a highway creates.

No they aren't that's the problem, they're not generating on-chain transactions. 

What happens generally is people buy within an app (e.g., Binance); miners will get new BTC from blocks and then send those to exchanges (e.g., Binance) and sell them to cover their OpEx. 

Single large transactions from miner to exchange are not enough to fund security long-term. Eventually the bitcoin block reward will dwindle and all that will be left is transaction fees. There has never been a single day where tx fees exceeded block rewards in BTC or USD terms. 

The economic measure we need to look at is money velocity. Bitcoin money is not moving fast enough! And as institutions increasingly get away from the chain and instead play with options, perpetuals, futures - the on-chain security will get weaker and weaker. 

I'm not saying the chain will collapse. I'm just saying it will plateau and we don't know what happens when a system that requires growth loses that growth.

Joseph C. Freeriding the bitcoin blockchain.

The bitcoin blockchain security model is many people doing proof of work to make blocks and validate transactions.

When people hoard bitcoin and refuse to transact in them, then they never pay for the security model. If everyone hoards gasoline (bitcoin) but nobody drives (pays btc for transactions) then the roads (miner network) will eventually fade away (security model becomes weak).

The assumption that miners will long-term mine at *a loss* out of altruism is not aligned with game theory.

Private schooling in the US is mostly about (1) sorting (don't want your kids messing with poor/dumb/bad children) and (2) money.

The problem with bringing capitalism to education is that the cycle lengths are too long. If I buy tableau and hate it I can quit to power bi quickly.

If I buy a year of 3rd grade and it sucks, the switching costs are immense: I might have to move, or rearrange my schedule to bring the kid to school, the kid will lose their peer group, have a jarring experience of being the new kid in a new school that may assume knowledge the kid didn't get at the bad school.

Bringing capitalism to education fundamentally requires commodification of education into discrete units.

I'm not actually against this- having "addition" credits vs "multiplication" credits where kids can re-do credits when needed or mix and match 3rd grade math and 5th grade reading is actually probably a really good idea.¬†

But bringing capitalism to education BEFORE you have commodified it into discrete units that can be interchanged and redone as needed does not work given the available data we have on state run voucher programs.¬†

Inequality in education funding is very real. But education is never going to get fully federalized, the states barely follow the dept education guidance anyway.

There's definitely an argument for early teenager sorting into career tracks, but I think in the US psyche, it has to be framed as student choice and not government sorting (which has hundreds of years of eugenics & genocide history in the US).

I had small class sizes so I can't comment much. But 40-50+ kids to 1 teacher is not teaching anymore, its a daycare program. Which unfortunately is enough for many parents who are barely above water in this inflation environment.

The kid safe is priority 1, them learning something is a bonus.¬†
Arizona is pretty much letting anyone who can speak English teach including immigration from the Philippines of non-teachers.

You can cover 99%+ of transfers with the same efficiency by just changing the math to arbitrarily reduce slippage and price impact. 

One could imagine a bridge using a Uni v3 pool design with Liquidity concentrated between prices X and Y. 

If you split your TVL into 4 chunks, then as long as trade imbalance doesn't exceed some k*(1/4 TVL) you can provide people the same exact pricing as if all the TVL was in a single chunk.

For example, instead of x1*y1=k to determine exchange rate (where x1 = amount in the only available chunk) you can do 4(x1*y1) = k. 

Up to some trade imbalance the LPers get the same capital efficiency (even tho their LP is not active at all times it shares the separated fees with everyone)  the only cost is that slippage goes parabolic when trade imbalance is high (until a backup chunk goes live to reduce the slippage again).

You might need Oracle solutions or an internal TWAP Oracle or something to make it work. But we don't actually have to put all the TVL in a bridge into a single contract that's a design choice
He likes Polkadot

They initialized their contract with a null address or something similar. This their process() which takes a signature from 1 chain to that says "you chain 2 owe X person $Y" but the process didn't actually ask chain 2 for confirmation of deposit (checker was NULL) 

People were able to loot the bridge by swapping themselves out for X person and requesting the same $Y with the same signature.¬†(Had to be the same amount of money).

The importance of Liquidity is a function of net volume on one side of bridge (trade balance between two chains); the Liquidity density is determined by the function used for swaps. You can have arbitrarily deep liquidity at a moving price point- this is how curve works.¬†

At some amount of trade imbalance, you would for sure want to turn backup bridges online to relieve that balance.¬†

But bridges aren't required to use Uniswap x*y=k constant product for pricing their swaps. They also aren't required to limit their calculation to the balance of 1 contract.¬†

My point being, you can separate fees to another contract (uni v3 does this!), Smooth the reward function, and do swaps w/ any arbitrary function.¬†

Fine, 2 bridges with less communication and multisig balancing.¬†¬†

We've seen >$2B hacked on bridges.¬† ¬†At some point we have to talk about throttling, friction to withdrawals, temporary no-transfer wrappers for tokens bridged

Is it ethical to accept a job that you are not currently qualified to perform?

[Is it ethical] - TBD, but let's assume you haven't told ANY lies at all in the process. You answered all questions to the best of your ability as scoped.

[accept a job] - someone offered you this job presumably so immediately I'd cut responsibility by 50-80% on the accepter's end.

[currently qualified] - hard to define. But presumably the job offeror is responsible for assessing the qualification.

[to perform] - the action is important. Underqualified for heart surgery kills people. Underqualified to make coffee just slows down customer fulfillment. 

----------------------------

Ultimately I think it's 80% on the offeror to vet correctly; 20% on the acceptor to confirm they represented themselves accurately and that their best effort will be tolerable quality.

No I don't think anything is stealing - both sides agreed on a fundamentally undefined measure of input/output quality.

If you are truly confident you will bomb this job / get fired within 3 months; then for sure- just for the selfish reason of not having gaps on your resume- tell them you don't think you can handle it.

This is a scarecrow fallacy. Euros are stores of value; they are down 20% against USD. 

Store of value has a context. It's about what can be bought. Euros can buy European goods. Their performance against the dollar doesn't change their store of value status.

The problem with Bitcoin is it doesn't have any context. There's no real economic activity happening on Bitcoin. It isn't the native currency of any microeconomy (except I guess bad stuff on Silk Road).

Ethereum has DeFi, NFTs, and other decentralized use cases that give it a micro-economy & context. NFTs are priced *in ETH* and don't change their prices based on ETH/USD ratios. 

Store of value is about consistency in its relevant economy. 

Bitcoin fails because it doesn't have a relevant economy. It's digital gold. 

As more economic activity happens on blockchains, whatever medium of exchange is chosen by the people doing the activity will naturally become a store of value (the micro-economy prices in the medium of exchange). 

USD prices are not the reason bitcoin is not a store of value. It's lack of real use cases and economic activity.

If you form a business to take people's money to put it to work for them, you should be regulated as such.

If these businesses were fully on-chain and it was 100% transparent what they're doing with people's money, then this wouldn't happen. It's the hiding that is the problem. Very similar to 2008 and hiding loans and liabilities...

I should caveat this by saying the reason rehypothecation is tolerated (and regulated) as opposed to banned is because *this is how economies grow*. 

Fractional reserve banking allowed the greatest advancements in human history to happen all in a 200 year span. We went from candles and dumping waste in the streets to germ theory, electricity, flight, and global instant communication within 10 generations.

The cost of this is when you overshoot it. When you have too much money flowing and not enough coordinated activity to accomplish. You get inflation, depressions, corrections/recessions, bankruptcies, moral hazard, bailouts. 

If we could only use $1 one time at a time, it'd take forever to innovate and for the economy to grow. Speculation is useful. 

We just haven't figured out how to control who loses when it goes awry- too often it's private profit, socialized losses. This is not a problem of free markets, it's a problem of crony capitalism.

Message:
The easiest 4% gain, is paying down debt at 4% interest.

Mortage, student loans, credit cards, whatever else.

Note: this isn't just a crypto thing. 

Runs on US Treasury bonds, prescious metals, and AAA corporate bonds can all happen to uninsured money market funds which have expectations of liquidity when in reality, they aren't robust to large events like 2008 & 2020.

Promising 100% liquidity when you're actually only liquid 90-95% of the time is dangerous, but common and legal. Otherwise nothing could really generate yield.

At the end of the day, debt is how economies grow and illiquidity is important for businesses who expect that their loans won't randomly be demanded to pay up (no one could plan a business if their debt was callable at any point in time, because in practical terms, it is when you most need cash that your debt would be called).

People don't read terms of service, but agreeing to them is still binding. These aren't banks, they don't have FDIC insurance.

And the reality is that the DeFi protocols they use for yield are not always (1) liquid (2) guaranteed to protect units.

If one of these groups accepted USDC from someone and placed it in the Curve USDC-frax-usdt-ust pool; then imbalances in that pool could result in having less USDC than originally deposited.

This is called impermanent loss (made permanent upon exiting the pool).

So we can't actually be sure any of these groups has 100% of deposits available & liquid at any time. 

Illiquidity is often and explicit and incentivized goal of DeFi protocols as well (e.g. stETH, veCRV, etc.). 

So even if funds ARE 100% there, they are rarely 100% LIQUID. This is what makes bank runs so dangerous, you can do everything legit, but changes in time preference can cause spirals that are fundamentally illogical.

This is made worse when users don't actually know/understand where their yield comes from and are given unsustainable interest rates and/or unsustainable access to liquidity.

Some crypto act exactly like stocks; others are nothing like stocks. Many crypto are worse than penny stocks. Many are outright scams, especially celebrity endorsed NFTs and rug-pulls. 

But crypto had TWO $35B+ Ponzi schemes collapse together and the infrastructure continued to work, tokens continued to function, and the market didn't need any bailout or circuit breakers. This is important to note. 

There is something to this blockchain / digital scarcity / decentralized compute thing being built. The first applications being dumb copy/paste scams & ugly monkeys is rough, but it's just a bad application of good tech. 

Much like encryption was debated thoroughly in the 90s as a tool for terrorists, but now https is completely standard and lack of SSL certificate is considered sketch.

Delicate balance between inflation pushing people out of cash and high risk assets struggling to compete with rising interest rates. 

The medicine is known: raise rates higher & faster and crash things quickly so we can skip to the recovery.

Playing it slow feels better, but we don't actually know if it reduces harm long-term.

I wouldn't want to be in any politician's or economic appointee's shoes right now.

Not a super fair comparison; market caps inherently assume there is less liquidity than the market cap.

This is just unregulated (arguably a good thing). Better to take 50% drops out of the way than the slow down markets arbitrarily, cap decreases to 5% a day, and slowly bleed 70-90% of the value over months. 

The current system has a very difficult problem to balance: slow down panic without causing more panic.
We can't keep kicking this can. We're acting like inflation & low interest rates are a social welfare program for the near-retired who need their 401ks regularly inflated to keep inflows going.

I measure security as a function of miners fighting for consented money under the constraints of being honest in how they construct blocks.

Other cheaper chains might be secure, coincidentally, that the miners/validators choose to be nice. But those chains are typically not plentiful in their miners & validators. 

Bitcoin is sufficiently secure, honest miners make $400,000+ a week.

Ethereum is highly secure, honest miners make >20x as much.

So "weaker chain" would need to be defined more clearly.

If you define weak as "changing" then sure, maybe ETH is weak because it changes over time via hard-forks. But its much more complicated than just saying "BTC is best" because it is the largest market cap. 

The vast majority of BTC exchange doesn't happen on the Bitcoin blockchain- I consider that weak personally.

The comparison isn't WBTC vs BTC. It's ETH Smart Contracts for WBTC being safer/more popular/higher network effects than BTC smart contracts for BTC.

But yes, all non-native assets to a blockchain are a risk; this is why I was very worried about the LUNA plan to make UST an existential risk for the entire industry by porting UST to multiple chains. 

I was even wiped out entirely on Blizz.Finance on Avalanche due to Terra's collapse even though I never touched LUNA or UST. 

Contagion is crazy.

All technically true, but realistically we're seeing BTC get moved to smart contract platforms at magnitudes of order higher than LN or Stacks.

It's easier to work with bitcoin on Ethereum than to try and replicate DeFi onto bitcoin. 

Bitcoin should focus on what it does well: fixed supply big name easy to understand digital gold; and fix its problems (HODLers don't contribute to security, free rider problem). 

Trying to force Smart Contracts on a UTXO chain like BTC is realistically not going to work.

Just as a more specific example. 291 Bored Ape NFTs were minted and have never been transferred. 

Some fraction of those people could have minted to their cold-storage wallet; but realistically most probably minted and haven't sold because they're diamond-hands. 

What would it look like to offer a cold storage solution where they can send their BAYC to a contract and receive a wrapped BAYC that has no transfer function; only an unwrap function. 

This would protect those holders long-term by making it impossible for them to sign a transaction that approves transfer of their BAYC because its held in a contract. 

Pretty much no NFTs I've seen have these kinds of staking tools to protect their community's $10,000-100,000+ assets. But it wouldn't really be that hard to build and if it saves even 1-2 thefts a year, it'd be worth it.

Cause once a BAYC is stolen, OpenSea has to block it from being sold on their platform legally; so tons of these NFTs are effectively out of circulation.

This is especially important to consider as the world increasingly moves toward crypto securities, where anyone can list a token/asset and 99.99% of them are poorly designed and *will* go to 0 (if they even get above $0 in the first place).

Governments can prevent exchanges from listing garbage (and arguably they should, it's embarrassing what Coinbase has listed and we have on-chain evidence of insider pre-purchases of the listed garbage) but they can't prevent people from running computer software and permissionless DeFi needs more shorting, not less, to protect regular people (who shouldn't be buying garbage but they do for some reason...) from bubbles going too high..

Ronald Pearson, PE  typically you collateralize a short so it's really no different. It's actually very unfair that it's *illegal* for average investor to short- not hard, actually illegal, exchanges have huge limits on how much you can even try to short.

If I buy a stock, I have a chance of losing 100% (stock goes to 0). 

If I short a stock, I have a chance of losing 100% (it doubles in price). 

Sure, the risks are asymmetric (most stocks don't go to 0 in 10 year timeline while many double in 10 year timeline) it's really not any mechanically different.

You buy a stock and have a limit sell. You short a stock and have a limit buy. Both protect you from losing more than you are willing to tolerate on a single trade.

The vast majority of people shouldn't be buying single stocks anyway (there's a reason 401ks and IRAs are tax advantaged and have indexes) but for some people to not have the freedom that elite bankers and institutions do is wrong in my opinion.

The only benefit to making shorting illegal is to remove pessimists from the market, so that bubbles happen bigger and faster. 

Bigger bubbles = more volatility. More volatility = more variance & market making profits.

Ronald Pearson, PE  it's the opposite, the vast majority of people are not allowed to short, and it is a critical market activity. 

Not being able to bet against a stock means that everyone is required to buy it or not buy it. So you get insane bubble behavior because the market doesn't get information (X people are *against* this price, not just abstaining from it).

You don't get Peloton down 80% if people like me who thought it was the stupidest thing they've ever seen were legally allowed to invest *against* it. The market would see this anti- stock feeling and slow down its bubble buying.

Similar with Zoom, which at one point was worth more than Exxon ü§¶ü§¶ü§¶ü§¶ just because it was the most popular web conferencing tool during 2020-2021. 

The regulations against pessimism fundamentally create bubbles, it's bad for everyone. Companies hiring like crazy, then the bubble pops & they rescind offers- their stock never should've gotten so high in the first place.

We're mixing contexts. 

Gold is valuable because it has industrial use cases (small part of value), is highly durable (big part of value), and has demand historically (biggest part of value). 

It's liquid and ownership is trustless and its physical so it doesn't need anything like a miner network & the internet to keep it functional.

Having said that, Bitcoin lovers are often very focused on Bitcoin as a Doomsday store of value. This is of course ridiculous, in an actual doomsday scenario without reliable internet access you can't use the Bitcoin you've stored.

In a Doomsday scenario you *can* use physical gold you've stored. So gold would be significantly more useful than Bitcoin. But- the average retail gold buyer is only buying email gold. They aren't taking physical custody of it.

Although they *can* and gold sellers/custodians must deliver gold when requested for legal reasons there is the same free rider problem of BTC.

Because they hold email gold, they are reliant on the same internet & network of custodians risks that Bitcoin has.

So in a Doomsday scenario: physical gold >>>>> Bitcoin > email-gold.

But few regular people are taking the physical gold, and thus, what is the point of email gold?

Why would people walking generate value? The obvious play is DATA.¬†

- urban planning data (find potholes, downed power lines, see where people actually like to walk, check cell phone telemetry, radio tower quality, etc.)

- health data (partner with health insurance companies to split discounts on insurance costs for users who need less healthcare b/c exercise, collect data on calories burned, weight loss, partner with fitness apps, apple watch, etc.)¬†

- advertising (give people extra tokens for walking in dense shopping districts, use a pokemon go model to get businesses to split visitor revenue and subsidize tokens)¬†

Do I think this will work? No, I don't, honestly. Globally walking infrastructure is pretty weak, and people's consumption is relatively rivalrous (people can't spend what they don't have so a dollar has to come from somewhere else).¬†

But- it could at least be a cool experiment and I hope it doesn't blow up too badly where people lose money and stop exercising haha.¬†

If you own Bitcoin, then yes, by having bought it, you paid tx fees and contributed once per purchase.

But this is just a simple money velocity problem. 

Imagine a country economy where people HODL'd and had insane savings rates (50%+).

Their GDP would grow hilariously slowly.

Add in deflation as fixed supply of BTC erodes as wallets get lost; you get a deflationary asset with minimal velocity.

Eventually that dries up liquidity.

Once liquidity is dry, both sides (supply and demand) shrink. So Bitcoin could stagnate as circulation falls and lose its security.¬†

I mean it's totally possible it stays secure with way less hashrate and more efficient energy making it trivial to mine as a hobby in some way. But the ideal scenario is that people use it and willingly pay fees so that the system security (& price) grow over time.¬†

To clarify, oracles are created in partnership with the relevant parties. So Terra the blockchain knew that the oracle they created with Chainlink had a $0.10 minimum.

You can see here in the oracle That Venus Finance used that minAnswer is int192: 10000000 (this translates to $0.10).

https://bscscan.com/address/0xec72d46011d67a6ac4fa7d3f476fa2049dc807ee#readContract

So the developers when integrating this contract into their platform would already be doing conversions for UI/UX and (should) know the parameters.

Here is the documentation on the options around 
https://docs.chain.link/docs/selecting-data-feeds/#risk-mitigation

For example on how to do this correctly, AAVE, the major lending/borrowing platform in DeFi uses Guantlet to run simulations and do thorough analytics prior to adding collateral options and new oracles. (They did not add LUNA collateral on ANY chain they support)

https://docs.aave.com/risk/

There is no excuse to holding your user's funds without understanding the security implications under worst case scenarios.

LUNAUSD was $0.0001 on market.
Blizz Finance (Avalanche), Venus finance (BSC) didn't prep for Chainlink oracle circuit breakers. 

So they accepted LUNAUSD at $0.10.

Go buy 100,000,000 LUNA for $0.0001 each; give it to Blizz at the $0.10 price; then borrow ALL the money in Blizz.

All oracles were working except LUNAUSD. The problem was that these protocols accepted LUNA as $0.10 when it was actually $0.0001.
They are not a centralized. This is like asking if "http" would benefit from freezing websites lol.

This is not Chainlink's fault. 

Their distributed oracle network (DON) has to implement price breakers when there are few oracles participating b/c to *allow* an oracle to signal a price 99.999% lower than recent prices is an attack vector itself!

The LUNAUSD oracle clearly states in the documentation and code that the minimum price for consistent service was $0.10.

This was >99.9% below LUNA's all time high.

Chainlink oracles must be free to exit service, the circuit breaker was set for 99.9% below LUNA's all time high. It crashed 99.9999% and these protocols FOOLISHLY allowed collateral into their products without having a plan for a flash crash of that collateral.

I got completely wiped on Blizz Finance (not for much I moved to AAVE months ago) because of their recent (5 weeks ago) decision to add LUNA as acceptable collateral; without proper due diligence.

This post has a fundamental misunderstanding of how Chainlink works. It's not a monolithic API company. It's a system for individual oracles to coordinate. Chainlink can't force DONs to deliver prices. The LUNAUSD DON, in coordination with relevant parties like central exchanges, set a $0.10 minimum for security reasons- not for fun!
Yeah it's not gonna do that.

Digital scarcity, e.g., my Ethereum address, gives me cross-platform ownership, cross-platform identity, cross-platform activity history, cross-platform data, by forming a single shared data layer (the Ethereum blockchain) that *any* platform can just choose to accept and post data to.

Stablecoins are a type of money market fund. They enable de-risking from high risk assets to a set of lower risk assets. 

UST being backed by only 1 asset was always a huge risk. The reason Dai is so popular is because it is backed by both decentralized assets (ETH) and centralized assets (USDC) along with some small yield bearing positions to cover risk (stablecoin liquidity pools). 

To bring UST to $1 requires people to buy LUNA at lower, lower, and lower, and lower prices until the market caps of the two get closer together. 

Buying LUNA at $0.05 when UST is $0.40 is irrational for anyone except arbitrage bots; LUNA will fall below $0.01 unless UST demand recovers dramatically. 

You can't even short LUNA and UST right now, the funding rate is so astronomically high, nobody will commit to lending the assets to you to short.

Markets are a gamble, but they're not the same as gambling. For any asset to have value, you need to know how much $ people would pay for it (order books, sell walls, buy walls, etc.). Because markets are *not* perfectly informed (most information is in peoples heads not in their order book) and people's willingness to pay for something are themselves a function of their perception of other people's willingness to pay, you get LOTS of uncertainty.

What options and shorting and leverage do is allow people to more accurately tell the market their opinion (including the range of prices where their opinion changes). This can improve market flow and estimation- but it can also cause derivative games like payment for order flows and open interest and dark pools and adversarial game theory. 

I think the answer is better apps with better UX and more options made easier to understand, then more people playing the game *transparently* so that we all get close to the same information.

The math on Uniswap v2 style swaps: 

The product of the number of each token must stay constant in a trade.

[(5M - 100,000) * (5M + X) = (5M * 5M)]

So 5M minus 100,000 USDC (what you're taking out) times 5M + X of your Token (what you're putting in) must equal 25M^2 (the product of the original amounts of each, 5M times 5M).

So you actually have to give up X = [(5M * 5M)/4.9M] - 5M = 102,040 Tokens.

Then, given that there are 5,102,040 Tokens and only 4,900,000 USDC in the pool left (technically I'm skipping the 0.05 - 0.3% swap fee) the USDC price of 1 Token is now 4.9/5.1 = $0.96.

Avax subnets are getting a subset of AVAX C/P/X chain validators to also validate your subnet. 

Choosing the 3 worst AVAX validators to validate your subnet does not pose a risk to the broader AVAX ecosystem b/c in the broad ecosystem anything malicious they do would have to be also validated by the validators not related to the subnet.

You can have a game on a subnet validated by the 3 worst validators, the 3 worst can collude to mess up your game, and it would have no impact on anyone not related to your game. 

Of course, if you mix and match multiple subnets for your game, and then 1 subnet decides to collude and steal all your game NFTs, it affects your game; but it doesn't harm other games unrelated to it.

You're implying that a bad subnet could harm the entire AVAX C-Chain or similar. The FAQs here state that subnet security is isolated to that subnet, e.g., having 0 fees on a subnet means you'll get DoS attacked, that attack does not pose a risk to other AVAX chains b/c those chains have fees to dissuade it. 

https://docs.avax.network/build/tutorials/platform/subnets/subnet-faq/

I didn't say inflation drives growth. It's critical to growth.¬†

Growth comes from 2 sources:¬†

More people.
More activity per person.

Activity has to be organized, typically with money.¬†
Money is: unit of account, medium of exchange, store of value.

If you have a fixed amount of money that never changes, then how do new people within an ecosystem access money?¬†

They have to get it from people who are *incentivized to hold it*.¬†

Why would you spend a nugget of gold for a coffee, if tomorrow a nugget of gold gets you 2 coffees?

Deflation disincentives consumption. But it's consumption that makes money flow and enables more people and more activity per person.¬†


There's a reason the goal of the Fed (arguable on if they've succeeded) is LOW STABLE inflation.¬†

As opposed to 0% inflation or even deflation.¬†

Because inflation disincentives hoarding and spurs consumption which is how you get growth.

Does inflation cause growth? No. Activity causes growth.¬†

But inflation makes units available to denominate activity which is important for growth.¬†

What are the differences between $FB and $AMZN on the New York stock exchange?

They're completely different companies with different stock doing different things.

UNI is the governance token for the Uniswap protocol. You use it to vote on Uniswap related proposals. 

CRO is the crypto dot com Cronos token used for powering their Cronos blockchain for making online payments to merchants with crypto faster.

All the tokens are different, they just use common standards. Much like Amazon and Facebook both files the same paperwork to have their stock traded on the same exchanges, even though the stocks are for different types of companies.

Web3 is about credibly neutral: payments infrastructure+digital ownership+computation.

The vast majority of payments, ownership, and computation does not *need* credible neutrality. 

I like that my credit card is not neutral! When I say fraud happened they believe me and reverse the charges. 

I don't mind if LinkedIn has copies of my past posts. As long as I can access them and they respect I created it and don't plagiarize me. But I might want to move that stuff to a credibly neutral place like a blockchain adjacent storage service so my posts are more persistent. 

I don't need Fortnite to be credibly neutral in how it renders my game or lets me play. It's just a game, I don't care if my Ariana Grande Fortnite skin disappears for some reason (although some might feel strongly the other way). 

Note that's a joke I don't play Fortnite and I think that skin is like super rare or something lol.

That question assumes an unrealistic vision of the world lol. 

Right now 10 Metaverses might exist all using segmented AWS/Azure/GCP stuff to run their Unreal Engine 5 online. 

If they all instead ran on-prem, it doesn't change anything, they still use common internet standards to communicate with users (TCP/IP).

The web3 part is about ownership of assets being recorded on public ledgers. 

Anyone can know that wallet address 0x4488adfa4... owns MetaBattle Sword # 17 NFT because that information is on a public blockchain. 

Whether that NFT is *useful* in a Metaverse is up to the admins and devs of that specific Metaverse. They can choose to generate an in-universe asset backed 1:1 with that NFT, or they could not do that at all. They could ignore that NFT entirely. Or they could say, "you have that sword NFT from another Metaverse, we don't use swords, but that's a popular item and we want you to try our game so we'll say that sword NFT is worth a cannon in our Metaverse game". 

There is most likely *not* a future where the Unreal Engine 5 game is working across a composite of random devices running zero knowledge proof computations to make the game work.
Here I mean liquid tokens like UNI, FORTH, YFI, etc. Generally tokens, coins, cryptocurrencies, etc. all refer to the same thing "ERC20" contracts.¬†

Problem is the tokens don't get revenue or equity so why would they have value?

It's often a pure extraction of value from community to insider cap table unfortunately, regular users don't really understand that and get confused when price nearly always collapses.¬†
It's not a direct replacement. Some things are objectively better when centralized and also run by groups that are trustworthy.¬†

I have more nuanced comments above in reply to Matt that may be relevant.

This 2nd thing- redemption being slow - is going to be a major headache for groups like Maker that want to bring in Real World Assets as collateral for their stablecoin Dai. 

Legally, this makes Dai even more of an unregulated Money Market Fund (see: Federal Reserve Taming Wildcat Stablecoins paper); and it also makes the peg harder to ensure as the most liquid assets get liquidated first, the worse the peg is, the harder it gets to defend - which can cause a death spiral.

In the regular world, if a company stock is worth less than the assets the company owns, they get a hostile takeover and are sold for parts at a profit. 

But how does that work in a blockchain world? How does it fit into who is not only allowed to hold a token (anyone on a public permissionless blockchain) but also who is allowed to sue? Will the courts find random token holders have standing?

If there is a single enterprise managing the renting and sending profits up to the token holders- are they registered as a security appropriately? 

If you avoid *all this* and just get a synthetic version of a fully regulated and very liquid REIT- how does redemption work when the synthetic is below the price of the REIT?

USDT for example is a popular stablecoin held by 10,000s of addresses. Their redemption has $$ minimums, fees, and is gated to certain kinds of institutions that are registered to redeem them. 

And that's for dollars. 

So for real world assets like real estate, redemption would likely be harder and slower and more expensive.

To clarify - the lies of fixed land sales is not that big a deal, you obviously have to trust the group to pay the cloud costs for the digital world, etc. 

We're talking about a few things in parallel, so let me focus on the Real World Assets point. 

In the real world, value flow is not irreversible. You can sue people who don't pay you and also sue people who overcharged you. 

So when I see "Decentralized Real Estate Ownership" I see a red flag. 

Many groups are doing this totally legit btw- they say, "tokenizing real estate" which means very specifically- hey we have a group of professionals, we're going to vet the properties, ensure renters pay on time, and share profits with token holders. 

They might even seek to follow good regulations around ensuring the token is equivalent to owning a piece of an REIT; they might even have total flexibility on who is allowed to hold the token (decentralizing 1 aspect of ownership- ownership of the token). 

But is it actually decentralized real estate? Or is the marketing purposefully hiding things? 

If the token holders don't get paid for 10 months. the price tanks. What is the plan for that? 

If the token price falls below the Native Asset Value, how is it brought back?

Not sure how you got to this from my post.

Real world assets are durable and have practical utility. You can live in a real world house to keep warm.

I am pessimistic because the marketing is inappropriate and people will lose real money falling for the hype.

The idea of tokenizing rental properties sounds great, but it shouldn't be sold as trustless or decentralized. My problem is the lying, not the centralization.

The great part of web3 is the *competition*. Centralized groups who are trustworthy can compete directly with decentralized protocols that are trustless - and that competition happens on credibly neutral turf. I am not anti-centralization, I am pro competition (but based on truth).

Again, metaverse startups are not telling the truth- they are marketing 10,000 or 50,000 fixed plots of digital land, when we know that often it's just a few button clicks to expand that cap when its profitable to do so (and it will be profitable, which is why we see big NFT groups create derivative collections!). 

RE: owning NFTs. If you are a NFT or web3 consultant trying to sell consulting services and you don't *USE* the tools, I think that's inappropriate. 

Also, there are many $0 NFTs! No Purchase Necessary.

DAOs will fail, but I don't think vote apathy is why. DAOs can use delegation models, although most use proportional coin voting which is a problem too.¬†

Really the reason DAOs will fail is because:

1) they're DAOs in name only, not D not A, barely O.
2) they fail to back the seigniorage value of their token so price collapses decay the org.
3) they never build a development pipeline that is scalable while also easy to contribute to.

Voting is very far down the list in my opinion of why they will fail. It's more about failure to build than failure to vote.¬†

Another reason I say this is also b/c you can pay people to vote. So the parallels to democracy where you explicitly don't get paid and actually have *to pay* to vote (time cost, travel to polls, waiting in lines, getting harassed by opponents), seem unrelated to the core problem.¬†

Those yields are paid in USD. This yield is paid in frETH and denominated in ETH. The assumption being that you're holding ETH (expecting it to grow against USD) and thus this yield would also be above USD.

Denomination in a volatile (assumed growing) asset is very different than denomination in stable assets.

Also, separately, this is fully on-chain, so the competition is other DeFi protocols or doing nothing w/ your ETH. These users do not have TIPS in their set of alternatives.

Date: RE: other assets. The way this was designed it can be duplicated for ANY ERC20! So wrapped DOGE could have a copy/paste of all of this.

Message:
The way we designed it is that the yield is given upfront in the frETH token. So the APY is not "earned" over time (which is what exposes user to yield risk- an inability to forecast the variable yield). Here, you get 100% of your yield upfront, the value of that yield in USD terms is of course market determined (just like any yield in a non stablecoin).

In my own analysis & opinion, in a mature ecosystem, frETH might be 0.02 - 0.04 ETH each, which is 2-4% APY (of course, could be lower if users are crazy patient lol). But this will depend on how it all plays out, the composition of users, their patience profiles, etc.

That policy can still exist. Banks (including central) can adapt and still thrive. They just have to do it transparently and in competition with crypto. 

They have plenty of good features to lean into: 

FDIC insured, under-collateralized debt, personal relationships, etc. 

The point of my post is explicitly that it isn't a winner take all zero sum game. They can issue their own stablecoins, offer custody services, etc.

My understanding is lightning is very centralized and not a "roll-up" in the way Ethereum thinks of Roll-ups. It's also not producing the fees needed to sustain BTC long term. 

But happy to learn I'm wrong

I don't own Bitcoin for a variety of reasons. But crypto like Ethereum is significantly more than a store of value. It's the token used to pay for the most in demand digital open source property rights system on Earth. It's use cases are an endless list and as more and more products are built on top of it (e.g. zero knowledge roll-ups) then the opportunity for trustless decentralized computation at scale opens up too.

But yes for Bitcoin, I don't really get the premise. Everyone buys it to hoard it, nobody *uses* it, but somehow it's the future of money? In 8 years the block rewards will fall by 90%+ in BTC terms. Given that transaction fees have *never* matched block rewards in BTC terms, it's hard to just accept some magical premise that block rewards can safely go to 0 and tx fees will just magically skyrocket.

Of course, education is a public good and I want the information out there and digestible and disclaimers clear and all that. But having been in DeFi for a few years, it honestly is just a better more transparent black box of finance lol. 

Tranches aren't more interesting because they're on the blockchain. They're just transparent and credibly neutral now. 

I've honestly heavily simplified what I do in DeFi because I don't care about finance that much. I expect many want to keep it simple too.

Why should it be clear? Most don't have any clue how finance works.¬†

Collateralized debt positions, Credit default swaps, puts, calls, tranches, mortgage backed securities, payment for order flows, repos, private bonds, ...¬†

It's entirely normal for people to not know an industry and still engage with it through regulated channels.¬†

I don't believe the 5 year vision is people knowing how to take an on-chain short via AAVE, or understanding contagion potential of collateralizable tokens.¬†

They'll have an app, it does fancy stuff for them, they trust it, it chooses money strategies and have a % take rate and various insurance coverages and then they get back to their lives.¬†

As I said, it's cash. If everybody bought Lotto tickets or gave their cash to gamblers because they're gullible and don't do due diligence, then of course, they'd lose it all too.

If you had an Enron pension in the 2000s you went bust too.¬†

None of this is new, scams aren't new, fraud isn't new, failed businesses aren't new.¬†

It's just digital now, and with that comes a new type of speed and scale that people have to get used to.

Should we have abandoned email when the Nigerian Prince scam came out? No.¬†

Should we have abandoned the credit score system when Equifax got hacked for 140M social security numbers, birthdays, and addresses?¬†

So people do the intelligent thing: make tradeoffs.¬†

Digital cash is a natural extension of the benefits of physical cash:¬†

Instant settlement, anonymous, no paperwork, no barriers, no headaches, no trust.

Inflation is taking value from current holders to fund growth (i.e. transfer that value to new holders). It is an important part of any economic strategy that requires more participants over time (i.e., the global capitalist system).

If population is growing 2% / year; then 2% inflation is fair. You have to have erosion of value from hoarders to make value available to new people.

Deflation doesn't work, it provides friction to *spending*, and in our current global economic system, it is *consumption* that drives 70% of the market activity. 

If we all stopped buying things, there wouldn't be jobs. No job = no money. No money = sell our stuff to buy food.  No stuff = hungry. 

Yes, inflation is stealing- but it's stealing with a purpose. 

Gasoline is what moves the engine of a car; consumption moves the engine of the economy. 

Yeah we could skip gasoline and bike everywhere, but it'd be slower and more difficult. We could skip consumption by making everything ourselves and hoarding deflationary assets for anything we do need to buy; but then the economy is smaller (see Global GDP from 1200 - 1800). 

The revolution is not bitcoin.

I get what you're saying. The incentive engineering is important and I am excluding that entire domain with my 3-item list. Governance, ownership, incentives are all critical. But ultimately, I would bucket that under Buy pressure. 

People buy because they want to join a community that is doing X. It's a form of utility.

I could see how this post would look reductive, "Business is just revenue and costs".  This excludes marketing, sales, product, etc. 

I'm not trying to discount those things. But it is still true that all the marketing in the world doesn't make up for no revenue.

Tokenized communities, whether they be NFTs, DAOs, protocols, etc. have to develop an engine that keeps buy pressure going.

A strong community, fun utility, good governance, a sense of ownership, etc. add a lot to buy pressure. But at the end of the day, there are operating expenses that must be covered: community managers, developers, artists, attention marketing / CAC, etc.

When these groups use high emissions and hype APYs and promises of development and early access to secondary NFTs they can dump on new people, that's artificial buy pressure.

So my post is meant to remind people the "revenue and costs" basics of sustainable business/community.

Hatim Rhazi Filali your data isn't private, that's the entire point of surveillance capitalism that you don't know who has what, when, and how much they sell it for. 

ID numbers don't have to be 1:1, it doesn't even need to be an ID, that wasn't the point of my post. My point about data context and how context determines the value of data not the data itself in isolation. 

Having said that, yes, it is possible that data leakage is a nightmare (see: Equifax leaking 147,000,000 social security numbers). But again, we shouldn't jump directly to worst case scenario.

Knowing (1 of) someone's Ethereum public address gives you a subset of their tx history. But it doesn't lead you to their birthday, social security number, address, etc. 

The current system of fragmenting PII w/o a native identification system on the internet creates that. 

I would rather 0 companies on the internet have my social security number, and instead log in with Ethereum to use their sites. They could keep my interactions of their site in their servers, w/o putting it on-chain. 

There's plenty of best of both world middle grounds. We are currently living in the worst of both (in my opinion).

Fair question. In both instances your data is recorded and available to people you don't know and have to trust. But in the 3rd blockchain situation, you are widening the trust circle to everyone w/ internet access.

The benefits to this are better informed markets with lower barriers to entry (and hopefully that flows to better direct costs to you).

The cons are that your data is exposed to more people, including malicious actors.

I would argue we have the worst of both worlds right now. We have low info markets/high barriers to entry, rent-seeking surveillance middleman (adtech), and still risks of malicious actors getting our info (because we have to trust the middlemen in how they choose to sell our data).

I'd note that customer ID can itself be secure and/or limited, e.g., the ID being a store instead of a individual. Or an individual being able to shuffle/refresh their ID periodically. 

I'm not advocating that every bit of info on every person go on-chain.
