Coin voting is tricky.

It's easy to say, "wow rich people shouldn't get more votes than poor people", but that assumes a nation-state context where there is shared defense, air quality, environmental protection, labor protection, and other complex interactions of capital and labor.¬†

DAOs are opt-in groups. They're not countries. You can leave anytime.¬†

So coin voting for a DAO is equivalent to share voting in a corporation. Which is considered standard- those with the most skin in the game get the most say.¬†

The problem is that attempts to rebalance voting power e.g. quadratic voting or log transformed voting shares, just incentivizes a corrupt game of making your big pile of money *look like* many smaller piles of money so you can still keep your voting power. See: Sybil Attacks.

My honest opinion is that responsibility tokens don't work, revenue share is critical, and that democracy in DAOs is overrated.¬†

The most successful corporations are generally dictatorships.¬†

I think the most successful DAOs will be constrained benevolent dictatorships. Look at open source programming culture and how Benevolent Dictators For Life (BDFLs) wielding very large amounts of soft power have propelled programs like the Python language to the top of their respective worlds.¬†

It's 1 UST can be minted from $1 of LUNA. And $1 of LUNA can be minted from 1 UST. So it's not always deflationary, as LUNA can be minted. There is a target of 1B LUNA max supply, but in an emergency that could be exceeded. 

It's one of those things where if UST depegs, people will rush to burn it for LUNA and market sell the LUNA. 

This could cause a death spiral for LUNA. As realistically there is only $1-2B of liquid LUNA available backing $10B+ of UST. 

The code has built in delays and smoothers to limit Luna minting in an emergency (i.e., they allow the peg to be lost and smoothly try and regain it). 

I'm skeptical USDT has anything to worry about. There are many popular stablecoins making different tradeoffs of collateralization ratios. 

UST doesn't have the depth against common pairs that institutions need to buy it. Although totally possible LUNA skyrockets for plenty of reasons unrelated to UST.

Yes & No, though. Using a Freezer makes the OTC deals easier as you don't need a personal relationship with brokers/competitors to manage large orders. 

But it doesn't solve immediate liquidity. If you really wanted to offload 100,000 ETH >=$2,400; this wouldn't make that any easier in the short term.

But you could for example break it into 10,000 x 10 ETH Freezers, lock them for 30 days, get your frETH yield, and then list your 10 ETH freezers for $24,000 each. You sell them in chunks at 0 price impact, 0 slippage, and keep your frETH. and After 30 days, you can just relock your leftovers, and repeat the process. 

frETH gives you a small bit of yield to hedge your downside as you work to unload your freezers.

Could you explain a bit more what you mean? 

Crypto has bots and desks that use time weighted average pricing (TWAP) to try and minimize price impacts when releasing large orders on buy or sell side. This helps but still exposes you to short term price fluctuations. 

The goal here is to decentralize the OTC process so that you can safely buy & sell discrete counts of fungible assets without impacting a specific set of order books (i.e., central exchanges or AMMs) and dealing with price impact or slippage or maker/taker fees.

Main risk is smart contract risk. 
We have a FreezerGovernor contract that mints the NFTs and holds the ETH. If this contract gets hacked we're dead. 

We're getting audited and thoroughly tested to ensure that isn't possible. In addition, there are smart contract insurance solutions if there is a problem. 

But really, the code is simple. Accept ETH, confirm you got it, mint NFT. Accept NFT, confirm you got it, destroy it, then give back ETH. 

This should be as close to (0 + 1) = (2 - 1) as we can get it code wise. 

The main counterparty risk in the OTC side of things depend on how its done. 

1) Marketplaces like OpenSea are thoroughly tested to ensure that IF offer is accepted, THEN, swap the ETH for the NFT, if anything breaks (e.g., the buyer moved the ETH to try and get the NFT for free) it all reverts. 

This is standard and trusted for $100Ms in daily volume. 

2) Direct OTC, where someone has to send the money first and the other party sends the asset 2nd, is the major risk. As now you are fully trusting the counterparty to deliver, without using a trustless intermediary/escrow/etc. 

My hope is that people use (1), and stronger hope is that (1) can be low cost and low friction too.

Project based implies scope is understood.
 
Generally, clients will be better about scope in hours based (but consultants will be worse and leech hours)¬†

While in project based, consultants will be better about scope, but clients will try and leech hours through scope creep.¬†

From my experience, scope creep is inevitable, so project based pricing has lots of risks. Although with clients I've had, it's often mixed.¬†

There's hourly rates, and then there's scope, and then there's fixed fee.

That way clients have a cap on overall expenses, and consultants have their hourly, but, to impress clients and grow business, they cram more things into the cap (i.e., finishing projects early and starting new ones).¬†

This makes it easier for clients to experience proof of concepts that they paid for in previous contracts, and they can choose to fund new projects based on those POCs. As opposed to making a contract to create a POC, which is never fun for anyone cause there's pressure to make the POC into an MVP which becomes a version 0.1 that is treated like a 1.0 and very messy.¬†

The winners in this are clients, partners, firms. The losers are the junior and senior associates doing 60-80hr weeks because they can't say no.¬†

Stable has a meaning, we can't just change the meaning whenever lol. 

USDC is stable relative to the dollar. 
It is not stable relative to the Ruble.

ETH is not stable to anything- it is the token required to pay for ethereum blockspace. BTC is the token required to pay for Bitcoin blockspace. 

Demands for that blockspace is also not stable. So there is no way to say there is stability through any "intrinsic" value. 

Dollars are the token required to pay US taxes and debts. It is not intrinsically stable either. It's forced to be stable by the Federal Reserve.

If the traditional financial system "collapses" - then we won't be talking about ETH and BTC. We'll be talking about trading 2 cans of Chef Boyardee for 3 expired Advils.

If you are talking specifically about the censorship risks of stablecoins - USDC and USDT both have address censorship as required by laws around AML and terr*rist financing. 

But others like UST, Dai, Rai, MIM, Mai, etc. don't have that risk. 

Some have other risks, like being backed by ETH in a contract, and a contract migration could mess up their backing. But that's a separate issue.

USDC, Dai, Tether (USDT), etc. are collateralized stablecoins. Dai is actually *over*collateralized. 

Some use an equity contract (i.e., money market fund but with less regulation, and I should note MMFs were bailed out in both 2008 and 2020,) some use a debt contract (e.g., USDC). 

Returns on stablecoins are a separate discussion. Anchor subsidizes unrealistic returns on UST (20%+). But sustainable yield of 2-4% is realistic. There are multiple $1B+ *over*collateralized markets in DeFi right now: Curve, Compound, AAVE, Maker, etc. with users opting into those rates.

My opinion is that the best of these stablecoins (the ones with the most liquid markets and desire to be held by institutions and whales, e.g. USDC, USDT, Dai) have proven to be good for their value across multiple highly volatile market cycles. 

Remember, the US Stock market has circuit breakers to stop trading. DeFi markets (nearly always) run 24/7 with no such supports to reduce volatility. 

If Dai and USDC can survive in these situations multiple times a year, I think the logical thing to do is start pushing traditional markets to run transparently, credibly neutrally, and without privileged access to after-hours markets.

Nothing is "stable in the sense of protecting against inflation". US Treasury bonds pay < 2%. Checking accounts pay < 1%. The word stable here explicitly means relative to their peg. 

A USDC is tradeable for $1 exactly, not $1 in value (like UST, Dai, USDT, etc. which are all equity contracts).

But we are in peak fad right now. 99.9% will collapse in price. 99% of new ones are just Fiverr ripoff scams. The 1% that are honest attempts to build a community around art and a creative vision are being drowned out; and even among those honest efforts, 90% will collapse because business is very difficult! 

People are spending too much on too many promises and it's holding the entire web3 space back. 

Decentralization means the market will get the worst that it will tolerate. 

Right now, we have millions of views on tiktok, youtube, instagram entirely focused on flipping & scamming NFTs: the worst parts of beanie babies mixed with the worst parts of penny stocks, with 0 regulation or basic common sense. 

I'm not saying I'm pro regulate everything- I'm saying that if we continue to tolerate the worst of the worst and throw good money on blatant scams, the regulators will come with a fury, killing off the 1% of good stuff there is here.

1 - They're ripe for scams.

Imagine mySQL just came out as the premier open source database solution then suddenly everyone started yelling "join my database! Look, you get little pictures and you can sell the rights to be in my database too" and suddenly there was billions of dollars shuffling around who is assigned ID 104 in which database. 

Completely nonsensical. 

2 - They're ugly. 

Seriously, the amount of NFTs that would make it into your local library kids art wall is staggeringly low. 

3 - They've made everyone forget about securities law. 

Somehow people think that if you add in an fugly monkey JPEG, then it's totally okay to sell unregistered securities to people on the promise of profit, future derivative works, revenue flow, etc. 

"We're gonna make comics & cartoons & an MMOPRG with these fugly monkeys!" - it is incredibly hard to break into comics and cartoons, let alone build a functioning, fun, correctly financialized game. These assumptions that every NFT can just become a BRAND because they managed to nab $2-3M off speculators is insane. 

4 - The word is too broad. 20% the people think it's just JPEGs, 75% don't even know what the acronym means, and 5% know it's just financialized distributed databases.

The better question is- who benefits from increasing the amount of dollars, and why would the amount of dollars need to increase over this time period. Who won and lost in the dollarization of the global economy from 1900-present?¬†

This chart is true, but it's not getting the point of inflation.¬†

The 2 reasons to inflate a currency are:
 
(1) Seigniorage: profit made by those who print the money above the cost to make it, I.e., if a $20 bill cost $1 to make, who gets that $19 in value difference? This is a dangerous game and governments have failed after exploiting this.

(2) demand for denominated assets.¬†

People want US dollars and things that can be made into US dollars quickly. What is cash? Cash is the most liquid and anonymous form of value transfer.

This has value. And the US has extracted a lot of value from this fact.

You wouldnt put up a chart and say "value of 1 Google stock" over time and see it plummet 95% and say it was poorly run!
 
Google strategically splits its stock (everyone keeps the same ratio they just scale up the amount) so that it'd be cheaper to hold a whole stock (although fractionalization is common today, it wasn't always so).

The US, having the world's most in demand cash, inflates its currency the same way. Inflation makes holding the base unit (a $1 bill or more specifically a penny), easier to do, because it takes less [insert product or service] to get a unit.¬†

The problem is not that the currency inflates (i.e., the stock splits), the problem is in how this split is not proportional, and it actually extracts value from current holders to support the acquisition of new holders.¬†

This is how networks grow- they add more people and those people's activities.¬†

The world 8x'd in population since 1900. The number of people the dollar is used by has >100x'd in that same time.¬†

The problem isn't the inflation, it's the lack of equity in who benefits from global dollarization.¬†¬†
Nah join now, it's ok if it's not mature.¬†

Your government doesn't want you using stable truly decentralized digital property to secure your wealth. They impose capital controls so they can continue embezzling and inflating away your life savings for seigniorage income.¬†

Depends, in my conversation with multiple lawyers, I've come to the opinion that (1) many of these DAOs are doing unregistered securities, (2) many DAOs are not legally structured to limit liabilities of their members/holders, (3) many are not tax compliant - and thus, they will be right in the SEC's cross-hairs eventually. 

If you sell tokens to people with the understanding that they will profit from the DAOs work, that's a problem. 
Right now, there's a massive "loophole" in "governance" where people can buy/sell a product (a voting point) and people just coincidentally profit/loss. 

But unfortunately, as we're seeing in I think 99% of DAOs, those tokens peak as emissions get too high, and then the price tanks. I can't think of any DAO off the top of my head that isn't down >60% from ATH without a complete tokenomics re-work to incorporate real revenue flows into the token (which makes it objectively a security).

Really, you buy DAO tokens to support the mission, they might as well be a donation given how poorly designed emission rates & liquidity targeting are.

We have coingecko APIs, we could add it. I just think it adds more confusion in some ways. These buyers & sellers don't think in USD terms, so we shouldn't misrepresent them.

If you buy for 10 ETH @ $4k each, and sell for 20 ETH at $2k each you gained 10 ETH but no $0s. The mental model is important. ETH is how these are priced. 

If a user sees $$ shrinkage they may think "oh this is tanking" but if could be confounding variable bias. Why would people sell at a loss? They're not, they're just thinking differently.

Problem with USD is that you need an eth price oracle to estimate value at point of sale. Realistically, people are submitting bids in ETH and it should stay priced in ETH. But I get the curiosity behind eth prices & NFT purchases, that will be explored separately.¬†

Don't exotic options require pricing to be a f() of the underlying asset (i.e. ETH) and/or a function of it's price in some look back period?¬†

frETH is not like staked ETH. It doesn't represent a 1:1 relationship with the underlying asset, nor does the price of frETH (in either cost to acquire or cost to use to unlock freezers) have a direct relationship with the price of ETH.¬†

Whether eth is $10,000 or $100, frETH is the pricing mechanism for keeping ETH off market. There's no means of trading frETH for ETH like you would trade a option to buy AMZN at $2000 prior to X date.¬†

Unfortunately, this is not how blockchains nor human rights work.

1) Ethereum smart contracts are immutable. The tornado contracts (there are multiple) exist in perpetuity until people stop staking in them, but they can't be deleted. Nothing the Patriot Act can do.¬†

2) Private transactions (i.e. cash-like transactions) are fundamental rights. As we are seeing in Canada (where I disagree with anti vax protesters) - the ability to close financial accounts and force people out of the financial system without due process leads to a *lot* of false positives.¬†

It sounds easy to say- "nobody who gives donations or crypto to people who block major highways!!! Banks go stop them".¬†

But then you get incorrect names... Or unrelated people with the same last name. Or 3rd cousins who don't talk to them but 3 years ago sent their aunt a money transfer to a shared account with a trucker.¬†

If we accept financial shutdowns of people without using the court system, we should expect BLM, pro rights, and progressives doing civil disobedience to get the same (probably worse...) treatment as soon as its politically expedient.¬†

3) The question is- do online transactions deserve to have a cash (anonymous peer to peer, the DEFAULT of money for 1000s of years) option?¬†

There's pros and cons on both sides. But the Patriot Act has literally gotten 100,000s of people killed all over the world. There's no way we should ever evoke it as a positive.¬†

4) Tornado has compliance tools to export your notes and tie together transactions for taxes. Of course, not everybody uses it. But it's entirely possible to tweak the laws in a reasonable way to require compliance reports for transactions above a certain size (note: this is actually how the current financial system works with $600 & $10,000 paperwork thresholds).¬†

Clarification on how OpenSea is partially at fault, but this is still fundamentally about phishing for a false tx signature (to my knowledge) ------

it's important to note the boundaries of where OpenSea's code was faulty.

Under the following conditions:
1) User generates a transaction signature that details a $0 private listing of an NFT
2) That user has OpenSea as approved for moving their NFT

THEN

3) Hacker can submit (1) to the OpenSea contract with [target address] as the exploiter contract they created.

OpenSea then (because of bad trust assumptions around how tx signatures can be generated) TRIGGERS the exploited contract's code once it moves the NFT to that contract.

This exploiter contract then takes *all* NFTs it can from the user with a single tx signature.

So YES - OpenSea code has a problem. But it's important to note that (1) and (2) are the necessary conditions for (3) to work.

Yes, as discussed in our other thread - OpenSea allows Contracts to be called in [target address], which triggers the contract code. 

In hindsight, that was clearly exploitable haha

They fluctuate between 0.998 and 1.002 most of the time. Occasionally going lower or higher for a few minutes in crazy market conditions.¬†

General replies to multiple comments:¬†

1) bank runs are not a thing. We've regulated out all risks of storing pure cash (that's why we have 0% interest, the risk was socialized by FDIC + US dollar hegemony)

2) that said, there is a real movement toward ending anonymous transactions (ending cash) and enforcing a centralized global financial system that allows for *negative* interest rates (which is worse than inflation in many ways)

3) crypto is great, I'm highly optimistic for stablecoins, especially decentralized ones.¬†

4) when people say "crypto is uninsured" they're misunderstanding the long tail risk. The risk for dollars is not that your balance will disappear (solved by FDIC & federal regulations). The risk is that the value of your balance will disappear (hyper inflation). 

The risk for crypto is the *exact same*. There's no risk your balance will disappear (solved by cryptography & decentralization). There's only the risk the value will disappear (loss of demand for your token).

5) having said that, any crypto/dollar pair will be highly volatile. That's the price of not having trillions of dollars available to algorithmic trading and centralized circuit breakers to stop markets.¬†

The benefit of the volatility is that it actually better reflects market opinion. The artificial stability of the stock and forex markets are like drinking when you're hungover. It might work at worst, but you'll pay eventually and it'll be worse and take longer to get better.¬†
(the candidate wasn't the one being paid to be there, if a thank you is in order, it's the other way)

I don't think anonymity is a problem necessarily. It's mostly about the transparency of who is in charge of what (e.g. multi-sigs), how community money is spent (on-chain voting vs snapshot vs delegated), and any legal structures that separate members of the LLC from members of the discord/DAO. 

It shouldn't be that much work to get done with all the tooling that exists today to spin up LLCs for < $1,000. But there's definitely lazy groups doing it wrong.

Short-term, I don't know. It feels like formal education is having enough troubles as it is, I don't see us adding cryptography and business acumen to the curriculum anytime soon. To some extent, we need platforms like Twitter, Instagram, YouTube, and TikTok to do better about undisclosed advertising and shilling of their own investments. It's terrible that 100,000s of people's first experience of NFTs is the widespread scam playbook. The price of decentralization and open source code is that it's trivial to spin-up scams. 

In just the last 10 years we've seen telephone calls go from fundamental freedom enhancing communication tool to unusable scam-fest where you can't safely answer unknown numbers anymore. 

Long-term, eventually, people will have semi-centralized playgrounds where trusted intermediaries give them guard rails for risk. VISA will have an EVM Roll-up. Coinbase will have stablecoin products. There will be numerous revenue generating crypto adjacent public companies traded on NYSE that people can incorporate into their 401ks. 

I don't think the future is some anarcho-libertarian paradise of self-custody, self-audited everything. But it's important the foundation is credibly neutral & self-custody remains an option.

Developers at large places generate $1M+ in revenue annually, at small places $200-300k+. 

I feel like the appropriate thing to do would have been to stretch to ¬£60k and formalize the growth plan (early or more than annual review cycles, a budget for conferences, or similar) inside the offer. 

Heads of development don't have the time (and it's arguably not fair) to mentor a single dev over others.

I often see the best data scientists go under their potential for comfort and end up leaving within 6 months. Nobody wants that!

For the skeptics. This isn't a perfect analogy but consider what an NFT is.¬†

An NFT is a distributed database assigning metadata to an owner (that metadata may include a picture, but doesn't have to). Typically, these are most effective when publicly available on a blockchain so that it can be composable.¬†

Let's say the NFL and Budweiser team up to give people 15% off Budweiser in stadiums. There's three ways to handle that currently: the NFL can integrate that into an app of theirs, or Budweiser can integrate it into an app of theirs, or there could be some broad [3rd way]. For example, a piece of paper or a card.¬†

The 3rd ways are great for being easily transferrable, but they can also be made fraudulent.

If instead the NFL & Budweiser both used Ethereum as a shared data layer, they could launch an NFT representing the discount and get the best of low cost for them, transferability for you, and fraud resistant.¬†

Loyalty programs, coupons, marketing, etc. are some of the low hanging fruit that can make use of NFTs.¬†

Just like you might have an app to your favorite food spots (Chic Fil A is a leader in app adoption for fast food), you'll have NFTs on a public ledger giving you *transferable* benefits for your activity.¬†

It isn't just art and money laundering. It's a really good way of tracking digital scarcity across users without over-sharing critical information. 

Does Chic Fil A really need your full name, email, date of birth, home address, and credit card? No, it's just that tracking transaction history to enable digital scarcity previously required such things. NFTs solve this¬†

Unfortunately "terrible for the environment" was a meme created by a competing blockchain to try and get people off Ethereum and onto their proof of stake blockchain. Ethereum currently uses proof of work (like Bitcoin), but is transitioning to proof of stake this year, which will reduce energy consumption by >99%.¬†

That said, using energy is not how "terrible for environment" works. Many things use energy, we don't moralize them just because we don't personally do it.¬†

Training AI models in the cloud, streaming 4K, the military industrial complex, global supply chains, the current financial system, etc. all use incomprehensible amounts of energy. Are they bad for the environment? Maybe, but that's a moral argument that they aren't worth their energy expenditure.¬†

Many support each of these despite their energy costs. If you are already anti blockchain, then of course you're going to say it's not worth it's energy.¬†

The US military industrial complex is the world's largest (& widest) polluter. I don't think it's worth it's energy or financial expenditure- that's my personal opinion ü§∑

Julian von Bargen it'd need to be heavily based on behavioral patterns. When I played RuneScape (too much) they were constantly paranoid about bots & farms. So doing the same behavior repeatedly for hours on end (which you did legitimately need to do sometimes because the game is a grind fest üòÇ) would trigger random encounters with non-dangerous NPCs that requires you to interact with visual elements in the game (kind of like a captcha) to get out of. 

The shadow economy of real world asset trading got so bad, that they even once destroyed their economy to stop it. They made peer to peer trading a nightmare, capped the amount of "market value" that could be transferred in a trade (can't trade a $10 sword for a $3 shield, too big of a gap in value), and just generally wrecked their game. 

Eventually they gave in and did the inverse. Created an entire grand exchange to facilitate *anonymous* peer to peer trading. 

So there are a lot of decisions games need to make when they want to intrinsically support peer to peer exchange.

One red flag I watch for, is focusing on the finance instead of the entertainment. 

I have NFTs for a game called The Treeverse. The goal is to create an MMORPG with runescape inspired skills but a more modern combat system. It is live right now with minimal features (houses to show off your NFTs, a small world for your avatar to walk around in, and chat boxes). 

To me, I like that they've focused on developing in public and being communicative about features and goals, WITHOUT talking about prices. When people complain about prices, they generally silo that conversation to a single discord thread. 

When I look at Axie Infinity (of which I own a small amount within an index token I hold), I see too much talk about revenue and asset accrual and volume and rarity, etc. Feels like nobody is playing it *for fun*. Of course, I could be wrong, this is just an outsider biased perspective. 

There's also the headaches of tokens. Axie has a two-token model. Treeverse doesn't yet have a token besides their NFTs (but they're planning them). 

It's these fungible tokens that *require* liquidity and inflation that bring the most danger.

First principles are: 

- How many people are regularly playing this game?
- What % of them are doing it for asset accrual (pyramid percentage)?
- What % of them are doing it for true entertainment (consumption percentage)? 

Obviously there will be a mix of both. As soon as you financialize a game you're inviting a wave of speculators and the resulting bubbles. You have to identify the "true fans" who are in it regardless of real world prices of their assets. But at the same time, you want those true fans to have an easy on/off ramp so they can *come back* in the future. 

My honest opinion is, none of it is truly sustainable. Every game worth playing has dilution and power creep that will never be managed perfectly. The goal is to create more fun than you create financial loss for people left holding the bag. 

Relatedly, is minimizing the principal-agent problem. As a game gets financialized you have to increasingly worry about information asymmetry. 

We saw this with OpenSea when the Head of Product was buying NFTs before they appeared on the "Featured Artists" page, and then selling them after for profit.

Your game developers and product managers and insiders who are planning new features will have front-run incentives too.

Yeas, I was not directly stating hashrate = security, because it's not really that linear. You can have "good enough" security at all kinds of hashrate/difficulty ratios.¬†

Overpaying for security via block rewards is the fundamental problem and there isn't really any interest in trying those two together.¬†

The optimal thing to do would be to subsidize security *less* when demand for blockspace is high, and subsidize it *more* when demand is low.¬†

Instead it's subsidized at a constant amount and then the subsidy is cut in half every 4 years with no care in the world to the blockspace demand context.¬†

Super risky, I'm not sure you can pull it off 20 years in a row without a scare.¬†

My understanding of Avalanche is it has a "4 Warden" structure where bridging is checked by centralized entities prior to accepting the request to bridge assets. So there's both custodial and non-custodial solutions too. 

These assets are not being priced according to their risk profiles. So you end up with a lot of people injured who didn't really understand what they were holding.

Lots of different bridge structures. Thorchain and Elk use their own proprietary token to back all their supported chains creating "continuous liquidity pools". When Thorchain got hacked from a tx.origin (never use this) bug, they just took the hit I think and the token price collapsed. 

This was a different type of bridge. Wormhole accepted WETH onto their Ethereum contract and then a signal was sent to the Solana contract to mint new wormETH (idk the real ticker symbol sorry). 

This wormETH was only valued as ETH on Solana because it had widespread trust and interoperability (you could bridge back and to my knowledge a few exchanges even accepted wormETH deposits as equivalent to ETH when given to their Solana addresses).

Jury is out on which model is better. There's always different ways of distributing the risk. 

For example, Hop Protocol has users stake assets on both sides of their supported chains and they earn swap fees. These users are the consenting risk-takers (as opposed to Hop Protocol). With wormhole, technically all the holders of wormETH are the risk-takers (most without an accurate estimate of the risk since Solana has an anti-open source dev culture that doesn't reveal their code).

Idk, it feels like it's important but maybe it can't be done autonomously, non-custodial and safely. Or at least not without some size limits and avoiding a very foolish uncapped mint allowance. 

We do have a multichain future, and we do need to be able to go across chains. Central Exchanges are bridges in some ways too, since they have EOAs on each chain they support.

Revenue tokens are like shares with dividends. You earn tokens for holding the token. 
Utility tokens have a specific use case, e.g., you pay for a Chainlink query with $LINK. Holding $LINK doesn't give you direct value. 

Governance tokens have the use-case of voting on changes to a protocol.

Often, because of fear and uncertain regulatory environment in the US, web3 DAOs will avoid revenue tokens and try to use their governance token instead. The problem is, that governance is constantly diluted to give new people a chance to govern too, and the price falls, and then people leave the project because they don't get value. 

If revenue tokens had better regulation, we would see less complex governance tokens, and better projects and markets overall.

An illegal security is just a security that is non-compliant with securities regulation.¬†The vast majority of NFTs have the same problem. How do we make these useful for holders?¬†A commodity has intrinsic use. I buy art to look at it. Businesses buy wheat to make bread. Refineries buy oil to make gasoline. In the US the latter 2 are regulated by the CFTC (because these types of commodities can be volatile and futures are very useful for smoothing this market).¬†A security is different from a commodity. The Howey Test for a security is: (1) investment in a (2) common enterprise, for (3) profit, from the (4) effort of others.¬†NFTs have 2 options. They can be intrinsically useful (see ENS, which uses NFTs to manage a decentralized domain system for web 3). This most often means, be cool to look at. Or they can be given utility. For example, being a lifetime pass to a series of events or be a tokenized version of some person's time (e.g. buy my NFT and I'll mentor you for 1 hour, which some famous business people are doing).¬†The other option, which too many are doing without registering, is being externally useful by deriving financial gain for holding the NFT.¬†Buy (invest in) our NFT to join our community (common enterprise) and you'll get pre-access to more NFTs / derivative tokens that the core team creates (effort of others) that you can sell (profit).¬†

NFTs are property. The US has 200+ years of legal history managing property as securities. The people launching NFTs without thinking through the legal side are ignorant of history. Land (i.e. property) speculation from 1800-2008 has ironed out nearly ALL the legal problems stemming from NFTs with roadmaps trying to convince people to get in early for profit.¬†They're unregistered securities, many violating the DMCA too, and no, being a DAO doesn't prevent SEC rules 506 and 504 from applying to offerings (i.e. NFT mints).¬†

Pietro M. That link does not have any relevant content on how quantum is useful for this problem. I replied to Greg in another comment on the technical limitations separate from quantum that make this probably not a good problem for quantum to bother attempting to solve.

Separately I think we switched contexts on accident. Brute forcing keys is easy-ish, checking them for balancing and initiating transactions has too many external limits. 

But a separate quantum risk is reversing hash algorithms. Not all hash algorithms are quantum resistant. But Keccak which Ethereum uses (SHA-256) coincidentally is, as there is not 1:1 relationship between inputs and outputs. So going in reverse gets you a non-finite amount of potential inputs. Hypothetically a quantum machine could get stuck finding infinite numbers of potential (and possibly invalid for the specific blockchain) inputs that hash to the public key. 

Quantum would be useful in removing the invalid ones (private keys must be 65 chars long and be compromised of only a:f and 0:9) but then you get into the problem I stated above ^ where speed of light limitations in fiber optics start blocking your theft attempts.

There are a few bottlenecks beyond just the quantum calculation. Even if you manage to brute force 1,000,000,000,000s of keys per second, you still have to (1) compute the public key, (2) check their balances which requires a link to the public blockchain (you can't just spam the etherscan API as that is rate limited even at institution levels to only millions per second and is subject to limitations in information throughput), and (3) initiate transfers to actually steal the money.¬†

Quantum could maybe possibly might be useful in steps 0->1 in the decades time scale, but there are other bottlenecks quantum isn't going to be useful for that will add decades of computational delay simply because of the limits of the speed of light in fiber optics telecoms cables.

I'm ignorant on quantum, so maybe I'm missing something.¬†
I don't know much quantum ü§£ I hope not!

Just to counterbalance the implied negativity of my post, let me detail why you *would* launch an NFT. (I'll go into more details on this another day).

0) There are individuals with overlapping goals. 

1) The goals would be achieved faster/better if the individuals were in a group.

2) The group would be best structured as a community (as opposed to a benevolent dictatorship which is what CharlieDAO is).

3) This community can agree on some subset of goals. 

4) Financializing the community supports achieving the goals beyond the harm it does to the individuals within the community.

5) Community quality does not grow with its size beyond a certain size.

---- Note, there are of course, technological problems that an NFT solves unrelated to this community building point. But again, focusing specifically on the common perception of an NFT, not on the tech. 

Will write more on this another time.

Timothy Rollings I wouldn't call chips a centralizing force, every major government has identified the geopolitical/national security/cyber security implications of relying on only a few manufacturers to make chips. 

Decentralization != 1000000s of suppliers. It's entirely possible that a free market can only sustain a small number of vendors because that's just how the unique economies of scale in that market hit an equilibrium. 

So I guess 2 notes: (1) proof of stake consensus is coming to Ethereum which will heavily decrease the computational requirements to run a node. (2) governments are actively working to improve domesticated manufacturing of chips for other security reasons. So it's not really like chip manufacturers are a cartel (yet). 

Hardware concerns are much more of a concern on high throughput monolithic blockchains like Solana. Not so much for the Ethereum max-modular roadmap where cell phones can one day to validation of blocks (proposer builder separation, more light nodes, faster verification, proof of stake, decentralized staking pools, etc.)

Tommi Vilkamo that's a bit of a false dichotomy. There's no large, credible movement attempting to ban monetary policy and close central banks. There's anarcho-libertarian Bitcoin maxis yelling that stuff on the sidelines getting disproportionate attention, of course. 

The point is to have competition. 

I use dollars. I use Ethereum. I use MATIC, I use Fantom, I use Avalanche. All have different tradeoffs in computation, cost, monetary policy, user experience, available markets, speed, etc. 

I am very happy that I am no longer limited to 0.01% savings accounts and a 401k with poor liquidity and terrible user experience. 

I can use a checking account, a credit card, and keep a variety of assets of a variety of risk profiles across self custody wallets, 3rd party smart contracts, and of course, regulated entities like coinbase with password protection and customer service. 

More people deserve this choice. It's not fair that being born in country X means you get worse than 0 of my list of things. It's about equality of financial opportunity (to me).

The long term of web3 is about flexibility, modularity, and choice. 

One possible future I expect is a spectrum of highly regulated Roll-ups using Ethereum as a common settlement layer.

We could have VISA and MasterCard Roll-ups that feel very much like using Ethereum today, but with flat fees or even subsidized fees. They could even integrate with Coinbase NFT platform and have reversible transactions in case of theft, and legal censorship to prevent inappropriate images or scam coins from showing up in people's wallets 

Users who want a fully regulated experience with fraud protection can use this layer, and confidently know they can choose to exit at any time (with some caveats, eg. waiting periods to prevent fraud).

We could then have public Roll-ups like Arbitrum that don't have any of that reversibility, are fully censorship resistant, and users pay fees directly based on their demand for blockspace and the urgency of it. This may be where higher yield activities live or where most of the NFT market chooses to settle to avoid refund-scams.

All of this can share Ethereum in unique ways.

Ok, I don't have an easy to copy paste reply, so let me just quickly outline my thoughts. 

(1) decentralization is a spectrum

(2) blockchain as a shared data layer enables lower barriers to entry for competition 

(3) Ethereum is chasing a fundamentally modular design 

(4) the 3 above all go together and reinforce each other. 

OpenSea being 95%+ of the NFT market by sales volume is a huge centralization problem. In addition to that, they are also the preeminent API service for NFTs. Critical tools like Metamask use OS APIs to render images. So the article is correct in that there's a *practical* censorship risk when using these vendors.

But the blockchain still helps- because OpenSea uses Ethereum to post transactions, they are susceptible to competition at *extremely low barriers to entry*. 

Check out LooksRARE. They are a decentralized NFT marketplace that seeded their customer base by airdropping tokens to OpenSea users (and we know who uses OpenSea because the transactions are on chain!). 

This is a natural cycle: centralized vendors serve a key need, get too big (e.g., freezing transfers when they know they control 90% of the market activity), and then they face competition that springs up nearly overnight.

Tommi Vilkamo not necessarily a bad thing. But if a country has persistent 20-25%+ inflation with GDP growth < 10%, we shouldn't be surprised citizens don't trust them, and we shouldn't be surprised citizens try to get out of that currency by any means necessary (including illegal underground dollar markets which exist today in numerous countries). 

There are 180 currencies among UN recognized countries. Should there really be this many? How many have proven trustworthy across >20yr time periods? The list is small (unfortunately). 

Web3 will give anyone with internet access the means of storing value (digitally) where it cannot be taken by anyone without your private key. 

Governments can and will do the standard bans (or more politely called "capital controls") as they do today when citizens attempt to vote with their wallets in ways governments don't like them voting, including: banning on/off ramps like coinbase, mass surveillance, warrantless searches & seizures, internet shutdowns, and violent coercion to identify those being "unpatriotic" by not storing their meager wealth in the the local currency. 

This is true revolution.

Ok final note - just to get to your comment of "anything actually practical that can help people get started on solving new problems with web3 today?" 

I think the promise of web3 as a foundational technology is generally being solved. 

Digital property rights (Ethereum) 
Immutable data (blockchain) 
Shared data layers (Ethereum, Roll-Ups, Decentralized Oracle Networks)
Compression, access, and costs ( Cryptography, Zero Knowledge Proofs, Roll-Ups, content-based lookups). 

The problems right now are in getting this stuff to be usable by regular people in ways that deserve trust. Upgradeable proxy contracts are fundamentally sketchy- but they are critical for organizations like AAVE which use smart contracts for autonomous lend/borrow systems that hold BILLIONs of dollars of value. 

So we already see tradeoffs being made to bring things to users (here, immutability is sacrificed to enable emergency powers). 

There's also a massive need in cybersecurity, code auditing, and provably safe code for foundational "LEGO" pieces of the system to work. 

Most of this is going to be solved in (Decentralized) Finance first because that's where the money is (both literally and in terms of potential - automate out all the VPs).

And maybe (4) just to follow up on your DM- 

Immutability, cryptography, and account-based blockchains have a really interesting derivative effect. They allow trust in *information* to inherit trust from an *account* using Zero-Knowledge Proofs. This is a very underexplored concept, that I am only lightly scratching the surface of in this article: 

https://charliemarketplace.substack.com/p/truth-trust-facts-and-the-blockchain

Essentially- you're right. (4) is NOT enough of a reason for an individual Bob to buy. He needs reasons 1,2, and 3 as well.

Fair question. This isn't really a 2-party game, so the Alice/Bob thing is a bit of a purposeful misrepresentation. 

Alice very well might not sell, in which case she is still locking, which benefits everyone including Bob. Bob would still need a (micro-econ) reason to buy. 

His reasons could include: 

1) belief frETH price will rise. 

2) Desire for frETH for his own ability to withdraw early. 

3) Desire to burn frETH to get a share of the new supply of FRZ revenue token. (The new reason added into the tokenomics).

I've done a bit of sleight of hand by combining his micro-econ reasons to buy frETH, into the macro-econ reason for frETH to be bought overall.

The market of all Bobs combined, has a 4th reason to buy frETH. 

(4) A high frETH price incentives locking ETH & selling frETH. This is where you get real impact on the "lowering circulating supply". 

An individual Bob buying (many) frETH has more internalized benefits for him than buying 1 ETH does (all else equal). But it's still very small. But many Bob's together changes the game.

A quick economist tip- 

"If you wouldn't buy at $X, you should be selling at $X". 

I fall for this trap all the time. I try to hold assets I have an emotional attachment to, without realizing that "if this drops 30-50%, I'm probably going to sell it before it gets worse". 

Then it drops 30-50% and I sell (typically, I like to tweet that I'm selling because I have a really good ability to sell at the worst possible time right before everything jumps). 

Because I'm focused on Deep Freeze, I really don't have the time to be watching a lot of assets and trying to catch knives & time markets perfectly. So I've been focusing on long term holds and things *I actually use*. 

I've definitely gotten burned hard for forgetting that rule, and will probably continue to get burned for it long term. Oh well.

Correct, if people expect ETH crashes, they would simply not lock and allow themselves to sell. And of course, just because supply is restricted doesn't mean demand will remain the same (and thus increase price). 

This is a mechanism for people to bribe people to reduce supply; but a decreased demand in excess of supply reduction is still a price reduction. 

Currently, there's no product that allows for anonymous payment to reduce circulating supply of an asset (except for buying it and hoarding it yourself, which is the most expensive way to restrict supply).

Also, there's the reality that plenty of ETH is in long term storage and *isn't circulating* currently. There's no way to estimate this though (you can use time since last move but that's just a proxy). This is on-chain evidence that some amount of ETH will not move. This evidence has a value for the market's information flow.

Free market determines that. It's people paying to reduce the circulating supply of ETH. My hypothesis is that locking 1 ETH away for 1 year should be analogous to the 1 year staked ETH APR (the "implicit" rate of return of ETH) after the proof of stake transition / merge. Those are estimated to be 3-5% paid in ETH. 

I think if frETH can maintain a value of 0.02-0.04 ETH, that would be sensible to me. 

The returns on FRZ are another story entirely, those are a function of the broader market's impatience. As that is pure finance theory. 

The net present value of a stream of payments (here, the payments are frETH early withdrawal penalties + ETH early withdrawal penalties). 

But it's all a function of ETH's price, it's volatility, the market's desire to reduce its circulating supply, and the market demand for FRZ by burning frETH.

12/ FAQs # 1

Why not double dip and do aETH or yearnETH?

Because this is about bringing yield to low risk LONG TERM holders of raw ETH. Contract migrations eat up gas. And custodial contracts are too risky to set & forget for multiple years.

13/ FAQs # 2

Won't everyone just dump frETH??

Yeah maybe! Then the price falls. But it doesn't matter.

1 frETH = [1 ETH removed from circulating supply for 1 year]

The market can price the bribe value. People are still forced to be patient. There is a natural equilibrium to be reached as the lower the price of frETH, the lower the *cost* of impatience (and impatience pays stakers). It also lowers the cost of future revenue (FRZ).

14/ frETH Tokenomics

Doesn't the supply of frETH go up forever as it's earned?

That was a problem originally, earned frETH was only removed by impatient people withdrawing early. But the new Curve style drip gives more pressure to remove supply, by burning it for revenue FRZ.

15/ FRZ Tokenomics

FRZ holders/stakers get their revenue diluted as new FRZ enters the market. This is a bribe too. By accepting dilution, it triggers a battle to burn frETH.

This gives frETH buy pressure, which is critical for liquidity.

"Fungibility refers only to the equivalence and indistinguishability of each unit of a commodity with other units of the same commodity, and not to the exchange of one commodity for another." 

10 ruble is 10 ruble. There's no implication of any stickiness in its value against another not-equivalent commodity.

"USDs are fungible because its value remains the same regardless of who owns it"

Yes. But I would maybe tweak this definition. It's not about not caring about ownership. 

A $1 has a serial number, example: B03542754F
An NFT has a serial number too - example: 0x704bf12276f5c4bc9349d0e119027ead839b081b/3248

Both have meaning.

On a $1, The B corresponds to being issued by the Federal Reserve of New York.

On an NFT, the first section [0x704...81b] corresponds to the ERC-721 smart contract and the [3248] corresponds to the ID number in that contract.

You can actually have fungible non-fungible tokens. Fungible just means Interchangeable.

$1 = $1. 

I have NFTs where the ID # is relevant because it corresponds to specific metadata about that NFT and its possible features of that metadata lead to different market valuations. 

I also have NFTs where the ID # is completely irrelevant. All of them are the exact same with no difference in aesthetic or utility. 

In both fungibles and fungible NFTs (hate typing this lol) - you may find that people pay a premium for arbitrary reasons.

Quarters before 1964 had real silver in them, often more silver than $0.25 worth in today's silver prices. But for currency purposes, they are fungible.

Went ahead and wrote a more specific post on this possibility-

Date: https://www.linkedin.com/posts/crmercado_web3-business-technology-activity-6884578285825613824-_f6A

Message: Wrote this post to clarify on what web3 MIGHT do for disintermediation: https://www.linkedin.com/posts/crmercado_web3-business-technology-activity-6884578285825613824-_f6A

I don't think the data has to be specialized necessarily. I think what happens is businesses will see that credible neutrality gives them an opportunity to multiply their data. If they contribute (some kind of agreed upon anonymization of) data, they will get multiples more data (from both competitors and non competitor other companies using similar data for a similar piece of their product stack). The specialization is in the business use of the multiples more data- and then new businesses will form having specialized in this data because it'll be profitable to form a very specific niche across multiple product categories/companies. 

If 100 different companies are doing deliveries (food, consumables, medication, paperwork), and 90 of them use image processing & geolocation to confirm those deliveries, and appropriately cleaned data on that is openly available, then niches will form, and it will be profitable for maybe 50-80 of those companies to use the specialized service for image processing & geolocation; and only the biggest 10 will do it all in-house (and maybe those 10 don't contribute data... in which case maybe the other 90 organize a permissioned exchange method to exclude them- lots of possibilities).

Multiple different possible models, many depending on regulations, especially those around anonymity & verification of identity. 

In some ways, it might be a micro-services architecture where different groups hyperoptimize their piece of the puzzle and all offer "services as a service". Like this article says: 
https://hbr.org/2018/11/the-end-of-bureaucracy

What web3 makes easy is organized, conditional, credibly neutral payments infrastructure; a shared data layer for collaborative competition; and immutable "algorithmic law". 

The idea that web3 will replace doordash is a tough sell; what is more likely is that it will enable the disintermediation & dissection of doordash into discrete offerings:

[background check] 
[driver authenticated nft issuance] 
[conditional payments]
[product ordering]
[routing]

Each of these components can be useful across many businesses; so the idea that every single food delivery company (Uber eats, doordash, instacart, etc.) should build all these services internally just for themselves is a very web2 way of running a businesses.

Web3 enables collaborative competition, where each of these pieces can be shared by competitors, and the companies profit from the marginal value they bring.

"collaboration, community, exclusivity, etc. is already done without them. Or it‚Äôs already in an NFT minus the public component.

So then what value does the public component do for a gamer?"

Transferability & "true" ownership that persists outside the game/platform. 

Are these valuable? Only in some small collectible sense; they still need a source of utility. Open source makes adding utility easier. But it's not a panacea.

An NFT is public, scarce, digital ownership. 

Most games don't need them. Most games will use them as a means of getting rich off regular people who get left holding the bag for something nobody wants or stops being useful. 

GTA 3 NFTs would maybe have value if people could have used them across GTA 3, 4, 5 and there's an expectation of that continuing going forward. An NFT would make the GTA 3 asset transferrable and collectible. But it doesn't make it render as the same exact object in future games (the game has to choose to render it as w/e).

The public component would be most useful if GTA 3 was open source. Then a community of GTA 3 NFT owners could choose to build on it, create mods, and develop a marketplace around mods. Oblivion & Skyrim mods come to mind.

If it's not open source, then the public component is weakened, but still keeps the fundamentals - a community of owners can choose to give it utility some other way. Realistically, again, without a platform most of these things are collectibles with no value. Which is why I think P2E is a bad framework. 

When I think of Oblivion/Skyrim mods & NFTs- I think about the financialization of the mod community. Would people *choose* to fund mods using blockchain? Maybe.

An NFT is just a representation of ownership in a distributed database. The image is just a fun quirk, although the database may have some attributes. The main thing is that the database (held publicly in a smart contract) distinguishes a community of owners. 

Bored Ape Yacht Club isn't valuable b/c it's funny ape pics. It's valuable because the community of owners does events, gets sponsorships, gets celebrities to buy them, etc. It's a luxury good. 

So, yes, ideally if fortnite was to recognize BAYC it *should* have some attributes persist (hat, moustache, etc.) But it doesn't really have to. They could say, "any BAYC gets you the 1 special Collab Fortnite skin". 

The spectrum of value starts at recognizing the community from the public blockchain within a private game. 

As for in game assets, they'd have a few components. 

(1) the platform component, which relies on the game engine to render. 

(2) the blockchain component, which provides a means for digital scarcity and transfer. 

(3) visual representation, typically via a JPEG on IPFS. 

(2)+(3) + discord + community managers = a community of owners. 

The future is a bunch of companies looking at the community, and adding (1)s to the (2). They may or may not use (3)

Gamification is pretty cool, can lead people to all kinds of interesting solutions to real world problems. Useless assets have a limited market, although we've seen a few gems like Fortnite earn a *lot* from being a leader in this, and of course the famous CS:GO skins gambling market; it's kind of adjacent to the core idea of blockchain gaming, where game assets are earned and owned.

Games that have persistent assets like MMORPGs will struggle to have only useless assets as ownable.¬†

So within gaming, there will be certain types of games that can get away with less useful assets than others.¬†

As for collaborative competition- it still has pyramid aspects of course, as you're going to have assets that gain utility also gain price and then there will be speculation on which assets will get 2nd game, 3rd game, Nth game giving it utility.¬†

And note: we don't need any attributes of the NFT to persist across games (a cross engine T shirt is a lot of dev time). It doesn't have to look the same or even act the similarly across games. Just be recognized across them in some useful way.¬†

The point is that right now, game assets have single sources of utility- the game that created them.¬†

But getting from a monopoly world to a 2+ world is a massive jump. The jump from 1->2 is bigger than the jump from 2-10+. Because it opens up a world of startups, community created games, etc. Paying CAC directly to their target customers and bootstrapping their games off of other games.¬†

People will have more options, those options will be more niche, and people will find the most entertaining thing for their taste.¬†¬†

I wont be the crypto guy who says buy crypto. But I feel like its important to note a few of the underlying assumptions required to purchase a home.¬†

(1) low, fixed interest rates.

This is kind of a given nowadays, you can walk into a bank and get a  5% fixed loan for a mortgage and some even without a down payment.¬†

(2) the city is minimally well run

If the city you buy in goes bankrupt or has some insane natural disaster or is overly reliant on a specific industry (or even single corporations) or decides to spike property taxes youre going to be adversely effected.¬†

(3) you dont mind forgetting its an investment

Fundamentally, the value of owning property is that you extract value from future people (possibly not yet born) with current value.¬†

You have to *realize* the gains.¬†

So if there arent new people being made (US population had its first negative year with covid) youre going to need your property to be better than alternative properties and thats a bet on the city, your patience, and your renovations of course.¬†

Relatedly, real estate is rarely this liquid. You can sneeze near a realtor right now and get 10 profitable offers in 80%+ of the US right now.¬†

This may not hold if the government is forced to get more involved in the market to incentivize more development as there arent enough homes where people want to live, and too many homes in ghost towns everyone is leaving.¬†

----
Having said this, I own my home in the probably the most recession proof area of the US (DC), and could probably sell for 30%+ gain tomorrow.¬†

I wouldnt buy the home I bought in the condition I bought it in at current market prices, tomorrow though.¬†

The web3 lessons here are:¬†

1) it pays to use things¬†

Competitors will look at users of products and literally pay them to acquire them as users. This sounds crazy, but it shouldn't. People who've done sales & marketing should get it immediately. Give CAC to target customers.¬†

2) communities of users are easier than ever to build

This does NOT mean, *profitable* communities are easy to build. Targeting *builders* will always be harder than targeting *users*. But there's a logic to rewarding the most active people at the forefront of a technology. And eventually the tools & analytics will get better for targeting certain customers over others.¬†

3) we're very early¬†

It took Google over a decade to get a 90% market share in the search market. It took OpenSea months. Once the big tech companies wake up to the opportunity they will have literally everything at their disposal- more product managers, more engineers, more money, more everything.¬†

And they'll be in the best position to use these same CAC strategies to take market share.¬†

If you're someone who cares about community driven development and/or someone who doesn't want to tech giants to own this new iteration of the internet then you especially need to be paying attention and working to build natural moats.¬†

The only moat in web3 is a loyal community of customers.

darn it my whole big answer got lost :/ in the interwebs - Shortened reply, happy to add detail:  

Banks want to play ball. It's governments that are stressed. 

Banks create money by undercollateralized lending against their reserves (deposits). Being able to access web3 and create their own stablecoins would be a massive boost to their bottom line. 

Governments control money by fiddling with interest rates and reserve ratio requirements (increasing/decreasing loan costs and increasing/decreasing amount possible to loan). 

Web3 w/ widespread stablecoin usage would create free floating interest rates and protocol determined reserve ratios (e.g. AAVE only allows up to 80% of collateral value to be borrowed against).

So it's the other way around.

Unfortunately I suspect the opposite. The nations with the most control to lose will be the most heavy handed in exerting control. Monetary policy is everything for corrupt regimes. It's the final leg of their legitimacy.

Gas is totally separate, I'd recommend not thinking of it when thinking of price of an asset. You can set lower gas targets if you're patient and/or wait until the network is less in demand. ETH gas is purely a function of demand for blockspace. We're very early, in the near future, people will be using Roll-ups for most transactions & there will be a much more professional application layer that abstracts us away from which Roll-ups we're using. 

I think 3-5 years and people legit won't even know what the blockchain is, same way nobody knows what SMTP or tcp/IP really means. They just focus on applications (websites).

More specifically, owning hashrate or PoS is a consensus thing, not a protocol thing. The protocol is determined by the EIP process and core developers and the ETH clients (software) that are made. Ethereum has multiple clients which gives it resiliency and forces more coordination and review for any large software changes- which depending on the change, is either a soft-fork (doesn't invalidate previous versions of software) or hard fork (requires upgrades that invalidate past versions of the software). 

The Merge will be a hard fork. EIP-1559 was a hard fork. But because client core teams coordinate regularly to ensure they don't develop in a way that's harmful to other clients, hard forks are generally quite smooth unlike the DAO incident that created Ethereum classic. 

Consensus is about getting fake blocks through. You actually need more like 67% of the validators to collude to break ETH post merge. There's a metric called nakamoto coefficient that is somewhat related to this as a measure of decentralization. 

The trilemma is real, ETH focuses on security & decentralization. Scale is coming through Proof of Stake transition, Roll-ups that inherit security by posting their data directly to ETH, and sharding.

jpg is not the asset. it's a fun representation of the asset, but it's not related. An NFT is a distributed database mapping [token ID => Owner]. Where only the owner can designate changes to the mapping of the token ID's they own.

That database only has value if its given utility by a community. Typically, it's a community of people who also have a [token ID => Owner] mapping within the same database (the NFT's contract address). 

The vast majority of NFTs have little to no community and little to no utility. 

The technical breakthrough is that because these databases are public, and the Owner has on-chain activity that allows you to characterize them as someone who does certain [behaviors] (e.g. own competitor NFTs or do a lot of crypto trades on-chain) ANYONE can choose to add utility to a database. 

I can target all the owners of Mutant Ape Yacht Club (of which I know Josh is a member), send them an airdrop of tokens, and hope some % of them use my product. 

This enables customer acquisition cost (CAC) to be paid directly to target customers. It's a multi-billion dollar innovation in marketing, sales, advertising, community building, etc. 

The JPEG is honestly the least interesting part of the whole thing.

I wouldn't phrase it as a progression. Hierarchy is useful, DAOs are difficult to manage when hierarchy is required for operations reasons. 

Not all JPEGs should be NFTs- image NFTs are honestly the low hanging fruit of NFTs, the tech is way beyond just images. 

Not all communities should be tokenized, it's probably a securities law violation to financialize certain types of communities. 

BTC/ETH are great assets, but it's like accepting gold. We probably want to use a stablecoin for most exchange, although in the near future, the friction to switch between assets will be so small, that it'll all effectively be the same experience no matter the currency. 

Login with Web3 wallet is 100% correct, it's disgusting how much we expose our emails, passwords (which people re-use too much), date of births, locations, social security numbers, security questions, etc. to companies who have 0 need for it. They just want to pummel us with ads. I hate it. I push every company in web3 to use ethereum based login. 

Not all video games should be play 2 earn; I think there's an argument that games should be more ownership by design, but financializing games can ruin the fun. Hardos come in with bot-farms and armies of low-paid workers.

RE: Public schools. There's some interesting research from the late 90s on school grades (A+ school vs B- school) and the regression discontinuity of home prices on the borders of school districts.¬†

It's a weird circular problem of high property tax = more school funding = better schools = higher home values = higher property tax.¬†

I don't think public schools should be funded differently based on the wealth of the locality. Seems to defeat the point of the word "public" in public schools. But that's a whole side debate.¬†

Now, should property owners be on the hook for roads that get used by other people visiting the business district they live next to?¬†

That's a whole debate. We see some states go heavy on property taxes and low on consumption taxes (sales, alcohol, similar taxes). Then we see other states do the exact opposite.¬†

Florida has no state income tax but property taxes and properties are insane relative to median incomes. This is different from California.¬†

The reason many are biased towards property taxes is because the supply function of land is not deterred by taxation. You have the same amount of land regardless of how it's taxed.¬†

Of course, *the thing built on the land* is super elastic to property taxes and you can easily overtax and lose development.¬†

So it's common for land and "improvements" (buildings) to have different tax regimes for certain zones.¬†

Cause economics is all about balancing opportunity costs. Land quality is totally separate from it's quantity.¬†

We see this today where cities with better farmable land are more dense than cities with worse farmable land (Chicago is denser than Phoenix).¬†

Within a city, same underlying economics, central land versus non centered land. Or land by water vs land by an airport.¬†

Two pieces of land have different *alternative uses*, it is these alternative uses that provide rationale for different valuations and prices.¬†

So it's not as simple as both being zoned residential. If one is zoned residential but is 5 minutes from a business district, it's going to have a higher alternative use value than a residential zoned house 30 minutes from a business district.¬†

I understand I'm not exactly answering the "why tax it differently" part, but it's all tied together.¬†

The value of the land is market determined, the tax assessment uses this for context because it does have other impacts (roads near business districts do get used more than faraway roads. They need more water management, more waste management, more policing, etc.)¬†

The reason I say discord is anti web3, is because when they actually *tried* to integrate ethereum stuff, their community went rabid - saying NFTs & crypto are all ponzi scams and they'd quit discord for gaming / clubs / etc. if Discord dared to expand its service offering.¬†

Similar to the pushback Ubisoft got even more recently.¬†

The rabid anti web3 crowd has been maliciously taught that NFTs destroy the planet (they don't, proof of work use a lot of energy, but proof of stake NFTs use effectively 0 energy) and that all crypto is ponzi scams (to be fair, if you search crypto on tiktok or youtube, you will get the most popular influencer garbage that I would never buy).

The problem is that these customers are bullying companies into not servicing customers that disagree with them. I'm not sure how Web2 companies pivot to Web3 without educating their current customers first and making it acceptable to them that they need to grow their business.

Hard to say. A lot of the biggest Web3 products heavily rely on centralized services like Cloudfare, AWS, etc. These services have actually been attack vectors multiple times for dapps, a Cloudfare API key caused a front-end attack on BadgerDAO that led to massive losses that weren't covered by smart contract insurance (web3 insurance doesn't cover web2 hacks :/). 

So in some ways, you have to wonder what's actually possible. 

Is it possible to have a decentralized S3? Yes, IPFS. 
Is it possible to have a decentralized EC2? Eh, technically, but not at a price point even remotely reasonable (we're talking 1000x+ costs).

For many, a web3 discord would just be a web2 discord that posts its archive to IPFS periodically, uses NFTs to segment channels & access, and then uses an ETH roll-up for value transfer. 

There's web hooks in discord today (e.g. collab land) that can jerry-rig this kind of stuff together using separate tools like login with metamask linking it to a discord handle.
ü§∑ I think there's something there, but it's under a lot of manure and not everyone is trying to dig through that.

Things to note & disclosures:¬†

1) I have a few DAO tokens, I don't care about their price, I'm actually voting in these very specific DAOs, e.g., PieDAO

2) stocks allow you to vote too (depending on the "class" of shares), nobody reads Prospectus (not even hardos like me), they just trust their 401k managers to do it.¬†

3) some DAOs are getting ahead of these problems through vote delegation (e.g. ENS which I've talked about many times) and DAO owned liquidity (which has risk tradeoffs relative to incentivized community liquidity).¬†

4) eventually, we'll see web3 native technology replace web2 stopgap tools like discord which is anti-web3 üòÇ

5) eventually the political apparatus will do something to update these laws, which will (if the US leadership actually does their homework and does the smart pro-US dollar move) regulate these entities as the special startups they're trying to be and not pigeonhole them into existing securities laws that don't apply.¬†

I'm optimistic, but I'm not delusional. We're very early and the space is very underregulated and chaotic. Proceed with caution.¬†

Roadmap is fluid, the momentum is shifting to raising the priority of roll-ups, specifically reducing the cost to post calldata (reducing L2 costs by 80%+). After that, I think the move to 4 shards is Q2/Q3 '22. But it's all dynamic. The beacon chain is live, the Proof of Stake stuff is live (but not flipped on), and I think shards are going live on a testnet in Q1 '22? But don't quote me on the last one.

And the costs for AWS multi-region support is painful; plenty of companies are forced to rely on 99.96% uptime guarantees and pray for the best.

Yes, but I should note Ethereum, Solana, and other blockchains that claim to be the future of global decentralized computing, are also hilariously reliant on AWS lol. 

I think the future is a mix of edge computing + zero knowledge proofs (e.g., zk-SNARKs) + credibly neutral computation. 

I imagine a future of people opting into to having their passive computing devices (everything from cell phones to tablets to work desktops) connected to some kind of credibly neutral set of applications - your device receives [data] + [instruction] and it outputs [result] and posts it to the application. 

Zero Knowledge Proofs enable us to confirm the instructions were followed exactly, edge computing is the idea that we do the computation as close to its end destination as possible (e.g., a model that chooses which ad to show a cell phone user, would calculate the optimal ad choice either on that device itself or on devices in the same geographic area), and then roll up technologies can serve as credibly neutral ground to post calculation results and store the outputs on either a public blockchain (e.g., Ethereum as compressed call data) or a private database (e.g. S3). 

It's a super complicated problem, that's for sure.

I hope Web 3 can completely reconstruct the current gig economy, remove as much middle-men as possible, and make the economy truly Peer to Peer (with decentralized conflict resolution with protocols like UMA and Aragon).

Daniel McAloon üï∫üï∫üíÉüíÉ - I answered your first question, "Web 3 is internet + credibly neutral money + decentralized use cases for that money."

üï∫üíÉ Note: I never said I was an expert!

How does web3 solve data collection? By giving consumers choice!

You can buy a TV online with a traditional retailer, give them more info than strictly necessary, and get spammed forever, or you can use a web3 solution, one I haven't used & am no longer invested in (which I discuss in the micro book you didn't click the link for üíÉüï∫) SPI - allows you to make purchases on Amazon or Walmart with only crypto. 

Submit an address of delivery, pay with crypto using your preferred wallet, then get the goods. If there's a problem, SPI coordinates it with you. Amazon never gets more than your address & SPI never gets anything except your transaction hash proving you paid for the order # generated.

Data segmentation preserves privacy. 

Personally, I don't mind Amazon and don't mind them tracking my data as they've proven to be good stewards and have good recommendation engines. 

Web 3 is very early, there aren't a lot of good solutions for real word purchases, but I'm hyped for the possibilities.

LinkedIn is the most underdeveloped social media because it has a monopoly on the "professional" market. I could go all day on how weak it is.


- no content reusability (a nightmare to find old content, content expires fast, although they've been working on extending this)¬†

- shares are shadow banned (to prevent things going viral, shared posts are treated as 3rd class posts)

- groups are useless - literally don't use them¬†

- newsletter is broken, also they monopolize the email list, so you can't leave the platform with your readers.¬†

- connection/follower distinction is outdated and they won't fix it
- articles aren't SEO optimized so they don't get read externally and like groups, don't get used internally.

- can't decide if they want profiles to replace resumes or be a post history (like Twitter)¬†

- analytics are 19th century (not a typo), effectively useless until you pay a lot of money and even then third parties like shield are 1000x better.

Truly, the worst of Twitter combined with the worst of Facebook.¬†

They need to:¬†

- end groups / articles
- buy substack and integrate it fully to replace newsletters (add twitters "notify when this user posts" & lists) including full portability of follower emails.

- make profiles significantly more customizable (and actually keep pinned content, not randomly resetting it when they update the servers...)

- allow shares to be first class citizens

They'd rather users spam worthless polls and get the ad views than actually connect people. So much potential squandered, I'm pretty much converted to Twitter.¬†

When you registered a domain, you purchased your name as an NFT. This NFTs metadata can contain things like: image avatars & links to IPFS files.¬†

If you link an IPFS *html* file to your NFT metadata, then going to:¬†

[Your ens].eth.link
 
Or similarly: [your ens].eth.limo and a few other extensions

Will render in a web2 browser (chrome, brave, etc.) as a website!¬†

Espionage and non competes are nowhere near the same. A $12/hr janitor on a non-compete is foundationally ridiculous. Nobody making < $250,000/year should be on a non compete in the internet age. Customer lists and trainings that are literally on Google & YouTube are not trade secrets.

Espionage is of course illegal. A janitor using their badge to enter offices and take photos of business documents is illegal. But simply entering offices to clean them and glancing at a whiteboard with information they don't have any context for is nowhere near trade secret protection. 

 I've signed 3 non-competes- all blatantly ridiculous and unenforceable. 

A freight broker who can't call their current customers if they switch jobs (even though it's 100% public information on the internet) is the only one worth arguing and it's still ridiculous in my opinion.

Another ridiculous one was predicated on the movie theater having taught me a special way to put ice in an ice machine & proprietary way to put butter on popcorn.
