Something like AAVE for example is a fully open sourced bank. Deposit funds, borrow with collateral, they take the spread as revenue. There's a core team and investors, but the code is fully open source. As a result, tons of clones have come around with different business models. For example, Geist copy/pasted AAVE and then instead of a core team keeping the spread, people stake Geist tokens to earn the spread. 

No investors no core team, just copy/paste tweak the business model. 

Is AAVE going to collapse? No, because people value their innovation and the market of users is happy to let them keep the spread in exchange for an increasingly advanced product. They're the market leader through pure market consensus, not any closed source monopolization of their product. 

Of course, this only works for software, you won't see this for hardware. But as we get further down the pipeline of abstracting hardware from credibly neutral computation, we'll see more and more software be open source, community driven, and profitable- even when copy/paste forks are easy.

David Helkowski I think that's where we disagree. Crypto is enabling value transfer to happen just as easily as information transfer online. 

This is a UX problem. Would I rather give Google my identity or $X/year? Well, the former, takes 30 seconds, the latter, they either don't even offer an ad free / privacy preserving version, or if they did, it requires the hassle of signing up, setting recurring payments, etc. 

I agree RE: core hardware. But credibly neutral computation (which is what the Ethereum state machine enables, albeit prohibitively expensive for most computations right now) would allow someone to make a Gmail or Google drive or even Google cloud competitor with organized payment via pubic smart contracts. 

It's hard to fund open source because the UX isn't there. There's some great work from Vitalik Buterin on quadratic funding; there's open source financialization platforms like Gitcoin that enable communities of users to invest in open source and see profit from revenue streams (& of course, speculation). And I do think a culture shift is happening. 

Developers know open source is the best work, and closed source is mostly stitching together the value created from open source. We just need to financialize it.

We'll probably never be able to do whatever we want on a Windows / Apple device. But what we can do is make it *profitable* to build in the open.¬†

These monopolies aren't that complicated. They prefer money over everything.

We see the rumblings of this stuff. Google open sourced Android and derivatives like Jio are becoming critical infrastructure in low & middle income countries (where phones often skip touch screen to reduce costs).

Facebook is building its walled garden Metaverse, but even Zuckerberg has acknowledged that Microsoft's failed attempt to create a walled garden internet (The Microsoft Network, MSN) in 1995 was a lesson for him in following user preferences- I expect natively open technology to become the norm. Facebook's metamerve must accept free flowing of users & their sovereign data in & out of their systems just to compete.¬†

We're extremely early on this stuff. I have 0 expectation that the next 100M users will touch Uniswap. That vast majority will use Fintech apps that custody their assets and whitelist the kinds of interactions they have in their apps.¬†

*But* it only takes a sufficient number of users demanding the ability to self custody and exit systems with their data as their own, to force these apps into setting up the rails to exit/enter them as users please.¬†

Coinbase is ahead on this, they know their custody business is not a century-long play. So they are building products to serve the whole spectrum of crazy TOR guys who use Linux that want a self custody wallet to the young woman investing a small piece of her paycheck in a fully custodied and insured Bitcoin ETF as part of her 401k.¬†

It took 11 years to go from Netscape to Amazon S3. Give it a few decades, making value transfer as native to the internet as information transfer is revolutionary, but revolutions are slow.¬†

Date: Most people should not be random buying random coins with the hope of getting rich. Bitcoin & Ethereum are plenty of exposure for the vast majority of people.

Message:
Crypto is a massive risk, it's extremely under regulated, and there's malicious actors using advanced AI to spam social media, manipulate coin pricing, and even manipulate how transactions are settled on the blockchain (miner extracted value- MEV).

Crypto is also subject to unique risks like flash loan attacks and poorly written code that leaves vulnerabilities in where user's funds are stored (see: Rekt, a blog site that tracks large hacks in DeFi).

This of course is not entirely unique to crypto, the SWIFT system in traditional finance has been hacked by North Korea for hundreds of millions of dollars and banks all over the world have to cover for edge cases like ransoms, transfers under duress, and even pirates. But in practice, deposit insurance is much more common and the day to day investing for regular people is much simpler in traditional finance.

The benefit of crypto is it's risk- the ability to completely control your own assets with no trusted third party. If your bank is told by authorities to freeze your account because your name sounds funny or matches a bad person- good luck ever accessing that again. Not to mention the grotesque rise in civil asset forfeiture (see: John Oliver's episode on this, it's disgusting).¬†

I don't think the future state is everyone being a full crypto cowboy that actually stores their entire wealth in fully self custodied wallets. But if crypto can bring: transparency, flexibility, portability, and credible neutrality to the finance system I think those are all massive positives that outweigh the risks (including the realities of money laundering and terrorist financing).

What you call "flout currency controls" I would honestly just call digital gold. Plenty of people are waking up to the problems with fiat currencies which are really only 50 years old (Nixon left gold standard in 1971).   

I don't think speculation is a bad word and I don't think it's bad to want to have a stockpile of assets that are safe from bad governance. I live in the USA, the most stable economy and government in the world, the longest running experiment in democracy. But as a student of history, I'd be foolish to believe there's no risk to holding my entire life worth in assets fundamentally controlled by others. 

That may make me sound crazy, but it's the same fundamental premise as the 2nd amendment (which is something I don't even personally use) lol.

1) most people don't need credibly neutral decentralized value transfer. 

Agree 100%. I use Venmo with friends. Bitcoin is not the currency for average person in a strong, open economy. If your currency inflates at/under GDP growth, you're probably fine. It's better for people with 8% GDP growth and 25% inflation who literally can't get ahead in life because it's illegal for them to "vote with their feet" and leave bad countries & currencies.

2) a buyer of last resort for energy can increase energy prices, hurting regular people

Also agree 100%. Much like taxing pollution through carbon credits, raising prices is a mechanism to enforce more judicious use of energy. If people choose to build solar in the middle of nowhere because it's profitable with Bitcoin, then I expect a benefit we will all see is more innovation in solar panels. I'm an optimist and think that kind of innovation will transfer well to solar not in the middle of nowhere.

3) decentralization is for sketchy terrorists

Yeah, ransomware & terrorists & drug dealers love Bitcoin. They also love dufflebags of $100s. ü§∑ It's hard. But I don't believe the guilty until proven innocent paradigm of tracking every person's every transaction is the right answer.

Yeah, confirming now that I'm looking at the auction, it's an erc-1155 (as opposed to a 721) and is within the OpenSea contract (instead of its own). 

Realistically, this won't matter to your end buyer, as they're purchasing your unlockable content. Just something to be aware of if you are trying to be fully decentralized & not rely on OpenSea in the future. Ethereum is the most valuable blockspace in the world, and the vast majority of small NFTs and projects shouldn't be on the premium luxury layer 1. Over the next few years, we'll see it become much more common to use layer 2 and side chains like Polygon for affordable NFTs.

Sam Nelson depends on the auction structure. If you used OpenSea Storefront (many do, to save money) then you don't actually mint the NFT on Ethereum (where it would get it's own contract address), instead your NFT is held within the OpenSea Storefront contract allowing it to be sold/bid on using only signatures. The negative of course is that it's under OpenSea's control.

The "proper" (expensive but fully decentralized) way to mint an NFT is to upload the image/file to IPFS for persistent data storage, spin up an ERC-721 contract yourself, and mint the NFT(s) with the IPFS URL in the Metadata for that contract-ID.

OpenSea will allow you to do it either way, but they have subtle ways of pushing people into keeping it under their control to save costs.

I don't own Bitcoin, but energy efficiency is really easy. Just give up decentralization.¬†

Bitcoins goal is to be the most credibly neutral means of value transfer in the world.¬†

Nobody can actually shut it down without effectively shutting down the internet as the hash rate drops as miners get taken out, making it easier for smaller operations to secure the network.¬†

Solana went down for 10hrs due to lack of client diversity, and my understanding is the hardware requirements are insane, meaning the centralization problem is a given.¬†

The easiest blockchain is just an excel file in the cloud 1 person updates and everyone trusts lol.¬†

Depends how we define efficiency. An excel spreadsheet of coin balances on a single computer is wildly energy efficient as there's little duplication or need to do dumb things like find a hash convergence.¬†

The trilemma is:¬†

Decentralization, Security, Scale. Pick 2.

Bitcoin prioritizes decentralization & security. And SegWit was the foundation for Lightning Network to work and eventually bring Scale. Every main blockchain competitor that scales well, gives up decentralization. Which I think is fine as long as we accept governments will regulate those nodes heavily and the chain will eventually lose credible neutrality ("you can't validate transactions involving these addresses known to be associated with sanctioned countries").

I think China is going to look back and regret giving up their insane plurality on the Bitcoin hash rate, especially as they want to diversify their financial reserves away from US dollar. As for energy consumption, it uses a *lot* of energy. That's undeniable. My point is I think it's interesting to wonder what it would look like when the big bucks are actually trying to make it more energy efficient and how that would have positive effects for energy elsewhere.¬†

To get good at anything you need practice. Bitcoin is the absolute easiest way to practice energy, because you can finance energy creation without actually having to do all the infrastructure work of bringing energy to cities, people, corporations, and managing that infrastructure.¬†

All you need is a means to connect to pools and send calculations over.¬†

Blockchains sell blocks. The transactions within blocks are immutable once settled (there's an entire attack vector called re-orgs, where miners can attempt to reorganize the transactions within recent blocks- this is natural given the competitive nature of choosing which chain of blocks to consider the "correct" chain).¬†

Block immutability is not related to the computational side of the blockchain.¬†

Miners run software called "clients" to choose transactions from "mempools" for inclusion in the blocks they produce and recommend for inclusion in the blockchain.

These clients can be pretty different in implementation, as long as the end result is blocks that are compliant with the blockchain's rules.

Bitcoin Improvement Proposals (BIPs) are ways for the community to recommend changes to the blockchain rules and how clients function to abide by those rules.

Some changes are backwards compatible and don't require every miner to actually agree to upgrade their client in order for new blocks to fit into the blockchain. These are called "soft forks" because.¬†

Some changes to a protocol are not backwards compatible and would require a "hard fork"- the changes are so significant that you essentially have to make an entirely new blockchain that inherits all previous blocks and continues with the new software rules.¬†

Ethereum & Ethereum Classic are an example of a hard fork. Segregated Witness (SegWit) is another example for Bitcoin which led to the Bitcoin Cash fork.¬†

So, blocks being immutable is entirely different from block creation being mutable. For more, definitely look into the block size wars for Bitcoin 2014-2017..¬†

Joining a DAO and experiencing the proposal / governance discussions and processes firsthand is great for understanding an entirely new future of work. No tokens needed, in fact, just doing helpful things like meeting minutes, curating FAQs, and helping newbies can earn you legit income as DAOs have money and need labor in all kinds of categories (not just developer/analyst/PM!). 

I would push against someone creating their own tokens or NFTs. It's all about community building and generating real value for people at scale. A 1,000th CryptoPunk ripoff might work as a get rich quick scheme temporarily, but then you're missing the beauty of Web 3.

My real opinion, is that having a global, decentralized buyer of last resort for energy would be much too disruptive for governments to accept existing. So they have a vested interest in getting the media and population against bitcoin on environmental grounds ("It uses so much energy!") without providing them any critical thought into why, how, the short-term & long-term impacts, etc.

(I'll note: I say this while owning literally 0 Bitcoin)

Proof of Stake is much easier to regulate, as you can go directly to the managed node services (e.g., Blockdaemon) and subpoena them for records on their customers, enforce know-your-customer laws, tax the on-chain revenue, etc. I fully expect PoS to become the standard and for governments to get in on the action. Some economists I follow expect Ethereum 2.0 staked ETH to replace US Treasury Bonds as a global yield bearing store of value. Of course, this is a radical statement that will anger many lol..

Proof of Work vs Stake isn't directly related to MEV- but it's important to bring up as we consider what we mean by "tolerable" dishonesty. What would be entirely intolerable dishonesty is updating the blockchain to transfer someone's assets to yourself without their permission.

In Ethereum today, there is something called MEV- Miner Extracted Value (it technically exists in Bitcoin as well, but I don't understand MEV in that context much to be honest). The ability to choose which transactions make it into a block (and ultimately onto the blockchain) and in which *order* those transactions happen is an entire field of study with $100M+ impacts just on Ethereum.

Proof of Stake is, by design, insanely less energy intensive than PoW. But at the cost of being a centralizing force. It takes money to make money in Proof of Stake. In proof of work, you could at least theoretically get lucky by contributing a very tiny amount of hashpower (e.g., a raspberry pi) for a long period of time to a pool of miners.

Both aim to solve the problem of those in power being honest (within tolerance). 

PoW seeks to prevent intolerable dishonesty by making block production very energy intensive. PoS seeks to prevent this dishonesty by making you put up a pile of value that can be slashed for being dishonest.

Technically, in both cases, the reward for successful dishonesty is magnitudes of order higher than the cost, so that's why cryptography comes into play. 

Less technically- Proof of Work is interesting because it allows miners to be "buyers of last resort" for energy. Anywhere in the world with a minimum connection to the Bitcoin network can immediately convert excess energy into bitcoin by validating transactions on the network. 

Buyers of last resort can have very interesting and positive economic impacts on a market. For energy, having a buyer of last resort provides a floor price for energy; this can incentivize green energy (hydroelectric, solar, even nuclear), better energy storage (so you can wait until bitcoin price is high), and better energy utilization (by reducing "cheap" energy- as you always have Bitcoin who will pay a minimum price).

This is of course completely the opposite of everything mass media says about bitcoin.

NFTs are a timestamped receipt with metadata.

If I draw a picture, I can upload it to IPFS, store the URL in the metadata of an NFT, and mint it on the Ethereum blockchain.

Now my image is permanent & you know with 100% certainty it is an original Carlos drawing because:¬†

1) it has an on-chain record proving it was the first NFT with that metadata (timestamp + NFT contract address)
2) it has an on-chain record it was created by me (my Ethereum address)¬†

Even tho people can copy/paste the image, reupload it to IPFS, mint their own NFTs with the same metadata- it is impossible for their NFT to:¬†

1) come from my NFT's contract address
2) have a timestamp earlier than my timestamp

None of this is relevant to copyright law. I don't own Micky Mouse just cause I make an NFT of it. But in terms of social consensus, people will know which one was first (but they don't necessarily *have* to like or value mine more)

This article does a better job explaining it than I could. Essentially you can track accounts/balances (what Ethereum does) or you can track coin transfers (including not being transferred, i.e., unspent, what Bitcoin does).

Both work and have pros and cons. Ethereum manages a global state machine of accounts, their balances, contracts, and their storage- so using account models make sense. Bitcoin only tracks coin creation and transfer, where an "account balance" is just the sum of unspent transaction output (which can be spent by anyone with the private key).

I personally prefer Ethereum

https://hackernoon.com/bitcoin-utxo-vs-ethereums-account-based-blockchain-transactions-explained-simply-164x37f5

What is it?¬†

Metaverse, now co-opted by Facebook/Meta, is the concept that the digital and "real" world will gradually merge over time.¬†

We already integrate our cell phones into everyday life- the weather app affects what we wear. We tap the screen a few times and a car appears to bring us wherever we want.¬†

Eventually as the hardware improves (glasses instead of a bulky box attached to your face) we'll see even more integration of digital content into the real world (often this is put under the sublabel AR- augmented reality).¬†

In addition to digital coming to real world, we'll see real world go digital. We already experience productive, collaborative work through tools like laptops, cameras, and Zoom. We also already see people create and maintain relationships with others entirely through social media.¬†

Metaverse is the complex fusion of these patterns with a new foundation layer: digital scarcity and thus digital ownership.¬†

The real world is unique because it is scarce. It takes people and energy to create things that are useful. While in the digital world it's as simple as copy/paste.¬†

Technologies like blockchain & NFTs will allow native value transfer on the internet and ownership of digitally scarce resources.

So the Metaverse is the future of owning, creating, transferring goods (both "real" and digital) in a digital & "real" world seamlessly.¬†

And unfortunately, the reality is the vast majority of academic work is worthless nonsense that will never be read let alone cited. We should probably stop funding that work. Financialization incentivizes quality.

The problem is that publishers create a moat where they choose what gets seen and considered authentic/quality/legitimate. 

The future is that every writer will create their work and will have the ability to both enable it to be freely readable by anyone they choose and allow it to be financialized if used by certain institutions. 

For example, I can write a paper on an economics topic and post it freely. I can also at the same time, release an NFT representing it's right to reuse & cite in formal work. 

The best papers and authors and journals and institutions can (assuming there is enough social pressure to do so) purchase my official copies for inclusion in their prints, curations, citations, and derivative work to prove they support original authors. 

Right now, there's no way to easily pay the author of a good paper for their contribution to human knowledge (the public good problem). 

Web 3.0 will usher in entirely new business models for public goods, while at the same time allowing completely customizable access to digital creations. 

Of course, if there is no *culture* of financing public goods and/or supporting academics self (or consenting collective) publishing, then this won't happen. 

We have to value the work.

Just remember the value is purely free market derived. So it'd be like making Steven trading cards. Not saying you couldn't do it, but collectibles are a tough market. Bringing in utility (e.g., having people buy a Steven NFT that gives them access to your website and calendly for mentorship or advisory consulting) can generate additional value (to you) but may come at the cost of your free audience.¬†

Just remember the value is purely free market derived. So it'd be like making Steven trading cards. Not saying you couldn't do it, but collectibles are a tough market. Bringing in utility (e.g., having people buy a Steven NFT that gives them access to your website and calendly for mentorship or advisory consulting) can generate additional value (to you) but may come at the cost of your free audience.¬†

There's a type of NFT called POAPs (proof of attendance protocol). Typically, they're collectibles, but if the community of attendees is well connected enough and the token drives enough utility (e.g., lifetime membership, discounts, exclusive events, etc.) then you get into the territory of having financialized a community and brand.¬†

Then, if it's on chain, you may see other, related groups start noticing your community and create "Legos" that fit on top of your NFT.¬†

For example, if an up and coming data science conference wanted to bootstrap community and drive attendance. They could look at the on-chain POAPs of competitor conferences and send them free tickets directly.¬†

One thing I skipped here that is extremely powerful and underrated- Because these stamps are easy to read, you can do something even cooler than just looking at them or buying them... You can integrate these stamps into your own products!

Want top 1,000 R programmers to become advisors to your analytics startup? 

Go give everyone who earned the R club stamp access to your products and offer them your own stamps in exchange for advisory consulting. 

You know exactly what public blockchain address they used to make their NFT. Just give them yours for free, some % of them will reach out and say thank you! Then you can try to work out a deal.

And I should note- this is 100% happening today (It's happened to me!)

One thing I was worried about in going full time into Web 3.0 (unattached to an employer) was that I would be working with broke startups and taking a massive paycut. 

I was DEAD WRONG. Capital flowing into web 3.0 is insane.¬†

For the past few months I've been involved in several DAOs at a very light workload (mostly advisory and community building). 

One of the large ones I'm in recently financialized their network effects.

My share of that was more than 3 months salary equivalent to my previous job...

If you're a fast learner, have a niche skillset, and are digitally social, these groups have cash and want your contribution.

My major point here- is that the future is 3 types of work: computers, community, creation. 

You're either working with a computer to develop new ways of working; working with a community to maximize their use of the new ways of working; or creating in real life things like manufacturing, food, art, energy, etc. All 3 will work synergistically in Web 3.0, as in real life things can have a 1:1 digital pair to ensure authenticity and traceability.

In any industry, if you're doing primarily things computers can do, you should be looking to shift to community or creation or diving deeper in the computer stuff to develop new "primitives" for that industry.

You'll still have AAVE and Uniswap.

Even if you ban proof of stake, Ethereum can function on proof of work (the transition to PoS is a hard fork so some fraction of people could continue to old PoW client by choice).¬†

You'll still have Roll-ups for reduced transaction costs. As long as the internet is legal, you'll have some form of Ethereum for no other reason that it has the most robust smart contracts, documentation, and history.¬†

It would be injured severely, but as long as open source code is legal, you'd have web 3.0 websites, with wallet log-in and ways to transfer money via the internet in a non permissioned way.¬†

To successfully kill crypto assets they'd have to coordinate 190+ countries all banning open source programming- which is the foundation of the entire tech ecosystem. It wouldn't cost billions in lost economic value, it'd cost trillions. Every politician would be decimated by 40%+ unemployment rates.¬†

It's a false dichotomy. Vast majority of landlords are small time. Every other developed country sent people money directly and they used that to continue paying their bills while figuring out getting back to work.¬†

US did the worst thing possible, greenlight businesses tossing millions of people into a bureaucratic nightmare to jump through hoops for obviously-not-enough checks. Then conditioned those checks on *not* working... Distorting the labor market even more.

Taxpayers, i.e., society, could have come together and financed a taxable basic income to keep the minimum money flowing. $30K/family, taxable, and anyone making > $X breaks even or net pays for it.

Instead they looked to landlords as a subsidy for unemployment insurance because they knew if evictions went through the debt would have ballooned.

Now we have thousands with destroyed credit, angry at other regular people, and stressed out of their minds.

We literally looked at every other OECD country and said "nah let's mix it up"...

I think those groups will be important in combating misinformation but ultimately I think it'll be average people collectively policing information.¬†

It could be pretty simple. All primary sources, e.g., recorded president speeches, are released by the relevant party (e.g. C-SPAN) as audio NFTs with frozen metadata.¬†

Anyone claiming to have recorded that speech and heard something else or doctoring it to say something else will, definitionally, not be C-SPAN and have metadata that is *after* C-SPAN metadata.

Right now, the problem is that trust is not financialized. I can doctor a video or audio, slap on a C-SPAN logo, and claim it's direct from them.¬†

There's no scalable, automatic/passive, means of verifying the original, so my fake tricks people.¬†

Once people are socialized to distrust everything not given an authenticity stamp (NFT metadata) - it'll be annoying in some ways b/c information will be slower to spread - but the speed difference between truth and lies will be greatly reduced.¬†

I don't personally like the guilty until proven true paradigm, but in some sense it's better than the rampant disinformation where nothing is trustworthy.

Mark Freeman II " In addition, the holders of the NFTs gets a vote of how the money is allocated " if the idea is that this voting increases the value of the NFT, you're hitting security territory. Even just the possibility that the NFT could be resold at more value based on the work of others is security territory.

Decentralized non profits can exist. People submit money to a pile and vote on spending requests (e.g., a GoFundMe type of thing). Things that get enough votes get permission to withdraw from the pile. I coded a small dApp that does this in solidity.

This might make more sense than trying to distribute ownership / control of a non profit venture via NFTs. Securities law is purposefully insanely broad and in my opinion outdated in the context of natively transparent blockchain protocols. Obviously fraud should be illegal, but otherwise retail investors need more freedom to take risks.

501c(3)s can take tax deductible donations in most property types, including crypto at the dollar amount at time of donation (see: bitpay). RE: raising money, there are initial NFT offerings (INOs), but honestly those are running head first into existing securities law and will have a painful awakening. 

The only way to raise money without being a security is to not rely on the outcome raising in value from the work of others. 

You can have any foundation create any material and sell that material, including collectibles (i.e., art) in a narrow sense, but if it's assumed that the collectible will raise in value based on the work of the foundation- you've passed the Howey Test (as currently interpreted by SEC) and are going to get hurt BAD in the next wave of lawsuits (a la 2017 ICOs).
Congrats Khuyen!

Louis Christopher Orona - sales are transactions. Crypto is property; it may be strange to think of trading house A for house B, but in tax law, that's the equivalent of what we're doing. We're doing property swaps everytime we transact, and a property swap is equivalent to selling. 

Buy bitcoin at $20,000; Trade it for $40,000 of ETH; pay taxes on the $20,000 gain even though you never touched USD.

When I talk to economists, we tend to disagree a lot on the idea of inflation. I look at the S&P 500 hitting all time highs during a global pandemic as a serious problem, I say it's indicative of too much cheap money chasing any place to be except cash. In a strong (high confidence) economy that money is put into new businesses not just inflating asset prices.¬†

I point to things like the S&P 500 / Fed Balance Sheet to support my argument that we're in a serious everything bubble and that speculation is running rampant.¬†

Economists that disagree with me tend to point to the global asset shortage. We've had decades where real economic growth has happened in countries with untrustworthy government and monetary policy. They're itching for trustworthy stores of value and they find ways to invest in our stock market accordingly. They note that the demand for US denominated assets (e.g., treasury bonds) far exceeds the supply.¬†

Essentially, that it's not inflation, it's globalization combined with disproportionate desire for US assets. They argue rising national debt, combined with low interest rates, is effectively not a problem, because the interest rate is fixed and denominated in a currency we control.¬†

I'm open to being convinced in favor of USD, but until then I believe staked Ethereum will become the global bond of the 21st century.

The astute reader will note: isn't this just creating a honeypot? Where access to your entire digital identity is held by your wallet address?¬†

Yes & No.¬†

It's true that your wallet address is itself a function of your private key, such that someone with your private key (e.g., using a keylogger) could rob you blind. But at full maturity we should expect companies to form that manage multi-factor authentication for wallets and for users to be able to easily move between those companies.¬†

If a leak occurs, you simply make a new wallet address (takes seconds) and transfer all your assets to the new wallet (and in fact, the companies will likely proactively do that for you in case of breaches). Essentially throwing away a previous identity and starting over.¬†

Websites would track data at the NFT level, so you bring your data with you when you change wallets.

I actually think the net effect on cybersecurity will be that incidents plummet, because right now, even the websites I rarely ever visit are asking for critical information (e.g., date of birth) and leaking it (Target, Yahoo, Equifax, etc.).¬†

John Cassil depends on how we define fees. Lightning network is making transfers of BTC on its layer effectively free. On Polygon I can swap WBTC and USDC for less than a $0.01 in gas (slippage & price impact ignored for now, of course, LPs charge fees too).

There's a joke that centralized exchanges like Coinbase will be "L3s" for effectively free swaps (possibly subsidized by PFOF, like Robinhood).

James Northrup people will make security / cost tradeoffs that best fit their needs. Regular people will use Fintech apps that use PFOF (like Robinhood) to make trades free / subsidize them. Some people will be purists and use Roll-ups / L2s to get < $0.01 trades. Others will be super purists and pay direct L1 fees which would be cost prohibitive at amounts < $100,000 (essentially, the settlement layer for institutions). 

People will stake their tokens through their Fintech app to get returns from providing institutions liquidity through the Fintech app's broader pool (sharing fees).

It doesn't matter, the whole point of decentralizing finance is so that there are no arbitrary delays in converting digital assets. Getting $100 of USD vs getting $100 BTC (0.XXX BTC) is irrelevant in a mature crypto world where swaps are near instantly settled at near 0 cost. 

Now, would I want my salary to be *fixed* in BTC (i.e., I get paid 0.0X BTC / N weeks) such that I take on all price volatility of BTC over the course of my employment... That's a much more interesting conversation.

I'll try to join today. NFTs for source data is on the right track, but that's not really how blockchain will improve databases. Again, I think the conversation around transactions, e.g., getting paid in crypto, is a distraction. The premise of decentralized finance is that it removes intermediaries that would cause costly delays in accessing your money (e.g., waiting 3+ days for an ACH transfer). Getting paid $100 USD or $100 in ETH (0.XX ETH) is irrelevant in a mature DeFi future, because swapping and settlement of digital property will be effectively instant and extremely low cost. 

Right now, I can switch between USDC and ETH on Sushiswap (or Balancer or Quickswap or many other decentralized exchanges) on the Polygon network for < $0.001 in fees (purposefully skipping a conversation on slippage & price impact of liquidity pools here) and it would happen within 10-15 seconds (if not sooner).

I think some of these comments are erroneous, happy to have a podcast call to clear up misconceptions on crypto != currency & crypto != transactions. The tax stuff is also pretty simple, crypto = property. We already have robust property tax law systems. Although NFTs as "collectibles" would be a bit different in terms of taxes, it's really not that complicated in my opinion.

Transactions is the 2016 conversation about crypto, it's been solved 1,000x over. Nobody is using Ethereum layer 1 to send their friends cash for a bill, we all have Venmo. The future is Web 3.0. This is not a financial revolution. It's a digital decentralization revolution where art and finance are the 2 easiest things to decentralize first. If you're still talking about crypto-"currency", you're at the Netscape stage of the internet.

VISA is significantly ahead of Mastercard in terms of Crypto culturally. They bought CryptoPunk # 7610. Noticing a lot of comments not getting it. Transactions are the low hanging fruit in decentralized finance. If you think of crypto as currencies or transaction technologies, you're missing the point tremendously.

Healthcare is a different beast. My experience is mostly public health, not commercial, but my general opinion is the healthcare market needs less middleman extraction, more care standardization, and massive price transparency. I can't shop around during a heart attack, that would be crazy. But if we're going to have insurance companies, they should be doing upfront work to identify the optimal "route" of care for a heart attack at the unit of care level. Sure, the first hospital I end up at will be whichever is the closest and the initial care is there too, but follow-ups, medication, related screenings, check-ups, etc. should already be planned for me ahead of time based on their relationships, data analysis, my location, etc.

If you want a commercial healthcare system there's a smart way to do it, if you want a socialized healthcare system there's a smart way to do it. US frankensteins the worst of both.

The housing market is definitionally manipulated because it is the primary wealth generation tool for the average person in the US economy. This, in my opinion, was the wrong approach for the government to take in the 1950s when they didn't know what to do with all the demand for housing and the beginnings of the "nuclear family". They couldn't build suburbia overnight AND convince people to invest their entire life savings in it without some kind of promise that it would be an investment (not an expenditure). 

So they created the modern US tax code that explicitly incentivizes real estate more than any other sector of the economy. They then further complicated the tax code to incentivize businesses to remain close enough to suburbs so that people wouldn't be overly mobile. 

A mobile labor force is a strong labor force, but capitalism needs weak labor. The best ways to weaken labor are: lock them into  fixed locations to restrict their job options & reduce unionization to restrict their collective bargaining.

Liquidity is beneficial to consumers, and speculation brings liquidity. But I would push back on speculation being beneficial separate from the liquidity benefits. A lot of interesting work in the crypto space on what the "optimal" liquidity is for a given commodity market- speculation can actually increase price volatility beyond the benefits it brings to price discovery & liquidity. But fair point to bring up!

Just to point out the "yes this happens in real life" parallel. Assets, even oil, have gone *negative* briefly to compensate storage costs of the commodity. 

This shouldn't be too crazy to think about. If it costs me $100,000/day to store an asset at my facility and there's a collapse in buyers, but I have contracts requiring me to take more of the asset or pay a fine. Then I could be economically smart to sell my older stock for $0 or even negative up to the point where my fines for rejecting new stock exceed my negative sales (paying people to take it off my hands). 

Markets are complicated. Econ 101 does a massive disservice to people's understanding of the realities on the ground of many markets.

I know you're joking, but this does actually apply to numerous food commodity markets where speculators buy massive amounts of Corn/Wheat/etc. with 0 intention to actually hold the commodity. They just want to buy rights to it, then sell those rights. 

Ergo- if you NFT food, then you can give the speculators their playground while leaving the utility part (the food itself) safe from speculation.

The idea is:
1) Things have value for multiple reasons. 

Houses are useful because they house people - Utility value.

Houses are useful because land is durable and the recordkeeping & legal system is strong so that you know who owns the house - Store of Value value. 

2) The Store of Value value is a major reason that speculation comes into the housing market. 

See: Massive amounts of foreign investment in Seattle, Vancouver, NYC, and other real estate markets. The houses are never occupied by the owner and often not even rented out. They literally just sit there empty. 

Why? 

Because people with money want to diversify their returns and where they store their money. 

This speculation is X% of a commodity's price. The Utility value is (1 - X)% of a commodity's price. 

3) NFTs are purely dominant (see Nash Equilibrium) in record-keeping and legal systems for maintaining ownership. 

Even if you copy/paste an NFT and make another one, that copy will fail to have the Ethereum Contract Hash Address of the original (that's how cryptography works).

Thus - for any commodity - a socially agreed upon NFT system for that commodity, should separate the X%, leaving only the utility ( 1- X%) value. Thus, deflation of assets.

Like, start with colds, aches, sprains, diet, exercise, physical therapy- going straight to trying to solve cancer with computer vision on x-rays is such a, I'll get harassed for saying this, "dumb man" way of going at the problem.¬†

I'll say EHRs a 3rd time. Also, the mechanics of the daily work are fundamentally incompatible with good data creation. Doctors went to medical school and yet 80-90% of their time is computers & paperwork?¬†

This is an automation first kind of problem. How do we get professionals off the computer and in front of patients while automatically generating usable data?¬†

Going AI first is a massive mistake and I've been a naysayer on big tech trying to dIsRuPt healthcare for years.¬†

I think it makes way more sense for big tech to collaborate on creating and running the most advanced non-emergency clinic ever. Validate some proof of concepts, optimize patient throughput, integrate passive data collection devices, build zero-knowledge systems that can protect patient data but still use it productively.¬†

Tons of steps before "look we AI'd some EHRs and cured Cancer!" But that's the shiny rock everyone chases.¬†

What a whirlwind. A lot of rumors that it's an inside job because of the single keeper of the multi-signature administrator. But also some talk that it was a cryptography collision. 

The idea is the contract was poorly written to allow anyone call a certain very important function, that function checks if the person's information hashes to a certain value, but it only actually checks the first 4 bytes of the hash. ü§¶üèæü§¶üèæ

Getting a collision on 4 bytes is only 2^32 brute force checks. A standard laptop can take random guesses over a few days and find a collision if only the first 4 bytes matter. Use some cloud computing or parallel processing and you can calculate hashes for a few hours and get a collision on that tiny of a hash. 

I'm leaning heavily toward inside job right now, but the hacker continues to gloat. 

They are now claiming they want to the return the funds (or at least the part that isn't locked or already given away), but you can tell their transactions to themselves (which are being watched by thousands) are someone who is clearly way over their head.

They admit they have no clue how to wash the amount of money they stole, but I don't think they can give it back without getting identified. Crazy!

You may be asking (smartly) - what's the catch & risk??

Well (1) I have to monitor my loan health factor. Because I don't make monthly payments, the way it works is I have to keep more ETH in my deposit than I have borrowed.¬†

If ETH drops in value, my health factor drops too.¬†

If it drops enough, I can get liquidated.¬†

Liquidated = they sell my ETH and pay off my debt.

The fee for being liquidated is 5%.¬†

So if I don't pay back my loan AND my collateral loses value beyond the health factor minimum AND I don't reduce my loan or add collateral within a certain time frame once liquidation begins- I can be liquidated.¬†

If a random stranger sees my collateral is insufficient and they want to earn the 5% fee, they trigger my liquidation and earn some money.
My debt is cancelled, but I technically paid my 4% APR + 5% fee for not maintaining my loan.¬†

No damage to my credit score or anything, all decentralized, all transparent, no administrators to argue with.

Mark Freeman II  ah, after some googling. Dictionaries use hash under the table to make the lookup constant. This is exactly equivalent to an R environment. Normally, you can't iterate on a hash, but python dictionaries allow iteration by tracking keys() in the dictionary (this is usually memory inefficient). 

So yeah, named list & environments cover the Python dictionary. Python just fuses them by tracking the keys in a dictionary for you (to allow looping through). 

Normally you can't loop through a hash table because it's unordered.
What's the difference between a dictionary and a named list?¬†

That would be the ideal scenario, make their money off under-cutting the credit cards (that get 2-3%) while charging a reasonable interest after a grace period. Still leaves the interest rate question though. 18-20%+ is credit card territory with none of the benefits of a card.

BNPL is dangerous and probably should be much more heavily regulated. It's one thing to smooth payments out for people so they can manage their cash flow- but that's not what those providers are doing.

It's like alcohol sales. 10% of alcohol drinkers make up 60% of alcohol sales. 

BNPL model is *not* to squeeze by on 4-8% APR and profit on user data (data -> ads -> make up profit). It's to get people in cycles of buying things they can't afford under the illusion they can afford it. The more people buy, the more kickbacks and late fees they can rake in.

At least a credit card builds your credit score- BNPL is the worst of credit cards without any of the benefit and targets people on the margins of credit.

The positive of Apple getting into the space is that at least they own a ton of the products people buy, so they arguably could afford to NOT exploit their buyers. But that might be a stretch too.

There's a funny tweet by Elon Musk RE: gold vs bitcoin. "An email saying you have gold is not the same as having gold". 

The idea being that *custody* of an asset is an underrated part of owning an asset.

Fractionalized ownership of art is a real alternative investment, but the reality is that you can't custody a fraction of a Monet. You're trusting that your email saying you have a piece of a Money represents the ability to sell your piece in the future (ownership = ability to sell). 

NFTs, existing on the blockchain, are (1) verifiably owned, (2) can be fractionalized officially through a smart contract and tokenization. 

So in reality, NFTs will completely eliminate the traditional fractionalized art ecosystem, not the other way around. We should expect museums to tokenize & fractionalize the art they own and make them available in metaverse compliant formats in the 3 - 10 year time horizon.

Presenter is anyone communicating the benefits of the products, e.g. those that interface with sales & marketing; but also those that seek additional funding to add features (e.g. managers).

Above in Mark's question I mention the types are moreso 'tasks' than roles. People can do the same job with the same title but have small biases/flavors across types.

In my mind they're tasks to be done more than roles. Realistically data engineers & data scientists are do-er/documenters; data analysts are that cross of do-er/simplifier/presenters; product managers are documenter/presenters; analytics translators are simplifier/presenters. It's never going to be clean cut, but people in the same title will have natural biases to the 4 tasks and you (ideally) want to construct teams where those biases are maximized at the individual level + team level (in aggregate). 

I am definitely more biased toward do-er/presenter. Documentation tends to be an afterthought for me, and as much as I like to think I can simplify things, I think of simplifying as more of a UX type of thing. Caring about how end users are abstracted away from the gnitty gritty of do-ers.

I'll also add, the Dive Bar data science team: 

- only proof of concepts, but nobody is actually checking on them or communicating with them on the business needs or even paying attention to funding. So they don't even prove concepts or the concepts they prove aren't relevant.

- completely constrained. No cloud, no write permissions on your laptop, takes 2 weeks to approve an IDE, no environments to reconstruct, no staging, no production environment. Basically monkeys with math degrees and keyboards (screens optional).

- No collaboration. Everyone lives and works on an island. No developer knowledge recording, let alone knowledge sharing.

The team would be equally productive at Happy Hour as they are in an office.  

Unfortunately, I've seen more dive bar data science teams than I've seen sports team ones...

Message:
You're moving the goalposts. This is a large corporation with the *ability* to have respected self-labeled licenses. Their *choice* not to is what's being judged. 

But to answer, no, of course not, data scientists have no clue what they're shoving into their training sets. Vast majority of the work being done is stacking trash on top of garbage and calling it Art Nouveau.

On review, this isn't going to work as you want. Websites post HTML which is easily extracted, but the 2019 page you linked uses JavaScript to render the text upon an event (clicking the profile). You would need significantly more advanced code (e.g. using the V8 package) to enable a light chromium browser to force the JavaScript to render and then read that. 

This is a common mechanism for preventing webscraping. Unfortunately, my experience with V8 in R was not fun. My understanding is Python' beautifulsoup has some built in mechanisms for this but I haven't used it.

Noticing a few comments / shares saying "well, public is public". But that's not actually valid on any known legal theory lol. We just saw the supreme court settle Google v Oracle with a somewhat narrow decision that their use was "fair use". 

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_LLC_v._Oracle_America,_Inc.

But this was contentious and flipped several times on the way up to SC. Reviewing the case, I don't see how GitHub argues its breaking of licenses, combined with its *ability* to have respected them (literally, FILTER (LICENSE %IN% (Open_Licenses) their training data LOL), combined with it selling the output ends up positive for them. 

Maybe the terms of service says "all your code are belong to us" but at that point they're just telling us to use their competitor...

Willem Hendriks - No, not private repos. But people mistakenly include API keys in their repos (improper use of gitignore / being bad at coding). I personally trained a mentee on R, RStudio, Git, and R Projects and within hours we were pulling an pushing code to a collaborative repo. He was within weeks as good as I was in R after 3 years.¬†

I might have known more math / data structures / functional programming after 3 year than he did in 1 month, but that's all google-able stuff. He could actually collaborate on a git repo with other programmers and correctly run his code across computers. Stuff plenty of data scientists can't do today because they're stats people who can't code.¬†

There are packages like pins that do data version control, but it's best practice to *not* use git for data. Instead follow a functional programming approach with defined inputs, outputs, unit tests, etc. In package oriented development, examples can run a toy dataset to prove function operations.¬†

Programming without git is catastrophe waiting to happen. I know, as I've built several large shiny apps without it and I wasted countless hours in version recovery.

Now I'm pushing myself to be better about package based workflows that support real functional programming structures.¬†

Yes unfortunately R usage is primarily driven by "stats people who can't code". I've seen it too often. We aren't taught any software engineering and then we're surprised when our code runs into the classic software engineering problem: "iT wOrKs On My MaChInE" lol¬†

Took me years to make this stuff automatic. And yet it takes 1hr to do learn and will permanently make you better than the vast majority of R programmers.¬†

DDOS and 51% are not directly related. DDOS is typically a problem in Web 2.0 interfaces. For example, on the standard internet, a DDOS attack can block the website for a protocol making it inconvenient for people to use it (b/c nobody really knows how to interact directly with contracts via Etherscan, they *rely* on the website to do that for them). 

A network DDOS can happen on cheap transaction costs networks. Something similar just happened to Polygon a few weeks ago. People were sending themselves 0 MATIC at 100+gwei to spam the network and cause a panic as nobody could do any transactions at even 50x the normal transaction costs.

But it's irrelevant to a 51% attack. All it does if flood the nodes with free money to block regular users; it doesn't injure the nodes in any way.

I think it's just a stopgap until FinTech companies + US central bank digital currency (CBDCs) instantly solve this problem of online payments.

The entire online payments industry is a broken windows fallacy. If I want to buy something from you in real life: I take cash out of my pocket and give it to you and you give me the thing.

It is because money is *not* native to the internet that we have all these online payment companies and struggles. The solution is not to scale these companies up; the solution is to make money native to the internet.

In 5 years Country specific CBDCs, native to Web 3.0, will make payment transfers as easy as "send the money to mycompany.eth" and you'll just send it. No apps, no registration, nothing.

It works right now, you can send Coinbase US Dollar to my twitter address and it'll show up in my Ethereum wallet fully tracked by the blockchain.

When I lived in Korea, it was the perfect non-blockchain version of this. I paid my bill by going to ANY ATM, typing in the utility company's unique address for my apartment, then sending them money. 

As long as that address got the minimum money, I was good. They didn't care WHO sent it. I didn't register with them or do anything.

I would add that the most important thing is dodging toxic & bad; if you end up in situations with just okay/good - it's totally okay if other factors in the role (life balance/fit, pay, comfort, etc.) keep you there long term. 

Life is complicated and a great manager may be great but have limited power given the company size, existing politics, etc. So make sure you're optimizing for you even if it means leaving great leadership.

(1) no set timeline. Be honest, if you're trying to turn this around fast, put up the ad and then *take it down* when you're inundated. The market would be more efficient if people didn't bloat month old ads.¬†

(2) no salary range. I get it, you don't want to overpay and you don't want to look stupid doing 50-100k b/c that's years of experience different. But even just "targeting 100-120k, willing to inch up for the perfect candidate" let's people self select out and also benchmark themselves so they can grow into a role like that later.¬†

(3) don't kitchen sink the job ad. Please just ask 2-3 people currently in the job to explicitly say 1-2 sentences about what they do. "I do a lot of SQL into Power BI with custom R scripts built in" is extremely different then "I write a lot of Python, contained in Docker, with APIs so I can quickly access multiple models with real time data flowing into AWS".

You don't need to understand the job that much, just get the people doing it to describe why they need help.¬†

(4) stop using idiotic vendors that don't actually parse resumes correctly and don't actually reconnect you to past applicants. It's really easy: upload resume, store them, make them searchable. NLP has gotten so advanced, you should be able to search "budget analyst" and it returns resumes with "financial analyst" because budget ~ finance. If your system can't do that, it's not worth the vendor lock.¬†

(5) Hiring is Marketing. If your hiring is bad and disrespects candidates, those candidates go to your customers, become leaders, and are biased against your product for life.

(6) most applicants can do the job within 3-6 months. Your mission is to hire the one that generate the most value and often that means, the one that will stay >2 years. Build a culture that incentivizes staying.¬†

ie. a 10-20% raise is cheaper than another hiring cycle. Stop letting profit walk out the door because of sticker shock.¬†

Demi Constantine I think COVID-19 brought about tremendous uncertainty, and uncertainty inspires inflation because businesses will (maybe counterintuitively) take certain risks to absorb more money short term (possibly at the price of long-term). They *don't* expand a profitable business to keep cash on hand (opportunity cost) or they raise prices on existing clients (vendor lock) to squeeze some cash at the risk of losing those clients later.

In terms of what's "inevitable" I think that's what everyone wants to know. The supply chain is so global and complex nowadays. It used to be that your inputs were local so your price exposure was local too (this is an important consequence for how we define "advanced" economies as those that are reliant disproportionately on capital and not labor; capital price exposure is significantly more difficult to localize). Prices could rise in one part of a country and not another, opening up arbitrage opportunity. Nowadays, everything is global and price exposure is globalized too. An oil delay like the Suez Canal, or a major traffic delays during Chunyun in China can cascade into price uncertainty everywhere at once. 

What do we need to reign inflation in? Frankly I don't think we know / can.
This is my primary issue with the DEI industrial complex; too many are focused getting tokens at the top and not fundamentally fixing society through institutions with real power.

I wouldn't word it that way, but yes I think we've incentivized debt in ways that are not sustainable. Across all known recorded history only a single country has ever survived a debt to GDP ratio > 130%. And that country regularly runs a budget surplus and is more worried about deflation than inflation: Japan.

That's a tiny piece of it, more obviously you can just look at cost of goods sold (COGS) growth on financial reports. But these costs are spread across the chain and inflation is measured at the end. Really hard to figure out which piece of the chain is eating profit to stay in business (the variable vs fixed cost dilemma).¬†

I'm on mobile but the short points are:¬†

(1) inflation helps debtors by reducing their debt in real terms. If the US is anything, it's a country of debtors.¬†

(2) interest rates are not just "how expensive is my mortgage" (see 1), it is also *how much value flow can I generate from being patient*. When we don't value *patience*, our economy is lighting the candle on both ends. We're not building a sustainable future culturally when these rates are so low.¬†

Obviously I'm oversimplifying like crazy, but these 2 points are nearly always forgotten in these conversations.¬†

Inflation is an insanely complicated calculation with numerous conflicts of interest (e.g. social security CoL adjustments). My opinion: inflation is not the target we think it is. I care much more about the effect of unsustainable interest rates on the average person than I care about inflation. One causes the other, we're overly focused on the symptoms.¬†

My ideal world would not judge based on degrees, it would judge based on concrete skills tied back to the real-world outputs of those doing the work now. But to answer your question, I don't think this question is currently illegal. But I do think it's tone-deaf, biased, and an example of a broader problem with the unrealistic expectation that people will "go back" to what was not working.

I'm noticing 2 camps form: (1) "It was just a curious question, don't assume harm" - the micro view, and (2) "This is representative of a broader pattern of trying to push past the global trauma of covid-19 and return to a normalcy that was *already not working* and we must call out these efforts to build back better" - the macro view.

I 100% understand this is 1 random tweet. Frankly, I posted this willy nilly and expected 4 likes and that I'd delete it later to clean up my profile (I have to delete things or else I'll never be able to find old content, let's beg LinkedIn for better search & archiving). 

But *THIS IS NOT ANECDOTE*. I challenge everyone with the micro view to ask their colleagues, friends, family, what it's been like to look for work or merge their life and work to this unprecedented level. 

**Personally** I have had a *tremendously* productive 14+ months. I got the largest bonus and highest scores I've ever gotten at a job; I've written hundreds of pages worth of articles; I've picked up new skills; I've made incredible money from investing, and I'm not even counting the personal good stuff- the list goes on.

Just because this kind of interview question would help *ME* doesn't mean I think it's good or fair.

It's probably not illegal (yet). 

We'll have to see how bad hiring bias is. But let me just note that intent isn't a defense. Interviewers have hidden behind the shield of intent to get illegal information for decades (e.g., family planning, disability, etc.) 

Consider the standard office requirement, "must be able to lift ~ 20 lbs over head occasionally". I used to believe this was a relatively standard statement saying, "you might need to do basic office things like refill the printer paper occasionally". 

Then I met disability advocates who note that this job description primarily comes from companies who knowingly don't have ADA compliant office space and can't accommodate a wheelchair in everyday meeting (e.g., only a single conference room is ADA compliant and it's always booked). 

This small, innocuous reference to standard office tasks is actually a shield against having to do reasonable accommodations for someone, e.g. allowing an entirely productive wheelchair user to work from home most days, or give their meetings preferential access to the conference room that actually is wide enough for them to use in practice (and not just tape measure technically legal width). 

I consider this is more than anecdote.

I expect countries will be legislating against covid-19 bias in hiring if they haven't already. Some things can't be asked in interviews (e.g. family planning)- biasing against caretakers, etc. should be on the list as well.

"Normal" didn't work, it wasn't equitable, we should be looking to build better. I agree, I think this is more than an anecdote, I think it's a broader example of the fundamentally insane idea that we go "back" to "before" and pretend this never happened. I can understand that's a comfortable idea for risk averse businesses, but it's just not possible.

Maybe it'd be easier to have this conversation if you could define what you think the difference between crypto and DeFi is and how they could be separated.

I don't know how they can be separated. 

DeFi is built on top of Ethereum. It uses Ether to pay for transactions (although complex direct to miner technologies like ArcherDAO are trying to circumvent this which is interesting and full of technical depth on how flashbots work and MEV fairness, etc.)

Andre Cronje, probably the 2nd most famous programmer in the space behind Vitalik, said it best recently: bull markets are bad for development. Anyone who actually wants to create a world changing DeFi project can't launch because within minutes someone with copy/paste their code and add a worthless governance token and now 90% of developer time is spent incentivizing the token instead of working on the protocol.¬†

Every effort to separate DeFi (useful tech) from Crypto (tokenization of a protocol's "governance") generally fails in these kinds of wild west conditions.

More practically, governance of a deFi protocol is the 2nd most important part of a deFi protocol. On Ethereum, smart contracts are permanent upon launch (unless explicitly coded to allow for injection of new rules or new owners, etc.) This means that every project is technically an isolated module. The narrative around which modules are a part of a single protocol (e.g. that "Instagram" is a Facebook product and not its own thing) involves community management (analogous to shareholder management), social media, marketing, etc. To make this work, you have to incentivize community participation and self dealt governance tokens propping up liquidity for itself through more rewards of itself (what I like to call self-dealing Ponzi APY) is the most common strategy to do this management.¬†

Point being, DeFi in practice today is 1000% reliant on Crypto because it is crypto that decentralizes the management of the financial protocols.¬†

The only alternative to this, Andre's strategy, is to build, launch, and let the broader community do whatever it wants and not worry about developer / product manager / core team monetization. I'm not sure that's sustainable. Most of these teams are themselves venture capital backed, which puts more pressure to gov token your way to venture capital profits.¬†

The complexity enforced the interconnectedness of crypto & DeFi because that's the "de".¬†
I need a SQL IDE that has autocomplete with capitalization for keywords; I use MySQL Workbench for personal projects and it's ok. What do you use? Does VSCode have a SQL module?

To clarify on (2): Bitcoin can be $250,000 in 8 years; if the block rewards fall to 3.125 in 8 years; we're making an implicit assumption on the energy costs related to mining those 3 bitcoin. It's not definitionally profitable. In some ways, the 4 year halving cycles imply that energy efficiency must X every 4 years. Where X is F( profit in time T-1, reduction in energy costs since T - 1).

You are correct in technical terms, but there are some real (not energy) sustainability issues in the ecosystem. 

1. Transactions require mining; I think it's 100% fair to say that total transactions / total mining energy = average transaction energy. The obvious next question to contextualize is is: *is this going down?*, if so, good! if not, problem. 

2. If bitcoin buy pressure falls, then the HODL anti-sell pressure has to *more than match* that drop in buy pressure, because the marginal *cost* of mining matters a lot to miners who have to sell BTC to pay costs. It's 100% possible that in 20-30 years the price of bitcoin is not enough to cover the marginal cost of mining which leads to less decentralization. This should be on everyone's radar. I mean, in 2139 they'll be fighting for scraps of like 0.001 BTC right? There's no transaction recording without mining because mining records changes to the blockchain so I don't think its fair to entirely decouple them. 

3. Layer 2 solutions, some of them insanely centralized, even when storing transactions on Layer 1 are subject to the effects of block size and block frequency. BTC's 10 minutes and 1 MB can be SegWit'd to some extent, but it's not a panacea.

That's my main gripe with BTC. Not the energy, that's a solve-able technology problem, but the culture of "HODL". Like, I thought this was a peer to peer exchange tool? You're telling me nobody actually uses it to buy anything? We're just restricting sell pressure for the paper gains fun?

I'm all about function, utility, use-case. I want sustainable cash flow from people paying for a service I provide, most often that's liquidity.

it will 100% address the UX. It's just that the ultrasound money meme won the narrative. But if 50-70% of the market is using a default gas price, then efficiencies from no longer optimizing whose transactions you include will be noticeable. Default bias is very useful. On Polygon for example to default is 1 gwei (in MATIC); I've never used another. Knowing that my transaction won't fail, I never worry about doing 5 or 8 instead. Unlike in ETH where I've been burned (pun not intended) a LOT from undershooting gas estimates and having my transactions expire. That costs real money. The result? I *overpay* constantly. 

EIP-1559 destroys the average user's need to constantly over-pay. A massive inefficiency.

The ad based internet was a mistake. People are constantly eroding their consent online. Apple is doing all the correct things.¬†

It is insane how to purchase anything online requires I give up core peices of information.¬†

Yesterday I bought some movie tickets online, it was $7 per ticket in convenience fees!! Unless I signed up for an account, giving them my name, email, and BIRTHDAY (why would I trust them with this info?) In which case they would waive the fee.¬†

This is completely unsustainable.¬†

Web 3.0 fixes this. If we treat money as information, then money becomes native to the internet. The reason we have ad based internet is because we didn't have a means of cleanly and trustlessly extracting value from the customers.¬†

That's solved. I fully expect to see a future where things are either run by communities of volunteers (open source everything) OR charges are priced directly at use (i.e. I just pay $0.25 from my web 3.0 wallet to read a NYT article immediately).¬†

Alex Bergvall I wrote about the tradeoff more on substack here: https://charliemarketplace.substack.com/p/polygon-layer-2-is-a-breath-of-fresh

Having said that, I don't know much about STRIKE as a layer 2 for bitcoin to make those transaction fees small enough to be viable and what the security concerns might be.¬†

There are also different kinds of tradeoffs available for scale vs security. Arbitrum, another ETH L2 bundles transactions to split costs without taking custody of coins / requiring bridging (what MATIC does). But these rollups have inherently limited Scalability but technically higher security.¬†

Centralization matters *a lot* to nation states.
 
Bitcoin has proven to be the most decentralized, secure blockchain for this type of use case. The reason I say this is because blockchains sell blocks. As much as we complain about high fees, the fees of a network are security as a service.

ADA, Stellar, XRP are all wildly cheap *because* they don't pay for security as a service through fees. The only way to have low fees + high security is to either offload your security to a layer 1 (which MATIC does) OR have absurdly high number of transactions that allow for each individual transaction to have low fees (goal of ETH 2.0).

MATIC, which I am heavily invested in so let me note that disclosure, or ETH directly would have been my high level recommendation to be honest. I think it opens a lot more doors for decentralized finance & self-banking (as opposed to bitcoin, which realistically is just going to be an alternative investment/currency but not a yield generator).¬†

But, what's good for bitcoin is good for all of crypto. I'm excited to see what happens!

I don't think they're contradictory. I'm actually slightly against (2) though. You want to create metrics that SHOULD be gamed.¬†

In sales for example, # of calls is a measure but it's a bad one. Evidence shows extremely limited benefit to monkey dialing and that's what happens when you incentivize the wrong thing.¬†

But something like net revenue, or net revenue as percentage of gross revenue are metrics that good to game. Of course, you still have to worry about the marshmallow test (you don't want all your sales to be tiny, low hanging fruit and forget to set up bigger sales that take longer than a 1 sales cycle), but that doesn't make those metrics/targets bad at all!¬†

Why "Quanity is Quality"? 

1. Quantity gives you lots of different resources to go back to. 

Given my self-imposed 2-hr time limit, I couldn't spend time re-visiting ggplot2 documentation, nor re-learn plotly. I had to remember the most relevant past project I had (here I used my Cereal repo) to copy/paste custom themes for ggplot2. Then I had to wrap them in ggplotly b/c I knew I wouldn't remember the plotly code directly LOL. 

2. Quantity helps you generate a variety of use cases. Better to have 50 things and 20 of them are quickly re-usable, than to have 3 amazing things, but they're so complicated you can't remember how to safely extract pieces out of them. This is even true for well documented and packaged things. My R packages are always clean and unit tested, but they're extremely specific, making them scalable but not necessarily flexible in a time constraint.

Mondays - 1hr prep for presenting results from last week. 30min meeting with client to review weekly progress. 30min meeting with team to review client feedback.¬†

Tues - Thurs: heads down, no email, no meetings. 1.5 of client work; 30 mins of also client work (default) or previously scheduled ad-hoc tasks (see Friday).

Fri: 1hr review emails. 30-min meet with anyone requesting ad-hoc tasks to schedule the follow week. 30-min team meet to review pre-client meeting and plan my 1hr pre-client prep on Monday.¬†

Realistically, data science / app development does take time, I don't see myself doing in 6-8hrs what I do in 30+ right now lol. Also, this makes business development essentially not possible on top of client work.¬†

Jami Vara Prasad That is not technically correct. Two infinities can have the same Cardinality but not the same Measure. This makes them both comparable (same cardinality) and yet still one have *more* than the other.

See: 
"It is not true that all infinities are equal, but it¬†is¬†true that the interval¬†(0,1)¬†contains as many numbers as the interval¬†(0,2). However, while there are infinitely many numbers in¬†(0,1)¬†and also infinitely many natural numbers, there are more numbers in the interval¬†(0,1) than there are natural numbers."

From: 

https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/182171/are-all-infinities-equal
They are but one is provably more infinite.¬†

Message:
I think I generally agree with you.¬†

401ks at an individual level can be really smart. Free compounding of money you would've paid in taxes.¬†

So 19.5k vs like 15k post tax is 4.5k additional money compounding which adds up to >$200k over 20 years at 7% interest.¬†

That's excluding any match which is semi free money.

But at a macro level:¬†

1) they lock up assets. While recent legislation has made it easy to access 50% of your 401k, locking your 401k for 20+ (often nearly 40) years is a major commitment that is difficult to fully understand when you're first starting out.

2) they create inelastic buy pressure. People put $X into their 401k and then buy their index at whatever price it is. This disconnect between price & quality is really bad. Stocks that get lucky enough to be put into popular indexes get bought automatically by tons of people while those people don't actually read prospectus or even know what they bought.

Combining (1) and (2) you get extremely low sell pressure (which inflates asset prices) AND inelastic buy pressure (which inflates prices).¬†

I support people owning slices of the economy, but I'd prefer they do so while informed and with free access to Liquidity as they see fit.¬†

I think self-banking is the future and I hope to see updated legislation allowing people to create their own 401ks with liquidity untied to employers.¬†

Just to add nuance. It matters how the money is spent.¬†

There's 3 categories here:¬†

(1) profitable efficiency gains

More renewables, more efficient transportation systems (e.g. freight), healthcare innovation, etc.¬†

These can actually reduce inflation because they *deflate* prices across large parts of the economy.¬†

(2) wealth transfers
Economies grow middle out, not top down. So if this is tax & spend funded with high income capital gains + financial transaction taxes. Then this will reduce asset prices (shrinking the everything bubble) and move money to consumption. Probably a good thing as the labor force participation rate has plummeted.¬†

(3) spoilage¬†

Unnecessary expenditures that don't benefit anyone.¬†


People are really pessimistic about government right now. They assume this will go 0%/0%/100% between efficiency, transfer, and spoilage.¬†

Realistically, small efficiency gains can make massive impacts. Post WWII saw the greatest age of middle income in US history. The middle never had it so good.

I'd be happy with a 40%/40%/20% ratio to be honest. I can understand how pessimists may say "we'd be lucky to get 10/10/80". But reality will probably be somewhere in the middle.¬†

Economics is all about aligning incentives. 

Imagine if your suppliers were never late because they owned a piece of the business and want you to stay creating and selling.

Imagine if your customers were nice to staff because they owned a piece of the business and want reduced turnover.

Imagine if your employees were comfortable making process improvements, automating themselves, and worked hard because they owned a piece of the business. 

This should be a natural evolution of capitalism- the problem is that the record-keeping technology hasn't been good enough. You always have to trust somebody in the pipeline to report profit & loss accurately. 

Blockchain solves the record-keeping, making the next stage of capitalism possible.

It's tough. Coming from a "1st gen" background where my mom dropped out to have me, college is an important symbol & milestone. My family never had context for *real* entrepreneurship - plenty of MLMs üò≠ but not actually going out there and building. The internet has changed so much.¬†

This next generation literally doesn't need school. It's a net negative in a *lot* of ways.¬†

(1) wastes 6-12 hrs a day (I has a 2hr commute each way to my "fancy" schools from 6th - 12th grade by bus, 1hr when I finally started driving myself) being taught things against your will.¬†

Sure a lot of it is important (literacy, arithmetic) but let's be honest. It's socialization, babysitting, and test prep nowadays. Teachers have had nearly all their creative freedom ripped away from them for testing.¬†

(2) there's minimal psycho-social support. School to prison pipelines, bullying, food insecurity, counselors who's goal is to get you to college no matter what. Add in school shooter drills now too.¬†

If we rebuilt school from scratch it would be:¬†

Highly creative teacher-consultants that curate projects, and self-learning (my 4 year old brother can independently manage YouTube kids videos that have audio & visual components for learning, combined with pausing and rewinding... How can rote live teaching compete?).¬†

Highly specialized child psychologists and nutritionists supporting kids not getting enough at home.¬†

Flexible targets and multi-age classrooms with peer learning. Each child on their own pace going through rigorous but flexible criteria. (Why can't a kid be 9th grade English, 8th grade math, and 11th grade science if that's just how they're developing??).¬†
