I've asked this before, and the answers I got were that most jobs can't be tied to explicit ROIs without immense overhead in calculating them; combined with many jobs being inherently experimental. To some extent, I think rewarding with equity is the most logical thing to do. 

If you can align people to tasks (hiring/training) & then also align them to the business model (training/sales/marketing/equity) then you get to unlock people's creativity. 

People naturally improve what they own. An office admin won't automate their job with python if it puts them at risk of losing their job. An office admin with ownership will see parts of their job they can automate, upskill themselves to take on new tasks (preserving their job), and then automate their original job (reducing costs) and be a beneficiary.
What's the practical alternative?

Similarly: you don't go to a restaurant and ask for a discount because you brought your own ingredients. Rolling up with old Excel dAsHbOaRdS does not make any part of the pipeline easier/faster/cheaper LOL.

People actively in the space are aware that Bitcoin's proof for work is a major Environmental, Social Corporate Governance (ESG) issue and that it was very strange that Tesla of all companies was buying it. These concerns have limited Bitcoin adoption by institutions significantly.¬†
 
To some extent, people bought the narrative that Tesla, being so renewable focused, could opt into leading the charge on making bitcoin use renewable energy (which it does use a lot of renewable energy, but also a massive amount of coal especially in Chinese mining operations). For example, using excess solar capacity to mine Bitcoin and enabling Tesla vehicles themselves to passively mine it. But Tesla didn't seem interested in actually supporting the network via mining, it was just speculatively holding.¬†

That was always going to be a difficult thing to pull off in the short term.¬†

Ethereum, which is making a transition to proof of stake while carrying a $1T Decentralized finance ecosystem, is the logical choice for ESG focused institutions because a successful migration reduces energy expenditure by > 99.99%.¬†

I expect Tesla will buy Ethereum and I suspect that in a few years 100+ of the S&P500 will be holding Ethereum.¬†

TopShots are NFTs on a centralized chain (NBA run blockchain built on Flowchain by Dapper Labs). They have complete control over the NFTs and the marketplace for the NFTs, including shutting down the market during package drop times to better manage congestion. 

Anything centralized can be taken away, just like how Big Tech can delete accounts or images or posts. 

NFTs in their current iteration struggle with resiliency. Many are on centralized exchanges like OpenSea or Rarible. Many are also structured poorly, using JSON metadata that points to an image hosted on a central server (e.g. by OpenSea, or an AWS S3, or another file storage platform). Because this metadata is on the blockchain, it's immutable. So link rot becomes a major concern. 

Probably $200-300M worth of NFTs will have link rot within the next 3-5 years. That's a conservative estimate. So the metadata on chain will be there, but the URL will go nowhere.

Alternatives include IPFS which incentivizes long term storage of digital information through a decentralized file hosting protocol, but even that is imperfect, as it relies on market participants continuing to host information.

The thing about bounded liquidity is that it serves the same mechanism as decentralized structured limit orders. So you *can* provide liquidity at different prices knowing that you'll only actually risk automatic trading at the prices specified; ergo - you can put ETH at $3-4k and Random coin at $10-20 (even if current price is $5) and you'll automatically accumulate ETH when the random coin crosses $10 (as people buy it from you as its price grows). 

I don't think it will affect gas prices honestly; to me its an entirely different mechanism. What I expect* is that ETH prices will skyrocket as PoS transition occurs and because people are in reality price sensitive to gas based on its $$ equivalent, we'll see decreasing gas prices in ETH terms but increasing in $$ terms until PoS and EIP-1559 launch. 

The fees already hurt a *lot* right now, and it's driving users to unsecure protocols and centralized platforms where high risk opportunities can be done with minimal transaction fees. 

I'm hopeful over the 1-3 year time span, but definitely worried in the 1-8 month timespan. 

Personally*, I'm not trading right now, I'm just entering various index funds and automatic yield protocols and waiting patiently.  

* not financial advice

Now of course you may be thinking "0.3% isn't that much benefit for the risk I'm taking!". 

You'd be wrong haha. 

There's a ton of fighting in monetary policy circles over introducing a 0.1% transaction tax on the stock market- this fee is 3x that and it is completely accepted by the deFi market. 

The thing to get here is that the 0.3% isn't in US dollars (unless of course one of the liquidity pairs is coincidentally USDC, USDT, or similar stablecoin). It's a 0.3% fee on whatever you are selling to the AMM. 

I have 100 MSFT and I want 10 AMZN? The AMM will take my 99.7 MSFT and give me me 9.97 AMZN back. 

That 0.3 MSFT is split between all the liquidity providers. So I am *constantly accumulating more stock just by providing liquidity between the stocks*. 

Traditional finance doesn't do that! They pay in $$$s not in stock. Because $$$s is known to be inflationary. 

This is a *massive* shift in thinking of how finance can happen without any trusted intermediaries!

The effects of these include: ageism (why add to our healthcare cost they look old), ableism (wow, someone takes a lot of prescriptions!), sexism (but if she starts having babies, it's on us...), structural growth problems (no jobs for young people who are in massive debt), political instability (see: The Arab Spring). 

It's a complex issue, but at a foundational level: healthcare is price inelastic (nobody shops for heart surgeons during a heart attack), inflationary (nobody can afford the inefficiencies), and embedding it with employment is the worst possible setup because it distorts the income spending of young, healthy people who need to be investing directly into assets - not expenses- while reducing important labor turnover including, yes, labor leaving the labor force which would put upward pressure on wages. 

The only real argument is: are we sure the government can make it more efficient than it currently is? 

My answer is: the bar is quite low right now haha, and we have models to copy. Public negotiation & single payer + private distribution model incentivizes both research and cost efficiencies through competition for defined services.

Healthcare is the #2 expense at most companies behind payroll.

It adds friction to the labor market because people who don't actually want to be doing their job can't afford to switch and lose healthcare coverage for even a small period of time (don't bring up COBRA, I doubt you've even tried it LOL). So instead they just do barely enough to not get fired to keep their healthcare.

It also keeps people who would otherwise be retirement ready in terms of $$s sacked away in the labor force for heavily subsidized healthcare from younger employees. 

The current system also fails to incentivize efficiency because there is 0 information flow. 

They've done the studies: call 100 hospitals and try to get a price for an elective surgery. 

Good luck, it's a mess.

Hospitals will agree to take losses on hearts from Aetna but make up for it in big profit on kidneys from them. It's insanely inefficient, especially adding in the amount of people they treat without any idea of if they'll get paid. So it's a constant gamble of how do you even get the revenue you're owed.

Well ownership matters in terms of broad wealth accumulation equity. Everyone should own their own data and have the right to price it as they see fit (to some extent and limitations of course). 

But in terms of centralization. 

NFTs have 2 primary components: the metadata and the object. 

The storage of the object *rarely* happens directly on the blockchain because blocks have limited memory size (on purpose) and taking up a whole block with a single transaction is prohibitively expensive. 

So something that is done *poorly* right now, is open internet facing JPEG file hosted on AWS S3 or similar that is linked to the on-chain metadata, but that link isn't stable (i.e. link rot). 

The way around this is to utilize redundant, decentralized file storage systems- the most famous being IPFS. https://ipfs.io/#why 

But there are issues there too in terms of incentivizing nodes to maintain files long term. 

That's why the most common NFT structure is centralized exchange (e.g. OpenSea) that handles the metadata and sales and file storage all in one go. But you then have to trust their storage (or provide your own alternative).

Multi trillion dollar organizations are going to be anti-decentralization. Just like internet used to be priced by hours, it took massive changes in consumer expectations to shift to an open internet model. 

We have data centralization to the max right now, the entire internet is built upon non-consensual data aggregation, sale, and analysis for targeted ads.

Once people get a taste of what it means to own their internet presence (here, I mean, calculable price & value- your internet persona as an asset) they wont give up so much of it so easily. 

Then you just need 1 big tech company to accede. Probably Apple, the most privacy supportive device manufacturer. And suddenly the entire internet / privacy / advertising landscape changes.

The astute reader will wonder: why would someone put up 150% of X to borrow against your $X? They clearly have the money. 

(1) Cryptocurrencies are considered property and transfers/exchanges of property are considered taxable events. Avoiding selling can be important for tax strategy that minimizes short term Capital gains taxes. 

(2) Some people don't want to sell their stuff for cash, they want to keep their stuff and just borrow against it to get cash. 

If someone owns their home, and wants to keep living in it, but needs cash, they can take a loan against their house for the cash. The house is the collateral, and often the home value is much larger than the amount of cash they are borrowing. This is an overcollateralized loan. 

HELOCs, Cash-Out Refis, 2nd mortgages, pawn shops. there are a plenty of traditional finance examples at varying risk and complexities.

Yeah, a lot of people bringing their favorite answers to the question, I prefer to identify the pros and cons and then specify which arguments personally appeal to me more.¬†¬†

I think raising the capital gains tax in an unsustainably low interest rate environment is just a roundabout way of increasing the cost of money. If we believe money is too cheap (I think it is, look at the housing market right now lol) then making it more expensive makes sense. But why do it on the backend with taxes? Just do it at the front end with interest rates.

You would actually think at 2% rates we'd do more deficit spending on investment and then raise taxes marginally and gradually as rates rise to cool down the economy and build up surpluses to continue infrastructure investment once the market is cool.

Just to continue my point. If the capital gains tax funds renewable energy re-education, infrastructure, childcare subsidies, and healthcare investment. Then it's entirely possible that a broad raising of the floor improves the economy overall relative to keeping the money in private markets where we kind of know the rich get richer lol.¬†

But if it's spent on irrelevant things or things that only serve a very specific niche of the economy (e.g. rural 5G, which just numerically doesn't impact that many people or businesses) then we might find it was a bad investment.

Realistically, where will the capital go? The stock market is at all time highs, we're in an everything bubble. The classic way to cool things down sustainably is to raise interest rates.¬†

I would actually support raising interest rates moreso than raising capital gains tax. But in some economist points of view, they are functionally similar in cooling down asset bubbles and incentivizing money to stay put for longer.¬†

It'll be complicated. Taxes aren't all the same. Improving water infrastructure reduces healthcare expenditures down the line. Some stuff pays for itself, most doesn't. It's always about where is this money going, will it be spent efficiently, will it generate returns.¬†

The vast majority of conversation about this stuff is just a proxy. If you believe taxes are bad, then you bring your answer to the question. If you think social services are good, you bring your answer to the question. Nobody is really considering the budget constraint & market context.¬†

A massive change in taxes is highly distortionary, regardless of direction. It's not a simple as down good or up good.¬†

My opinions are:¬†

(1) we're generating a lot of tax revenue, over 1 million million a year. If we have ideas on how to spend it better we need to live within the budget constraint and shift money around. It can't all be new money.¬†

(2) some activities are actually harmful and taxes are a good way of regulating that (e.g. renewable energy vs polluting energy). Others pay for themselves, at 2% interest, deficit spending might make sense, but does that mean we should let markets get addicted to cheap money? That has problems too.¬†

(3) the worst thing you can do, is constantly change the rules. If it's going to be 40%, fine, but can we keep it for 20 years instead of 2? Of it's going to be 20%, fine, but can we keep it for 20 years instead of 2?¬†

It's one thing to build a plane while flying, it's another to be in the air before you've picked a destination.¬†

Wallet distributions matter if the wallets are live. Otherwise they might just be early burn, which is very common for proof of work based chains. 

The important metrics are really not on the Blockchain, it's at the consensus method. Are nodes colluding? Are nodes ordering transactions within blocks to take advantage of slippage? Are nodes ordering transactions to take advantage of price impact? Are they inserting their own transactions to arbitrage between buys and sells? 

Liquidity is the most common scam method. You create a coin, provide liquidity, drive buyers to your coin, then pull liquidity, stranding buyers without a market to sell to and taking their ETH or similar. 

That's not relevant to DOGE tho.
Replied. I do think DOGE stinks but not sure scam is the right label based on only wallet distribution numbers.

Can't go into all this now. But disproportionate wallets is not proof of a scam. Proof of work requires the founders to run their own nodes to minimize 51% attacks. Bitcoin's founder's wallet has over $100B in bitcoin. What's important is that the funds have *never* moved. The market assumes it's a burned wallet on purpose (i.e. those funds are lost)

Wallet distributions are not enough of an analysis to call a scam. We'd need to know if those insane wallets are live or not. If they are live, then yes, that points to network collusion risk, but if they are burned wallets from the earliest days of DOGE and the funds have never moved, then we should consider them permanent reductions in supply. 

Having said this, DOGE definitely makes crypto look bad lol. I personally hate what it's doing and I think investing as entertainment is a dangerous paradigm. 

I'll add one last note tho: these networks aren't static. It's entirely possible that the markets obsession with DOGE might actually drive developers to the network and that DOGE could improve to deserve its place in the market. 

I currently doubt this will happen, but developers are an interesting bunch and the DOGE network does have higher throughput and block sizes than bitcoin.

I agree with this point but I want to emphasize to the American reader what the tradeoff was and what decisions were made.

(1) deindustrialization

Paying union wages for manufacturing work was expensive, it was cheaper to simply reconfigure the supply chain to use global labor and manufacturing.

This had a tremendous impact on equalizing wealth globally. The amount of people living on <$1/day as plummeted as jobs have transferred to other continents.

It also had a tremendous effect on reducing the costs of good, which does help consumers, but the economic literature has generally found that this cost reduction, when adjusted for significant quality reduction, has had a net negative effect on americans.

(2) the internet 

Colleges have to run an entire IT organization on top of the traditional teacher+books+seats model. This has driven massive expenses on non-teaching staff raising college costs (they're not profiting off these insane costs) 

(3) NAFTA

(1) but like more and I the 90s. 

When you complain (rightfully) that US wages have not kept up with productivity. The economics is that, with globalization, wages were actually over productivity before, and now wages are equalizing to global productivity.

Maybe lol. The way I explained to my client:

Billy loves baseball. He plays baseball video games and trades baseball cards.

Sally loves sports, but not video games. Both are in a baseball trading card FB group, but only billy is in the baseball video game group.

Using network analysis you can map individuals across some subset of FB groups.

Using community detection models you can even "re"-group people based on their connections to each other and interests.

This can lead to interesting phenomenon like Billy and Sally both being in the "baseball" community. Or maybe they're both in the "cards" community. Maybe most obviously, they should both be in the "sports" community.

In reality, they are in multiple types of communities which are themselves subsets and partial overlaps of other communities.

Ordering these subsets is actually an incredibly hard & computationally expensive process. What hierarchical community detection does, is actually bucket groups in layers.

Is it more "organized" to have the baseball cards group fall under "sports" first, or under "cards" first. 

This has major implications for non-personalized targeted advertising, but I am looking into it for public health & disease model purposes.

LIAM DARMODY A DAO is a decentralized autonomous organization. The idea being that the population at large can opt into (and out of) the community and propose new ideas (i.e. products) and vote on them. Proposals that receive enough votes are put on the technology roadmap. Generally you buy/sell votes via the DAO's governance token which uses the free market to price control/ownership of the DAO (like a stock). Developers (and the Core team) are typically funded via a centralized group (venture capital) that forms the DAO and have a disproportionate amount of tokens, but best practice is to have a large vest period (5+ years) so that they success = multimillionaire for them + early investors and failure = a lot of time lost LOL. I'm a member of PieDAO and important disclosure is I'm heavily invested in their products and community -  discussing economics of the products, recommending product tweaks, etc.

Relatedly, a successful DAO is one where the governance token is spread out among the broader community. The founders start with 100% of the tokens, but by locking tokens and also using the tokens in marketing (imagine Facebook gave facebook stock to the first 1,000 users and more for each friend they invite), that % drops

Reuben Rapose Maybe. You would need strong centralized buy-in at some level. Whether it be the government, allowing motor vehicle departments to  run oracles on the blockchain for authenticating wallets via drivers licenses, or Facebook with their current ID process, or fiat on ramps (e.g. coinbase) that are obligated under know your customer laws to identify users of their centralized services. 

We often intermix Blockchain use cases to our detriment. 

Trustless, multi-agent, automatically governed transactions is the most common use case. Smart contracts and immutable record keeping being core to that use case.

In terms of NFTs, the benefit is portable, digital scarcity, using smart contracts and immutable record keeping, but automatically governed transactions is less relevant. We should expect to see a lot of industrial NFT usage to be explicitly not decentralized (e.g. NBA TopShot).

We need to see decentralization of online verification. People want the blue check mark on different social media. With authentic identification, we can then see digital scarcity that accurately ties back to people. NFTs can be used for unique identification of people, one of many use cases.

It's just more proof that we're in a special type of bubble; but a lot of this web3 (the primary digital scarcity NFT use case) is way premature. We haven't successfully normalized AR/VR. Until then, digital scarcity is going to be mostly a meme / niche early adopters. 

It's totally normal for new things to be ahead of culture, I think this is a normal part of innovation and we should be patient to some extent. The insane VC funding of bitclout is, in my opinion, an unforced error on VCs part. 

The first is rarely the long term leader (Myspace, Vine, Yahoo, Pets.com, list goes on).

The only logical system left is market socialism, often labeled democratic socialism. Use free markets whenever possible, but put boundaries around markets that deal in goods beyond a certain inelasticity threshold (where free markets meet survival constraints and tend to be exploitative) including certain caps on capital concentration (i.e. taxing capital to fund baseline programs).

Virtually every economy in the world is one of 3 forms: market socialism, state capitalism, fascism.

State capitalism is an inversion of market socialism. Use free markets whenever possible, but put boundaries around markets to sustain capital development (i.e. tax labor to fund critical capital creation). It is unstable because by design laborers outnumber capitalists which leads to political turmoil and demand to move to market socialism.

The easiest way to own labor is to own (monopolize) tools that scale labor in a way that laborers without those tools cannot compete.¬†

People tend to get capitalism confused with "free markets".¬†Free markets just means that products and services are priced based on the individual actions of economic actors. That, in general, information will flow and convergence happens.¬†

You can have free markets without capitalism. You can have capitalism without free markets.

Capitalism without free markets is generally labeled fascism. Free markets without capitalism doesn't have a general label because you can organize it in multiple ways.¬†

Communism can have free markets, but will typically use the state to allocate / control capital.

This system is unstable because it combines the worst of fascism (no free market for capital) with the worst of capitalism (state control of labor). It is the best connected/most powerful who become rich as opposed to the standard inversion of the rich becoming the best connected/most powerful.¬†

It's the same as "culture fit". 

1) the vast majority of companies don't have a defined culture. Value statements are not culture. Behaviors are culture.

2) you don't really want people to "fit" into your boxes, you want to build an environment where people can excel because they feel belonging. Belonging is about ownership, trust, respect, accountability. Not little clubs. Belonging is how creativity happens. 

3) "the best" implies a metric. I don't know about anyone else but I've never done a job interview and been told I scored 86/100 on their interview. 

Companies are an excuse for people to work on something together; making it some weird club that only "the best" can enter is a guarantee that you end up looking, thinking, and acting the same and the market rarely rewards such monotony.
Not saying this as a negative, I think it's good that companies be willing to train people.

How WeWork can (but won't) earn it's valuation: 

- drive community in all facets. 

Regularly pooled/subsidized catering, events, speakers, etc. All operated by professional community organizers who drive cross-pollination of startups/companies within an office. 

- flash renting

Get insanely nice conference rooms with the best AR/VR, airstream, etc. Someone should be able to walk in and share screen/audio on gigabit internet within seconds with minimal friction. 

1-3 days at a time. I can imagine semi-virtual conferences where the speakers and organizers are together to simplify ops but broadcast across all major platforms (twitch, YT, etc.) with 1-click WeWork tools. 

- pooled hiring

WeWork can run initial interviewing of talent for companies that opt-in to bypassing part of their interview process for WeWork selected candidates. Including pooling costs for technical assessments like livecode. 

- support startups with best practices in scale including finance e.g. Blockchain enabled ownership models (e.g. DAOs).

The value add for WeWork is NOT partitioned real estate. That would be the lowest value case.

The value add should be highly technical community organizers with relationships to resources that help members grow.

I don't think there is a real difference. 

A business analyst might do more "limited" work like: mostly Excel, minor SQL, minor R. But they'll generally be a product person. 

While a DA/DS is going to cover advanced excel, SQL, R, Python, some cloud. But rarely be a product person too. 

I think the distinction between DE & DS is much larger than DS & DA. 

And too often DAs are confused with BAs which is a *purposefully* tech limited role because it is product biased.

So, if we confuse DAs as BAs, yeah this gulf will feel big. But when we recognize that it's really a spectrum of: 

Product oriented <-- --> implementation oriented 

It's pretty quick to recognize who is closer to what on this spectrum and who is surprisingly close together.

Lots of bubbles, scams, hype, etc. I don't focus on specific implementations or money making schemes. I focus on the technology and whether it is a true innovation that will impact the global economy.

Leanpub.com/blockchainthoughts swipe to $0 for a free copy. I detail the technology, why it's revolutionary, and how I perceive value in the technologies. I disclose what I'm involved with and also identify things I'm not invested in and why. 

Not financial advice. Just a guide on how an Economist sees the opportunities.

To clarify on the *not financial advice*. Imagine it's 1991.

I'm telling you "the internet & personal computer will be crazy, study up! Keywords include: http, website, domain name service, RAM, CPU". 

I'm NOT telling you "go invest in Netscape/AOL/Yahoo". 

Because specific implementations of the technology are not really the point. It's about what this tech *can do*, not how it's currently being done. 

I don't know which of these is Google/Amazon/Netflix versus NetScape/Actua/Blockbuster.

But soon, you'll have the opportunity to decide for yourself in a way that fits your risk profile and researched opinions.

To answer the question directly. There is literally 0 argument that NFTs are anything but the future of digital media. They will completely revolutionize AR/VR, secondary markets of all forms, music, entertainment, and probably a lot more. 

Keywords to google: 

Web3
ERC-721
NBATopshot 
Rarible
OpenSea NFT Bible

I've talked about them a lot, feel free to check my post history for more. Short summary of my thoughts:

Pros: 

+  Immutable record keeping and transfer of semi-unique digital items (including digital wrappings of real objects). 

+ Enables standardization of digital items across compliant platforms (e.g. in video games, items bought in one game can transfer to another this makes huge synergy opportunities across multi-billion dollar entertainment products). 

+ Robust secondary market for digital goods including innovative auction methods and streams of payments to creators. 

+ Value is completely market determined.

Cons: 

- Typically *not* created and managed correctly due to lack of knowledge by the average enterprise engaging in NFTs. Many NFTs use centralized file storage to store the digital object itself and/or its metadata. This can lead to link rot, which would essentially destroy the value of the NFT. NFTs need to be stored within the blockchain and be purposefully duplicated (i.e. IPFS is not enough). 

- Anyone can NFT anything, so NFT-ing copyrighted material has no intrinsic mechanisms for a centralized group (i.e. the government) to enforce copyright.

- value is completely market determined.

Military vet, multiple tours in Afghanistan (secretly, due to being a high value target), multiple startups related to mental health (BetterUp's industry), experience in high profile, high stress roles.

I think it's obvious that there's marketing value for them, but something detailed really well in the book When Coffee and Kale Compete is that the *who* matters.

A business executive paying $200,000 to get coaching from Jimmy McBusiness, versus paying $200,000 to get coaching from Mark Cuban, or Oprah, or Prince Harry - can completely change how the coaching is received. Even if the words are the exact same. 

So the idea that this is just some fru fru royal getting a cush do-nothing job to get some marketing going is probably not correct.

Sure, it's marketing, but if you actually look at their business model and ask - "can he make noticeable contributions based on his experiences" I don't see how anyone can say no.

Real question- don't ATS "sort" resumes for review? Or allow for keyword searching? 

I would imagine the cutting edge ones include natural language processing for generating recommendations based on the job description keywords. 

I built a tiny ATS that ranked by keywords for a company I was working at. It literally just stored resumes and sorted them by containing your keywords. 

It's very difficult for me to understand how a professional ATS wouldn't have candidate sorting using some kind of regular expressions search at a minimum.

I think it's entirely compatible for people to want to "beat ATS" in the context of being read by a recruiter at a good time (e.g. first thing in the morning, or on top of the results page). 

Or does it have 0 similarity to SEO? I am thinking of the problem like SEO.

I think the biggest threat to business is fear of innovation.

I'm not saying you need to be on the cutting edge of everything.

You don't have to invest in every "nExT fAcEbOoK" you get pitched.

But you need to identify where you're not making business sense.

1) the vast majority of business decisions are directional.

Do we think X is profitable?

of course, the "proper" thing to do is assess opportunity costs and risk and all that. But typically, the choice avoided is just the status quo. Which you should understand really well having lived it.

For #datascience this means calling it when PCA, LR, RF, CART, KNN, LDA - the standard stuff - are JUST FINE.

2) the vast majority of business decisions are reversible.

Run your regression, test it on data it hasn't seen, interpret the results and try it out. 

obviously some decisions are massive and this doesn't work (e.g. in pharma) but retail? entertainment? consumer services? 

Agile has beaten waterfall for a reason.

3) If somebody else has already done it, you're not innovating.

I've heard stories from industry folk that ANY new idea they present must include case studies on how it's worked for competitors... 

You have to be willing to be 1st!

Solidity is a JavaScript derivative language for coding smart contracts on the Ethereum blockchain.

A blockchain is an immutable and cryptographically secure database that uses decentralized computing resources to manage transactions (i.e. addition of new blocks to the chain). 

These blocks can contain data (several megabytes is common) in addition to their metadata.

This feature of decentralized, rules-based cryptographic security and information collection allows for perfect transfer and record keeping of data- (the data isn't necessarily correct, but it's perfectly stored) - and that can include who owns what, which makes it very useful for things like tracking transfers of information between groups (e.g., financial transactions). 

Smart Contracts are best understand as algorithmically enforced rules (or "laws" or "governance") that allow for coded transfers of information to occur without any individual (or centralized group)  triggering it. 

These rules exist directly on the blockchain and they self-execute when their parameters are met, every time their parameters are met, without deviation. 

With this tech, we can automate trillions of $$ of finance operations.

Leanpub.com/blockchainthoughts

More info including why this actually matters (hint: if you're reading this from a country with low corruption, good governance, and an insured bank account, the vast majority of the world does not live that way) you can check out my short book (~60 pages, less than 2hr skim). 

Leanpub.com/blockchainthoughts

Michael Farmer just to add on Chic Fil A's success story.

1) mobile nativity - they pushed mobile at the right time and the app is sleek enough to perform for individuals at lunch AND major catering (100s of nuggets, dozens of drinks) without issue. 

2) design for scale - they really were the first to normalize staff outside taking orders to streamline lines. But they have an advantage in a limited menu. Mcdonald's is copycating but their menu size complicates this and push for order speed can cannibalize order sizes. 

3) culture - they've solidified themselves within a key demographic with their Sundays closed while largely averting the fallout from being anti-lgbt by reducing their donations to conversion therapy clinics, etc.

Preston Lange Yes, tract housing, suburban / automobile oriented development, etc. are major concerns in the literature - but those problems aren't new in the context of teens needing third places. 

What's new is a digital-native generation facing structural impediments to normal social developments; e.g., the loss of funding for public spaces post 2008, creating a vicious feedback loop where: 

 Nobody uses public space because it isn't good --> 
 nobody uses public space anyway they have social media --> Why make public spaces better if everyone is just on their phone --> Why get off my phone, there isn't anywhere good to go anyway.

I don't hang at the 'Mart personally, and it's not currently designed to be a positive place, I acknowledge all that grey lol. But it will have an easier time than Amazon if it sees fit to become one.

If you believe in a technology and want to invest in it- the rational thing to do is make it a reasonable fraction of your overall investment portfolio and dollar cost average into it. 

If you're interested in the technologies behind NFTs but don't necessarily want to invest in a JPG- you can invest in the companies behind the technology. 

I talk about this more in my book that I don't want to shill too hard here - but needless to say, you can invest a reasonable proportion of your portfolio into cryptographic assets like: 

RARI - rarible's token 
ARTE - Items, a technology that does ERC-20 wrappers for NFTs
NFTX - an index for NFT technology 

There are numerous others.

Disclosure: I was an early buyer of ARTE.

Doesn't need to be grey. They can do a major brand and design overhaul and it's likely overdue. I imagine everything from mini-golf to VR lounges.

I think what's grey is how teenagers today: aren't driving, aren't getting high school jobs, aren't seeing friends unsupervised, aren't going out of their homes unsupervised, and effectively living their lives entirely on social media / internet. 

These are only worsened with covid, but the pattern has been years coming. The amount of 8th graders who said they had spent times with friends in public without parents has plummeted since the advent of the iPhone (correlation that I'd argue fits causation). 

Similarly, suicide rates for young girls ( 9 - 12 ) has skyrocketed in the same time period. 

As an urban economist, I'm hyperfocused on how we've lost "third places" for this demographic. We need libraries, malls, public parks, and yes- even Walmarts - to get people out of the home-work-home-repeat migration pattern. It's just not healthy for us to have so little variance in our environments.

I actually disagree on your UBI cop-out point.

Something I think about regularly is the inverse relationship between labor productivity and entrepreneurship. This makes sense, entrepreneurship has wages as the opportunity cost, and wages should be related to marginal productivity. But entrepreneurship (and small business in general) is critical for a diverse, resilient economy. 

What UBI does is let us get out of the minimum wage distraction conversation, separate healthcare from employment, stabilize consumption (smoother business cycles), and give more opportunities for entrepreneurship which I think will pay massive dividends in innovation, quality, pricing, and local resilience.

I look at is as a foundational piece of the economy, payment streams for natural resources is a natural funding mechanism for UBI and could be configured as part of a property tax schema to minimize distortion / dead weight loss.

Message:
Everything is a spectrum, it's easy to yell "raise the minimum wage" and "tax the rich"; it's also easy to yell "regulation slows growth which slows job creation" and "countries compete for companies via tax policy". 

All 4 of these things can be necessary and true without conflicting. They can also all not be appropriate depending on the economic context. We need to raise our discourse to take in more nuance and identify clusters of the economy where shifts in policy can make an aggregate improvement. 

When we bundle up all industries into "the economy" and try and enforce 1 size fits all policies (whether they be labor or capital biased) we risk simpson paradox effects that worsen the situation and complicate our understanding.

Solutions - none easy: 

(1) diverse economy with minimal reliance on state funds. This is extremely difficult given the public necessity of energy, telecoms, defense, transportation, finance, healthcare, etc.

(2) robust independent monetary policy that is willing and able to slow down good times to build up funds for bad times. Extremely difficult knowing that not everyone makes it during good times and policy will leave them behind. These people at the margins are especially at risk during downturns, so them missing out on good times is also a sociopolitical stability concern.

(3) a healthy, educated, and age diverse population with strong social trust and good information flow. Population is elastic to interest rates and is not overly biased towards savings (hoarding) or spending (hyperconsumption) that makes business cycles worse. 

(4) a balance between short term monopoly rewards for innovation and a highly competitive private sector that ensures economic mobility and politically acceptable income inequality. Extremely difficult without (1) and (3), as high income inequality leads to social unrest which leads to uncertainty which can lead to defensive inflation (prices rise to spur capital owners savings, not costs).

Interesting but probably not usable in practice. These calculators tend to assign probabilities based on your opponent having 2 random, but possible, cards, i.e. they have the same chance of having 2,7 as A,A when those cards aren't known to be exhausted on the board or in your hand.

You need an interface to input your expectations about their range of potential hands, and then the calculator can determine likelihood respective of the uniform distribution of hands you've determined to be possible for them to have. 

Limit holdem has been solved by adaptive AI that continuously updates the opponent hand likelihood from their historic betting patterns. But no-limit holdem is effectively infinitely more complex due to bet *size* being a continuous and inconsistent factor (i.e. people can have balanced sizing for bluffs and non bluffs). 

Still cool! Just warning people that AI struggles with certain types of games. The augmented reality part is separate from that and very interesting too. 

One day these will be an app available on your smart contact lenses.

I think it's common for the individual contributors to have 0 P&L responsibility (although they definitely SHOULD have P&L awareness and exposure)- but I imagine up the chain at the PM & VP level it gets very into the weeds of P&L. 

In consulting everything is in hours, so projects have to validate their spend in human hour terms, which are then tracked back to the opportunity cost of the resources. Depending on the client contract, quantification of impact IS denominated in P&L, specifically in cost reductions and labor hours saved. We then calculate different ROI metrics depending on the situation. 

I don't personally see it much for my work which is more research focused, but I've seen it in other data science projects including hearing about it from others in industry at other firms. 

I've never done internal data science at a company, so I don't know how much they are tasked with P&L relative to sales oriented consulting data scientists.

Doesn't even count the non profit sales / cold calling / BD, and education sales (yes, convincing parents your private school is a good fit for their children is sales too!) and startups selling to get funding that I've done. I don't think I've had a job that didn't touch sales in my entire life. 

The fact I could do all this for literally a decade and I still thought sales was icky is insane in hindsight.

First job at the movie theater. I was top in average transactions, great seller. But sales was looked down on so I didn't want to do it.

Started college, became comms director for the largest non-greek club on campus, selling everyday M-F growing it 3x. Selling was looked down on so I didn't want to be known as a salesperson.

Started working retail for an arts shop that paid commission. Was making more selling than I was when I was made manager (no commission). Sales was looked down on, so I took a terrible promotion to get out of it, even tho I was good.

Got recruited out of college to do freight brokerage sales, started during my senior year, didn't even graduate college and I was cracking 10s of 1000s in revenue monthly- not much, people bring in $Ms casually now, but it was respectable and tough.

But Sales was looked down on. We were just a bunch of ruffians making frat jokes on the floor, cracking beer at 5pm on the dot to get ready for the west coast 2nd wave. I was selling 10-12 hrs / day. Still looked down upon, so I got out. 

Years later, in data science consulting, leading AI technical sales, I realize. Everything is sales anyway. 

100% agre. sales is legit, people can start early.

Might be hot off the press, I just found out, but I don't expect it to hit mainstream media much.

There are risks though. Centralization of nodes onto a single cloud provider, even one as advanced at handling outages and mixed-region data center as #AWS, reduces points of failure. I doubt we'll see Amazon hold enough of the network to where an outage takes them noticeably offline, but we might see enough centralization to where an outage makes the surviving nodes vulnerable to a coordinated attack, especially if an adversarial government had the desires to cripple adoption of a technology that injures it's currency monopoly.
Check out my book if you want to know more about Ethereum (really the primary coin I talk about) and the technology / finance implications of Blockchain.

Important caveat. I used the word copyright. That was bad word choice. 

I do not mean that NFTs will be the future of government enforced monopolies of first mover products. 

I mean that NFTs will be the future of algorithmically defined and market valued monopolies of first mover products. 

I do not expect modern, centralized, copyright law to play a major role in NFTs outside of very large disputes (multiple millions $$).

You seem committed to misunderstanding the technology and the argument. If the 1 pixel improvement is better, the market will value it more. If it's not, the market won't. If you're saying the market is irrational, go ahead, I'd agree, I don't think that art is worth $1M. If you're asking me if an NFT is defendable copyright. I don't know, I'm not a lawyer. I'm an economist telling you that the blockchain will differentiate the historical sales record of a non-fungible item and that I expect your derivative work will not be highly valued by the market given it doesn't have any tie back to the original item or creator.

If you try and force decentralized technology (NFTs) into a Centralized framework (government supported copyright law) you're going to miss the point.

Again, I already agree that art is not worth $1M *to me*. 

Getty might come after you for stealing their image and changing 1 pixel using the government's power to enforce copyright. 

In NFTs, the market will simply not value your derivative work unless it does, the historical record is available and immutable. Anyone will know when you made your derivative work and it'll be trivial to identify the original.

But that 1 pixel might be really good for all I know.

Having said that, it's objectively the future of art, since artists didn't use it and now they are using it LOL. Some of my favorite artists are already minting custom album covers, tokens used for special access to live streams, etc. Of course, we're mixing fungible and non-fungible in this context. 

I think $100,000 garbage frog art is a bubble for sure. But the underlying technology is very real.

Beanie babies is an important argument for anyone interested in cryptographic assets to consider.

And correct, NFTs are not money. That's the whole non-fungible part. 100% correct. NFTs are not money.

Not quite. Stealing is easy regardless of blockchain, just like screen recording a movie is trivial.

It's about having a legitimate marketplace where buyers in good faith can access content. There's a phrase- "piracy is a service problem, not a pricing problem".

Netflix killed pirate bay, not copyright laws. If you make something accessible and legitimate, the typical person will pay a fair price for it. 

NFTs offer the same mechanism for all creative content. Sure, you can download an image, but if you wanted to know who the real owner is- right click, image search, boom- there's a wrapped NFT detailing it's creation, owner, and history of sale. You can buy a "legitimate" copy through that service, which would give you access to a secondary market of other legitimacy seeking buyers in the future, or just steal a copy for your own use. 

Paying $4.99 for a movie on google play is easier than stealing it since google play can immediately cast to my TV.

If you don't like the private corporation examples, swap them out for any 2 government agencies like NOAA and NGA. There *should* be a market for combining spatial data and weather data - but it hasn't happened yet due to the easy ability to copy/paste data without any record of ownership.

I have a lot of thoughts on this as an economist, happy to dive in more, here's a good related article.

https://flowingdata.com/2010/08/18/how-weather-data-became-open-data/

There's a lot of interesting writing out there on the intrinsic value of data. Some argue it's oil, I used to agree but was convinced otherwise. Data requires a system. You could take all of Amazon's retail data (worth millions to them) and give it to Facebook and it be near worthless. 

Oil is generally good at multiple refineries. 

Maybe part of that Amazon data is usable by Facebook with enough integration work, but it's hard to argue they could turn it into the billions of dollars of value that Amazon generates with it. 

A decentralized, trustless, curated, generalized data marketplace would incentivize work to occur between these edge cases. A public dump of Amazon data is "open source" but it's not necessarily economic value. but a public dump + incentivized individuals that curate pieces of it for derivative use and profit from making datasets that can then be resold/tracked would be economic value.

It just opens an avenue to allow for better tracking of ownership, transition of ownership, and payment streams to owner(s) (including original owner). It allows for trustless coordination of complex, possibly adversarial, multi-agent systems. 

For example, can Google and Microsoft anonymously share data with a marketplace (or with each other) without relying on a centralized intermediary like SafeGraph (a data company I really like) coordinating the agreements and enforcement of those agreements.

I don't cover NFTs in my book, but the same thinking holds. Trustless, complex, multi-agent, decentralized organization and transfer of information is game-changing.

Sure, but the foundational difference is still that news sites choose to use facebook and put content on their platform; while news site publish to the internet (not owned by any particular company) and google makes derivative content and scrapes their websites to enhance their product (search). Relatedly, other sites like webarchive will copy their content explicitly to make available and their content is used across the internet as cited source material, etc. 

News is a public good and we're treating it like a club good and if we want high quality news we need to fund it. a social media platform funding it is a harder sell than a search engine that takes their content as inputs into their product. There's a reason it resulted the way it did.

Different situations though. Facebook is a place news companies choose to post articles.¬†

Google doesn't own the internet, so it's scraping news websites to make them searchable and mine them for summaries, e.g. its amp service.¬†

That's why Facebook refused to pay and Google couldn't refuse.¬†

People expect news from Google, plenty of people are just fine using Facebook for family and friends and not information.¬†

Although, personal opinion, I think this makes fake news significantly more risky for Facebook's brand. It's already fallen out with young people who prefer instagram (owned by FB but at risk of separation in an antitrust case) and tiktok.¬†

Depends on definition of professional level / production-grade. RConnect can handle virtually all of those issues including load balancing, APIs, scaling up resources, parallelizing, etc.   I've deployed Shiny apps onto RConnect, R Shiny Server Pro, and even ugly desktop deployments to low-tech environments; and deployed web apps with multiple containers, APIs, the works (typically on Azure). Obviously you need the right tool for the job and many jobs are complicated, but I would push back on the idea that Shiny + RConnect can't be professional if we accept professional to mean generate millions of dollars in value for business.

Michael Green got a vote?

Robin hood stole from the rich and gave to the poor. I expect at the end of this, the poor will be poorer. People are putting their life savings into a chicken game based on a few people who got in early (and got *out*) paying off student loans and exaggerating their gains.  

I don't really see anything positive out of all this, although I guess more nihilistically, it is *interesting* that it was possible, but frankly, this is just a compressed version of the more famous meme stock $TSLA.

So to answer your question. I don't see it as a decentralization of power, I see it as a successful astroturfing campaign strategically manipulating a community. And I think the losers are going to be the everyday person who doesn't know when to get off the ride.

My understanding is a bunch of finance whales identified that GME was one of the most short positioned stocks in history.

Shorts are interesting because they're inverted, the profits are capped at the stock price, but the LOSSES possible are technically infinite. 

So they decided to buy a bunch of GME, which algorithm traders shorted because well that's their position.

Then they ran an astroturf campaign on R/wallstreetbets that "gamers need to support gamestop" and "this is our chance to Robin Hood the rich". 

So the masses started buying it as a meme. 

This caused a "death spiral". Typically a death spiral, like Bear Stearns in 2008, is when you go to sell, there's no buyers, so you lower the price and try again. When people are all trying to do that at once, it's a race to the bottom. Once a stock drops too much too quickly, you get even fewer buyers interested. 

Because GME was so shorted, it's death spiral is to go *UP* in price. Also called a "short squeeze". Short positions get so scared of seeing losses >100% that they rush to buy out their position. But nobody is selling. So you get an upward death spiral.

The options are to wait it out and see 2-500% losses, or join the death spiral and make it all worse.
This is what I expected and why I voted supply tremendously higher than demand.

Poll still running but interesting that the poll and the comments seem to be reaching completely opposite conclusions. 

I know business-stats-R/Python-excel-SQL is a totally legitimate business need and one that will not be dropping anytime soon. 

But the kind of evidence I would expect that the *supply* is not meeting this demand would be: 

1) faster hiring cycles
2) higher wage growth
3) less applicants per role 
4) bootcamp/university graduates with multiple offers upon graduation
5) acceptance of cross-industry experience in hiring (as opposed to looking for in-industry exp specifically).

I see all of these for data engineering, and have yet to find any evidence it's true for data analytics.

I know NCSU publishes their MS analytics data and they have an average >2 offers per student upon graduation, but they cover a lot of data engineering in their program so I'm not shocked. 

You'd think bootcamps and universities would be shouting from the rooftops if their analytics masters and data scit bachelor's students were drowning in job offers?
How would you set the bar?

Personally, I think MS Analytics programs and bootcamps are pumping out graduates faster than business can turn data into money.  

If you post a job saying "good stats, some business experience, R or Python, and a little bit of SQL". You'll have 200 applications within 2 days. And a massive amount of them will have degree and certificates with those skills. 

If we accept the premise that anyone who can effectively do the job or learn to do the job within 30ish days is "qualified". I'd say it's still a whittling down of 20-50 legit applicants. 

I feel like the supply is tremendously higher than demand and that wages will stagnate or fall soon.

I would feel differently if businesses *needed* more advanced stuff. But from what I'm hearing about the market, a lot of highly qualified data scientists are doing very foundational work that could have been trusted to someone with enough skill at a lower wage.

There's not enough advanced work to go around. And businesses selling themselves as "AI" can't admit that what they really need are Excel templates, a PowerApps workflow, SQL procs, and a few shiny apps. 

I think the dot-AI bubble is bigger than the Bitcoin bubble.

More evidence really that the ad based internet was a genius idea taken too far. We can't have a functioning relationship with a product that doesn't *have an explicit price*. It breaks so many fundamentals of Economics and how goods are interpreted.

To clarify my point, skimming the concept paper, available here, I think there is something to be said around their argument about Google AMP and similar that bundle news and cache them for consumption (thus effectively requiring the media to write in a format amenable to AMP).

But I'm still not seeing the connection of how news would be paid for making their content available to the masses. If anything, you would think the natural relationship would be for the news to pay Google and Facebook to reach audiences. 

Which they do of course through advertisement, but not through search and news feed.

I think the broader issue here is that we have an advertising duopoly with an ad business too intimately tied to the native products (search and news feed respectively). 

I think the government's role would be to bust this duopoly, but realistically they can't. Because by design search and news feed don't have any revenue generating properties and *creating one* would be terrible for how people use the internet today.

The more I read the more difficult I realize management of big tech is...


https://www.accc.gov.au/system/files/ACCC%20-%20Mandatory%20news%20media%20bargaining%20code%20-%20concepts%20paper%20-%2019%20May%202020.pdf

Search drives traffic to sites. If these companies are summarizing news or taking their writing and making it available off-site, they should pay for doing that. 

If the search is simply driving people to sites and the people click the site, then it's up to the news media to price appropriately. 

The reality is that news is a public good. But we treat it as a club good. This misalignment means that good news is expensive and thus in low supply, while literal garbage fraud is cheap and in high supply. 

It is the *governments* role to support public goods but because of the sensitivity around media's role as the "check on government" and their historic issues with being beholden to owners, that has had limited success in terms of fair domestic news coverage. 

This is an issue going back literally *hundreds* of years. 

How do we determine truth, how do we pay for its summarization, how do we pay for its spread, and how do we reduce the spread of lies- which are in any sense of how they play out in groups of humans , a virus. 

The public vs club good misalignment is not going to be solved by having private organizations battle out who deserves a fraction of the search money and who doesn't. They'll pick the cheap fake news.

My understanding is it's equivalent to adding in words to the search that are within some similarity distance of your word. 

So, 

"How to become rich" 
Vs "how to become ~rich" 

May be equivalent to 
"How to become rich wealthy money" in that searches that don't explicitly say "rich" can be higher ranked than they normally would. 

But Google's engine is so semantically based nowadays I'm not sure this simple example is doing it justice.

The core of this argument is Disney has live experiences and  bought Marvel, DC, Star Wars, and Pixar before Netflix could. 

The argument looks kind of weak in the context of Disney's liabilities though. Massive workforce, weak globalization of content, theme parks, manufacturing commits, retail establishments, etc.

Underspecification Presents Challenges for Credibility in Modern Machine Learning

https://arxiv.org/abs/2011.03395

"...An ML pipeline is underspecified when it can return many predictors with equivalently strong held-out performance in the training domain. .. Predictors returned by underspecified pipelines are often treated as equivalent based on their training domain performance, but we show here that such predictors can behave very differently in deployment domains ... is a distinct failure mode from previously identified issues arising from structural mismatch between training and deployment domains ... problem appears in a wide variety of practical ML pipelines, using examples from computer vision, medical imaging, natural language processing, clinical risk prediction based on electronic health records, and medical genomics."

RE: income inequality. 

News is partly a public good, in that more people being more informed pays dividends to society. But it's treated as a club good- you pay for access but your reading of the NYT doesn't mean I can't also read that same NYT. 

More people having less money means less potential subscriptions per person. I can't realistically subscribe to 15+ news sites, it's the same problem as streaming! I'm spending more than cable nowadays to have Netflix, Hulu, Disney+, Amazon. No way in $_+# I'm getting NBC, ABC, CBS, HBO, and a billion others. 

This means more ads are needed to subsidize the content. 

But it also means the ads have to be of lower quality goods (cheap ads) because people won't click on stuff they can't afford to buy. 

This is a vicious cycle of more cheap ads leading to more cheap ads (I mean, Google Internet Chum lol). 

To some extent the logical answer *is* to subsidize news, but then we get into a sticky situation of either the government choosing news outlets (propaganda risk #1) or the mega-rich choosing news outlets (propaganda risk #2- current state). 

another answer is to reduce income inequality and raise more peoples incomes so that they can afford to buy good news.

A difficult case. In the US publishers often change their content based on if it's a bot or a person (i.e. allowing bots to mine the text for keywords but if a person clicks a link, a giant banner blocks the text requiring subscription). 

This is actually against the Google Terms of Service but is considered a necessary evil to drive traffic. 

Overall, I think the ad-based internet is a brilliant invention gone too far. Business cannot survive from getting their customers to buy *other companies stuff* in exchange for a few pennies. 

We've turned the entire internet into an affiliate marketing program. 

Relatedly, journalism that is *good* costs money to make, there's a reason the disinformation in the US is free, it's because people are paying billions of dollars to propagandize people and a paywall defeats the point. 

This is a much bigger issue than just search engine listings versus publishers. It's about how do we fund the work it takes to write the Truth, especially when Fake is not only cheaper to produce and more viral, but it's actively subsidized by moneyed interests.

This is also intimately tied to income inequality, which hurts this issue two-fold.

You may have noticed I switched from Urban Studies enthusiast to Blockchain Enthusiast. 

I think blockchain will be a critical technology for Cities of the Future and don't see it as a switch, moreso a specification.

MIR - mirror protocol allows for traditional stock ownership through mirroring stock price changes.

HEX - high interest CDs (certificate of deposits) for those interested in holding coins long term with less exposure to volatility.

AMPL - structured volatility coin, has a unique variance setup so that it doesn't over correlate with bitcoin (this is a major problem). This white paper was a great economics read. 

Melon - automates asset management paperwork for coins, scaling how hedge funds communicate reports.

UNI - allows people to make liquidity pools from a pair of coins, and get rewarded for doing so, ensuring smoother trades of up and coming coins. 

There is SO MUCH happening in this space. It is NOT about bitcoin replacing gold. That is really the lowest bar of them all. 

It's a movement to open source finance itself. Anyone who likes money or works for a bank ü§£ that is sleeping on this stuff will be in a LOT of pain in 5-10 years.

The big banks are roughly 3 years behind on this.

This article details how the reduction of the federal funds rate allowed **BANKS** to generate massive amounts of liquid assets.

1) cashing in on current tax law

2) Covid related property sales and purchases

There's a few points of disagreement we have that I've detailed my position on elsewhere in this thread. 

It's a deflationary Hayekian currency. It's gold that can be sent digitally. It's value needs to plateau for it to be long term useful as a medium of exchange, it's value will be determined by the inflation and seignorage of other countries. It can argued that it's market long term is its penetration rate into financial markets (effectively becoming a bond, hedging against inflation/seignorage globally in the long term) + it's value as a remittance and financial transfer technology.

The idea that the coin should be worth $0 because it's "IP packets" is probably nonsense. The idea that it's value should be a few $100 at most because, like you said, it's currently at 40x the largest currency, is one that is very much worth considering.

My personal beliefs are that our global financial system is >$200T, and there are only 21M coins that will be made, so it's just a math problem of (200T * penetration rate) / 21M.

I could believe a penetration rate anywhere from 1M^(-1) to 1%, probably non uniform and probably changing over time as ethereum and deFi grow. But precisely 0 is a tough sell for me.

Total bond market is $100T. It's a worthwhile conversation to have, but until BTC plateaus, not sure it's worth discussing alongside barely inflation following bonds. Although it is an important substitute asset to consider. 

As I mention elsewhere, we may see that 90/8/2 outperforms 90/10/0 or 94/6/0 stocks/bonds/crypto.  It does all matter eventually.

Anything is possible! Some things more likely than others. I think the amount of whales (including a known $1B whale hedge fund) signals that serious investors are getting involved and they won't tolerate too much dropping. 

My benchmark is: "Bitcoin is saturated when my grandma sends me a satoshi through facebook messenger for my birthday."

Until then, I'm bull.

Well, be careful assuming risk tolerance is a direct connection to conventional assets. You should diversify according to the historic patterns of different asset allocations. 94/6 stock/bond outperforms 99/1 historically- so risk is not a linear combination of the individual risks.

It could entirely be the case (and I do expect this to be proven out) that a 90/8/2 stock/bond/crypto spread outperforms several 9x/x/0 spreads in a long enough time period to be considered a more "safe" allocation.

That 5.5 is a little off because the growth rate of bitcoins available is nonlinear and the growth wouldn't be over 120 years, it'd be over whatever time period it takes for bitcoin to reach it's stable penetration level. If you believe 1%, you are implying a 20-30% growth (726B -> 900B) over a yet to be defined time period for market correction (i.e. for it to no longer be underpriced).

The connection is that assets have two competitors: spending and other assets. 

Every dollar in bitcoin is a dollar not spent and probably mostly, a dollar not invested in the stock market (it's not like bonds or savings accounts are beating inflation right now). 

So the idea of penetration as a % and *when* you expect it to hit that %, is a function of your estimation of people's preferences, and less so a function of the supply of the coin or its price. 

My point is that the modern investor considering BTC should be focused on making an estimate for the penetration % and really not get distracted by the supply (because it's essentially infinitely divisible with satoshis + enough advancement in computers) and price.

Sabuj Chattopadhyay You're looking at this completely out of context because you've bought into an invalid framework. 

Platforms are run by companies.
Companies exist in a location. 
The location regulates the boundaries of speech. 
In the US, incitement of violence is a boundary of speech. 
The platform has users. 
The users agree to a terms of service. 
The terms of service include commitment to legal boundaries (AND MORE). <- We can have a very robust debate about how extensive that AND MORE is, and whether that AND MORE veers into censorship that would offend our sensibilities around free speech.

The user in question repeatedly violated the AND MORE part of the terms of service, but was given preferential treatment. 

We can ALSO have a robust debate on the validity of a platform choosing who and who doesn't get preferential treatment. 

When the user in question went beyond the AND MORE (where we can have robust debates, with appropriate context to the preferential treatment received) and broke legal boundaries. 

The platform's preferential treatment stops mattering.

More specifically to is it related: yes. Very related. Silicon valley can either expand requiring more highways and super commute development or it can infill and start developing in gaps between cities (where it faces the formidable NIMBY movement fighting against that). 

Under all this pressure of cost, commutes, chaos, it's no wonder states with different priorities (e.g. TX with effectively no public transportation, no state income tax, car-first culture, minimal social safety net) have been fighting to pull tech away from CA, they have something real to offer. 

But if the question is whether Austin will become the next X. That is going to depend on more than just the ability of workers to have good internet and work a CA job in TX. 

It's going to depend on regulation that determines the ease of business, the bias between employee and employer protection, it's ability to infill vs expand, it's ability to dynamically connect multiple city level economies into a regional economy with a lot of creative destruction & knowledge spillover. 

I think most states are doing this wrong, you can tell heuristically by the inequality of Economics output of cities within a state. 1-city states struggle.

The literature (which frankly can be quickly outdated, I was occasionally reading/citing papers on the knowledge economy pre-dot com bubble) says that companies and *people* choose larger cities partially because of knowledge spillover benefits. 

There's few markets like silicon valley where you can: 

1) go in 
2) learn a ton from co-workers
3) intimately learn an industry
4) find an unsolved niche in your industry
5) grab a few co-workers and form a startup 
6) possibly get your former employer to invest in that startup after you leave. 

The non-compete laws in CA are boons for Economic development especially in tech. 

There's a reason Florida (I'd say the worst state for non compete law relative to its economic size, having lived there and left because of a poor economy) struggles to build up it's tech ecosystem.  It's pretty much satellite office in Miami/Tampa or the oddball startup. 

As for Boulder, Austin vs NYC, SF. Companies are going to have to chase talent and talent is getting overwhelmed in large cities: cost, crowding, commute, chaos. I think if CA had done a better job handling it's homelessness and affordability crises we'd see a lot less shift away from the state.

Shorter: 

I can spend $1M/acre infilling downtown Chicago, or 1.5M/acre developing an undeveloped suburb and connecting it to city services, etc. 

I can spend $800k/acre infilling downtown Phoenix or $500k/acre developing an undeveloped suburb and connecting it to city services. 

Agricultural viability would the (fundamental but yes, frankly a bit theoretical) reason why Phoenix would be more sprawled than Chicago (infill is more expensive in Phoenix than just growing out more).

Note: it doesn't need to *literally* be agricultural value, it could be any general value of not being developed (value of green space, expected value of undeveloped land in the future when undeveloped land becomes more rare, etc.) Agricultural value is a bit of a shortcut phrase to be honest, but it fits in the literature and history of how cities developed.

It's not about restoring land to agricultural use, it's about how land converts fron undeveloped to developed. 

You can expand a city by developing its outskirts (i.e. city chooses to increase the space it considers incorporated by adopting unincorporated land) OR by performing infill development where undeveloped pockets (i.e. the owners of land strategically purchased it but left it undeveloped because it was the best value) become developed (or re-developed in the case of tearing down small buildings to build bigger ones). 

Even though the 2nd option doesn't directly involved agricultural land prices; it should be clear that in the context of opportunity cost, the agricultural value of unincorporated land plays a key role in deciding between expansion, infill, or re-development.

Quants often have unconscious incompetence with qualitative data. They see it as a natural language processing problem at worst, "if we throw enough BERT at it we'll extract features and make this a quant problem".

Being in public health consulting, I am surrounded by qualitative data. Public comments on medication policy, narratives on disease transmission, site visit reports, the list goes on.

Not once has NLP reduced the number of problems the health experts had. Regular expressions? Super useful great feature engineering. 

But NLTK? Gensim? Sentiment analysis? 

Really just complicates the issue. 

Obviously, sometimes more problems is a good thing if it gets you better solutions, I'm not knocking NLP. 

But the information isn't in the data. The information is in how the data can serve the information the experts have in their heads about causality, potential mitigation strategies, thematic fit to the literature, etc.

Not saying AI doesn't have its use cases for qualitative data, it definitely does, I've managed product development for supporting qualitative analysis at scale and trust me- the math isn't the hero of the story.

The science we have is based on specific clinical trial dosages and we should stick to that against nearly all other odds. Any misstep is too much right now.

Bonus tips to win Monopoly:

- mortgage before you trade. Just to force people to burn cash to un-mortgage. No discounts.

- early/mid game pay to get out of Jail immediately, it's a token amount of money and rolling doubles is the same chance as rolling a 7 but generally a worse position to be in (you don't want to travel the board without buying properties) 

- in late-game, stay in jail the maximum amount of time possible if all the land is already developed. 

- offer people complex deals including: 

   - 1 or 2 turn immunity / rent insurance included in a trade when they're near your developed land.

   - insurance on home destruction on land you trade them (if they ever have to sell a house you'll match the bank's payment of half it's cost). 

- offer to pay their next jail visit if they're 6-8 spaces away from go to jail (alert them they're 6-8 spaces from Go to Jail)

- trade people low value land in exchange for immunity / rent insurance on their most developed land, especially if you're 6-8; 13-15 away.

For those curious how an Economist plays monopoly:

- Buy everything you land on 
- offer other players 2-5x what they paid for anything they land on as early as possible cash has no meaning and you can always mortgage. 
- once you have a set of 3, use 4 houses, not hotels. There are a limited number of houses in the game, lock out other players ASAP. Although this makes street repairs more expensive and reduces marginal revenue, the lock out effect is critical until you can bankrupt a player. 
- the best spaces are the spaces 6-8 squares after Jail, and Then 6-8 after Go.
- the worst spaces are those 6-8 squares after Go to Jail square
- don't be afraid to overtrade for your 2nd square of a set, especially if you're 6-8 squares away from what would be your 3rd of the set, people (rightly) hate giving people their 3rd, but underestimate the probability that you'll land on a spot 7 squares away.

A robust debate on sustainable economics is worth having but I think you've misunderstood me. The planet resources are limited and are replenished at at a rate either not in control by people (or in most instances frankly, actively harmed by people). I agree entirely with this. 

Technological growth (labor multipliers) would include increasingly efficient uses of natural resources. (Or in any case, more efficient extraction methods).

But we aren't creating more land or water or oil or similar, so Economic growth isn't going to be a function of creating resources, it's just going to be a function of extracting and using them which is generally considered part of labor multipliers.

I think we both agree on the fundamentals though, our growth required capitalism is not sustainable and we either need to change the planet (find a new one to exploit), or learn to live within the planets means (sustainable economics).

Some of the key initiatives at the federal level in terms of AI include: 

Deep research on Adversarial Networks & Adversarial AI

Example: Can you trick a satellite imagery based AI model into incorrectly tagging illegal Nuclear refinement facilities as hospitals by painting a big H on the roof?
