Hey Greg, you may appreciate our first of several papers touching on this topic. What people are calling ML in Production, we try to think about as a culture of AI as a Laboratory of ideas. 

AI, Data and Cloud are intimately linked. (MLOps / AiOps, DevOps)

Successful data science (the kind that makes good outcomes for customers): 

- has control over the data used and the environment where that data is analyzed and modeled (buzzwords: Cloud, Version Control, Infrastructure as Code, Data Version Control, CI/CD, APIs, etc.) 

- has self service in both provisioning of infrastructure (can you get a custom VM without anything more than a ticket to IT? Is that ticket automatically approved if it passes certain tests?) and using production models (can a salesperson interested in a specific type of client both filter available data to that client and also apply production models to that just that subset?) 

- has security and controls ("AAA", role based controls, etc.) 

AI that misses on Data and Cloud is in my experience a primary reason that data science doesn't end up affecting (positively or negatively!) Customer experiences. 

https://www.linkedin.com/posts/crmercado_creating-an-ultimate-ai-lab-activity-6729492378392117249-71x4

You may enjoy reading about the successful data curation efforts at companies like Spotify (Lexicon) and AirBnB. 

https://engineering.atspotify.com/2020/02/27/how-we-improved-data-discovery-for-data-scientists-at-spotify/

https://medium.com/airbnb-engineering/democratizing-data-at-airbnb-852d76c51770

The idea being that by increasing the visibility of successful datasets you essentially create that Pareto 20% of datasets that get you 80% of value, and more resources can be spent ensuring that those primary, high impact, regular use datasets are clean, interpretable, and friendly at all level of users. 

To do that you need successful enterprise knowledge management (the ability to understand nuances of local domains quickly) and developer knowledge management (the ability to understand nuances of past artifacts quickly).


My non-committal belief is that plenty of people can look at data and generate insights, even if the vast majority can't appropriately create, shape, and manage data. This is where you want that fundamental divide in the engineering of data and the analytics of it.

Alec Campanini  the democratize AI movement generally believes that anyone in an org should be able to access an appropriate amount of data on the org (role based access) and numerous preset analyses/models (typically created by data scientists and made available as self-service). The idea being that if the models are documented well enough that any end user can, for example, run a (pre parameterized) random forest algorithm on their data pull and get curated results (e.g. a pop up infographic would have boiler plate explanation for how relative importance is captured by the trees) and how to interpret coefficients. 

This is really just 1 step up from Excel -> OLS -> infobox detailing how to interpret slope coefficient 

I'm not sure where I fall on the spectrum of this versus "no analysis by anyone not named an analyst". 

Realistically, everyone performs analysis and leverages AI everyday constantly without thinking about it (Google search is just an AI librarian after all). 

So it's hard to be a gatekeeper here to be honest. And I don't do internal data science, so I'm probably not the right person to recommend anything on this topic.

What I've done successfully is spend extra time upfront working on the template and explaining what my code will look for to extract information. Examples: 


I'll know it's the last column of your table because the N'th+1 column will be completely blank. So don't add notes to the right of your data, if it's not 100% blank, I'll spit out *this* error to remind you. 

I'll know to ignore the top metadata area because I won't start reading a table until I see a 100% blank row above the table. 

The headers need to be consistent, so I'll force the program to make everything lowercase and we can fix it in the visualizations. 

Etc etc.

Common problems with Excel workflows: 

1) nested headers 

Just don't do this. You end up having to read it all as characters, then attach the nest as a prefix to the 1st row (the actual headers) and then replace them and then re-class the columns. It's just setting up a bad programming session for a developer.

2) merged cells
Not normally a big deal because it can just be duplicated across cells when it's unmerged but it often leads to 3. 

3) inconsistent templating
Adding columns, changing column names, changing the amount of cells merged, adding in blank rows to separate things visually, doing ad-hoc NAs (NA, N/A, n/a, -999, Not Applicable - I've seen all of these serve as NAs within a SINGLE Excel file once), hidden sheets, changing the order of sheets, changing the name of sheets. 

All of these things make actually *working with* Excel incredibly difficult because you've designed for anti-scaling. I just have to assume you're scared that following a template and being a team player with the analytics people would cut you out of a job ü§£. 

I've done plenty of R Shiny apps that read explicitly designed Excel templates and I spend probably 20-30% of my development time writing warnings for different template errors.

The fact the residuals are so easily modeled by the predicted value would indicate there's some structural problem with the model. When residuals aren't random, you've typically omitted a variable (s) or chosen a poor modeling structure (e.g. went linear when the truth is polynomial).

In the context of this being an XGBRegressor model though, I don't have any specific comment on why this is the way it is. Frankly, I've forgotten the math behind XGBRegressor lol.

That confusion is typically for identical inputs returning two different values (i.e. g(x) = (y, -y) ).

 This graph is showing the predicted value y-hat versus its residual. So for some inputs [X1, X2] => f(X1) = yhat1 = f(X2) = yhat2  but the corresponding truth Y is actually the opposite. F(X1) = y1 != F(X2) = y2. 

This can be the case for logistic regression which Adrian pointed out. Where you have some probability of either 0 or 1, two sets of inputs can return 1 when modeled, while their true values are 1 and 0. 

This is how you would get the same predicted value (e.g. 0.5 from LR which needs a cutoff for binary classification) while the residuals be opposite for the same yhat.

Duplicated from comment: 

7,000+ resumes reviewed by 480+ recruiters and resume experts. 

2 pagers consistently ranked higher EVEN AT THE ENTRY LEVEL, even when they *self-admitted* that 1 page is best and 2 pages is only for the most experience. 

Again, never assume people truly know their own preferences. 

I like 1 page things cause it's less reading- but I like 2 page things when I want to have extra information to assess something. 

Another bias that might be hidden here is the mere exposure effect. Simply holding something (or seeing someone) for a longer period of time makes you biased towards liking it more. 

Now- naturally the counterpoint here is "Carlos- these people know they're in a study, they have all day to review these. It's not like they're at their job under a time constraint. When it counts they'll appreciate brevity".

That is a great counterpoint- one that you should seriously consider. 

The answer isn't to ignore this evidence and assume the evidence-less position. The answer is to make sure that if you do write 2 pages, it is actually engaging, informative, and a good sales document. 

https://www.resumego.net/research/one-or-two-page-resumes/

Available evidence points against this. This study identifies that 2 pages is the *revealed* preference of recruiters and hiring managers, although their *stated* preference is consistently 1.

That reads to me as a refined, public health version of the well known Economic principles around pollution, congestion, etc.   It's difficult to read that and know how little was done culturally to generate buy in for those kinds of economics preserving strategies.

And now we're in the worst season ever and fatigue is at its maximum and nothing innovative is happening even though we finally have a light at the end of a tunnel- which is typically when you'd expect the most cultural buy-in since we can now identify an end date to all this.

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Road_space_rationing

Public space rationing is a legitimate strategy for reducing negative externalities when used in *short bursts*. It doesn't work long term because strategies form to get around them. 

Anyway, I'm digressing, but there wasn't as much experimentation as there could have been. There wasn't as much subsidies as could have been done (e.g. grocery delivery, paying people to not work jobs that involve a lot of close contact traveling, etc.) 

There wasn't as much contact tracing, as much group testing, as much coordination across countries to test and validate specific strategies (i.e. EU keeping schools open, us closing them). 

It's a lot to learn for next time.

Economic value of a human life is worth roughly $2M-$10M in terms of government expenditures (this is aggregated across surveys ranging from lawsuit payouts, implied value based on human-years saved in government expenditures on certain time efficiencies, aggregate taxes paid, various benefit-cost analyses, etc.) 

I know it's not fun to say that but it's important to be aware of how governments tend to think in terms of balancing costs and human lives. 

Now that we have that number. We can pretty clearly and quickly say: $1200 per person to keep them safe during a pandemic was woefully inadequate. 

We could have subsidized wages directly, subsidized mortgages and rents, strategically closed down more strictly for shorter bursts, etc etc. 

Imagine if we went full shutdown every other week (subsidizing business costs in those weeks appropriately) in the early months of the pandemic.

New cases would have time to become symptomatic, improving the ability for people to self-regulate their exposure, making contact tracing easier. 

There were a lot of options we didn't consider and a lot more natural experimentation we could have leveraged (i.e. discovering indoor spread risks sooner).

Contact tracing could be focused in sprints.

I think the fact TFP AND GDP fail to reflect wikipedia's value is more a function of a metric failing to capture what it wasn't designed to capture. 

Wikipedia, stackoverflow, open source programming languages. They're driving entire industries like software development, data science, etc. When those industries are successful at *reducing waste* what we might expect to see from an economic measurement perspective is that firms actually do less discrete recorded purchases (e.g. paying a company to manage it's databases) and instead see that money spent on salaries (but only a fraction of it), new investments (again, some fraction of waste saved), and cash stored. 

Cash stored is *supposed* to be new investment elsewhere, such that it still counts in GDP somewhere, but unfortunately given the structural low interest rate environment we're seeing a pretty big breakdown of how the economy is measured. 

 I think we're miscounting, not missing growth in this decade.

In high school our psychology teacher asked us to visualize a poor family, using SNAP benefits or standing at a food bank line.¬†

The entire class (except me) drew caricatures. Black families, almost always overweight.¬†

I drew a Latino one, having grown up visiting the projects of Puerto Rico to stay with family in the summers, I was just drawing what I knew.¬†

Back then, as a kid, 6,8,9,11,13 years old, it wasn't weird to be sent to the store to buy cigarettes, beer, and lotto with welfare benefits.¬†

The psych teacher correctly assumed that we had these hidden biases around poverty and race, and shared with us that she (was white, midwestern heritage) had been on welfare and used food banks during 2 especially bad periods of her life for several months each stint.¬†

It blew the class's minds (our school was 90%+ white at the time) that a "regular" "moral" "normal" [these are codes for white presumably] person would ever rely on the social safety net.¬†

But I mean, that's what it's for right?¬†

You can do everything right, have all the potential in the world, and just get downright plain unlucky and need a hand up.¬†

Thanks for sharing, it's important for people to see that successful people can have "lows" (I mean, it's just poverty, we shouldn't moralize it. Sh*t happens, be cool about it).¬†

I'm going to echo that this post is worded in a dangerous way. It is totally fine to ask "why is this vaccine so successful so quickly"? 

The answers are: 

(1) it's novel but a lot of previous research in SARS has turned out to be useful. 

(2) the entire bureaucracy has prioritized this vaccine in a way no other public health crisis has ever been prioritized. We have government employees working 16 hour days to get the paperwork processes at maximum speed of approval while maintaining the highest safety standards. 

A bungled vaccine that doesn't work will cost TRILLIONS of more dollars than just getting it right the first time. It would be a collapse of the highest order, possibly unseen since the fall of the soviet union in terms of chaos and human life lost, if people en masse decided to let Covid-19 run its course through the population because they lost hope.

(3) unprecedented investment (both public and private) in not just money (Billions) terms but also people-time. These vaccine trials get literally 10s of 1000s of people willing to put themselves at risk to support it's development and really *good* candidates too. 

Normally it's people with extra time or need money who volunteer. We're getting better samples.

One day at a time. Just handle whatever is in front of you. And let yourself feel whatever you're feeling. Something I learned in a metacognition course before I dropped my philosophy goals was that ideas and feelings happen *to* you. You don't choose them, they are *not* YOU. You are the awareness choosing which items from the menu of ideas and feelings you want to actualize with actions.

So if you're feeling overwhelmed and manic, just let yourself feel that but try not to commit any *actions* based on them. Just sit, they'll pass eventually. The vast majority of human feelings have roughly a 20-min cap on how long you can feel them in one sitting. 

Things like grief, depression, despair, etc. of course will have multiple 20-mins within a day, even within an hour, but realistically, thinking about how you're feeling prolongs the feeling.

Metacognitive thinking (thinking about thinking) can allow you to just accept the wave, be patient until it passes, and then go back to what you were trying to do. 

A lot of people make the mistake of internalizing feelings. That because they *feel* something they *are* something. That's just not what modern brain science tells us. It's when feelings become actions that they become "me".

My point is that being able to take an issue and look at it thoroughly through different principles is critical for making tough, informed decisions and doing it in a way that preserves our ability to debate (in good faith) with people who disagree and reach compromise that makes a positive impact on people's lives even when it has negatives with it.

Part (4) if all the farmers are making corn then we get unintended consequences: 

- overproduction, which leads to waste including actual destruction of crops to keep prices stable (this is a real thing, we pay farmers to burn crops (strategically I should note) to stabilize prices and keep enough profits to keep the engine of innovation going.

- misplaced production, there's so much corn and they need to be used somehow because, I mean, who really *wants* to waste it just feels wrong. And then we get high fructose corn syrup and that gets put into every food imaginable and now we have an obesity and child diabetes epidemic.

- crowded out production, all that land used for corn that got burned and all that subsidy money wasn't spent on its next best use-case. The taxes that paid for that subsidy might have been the money someone was going to use to create a small business or go into farming themselves with a new idea that could have improved the whole industry. 

So now we have something like 2-1 or probably more like a 2-2 tie for the conservative vs liberal positions on this issue. 

No principle is *wrong* nobody is a *bad person* who wants to starve americans or kill the small farming industry. Its just tough decisions.

Part (3) so if the (neo)liberal compromise is to subsidize the food at production, then we get both lower costs to the consumer and enough profit for the corporation to innovate and lower food prices through efficiency of scale. 

Looks like it's somewhat tied now, 1-1, or maybe 1-2 because the neoliberal system is what is currently in place today. 

Deregulation and free market for something like food won't produce enough to keep costs low and that has political risks (we can look at how rising bread prices was a major catalyst of the Arab Spring that saw major civil unrest in multiple countries). And the current (neo)liberal system of subsidizing production and food stamps seems to be leading to enough food production and use that people are not starving en masse in the streets (although we do still have ~10-15% of people as food insecure in the US). 

Ok well then keep going to principles. 

Conservative principle says that whatever is incentivized gets done. The bureaucracy layer of the (neo)liberal position requires explicit laws and regulation to decide what production gets subsidized. 

If all the farmers are making corn then we get unintended consequences. (Part 4)

Part (2) Agriculture has a very steep efficiency curve. What takes a local farmer 2 acres to grow, a highly efficient mega-corporation may take just 0.1-0.5 acres. Plus, land is limited and there's lots of interesting side theories to google on how agricultural value of land serves as a limiting factor to city sizes and how there's history to understand in this argument.

That is to say, the best land for farming was probably absorbed by major cities historically and you can't farm where a building is. So there are limits to what the conservative principle can actually *output*. 

This efficiency of scale is critical for feeding a large population. So we get back to the conservative vs liberal principles. 

The conservative principle is that the price of goods should reflect whatever the market says. If food is expensive, well, it is what it is and people need to pay up, eat less, or eat worse. 

The liberal principle is that people have a right to some amount of food as mentioned above, but the bureaucracy layer is a major problem.

To reduce the bureaucracy layer, the government can instead of subsidizing food at the consumer level (food stamps) it can subsidize it at production. 

This is a kind of (neo)liberal compromise

I took a lot of philosophy in undergrad and in my embodiment of mind course they hammered in that memory is just knowledge you can access in negligible time. 

A person who carries a magic book that opens to the page with an answer of any question they have in their head immediately is indistinguishable from a person who memorizes the answer to all questions and takes a second to think about it. 

So the sooner we can accept that anything we can find on the internet within a few seconds is indistinguishable from what we have memorized, the sooner we can just stop memorizing things and instead memorize actions which actually accesses a much broader part of the brain. 

Once you're leveraging the action parts of your brain, things start to get scary fast and efficient.

There is no defensible way to say that people above some income are more deserving of financial opportunities than people below an income. 

It implies that any of this startup stuff is anything more than relationship building, networking, and taking enough shots that a few go in. 

WeWork bamboozled billions from sophisticated investors around the world. 

Looking into the history, it seems the foundation of the law are from a Securities Act of 1933. 

Nearly a 90 year old law! 

No wonder BIPOC are systematically less wealthy. They're locked out of systems that give them moonshots to intergenerational wealth.

I'm fine with there being rules around investment categories, I'm aware of the Series 65 certification. 

I'm fine with there being a $175 test fee and 50-60 hours of study. But I'm not fine with it being something only SOME people have to do. 

Make everyone do the exam if it's so important to keep people safe from themselves.

Just to add more detail on why this is so bad: 

(1) it's just plainly illogical. People can buy guns, have children, start businesses, without an income or wealth test. 

(2) it's a completely arbitrary amount of money. Why not have a a legal liability waiver than anyone can read educating them on the extremely high risk nature of the activity? 

(3) it enforces structural inequality. 

The best investments are RARELY after the Initial Public Offering (IPO). In reality when startups IPO it's because they've plateaued on value creation. The majority of top tech startups drop in value after their IPO for at least 2-3 years until they've found a profitable niche in the market. 

Look at Uber, it took over a year for that stock to break it's IPO of $40 (it's at $47 now) after plummeting 50% in its first 6 months. 

Waiting for IPO is not what the rich do. So why is it the only hope the poor have? (and yep, clearly 93% of us are poor, because only 7% make 200k+ a year according to the census.)

It'd be one thing if I wasn't the kind of investor they wanted. Too little funds, no strategic benefit for the startup, etc. But to be *legally* not even allowed to ask if I can join a crowdsource is just flabbergasting.

The U-3 unemployment rate has a few issues:¬†

The government should not be able to arrest someone for speech that does not directly incite violence.¬†

Private organizations serving as a platform for speech should be responsible and potentially liable for the results of the content on their platform and they have a duty to moderate the content and identify blatantly untrue speech because the potential for speech *at scale* (e.g. going viral) to incite violence (including stochastic terrorism).¬† ¬†

This is not new. Radio, television, newspapers, etc. are all under some constraints in terms of libel, slander, and unregistered foreign lobbying laws.¬†

Of course, there are distinctions in terms of the scarcity of the infrastructure in use (there are only so many slots on spectrums for radio, there are not really any limits on how newspapers could exist in theory. The supreme court has recognized these differences as relevant to speech).¬†

I think it's mostly inertia on cloud ‚òÅÔ∏è.

When the cloud is just "a computer in virginia" it's hard to see it's value over just doing data analytics and reporting locally. 

The value comes from: 

1) it's always available
2) complete isolated controls over access, authentication, and (oops forgot the 3rd A, there's a 3rd A in our paper LOL) 
3) decentralized development supporting alignment of development and production environments. 

The vast majority of companies don't need a bunch of elastic computing power running hundreds of terabytes of RAM in production in some fancy hybrid cloud structure. 

But they need to get past "email me this week's Excel file and I'll run my old script on my laptop". That works short term, but it doesn't scale and it's dependency mgmt hell. 

Its a paradox really. A wildly common problem I hear from clients is, "we need to build something that persists after the person who built it leaves" which is actually a huge pro-cloud argument, but they use it as a "don't make anything too fancy, keep it in Excel" argument. 

Combined with lack of capabilities in cloud, APIs, servers, databases, containerization, etc. It's a tough transition to make. 

This tech should be part of the data literacy movement.

I wouldn't describe the poll problems as p-hacking. 

Poll problems include: 

(1) arbitrary weighting schemas to force representativeness (this is extremely difficult to do well and is probably the primary source of polling errors)

(2) non representative sampling
People who answer the phone for random numbers might just be fundamentally different than people who do. They may systematically be distrustful of others and have a different split of ideologies. Can't really fix this lol. 

(3) Herding. Nobody wants to be the polling place who has Biden +35 in Texas. But good pollsters post their outliers because sometimes when you do sampling you just accidentally sample a non-representative group. 

(4) small sample sizes. 

My personal opinion is that polls need to double and maybe triple their sample sizes. Everytime I see a poll with 800 person samples I just feel dumbfounded. There are more than 10 types of people when you cross gender, age group, race/ethnicity, background, education, location, ideology etc. 

So in reality, your 800 person poll has at most 20-80 of each possible "type" of person (if we accept the premise that people can be bundled into "types") so the margins of error are probably WIDER than they report.

The fundamental theory of stocks is that the price is simply the net present value of it's expected stream of dividend payments.

If you believe this, then stocks cannot be cheap or expensive, they are simply a single number assessment of how a company is forecasted to make dividend payments. Any deviation is just noise or arbitrage or market correction in progress.

Of course, in reality, we know that stocks signal more than that, they often act as an investor confidence index. Low confidence, switch to cash, otherwise put the money back in stocks.

To that end, we can use stocks as a proxy for people's confidence around uncertain events. Even if those confidences are "accurate" (e.g. world will collapse) they could be incorrectly calibrated (the world barely collapsed and will only be down for a few days). 

This gives 2 opportunities to make money. (1) off the people who are wrong and (2) off the people who are correct but exaggerated. 

So can stocks be "cheap"? 

Yes, if the market is correct but exaggerated or if the market is just plain wrong than a stock can be priced under it's intrinsic value.

Yes, I think people misunderstand that pride in being irish, or Italian, or English, etc. Is all well and good, there's culture and history and food and language to celebrate. 

In the US, black people rarely have the ability to take pride in being Senagalese, or Ethiopian, or Kenyan, etc. Their culture and history and food was distorted through the diaspora. 

Black pride is pride in-spite-of not being able to better identify with a specific peoples or culture. And without a singular "place", e.g. how Puerto Ricans like me can claim the island, the only thing left to do is to take pride how your people have managed to survive and adjust to segregation and exploitation. 

"White" pride doesn't make sense when you *do* get to know your more specific and more accurate culture and history of a peoples.

The second issue I see is "American" pride- which I have, in spite of the craziness sometimes I think the USA is on to something with this experiment of ours, is that people will use American pride to exclude people who were critical in building the USA: black people, chinese people, and immigrants and many other countries. No it's not definitionally unsustainable it's just difficult to sustain. 

I can go into a bunch more detail, but the thing to google is Malthusianism. The idea (was/is) that fixed renewable resources (e.g. how much the Earth can replenish per year) serve as a cap to human population and consumption. 

The truth is that historically we've managed to use technology to become ever more efficient in food production and consumption such that we've managed to have 7B+ people, the vast majority of which were born only in the last 100 or so years. 

The theory behind economic growth is that growth is fundamentally a function of: population growth and technological growth. 

(Picketty in Capital in the Twenty First Century details a similar parallel theory, that if the rate of return on capital exceeds these two growths as well, income inequality grows). 

Technological growth is a generally fuzzy word not strictly meaning computers, it just means efficiency gains through better use of resources including labor, good management would be a technology. 

We can have less people, but reducing our consumption reduces our income (my dollar spent is your dollar earned) and managing the resulting scale-down of the economy would be disastrous.

Rowan Schaefer specifically the setup.  And honestly, any language is going to be easy or hard based on your previous experience with similar experiences. Pretty regularly I see people with certain Java/C backgrounds prefer Python and people with sas/stata backgrounds prefer R. 

Python is easy to read but dot notation can be confusing for people along with OOP. I know some VBA heads that do like Python for this reason. 

My brain is much for FP in which case R just fits easier for me. 

Both of my mentees are R users, 1 of them is doing engineering in undergrad and took Java and C courses (like my experience, those courses were essentially worthless in terms of long term applied learning) but much prefers R do to easier setup and better fit into how he thinks. 

I don't want to make it a social science vs hard science thing, but that seems to be a common fault line.

R is much easier for step 0, but python is more popular and used outside of data science extensively (e.g. web development, software engineering, even mobile app development has some python modules). 

With R, you just do R/RStudio. With Python you have to set up your environments, use command line to install modules, sort out which IDE to use and its super annoying to do interactive consoles. You end up just using notebooks which really isn't the best way to learn in my opinion.

15 minutes is not an unreasonable request. I agree. But the reality is that you are selling the job to someone who doesn't *have awareness* of that job. 

Let's just switch the context to sales, 

"In the majority of cases, the buyer will get a cost reduction or value-add that greatly exceeds the commission the salesperson gets for helping them". 

This is 100% true, everything I've ever sold was a value-add that exceeded the cost of 15mins to the buyer. But nonetheless, I still have to jump through a bazillion hoops to get them to agree to a demo, agree to get my emails, agree to talk to me, etc. Because they don't have awareness of my product, and I have to build that awareness for them to even fit it into their head. 

I mean, clearly your successful at your methods and do this full time, so I'm not trying to tell you what to do. 

But as someone who recruiters reach out to, the ones that give me everything upfront are the ones I am most willing to talk to because they've signaled, "here's everything you need to know, but know that I have even more that you might want to know" and then I get to talk to them as individual people without having to do the run-around on salary, etc.

I think you're coming from an internal data infrastructure experience and I'm coming from a data consulting experience.  I've never been in an organization where scientists and engineers are discrete roles with transformation allocated to a particular specialty. In consulting we just do everything clients need and the team is pretty fluid and ad-hoc. Of course, because of this, I do most of my data science in the very early stages of the maturity curve. 

My point in anti-algorithms is that I'd rather teach models based on use cases and how they work and what the results are and how to read particular outputs. 

As opposed to sitting down and learning the proof behind it, doing all the math by hand, performing matrix algebra by hand, etc. That's how I learned all my econometrics and it sucked and I really didn't learn much after the tests. 

Maybe anti-algorithm was poor phrasing though. You do need to understand how the optimizations are made and what the parameters are, etc.

I'd focus on a domain first; otherwise it's too overwhelming. For me, it's urban economics. 

https://www.academia.edu/36570119/Lectures_on_urban_economics 
This book is great for understanding how our cities follow a variety of economic theories of development. 

From there, you can either focus on self-study through QGIS with a book like:  https://books.google.com/books/about/Thematic_Cartography_and_Geovisualizatio.html?id=P_URAQAAIAAJ

To practice cartography and map-making ("front-end" focus) and understand some history and best practices. 

Or you can take an online specialization that has more "back-end" focus on server-side GIS.  

I haven't taken this specialization and it uses ArcGIS (not QGIS, but no biggie), but UC Davis is a good school and based on my reading of the course outline, I'd be comfortable recommending it. 

https://www.coursera.org/specializations/gis

Well if you have mobile experience, you can try and lean into that and look into cell phone telemetry and how GIS uses cell phone data to understand movement and concentration patterns of people. That's a growing domain.
Just focus on what your goal is and let the skills only start mattering when you're constrained in getting to your goal. I've managed to go years without Python ü§£.

I'd recommend someone interested in GIS study Python, ArcGIS and QGIS. Then they could splinter and focus on more data viz and learn Adobe Illustrator and JavaScript. Or focus on data engineering and learn SQL and get AWS certified. The ability to make standalone interactive websites with really aesthetic interactive maps is so under-resourced right now.

Tobler's law says places closer together are more similar than places farther apart. 

The modifiable area unit problem says that all phenomenon the happens at individual level is definitionally distorted when aggregated up and that these area units (e.g. census tract, county) themselves have historic reasons to have bias and are typically arbitrary in nature. 

Spherical Geometry shows us that all 2D maps have distortions. 

Simpsons paradox says the statistics about individuals and statistics about groups of those same individuals are not fundamentally correlated or predictable. The trend line of individuals could be positive but the trend line for clusters of those individuals be negative. Now imagine what that means for every heat map at the state level you've ever seen...

Continued -- it's not just big players like Google maps. The open source community is heavily involved in mapping. Open street maps for example, or participatory mapping in the developing world. Big business is involved especially around cell phone data. The government is involved with GPS and satellites.

Small and medium sized businesses are finding a market for themselves through optimized route calculations, distance matrices, geocoding, drive time radiuses, traffic tracking, etc. All available through cheap APIs.

There's so many potential subdomains to specialize in too. Of course, there are experts there already, many looking to learn data science too which is awesome. But there will be openings as it grows and it's so high impact. 

I highly recommend people look into geospatial analytics specifically and study some cartography.
AutoML will be great for those using Excel or Power BI who just want to have a forecast of sales or work with very simple tabular data with a very clean Y variable.

Well there's a lot of flavors of data science which I think is explained well. It's all about your goals and target industries and studying which skills are actually used in your desired industry. 

If you want to do data science for international heath, AWS / Docker / Spark probably is the wrong target technologies, but if you want to do retail Analytics, those are great technology choices. 

It'd be inappropriate to give everyone the same exact list of tools to learn and in what order.

RE: data engineering. I consider that "back-end" data science and would purposefully not cover it in much depth to instead focus on front end and communication. 

Although having said that, I think 1 week to discuss common infrastructure and setups so that students can at least name critical technologies and services used in data engineering is worthwhile. Even if they don't do it themselves.

I'd teach R, Power BI with an emphasis on using R inside it for data transformation, and then SQL basic with connecting to SQL in R. 

As for algorithms, I'm anti-algorithms in general. I'd focus on business case studies, simple models that add value, and the rapid googling skills for when you do want to get more advanced.

"miss leading [sic] and snacks [sic] of dishonesty. Per capita is the correct way to measure the death toll from any event" <- 

Your statement of X/Y is the *correct way* for *any* event is what I was referring to by my use of the word "this", when I said "this is the strangest lie..." 

Its a common misunderstanding in data interpretation that per capita is the *only* way to understand a phenomenon. The reality is it is one of several ways to understand a phenomenon. 

Including: 
Coefficients of inequity (how phenomenon affects different groups) 
Per capita
Per household 
Adjusted weightings (e.g. standardizing differences in state level demographics like age prior to reporting, or more common seasonal adjustment). 

Again you're coming at this looking to fight. Ian presented raw numbers, yes he chose which events to include and exclude but nonetheless the numbers as presented are generally considered to be correct in magnitude. 

You can interpret these as saying, "this pandemic is on par with these events in terms of humans harmed" or "how humanity as a whole was harmed" and there's a fruitful debate to be had in doing so. 

I'm pointing out that the idea that raw numbers are dishonest is not true.

My last point said a little more quickly. 

If some says the value is X. 

And you say, "you're a dishonest idiot lefty, you should be saying X/Y". 

I'm not here to tell you X/Y is wrong. I'm here to tell you X has value, X/Y might also have value, but anytime you engineer a feature (here the choice to divide by Y) you are adding complexity and that must be done on purpose and you cannot forget the: 

Ecological fallacy
Modifiable area unit problem
Per capita fallacy 

Because it is entirely possible, that X/Z is even more useful than X/Y. 

It all depends on context and the decision making framework that you are in. 

You will have a much more informed discussion when you can flexibly understand when and where and how normalization is useful instead of thinking there's only 1 way to do it and anytime you don't do it there's dishonest lefty fraud.

Sigh. You all are committed to missing the point. Yes populations change. Yes per capita can be useful. I've never said they weren't useful. 

I said that raw numbers and normalized figures both have value. 

But people are insisting that anything that is not normalized is worthless and that is just a factually bad take. People are saying comparing raw numbers is "dishonest". No, it's just the numbers, it's the reality, it's the most compact form of information. 

Normalization is not a panacea. 

Example, it could be argued WWII deaths should not be considered per capita, because men were disproportionately sent to war. You could consider per household instead to better understand the loss. (comparing WWII to non-wars). 

Households change over time, so even that has issues. 

My point is not that posting a bunch of raw numbers is like some amazing thing that the OP did. My point is that the raw numbers are what they are. If you want to add nuance to the conversation through per capita, per household, per adult male, per labor force, or % change in GDP, or w/e. Go for it. Add nuance. 
I explicitly said "212,000 / 330M is fine for context". 

I'm just explaining a common fallacy in data interpretation. Not here for politics.

That is not true.   Normalization is a choice much like presenting raw numbers is a choice. 

There are legitimate reasons to not normalize data. 

Yes, more numbers can add context, e.g. 210K / 320M. But normalization without using thinking is a big problem in data science, raw figures can be extremely useful features. 

Recommended googling: 
Ecological fallacy
Modifiable area unit problem
Per capita fallacy

There is no such thing as dying "purely" from anything. Hopefully this article can explain in simple terms how big of a deal this is, so that nonsense talking points you clearly got from Fox News can be dispelled. 

https://hub.jhu.edu/2020/09/01/comorbidities-and-coronavirus-deaths-cdc/
Excess Deaths show our numbers are likely an undercount.

This is the strangest lie told about data.

Normalization is a *choice*, there are a variety of reasons you wouldn't use per capita metrics. For instance, understanding how many *more* could suffer. 

212,000  / 330M is fine for context, but normalization in small areas, (e.g. deaths / 100K people) can mess up interpretability when, for example, 80% of counties don't even have 100K people. 

It's not misleading. Raw numbers are raw numbers. There's no requirement to add other numbers or divide or do anything. 

Some keywords to google for more info: 

Ecological fallacy
Modifiable area unit problem
Per Capita fallacy

The major argument against abolishing the EC is that "mob majority" is bad; but the reality is: 

Current system disenfranchises people by state. Republicans don't have any reason to bother voting in CA and that's *bad*. They deserve proportional representation. 

It only takes 24% of the population to get 50 senators and that's bad, as already discussed extensively by Alexander Hamilton in his federalist papers detailing his issues with the Senate body as a whole. 

We should: 

Make more house seats, 1 house seat per 50,000 people, so that dense neighborhoods can get fair representation. 

Make senate 2 minimum, but have some high threshold for additional senators (e.g. 1 per 1M population). 

Small states and rural areas have unique needs and deserve to be represented, possibly even lightly overrepresented by population, but minority rule doesn't work. 

The EC is the ultimate minority rule.

Example story: 

Client has a regulatory mandate to ensure their customers have access to client facilities or else the client would have to do the legwork and find 3rd parties to provide coverage. 

"Access" is a difficult word, and it's being defined as drive time distance. 

Well, if you've ever worked with spatial data, you know it's not as simple as just doing all possible routes in a distance matrix and then subsetting to those within range. That's both computationally and financially expensive. 

I racked my brain for a few days on this problem because (1) we were only at the proof of concept phase so I couldn't assume money was coming and (2) there just had to be a way to get this through some big company (i.e. Google) API. 

Luckily, because I spend so much time attending vendor webinars and reading miscellaneous stuff, I remembered a smaller company that specializes in "small" GIS and looked into their APIs. 

Lo and behold, they had not only the exact product I needed, but a generous, free, and well documented API. I had the proof of concept done within a few weeks and now I'm telling everybody about Mapbox and their tech will be a major boost to our GIS capabilities for years to come.

I'm not sure that small companies are systematically getting taken advantage of by cloud. 

The free tiers tend to be generous, and costs only really start hurting when you are making mistakes: putting the wrong amount of data on the wrong storage servers, paying tons of money for downloading data you didn't actually need, running experiments chaotically without a plan, excessive model training, etc. 

I would agree that small companies are disproportionately at risk of making mistakes, but hopefully their size also serves as a cap for how big a mistake they can even make. 

There's tons of free training on these platforms, they have billage warnings, caps, optimization guidance, etc. 

I'm just not sure I buy that the tiny players are what AWS is making tons of money of off. I'd assume 80%+ of profit is coming from the big power-users that are likely subsidizing services small companies use like customer service, free tiers, etc.

It's critical that multiple models are in use in parallel and regularly tested against each other to identify structural issues that may be explainable, i.e. models with deep lags in their autoregression may quickly bounce back once pre-covid falls out of the lags being used.

I wish there was more space available. But I've found that the people who take the notes and are able to maintain continuity of flow across meetings have a lot of say into the direction of decision making. This is of course a bit dangerous ü§£ but nonetheless an important role that people should look to contribute to.

We see this in open source all the time. If the goal of a 1000 individuals is to make a specific package hit user targets, those 1000 individuals can make autonomous contributions that add to the whole goal. 

If the goal is some ephemeral thing like, "make it the best at X feature, no make it the best at Y feature", you get conflicts and in tech terms again, you get "forks". 

Forks are when people will copy/paste everything up to a certain point and agree to go separate directions after that. 

Companies need trusted, autonomous groups making local decisions that inch everyone toward the same goal. Add up all the inches, you get miles.
If you misalign departments, you can't be surprised when they decide to fork and pursue their goals separately. 

Which of course, is completely dysfunctional when company departments can't actually split off, you end up with "outsourcing" entire competencies. 

You can't outsource sales or marketing or IT. Those are core corporate competencies. The companies of the future will have: 

- everyone as a sales person
- everyone as a marketer 
- everyone as a techy. 

Because they'll be seen as competencies to incentivize. Your next big sales idea may come from someone NOT in sales. That's innovation.

I'd just add that taking (calculated) risks is something that can set you apart as a junior. 

Propose radically different answers, make a hypothesis and check it out a bit before bringing it up so that when people ask you qualifying questions about your ideas you can say, "I lightly checked out X and I think there's something there". 

Also, just general advice, be the most prepared. 

Read all the attachments to the meeting invite, in their entirety, bring questions, bring additional research that you thought would be relevant to the conversation.

Here's a mix of answers and redefining some questions:

1. Probably not something you should worry about early on. You may end up in an internal role. You may not be working business development at all. 

2. What is the *problem* statement. Identify your ideal data, then identify what's the closest you have to it. What data do you collect? How do you collect it? What are the known issues with collection? How do you store what you collect? Is it 100s of xlsx, is it Access, is it S3? Is it structured? Is it on SQL Server? Is it relational? Is it graph? 

2b. What technology stack do you invest in? JupyterHub? RConnect? Anaconda? Wild west everyone on their laptop doing whatever? Do you use Azure DevOps? Enterprise Git? AWS? 

3. What is the data science hierarchy? Is the data science team embedded in the domain (i.e. marketing, sales, manufacturing) or is it centralized and the same people work across domains? What is the expectation around how autonomous individual data scientists are with choosing models and process and dealing directly with stakeholders (as opposed to through a designated stakeholder representative). 

4. Will vary by project, don't stress about this. Learning the business is important but see (1).

Random notes: 

RDA objects are weird, recommend RDS. I've noticed that RDAs rely on where they exist on a computer to be read (I can't send someone an RDA and expect it to work, RDS doesn't have this problem). 

Something to do with serialization, above my compsci knowledge. 

Also, you should try to get into the habit of versioning packages with tools like renv at the project level. 

I try to ensure every project has its own private library to avoid mix/match and deprecation. R version really should not be relevant to how you worry about package installations. Package installing really isn't too bad, even the big ones like BH take just a few minutes for each project. 

You'd be shocked how dplyr can conflict with other packages, plus adding in risks associated with critical packages like BH and Rcpp, etc. Much better to get at the root of the problem and make private libraries for each project.

My point about socializing some fraction of the costs is that education was state funded for decades and then student loans became a blank check industry. It's irrational all around to privatize the cost of a social good. Everyone benefits when the population is more educated.

Date: And we know this is true because we have consistently funded and expanded socialized education for decades for children 4-18. Now experiments are showing benefits as early as 2 for socialized education.

Message:
The numbers do not bear this out at an aggregate level. 80% of jobs from 2008-2014 were filled by people with at least *some* college. 

The possibility of an event does not mean we should ignore averages and distributions that show significant risk and costs correlated with not going to college.

It would be tremendously (and maybe where we agree- arbitrarily) difficult to get numerous jobs out there without a degree. 

Does this mean degrees are the only way to get skilled and education? Of course not. This is blatantly true. 

But if a system has a bias towards people who got a university to stamp a piece of paper for them, then we'd be lying to put our heads in the sand and pretend the bias isn't relevant to life-planning. 

We should acknowledge it and actively dismantle degree bias and push for wider acceptance of alternative proof of skills while socializing some fraction of the burden for people experiencing the bias.

Emma Horton oh for sure, I'm saying go around resumes entirely. I'd like to see better guidance and education (publicly funded) on how to sell yourself as a business. Resumes are not it, and 100% agree shiny resumes with the optimized taglines are just a wealth test. 

Wealth tests are ubiquitous in hiring. We get judged on our names (race/gender), education (nationality/wealth), etc all based on that 1 piece of paper which barely correlates to doing the job effectively. 

I'd like to see recruiting scaled down tremendously where jobs get <50 applicants because the job ads are actually written well, in depth, and correctly representative of the job. 

Until we get there, we can't be pikachu-face surprised when 700 people apply because all of the internet is reminding people, "JDs are a wish list, apply anyway, even with just 50% of the reqs".

Fair points, I think we can say both: 

(1) people need to take more responsibility in being a business of size 1 in selling themselves

 and 

(2) businesses need to have human centered design in their recruiting practices because how people apply to your jobs heavily impacts your brand recognition overall. 

Without conflicting. I agree that there shouldn't be complaining that you're getting interest, but I do think it's a fair criticism that people: 

 (1) apply to anything without really trying 

This is bad not only because it inundates companies, but also because it doesn't work and it's the path of least resistance. I can pump out 100 bad applications and collect unemployment and complain nobody is hiring and feel righteous anger about the system. 

(2) apply to things they aren't actually a good fit for. 

This just wastes time all around and at best is a result of desperation (if you ask me my personal opinion, I think we're rich enough as a country that we should separate basic survival from employment) and at worst is unemployment fraud. 

Again, see my personal opinion before anyone thinks I'm inhumane. I've been desperate on the job hunt before. It's terrible, anxiety ridden, stressful, and honestly cruel.

Stop being in the crowd is the fundamental advice. 

I've done lots of possibly sketchy things to get around this problem. Some listed here, 

https://www.linkedin.com/posts/crmercado_breakingintodatascience-datascience-jobs-activity-6707771662827438080-kKfS. 

In reality, people make the same mistakes on the job search: 

(1) They don't target roles ahead of time and build relationships before they need them. This causes them to apply to anything even lightly related to their goals, which leads to the *requirement* that they template everything, but templating everything also reduces your win % to near 0. 

Complete catch-22, but also completely avoidable. 

(2) They don't exploit (I mean this word positively) the human bias towards stories and narratives. They detail all the tasks they've ever done instead of telling 2-5 relevant stories that implicitly show they have the skills needed.

I like this wording a lot and it's very true. We're not used to: 

1) immediate feedback - this can be stressful because we mentally think the amount/speed of feedback is proportional to the difficulty of the problem. When in reality, a 5 hour problem and a 25 hour problem often have the same length of error code. 

2) lack of an expert - I often find entirely new bugs that aren't covered in documentation. I then have to break down each bug into its components to discover I actually have 1 (solveable) bug but it's return causes a bunch of derivative errors and those are the ones I see first. 

There's no expert just readily available to read your code and tell you the problem. School teaches us there's always an expert and the answer is readily available but being explicitly withheld from us to learn something. 

The reality of programming is, the answer is never withheld, possibly available, but rarely readily.

A completely different (and better) learning paradigm.

Oh man, I try not to think about Giffen goods too much. 

Being so broke that increasing prices for bread destroy your whole budget. You then can't even afford your token amounts of SPAM for variety anymore, so the only option is to commit to only eating bread and now you're buying more of something as the price goes up. 

The cause of many riots and revolutions. 

Alternatively, for luxury goods where price is a signal of quality/prestige, it is possible a price raise crosses a psychological threshold that leads to the good being more valued and increasing in sales. This is not as studied as poverty goods in the literature but its possible.

Your question translated to Economics is: "what if the good is highly inelastic, does this affect the substitution effect in general".  

Where inelastic means, the price must change drastically to change the demand for it (often governments even get involved in inelastic goods when they're essential to minimize predatory pricing). 


The answer is still it depends. Gasoline for example is highly inelastic, you can't put anything else in cars. 

But there is always substitution, for gasoline it's public transportation/walking/etc.

For food it's often lower quality food (e.g. SPAM). 

Often these goods with high substitution and low income effects are known as "inferior" goods.

Things I've done when considering jobs: 

1) I had coffee with current employees doing the work before I even applied, once in the morning before an interview. 

2) I've gone to meet the company's client after interviewing and before the offer stage.

3) I've requested a shadow hour to go watch the work being done and with what tools and by which person.

I've had multiple people message me that they turned down offers from my team to go work somewhere with a fancier job description and title, just to find out on day 1 the work has 0 relation to data. 

I've had others ask how they can infuse more data analytics into their work after 4 years of doing non-analytics.

I've heard others wonder how to figure out which job descriptions are overselling the job. 

The answer is the same: 

Trust, but verify. 

Unless you're the first data person (which I highly recommend not doing that), there will be someone on the team you can talk to. 

If you read a job description, do the interview, avoid asking questions b/c you want to be "agreeable", and then you pikachu face when the work doesn't fit into your goals... That's on you. 

Take some responsibility on pushing and asking for evidence that the role fits your goals. You're a business!

Source runs an entire script, it's not just functions, this is useful for putting certain objects in certain environments all at once. 

Packages are the right unit you want, and calling them strategically let's the scoping automatically find functions (well, any object) across the environments.

I think packages would help you, packages are loaded as environments, so you can just work across different environments and keep functions strategically separate. Not totally understanding the use case if source() doesn't work. If you have very purposeful source() across scripts it's pretty easy to avoid overloading your global environment by calling them in specific orders.

Timothy Ushie summary of what I DM'd you. 

- you need to know companies that align to your values and goals (you have specified your values and goals right?)
- you identify people who are doing the work you want to do. 
- you connect with them and point them to your content they might benefit from 
- you make content that they continue to benefit from 
- when a job is posted at their company that you are a *great* fit for (don't waste time on poor fits just because you need a job any job) you can send them the link and ask them to talk about the role and a potential referral. 

If you've given them enough free value, they'll be inclined to say yes and help you. 

People will not help people for no reason. This is why it's critical to build your network when you *don't* need it.

Upon further reflection: I don't want to imply that organizations serving literally hundreds of millions of users don't know what they're doing. I would actually assume they're very good at this. 

Adding new features might be *purposefully* replacing old features because the old feature is no longer a good market fit (markets change). 

Adding new features might have short term negative effects but long-term positive effects (teaching the market how to do something better. Uh, hello, touch screens on cell phones anyone?). 

Adding new features might *augment* old features or even *revive* them. Story memories might make good feed posts in a year or so. 

There's always a calculus at play, so I don't want my post to be read as any ding on any service or product team. If anything, I hope its illuminating to how they think and what their worries are.

But that advice requires only a limited number of people do it, which makes the advice limited in usability. If no one did first 2 years at university, there would nowhere to transfer lol. 

Because the advice requires a subset of people to not take it, we know the problem is systemic. Individuals do not actually have the freedom to all, overnight, take that advice. 

It's like saying you can use a drill to put in a nail to hang a picture instead of a hammer and nail. Sure, but I'd actually be better off without a drill or a nail if I could just hang the picture using a command strip. 

What we need is for states to invest in universities, for universities to stop being football programs that teach on the side, and to scale up the best universities using technology. 

Why should only people who can afford Harvard get  a Harvard education. We should be recording and scaling those lessons and providing state sponsored support groups to copy/paste/edit those lessons to local audiences. Then we need independent review boards actually testing people on skills that prove to be *useful* in generating business value. 

The future is Udemy/Coursera. We should be accelerating that. Otherwise we're just putting bandaids on bullet wounds.

But even the students are sold on a specific vision from youth that you go to college to have "the experience" and then your network gets you a job. If community colleges had better corporate pipelines, people would go there. They just don't because its a systemic issue. 

I'm not saying the student couldn't make sacrifices on costs and experience; they deserve some marginal blame in terms of the options that were available to them; but its the system that limits their options. 

Why does every job require a bachelor's degree anyway? If I'm choosing between a bad sandwich or a bad burger, you have to start wondering why there isn't a better chef in the kitchen, even if you know I could theoretically get up and go out of my way to a different restaurant (whose food probably is just bad soup...)

We know it's the system because no private bank would give her 80k to start a business, and yet someone will give her 80k to study for 4 years with the hope of joining a business.

It's also the schools fault for pushing costs onto students when for the vast majority of their history they pushed costs to the state and local governments (good schools drive good taxpaying corporations to set up nearby, it's an *investment* not a cost...) 


Sure, are there cheaper schools, yeah, but remember that when you give advice, that advice needs to work for everyone to be useful. If everyone went to the cheap community colleges and took tests to waive courses, the universities would go bankrupt (like they already are). The universities are actively commiting fraud (look up law employment reports on this, schools will hire their own graduates for temp jobs to inflate their post graduate employment numbers). 

I get why someone would say, "she signed the papers", but come on, it's a coercion, if everyone suddenly woke up to the system's lies the system would collapse and you don't want that either. So don't make it about individuals if you know that too many individuals making a certain individual choice destroys everything.

Outdated Model + Infant Model = REAL problems with understanding how your users are navigating changes.

Every feature: 

*Adds new users* 
*Moves current users*. 

In economics this is called the income and substitution effects in action. 

When a feature adds new users that's good, but if it moves too many users, that can fill a previous feature. The lack of economists in product teams leads to this kind of disaster. 

Because new features move people off old features, the algorithm trained on old feature interactions become worse and the algorithms for the new feature need lots of time to get new data. 

Combine an outdated algorithm with an infant one and you get the exact problem you're describing.

Interesting point, I agree that a lot of tech expects the business to adopt and conform, instead of adopt and succeed. This is why I'm skeptical of most off-the-shelf solutions. In reality, businesses have some general problems (sales forecasts) and some specific problems (automating my process given a history of haphazard tool adoptions that all make sense for there individual pieces but don't actually combine together well). 

Why do companies have Tableau, Power BI, and Qlik? What will a 4th BI tool actually do for them? 

They have duplicative stuff because they have duplicative roles. This is on purpose, you can't have 1 of everything. But when you hire, you're hiring people with specific skills and that turns into X team prefers Tableau, Y team prefers Power BI, and it's prohibitive to choose one and transfer everyone and everything built in the last 3,5,10 years to the other one. 

Too many software companies are trying to be the 4th tech in the room, while selling themselves as the only tech needed. It's disjointed and doesn't work and adds headache. Better to discuss why some people will prefer the 4th tech, how the tech fits into the business as a 4th tech, and how the net value is profitable.

RMSLE is again all about business contexts. How do you want to reward over and under estimation? RMSE does so equally, RMLSE punishes underestimation more than overestimation. (Might have this flipped sorry, not looking at the definition right now). 

Similar to a cancer detection problem where you have to make trade-offs between false negatives and false positives (due to imbalanced data, cancer is luckily not 50% prevalent in a random sampling of people) RMSLE asks us to tradeoffs the penalty of being wrong (too little) with being wrong (too much). 

Not exactly an apples to apples comparison with sensitivity(recall)/Positive Predictive Value (precision), but it's a useful metric. 

But again, in terms of "targeting" errors for a model, I see RMSE/RMSLE as a different thing. 

I can look at a confusion matrix and say, "cut the accuracy, we need better recall", I can look at the RMSE and say, "our training and testing split is wonky, we need to do some better cross folding before the validation set". 

Those are different conversations and I think that's what I haven't articulated well when I said it's not an error metric. My point is that it's fundamentally different than accuracy and other goodness of fit measures.
Yes, Harpreet made that correction as well, which is a good point thanks for clarifying.

Large RMSE indicates that the true underlying data generation process is noisy. Stocks for example have a tolerance range of price where nobody thinks it's a signal. Nobody starts a panic sell off when AMZN drops $4 since the last hour. 

If a $1000 stock fluctuates $1 each hour, nobody is really thinking about it. 

If a $10 stock fluctuates $1 each hour, you'll have billions of dollars lined up trying to model that phenomenon and get arbitrage and algorithm equity to profit. 

So a $1 RMSE (RMSE is in the same unit as as the residual) isn't, by itself, a good measure of whether your model is accurate or not, it is simply stating the estimate for the noise behind the true data generation process. 

On the other hand, if your predicted values on testing data have some (higher) RMSE then I think what Harpreet Sahota was saying is that the RMSE on testing data can have some amount of value in gauging your model. I'd argue it's moreso a statement about the comparison of your training and testing data (in time series modeling which is where my example came from, it's pretty hard to split training and testing and ensure they have similar distributions due to autocorrelation).

Specifically linear models, but if I'm incorrect happy to hear how so. This was inspired by conversations I had with someone who had a "target" RMSE for assessing goodness of fit for their model, RMSE was not appropriate for his use case and this post is meant to detail how. I'm happy to hear how other models may use RMSE for a different purpose

Note: in many contexts, minimizing RMSE is a good thing, my point is that there is a true floor to your RMSE and forgetting this can send you down a rabbit hole of trying to hit a "target" RMSE, which may not be possible; whereas it's pretty possible hit a "target" precision or recall or accuracy, you just have to make the trade-offs. 

RMSE doesn't really have "trade-offs", which makes it a bad accuracy metric for business problems involving prediction.

I've reviewed a few dozen GitHubs, I look first for organization of repos (does it show git was actively used in development or are they just dumping code at the end), READMEs written for the appropriate audience in the appropriate form (narrative vs explanatory), I'd say roughly 10% of portfolios I've seen do this correctly, and then I pick whatever repo seems to be the most representative of their goals & interests (I generally ignore school/Bootcamp repos unless they are an independent capstone thing) and review the code. 

I don't really see gists used by the average programmer, it's mostly just ipynbs dumped in at the end with no structure to the experiment lol. Just random get data, throw neural networks at it, look my accuracy is amazing.

Well, READMEs should be blog posts, I might be confused because rereading your post (pre-edit) it seems to be implying that a single repo would act as a portfolio. This is typically bad practice (although I did it as a beginner!). 

Gists are snippets, they would have a minimal README, if any. You can collect a class of gists on a topic and put them in a repo and treat that as a type of documentation of sorts, but at that point, you're probably better off using formal documentation tools and having a legit package with vignettes. 

I've enjoyed others' gists the way I enjoy seeing a canonical stackoverflow post: "in this language, this is the near-objective best way to transform X in Y under Z constraints". 

But I don't really use them much and I'd probably tell a GitHub beginner to ignore them the same way I say ignore git stash, cherry picks, and often for solo projects even branching.

Gists are essentially smaller, often less documented vignettes. They are meant to show off a capability or interoperability that you may not have considered; a vignette would be showing a capability in depth and documenting it's normal use case. 

For example, there's a gist in R that shows how progress bars can be used inside the content argument of downloadhandler for r shiny.

Separately there is a vignette on progress bars and a vignette on downloadhandler in the original documentation. 

Gists are useful as REPREX, but a GitHub repo is for active development where you are pushing, pulling, committing, branching, etc.

Your trade secrets likely don't meet the legal definition of a trade secret which is the point of (1).  If (1) is outside your purview then you should probably take a pause and read up.

There is no "force" in giving someone any secrets. You show someone how you run your business because it allows them to run it in your stead. This does not give you legal control over their labor after they leave your business.

The idea that you have a trade secret that is legally protectable already exists, it's called a patent. If someone violates a patent, you sue them. But it's a very high bar, and your customers, your ordering system, your secret sauce ingredients, etc. most likely don't meet that bar. 

(2) is relevant because it is how the legal bar is met. 
(3) is a statement of risk which I expanded on. 
(4) is relevant because it's the only competitive mechanism for keeping talent, attempting to restrain the labor market through non-competes is not competitive see (1). 

The legal options for a business to protect their trade secrets are: 

(1) patent them for defined legal protection
(2) keep them a secret and don't tell people including employees 
(3) use other mechanisms such as NDAs for *specific* information (see Waymo/Uber).

It's not enough to just be so good that everyone knows you do good work. "Everyone" includes too many people now and "good work" has to compete harder to be considered "good".

I'm not saying the ad is trying to educate its customer, I'm saying the ad as created makes assumptions about people's understanding and care for privacy; and I think the underlying assumptions are probably incorrect. 

I like Apple's brand, the most impactful narrative for me in terms of Apple + Privacy, is that Apple refused to jailbreak a suspect's phone for the FBI. 

https://www.wired.com/story/fbi-backs-down-apple-encryption-pensacola-iphones/

It's not a good story for an advertisement because I think most people would say "just unlock it for them this one time!"; but if Apple wants to portray commitment to privacy, I think it could do so through a narrative of how it protects your privacy. Browser histories are probably not a good example of that, given Apple has limited control over search data on their devices.

I'm not sure this ad converts it's message well. Does the audience actually understand what a cookie is? 

I'm not sure the average person even sees targeted advertisements as a problem. Sure they hate data leaks, especially important ones like Equifax (still surprised they survived as a company...) but they probably don't really get the negatives of Target or other breaches. 

Even with cambridge analytica and Facebook and russian disinformation, the average person is quick to blame specific companies, but I'm not sure they see this as a systemic issue of tracking, categorizing, and targeting people for content and consumption. 

Studies show paradoxically that people would rather quit these services that track them before they'd pay even a few dollars a month for them (i.e. instead of being tracked), and yet they'd require noticeable payment ($1k+) to quit them for a year. 

The Economics of privacy are that people have no clue what their data is worth and wouldn't know where to begin in pricing their internet privacy. 

I'd even argue that the *revealed* preference (as opposed to the stated preference) is that people *enjoy* targeted advertising since it helps them be better consumers.

Depends on the use case, I posted my ideas in the other comment, I try to focus on specific coins and specific industries and avoid things around trading (too many gamblers looking to sell pips and trade leads). What are you interested in?

We're seeing distributed ledgers specifically coming top-down. I imagine once the federal government is using this tech actively in its finance work, the tech will trickle into the healthcare space as the space increasingly intersects with government. Already nearly 80% of doctors do at least some training in federally run facilities, once those facilities are teaching how to input and extract critical patient data from ledgers, the doctors will be demanding their long term employers use these systems too. 

It's definitely early, but decentralization with strong, agreed upon consensus mechanisms are just too valuable to avoid long-term. So much AI and automation potential.

So to that point, I just pick the coins that I think are most interesting from my economics perspective and I just read everything available on it. So far I've read nearly everything on Melon, read everything on AMPL, and have read the original paper for Bitcoin and a few derivative papers discussing Hayekian money and the theories of decentralized finance. 


More specifically for distributed ledger technology, I read case studies on the application of blockchain for supply chain, tracking, and other use cases across pharmaceuticals, retail, health, etc. 

I try to avoid reading hype pieces that aren't specific to a particular protocol. I also avoid anything about how to trade these coins in the short term for arbitrage profit. I don't doubt it exists, but it's just gambling at this point. I'm trying to identify the 2028 top 10 coins 8 years early.   Bitcoin will of course be there as the market leader and eponym of the industry. 

I'm lightly looking into liquidity pools and how you can make stable short term profits by providing liquidity between popular coins while reducing market exposure. My friend's portfolio is up 700% since March managing his liquidity pools and avoids both spikes (tons of missed profit) and dumps.

I care about particular coins the most, so I just pick the ones that seem to have a completeness of vision, all star ex-finance people involved, etc. 

For me, I'm especially interested in AMPL and Melon. 

AMPL is elastic supply to target a stable price (i.e. if they become too popular they multiply your coins to reduce the value of each coin and if the price is too low, they destroy your coins to make it scarce again). It has a unique volatility curve which is important because right now cryptocurrency is systematically correlated which defeats the whole point. 

Melon is a protocol for coin management, it automates nearly all back-end functions of a hedge fund including transparency, reporting, reallocation, arbitrage, admin, etc. 

The President of the coin's oversight board wrote this article. Her completeness of vision is A+. I'm ready to hop on it. 

https://medium.com/melonprotocol/a-day-in-the-life-of-an-asset-manager-in-the-summer-of-2030-4f18009a5020

Point (2) is an extremely common misunderstanding. 

I see people say they use a NN and they get 85% accuracy and that's the whole bullet point on their resume. 

I have to ignore this bullet point because it doesn't have real meaning. What's the baseline accuracy? 

 In my above example on car accidents, baseline accuracy is 97% "there are no severe accidents"; the recall would of course be 0. 

We ended up tweaking our model to have only about a 60% accuracy, but it's precision was 4x better and recall was 22x better. 

In our problem, both because of data imbalance and cost implications of severe accidents that cause long delays in driving, recall is a very important metric and false positives are low risk. 

It is critical that you set thresholds and accuracy metrics *before* you do too much modeling so that you have an appropriate business framework to work within.
Link to data - for those Curious  https://www.kaggle.com/sobhanmoosavi/us-accidents
TRAINING DATA LEAKAGE IS A HUGE PROBLEM!

Bonus: Two problems with his approach. 

(1) he gave up a lot of valuable variance by downsampling the FALSE cases. So I showed him how to split into training/testing first (I showed him an article on training leakage), and then upsample the most severe cases (i.e. with replacement) to get a more balanced dataset. There are always tradeoffs when you do things like this but it can pay off for certain problems. 

(2) the model was accurate, but it had terrible precision and recall. This was new to him, as all the literature he found really hammered on accuracy, accuracy, accuracy. Showing him how to calculate precision and recall, we talked about how your metric of choice is a business decision. There are situations where false positives are extremely dangerous and others where it's completely negligible. This determines the relative importance of precision and recall for your model. 

For example, in a cancer detection problem, the price of false positives is that you put someone through potentially dangerous screenings and scans, but a false negative can doom someone to cancer. 30 FPs to 1 FN may be too risky, but 3:1 may be fine. This means that accuracy may matter less and precision matters more.
