If you want a software engineer, hire a software engineer. Data scientists write functional mess and only what actually works out gets implemented. My understanding is the most mature organizations actually pass on the data scientist output to be rewritten in optimized languages for mission critical production code.

When I attended a talk at RStudio about salaries they had a really good setup. They defined 4 levels of data scientist and the differentiator between the levels was NOT SKILLS. It was actually AUTONOMY.

You pay a premium to hire people who you can trust with the problem and don't have to babysit. 

Level 1 - needs code review, guidance, double-checking. Essentially they're in training. Typical data analyst new to a team kind of thing. 

Level 2 - should do code review just to enforce style and good principles but generally can be given a task and expected to return an output with minimal oversight. May oversee 1-3 level 1s. 

Level 3 - completely autonomous, can run projects, only really needs guidance in terms of overall strategy, but not implementation. Typically is coaching up the Level 1s and overseeing Level 2s. Typically 3-10ish people under their oversight.  

Level 4 - completely strategy focused, oversees the growth of 3s into 4s and 2s into 3s. Isn't granular enough to be overseeing 1s unless it's a large group and isn't really doing code review. Tends to work at the system architecture level thinking at the scale of platforms and applications. Typically 10-50+ people under them. 

This is how pay should be assessed.

So this is a really common issue in mapping. What you made here isn't really a Starbucks map. It's a population density map. 

I mean it's cool to see that Iowa is nearly all licensed stores I guess. But what's the goal of the visualization? 

Is it to identify patterns in corporate vs license owned? I think a state level map with licensed vs corporate as a ratio on a continuous scale would do that. Or even county level with lots of blanks for no-starbucks present. 

Is it to identify where Starbucks can still expand? Use a county level map with Starbucks/Population (you can make it bi-variate if you want to get licensed vs corporate, although that tends to be busy). 

The dots are also too big, they're like city-size. You're almost just seeing the row order (which dot is on top) not actually seeing differences in ownership type. 

I'm being a bit critical, so apologies there. Also, the projection probably isn't relevant here, although you can switch to an albers projection if you want to be more accurate in terms of spatial density of points within states.

My CMS data experience is very limited, but I would question how minor those updates are. I see record corrections, rejections, deletes, additions months, even years later. When you rely on hundreds of 3rd parties to submit data under different data definitions data collection becomes a bigger headache than modeling really quickly.

Depends on data size. Fully mature organizations typically maintain multiple S3 instances with differing amounts of data access settings and metadata storage to manage which records were placed where and when. Some use DVC, I've never used this, but apparently it's git for data. 

There's also custom blockchain methods that can manage the metadata of when records are accepted and where they're placed on ledgers. 

For small enough data in easy formats like .csv or .txt, git can also function as a data versioning system. 

Somewhere in the middle, there are shortcuts like appending metadata to records, e.g. Adding "date added" as a column for data on SQL server so you can get conditional extracts for dates based on record date and date record was added. 

My clients are typically in the earlier stages of the maturity curve and this isn't (yet) a problem for them, as they aren't actively monitoring data streams to the level where late data vs on-time data differences are being analyzed.

I said it on my episode with you, but we aren't using 2000-2001 and 2005-2009 as lessons for how we incorporate black swan events into our modeling. 

We'll see roughly 3 schools of thought emerge from this situation: 

(1) leave it in, just retrain and see what happens (all models get much less confident essentially) 
(2) try to ignore it or impute some new value into it (this is going to be chaos, but will probably work well in some industries that bounce back quickly). 
(3) throw out everything pre-covid and start over on smaller data in real time. (Inappropriately confident models that will fail to predict "normal" leveling off. It'll assume everything is exponential b/c it's a recovery, but may be highly accurate in short time periods!). 

I don't think any of them are more right than any other. It's going to be domain specific and customer profile specific. All you can do is coordinate with SMEs and try to adjust. Models are supposed to be applying numbers to real world intuition, anyone not modeling with a specific logic in mind is dooming themselves in these kinds of events.
We need this but for AI.

I also avoided them my whole life, I just happened to see it at the library and laugh that it even existed so I checked it out. I was thoroughly surprised and impressed. It starts with a good summary of the history and how culturally, when AI (as it was known contemporaneously)  became highly effective, it became accepted and then assumed. Then that assumption discounted it. 

We don't flinch at spell check and we don't flinch at airplanes essentially flying themselves. These "expert systems" - intricate, large, but ultimately rule-based and entirely interpretable systems were extraordinary and then completely basic and normal. 

The book has other and better explained examples. But essentially, we move the goalposts of AI regularly and whatever we call AI today (GPT-3 chatbots) will be as boring as spellcheck eventually. To some extent we define artificial to be almost -"whatever I don't understand", so once we understand it or solve it, it loses its je ne sais quoi and then AI becomes whatever the next thing we don't understand is. 

So to me, at that point, I'd rather just label AI anything that would have been labeled AI 30-70 years ago, of which many "basic" things would count.
The book AI for Dummies has really convinced me to lower the bar, I recommend it, I never knew the For Dummies series could be so good.

My reasoning is a bit ends justify the means. The shift to calling everything AI has correlated with a large cultural shift and investment in data literacy and data education. Every company is pushing to be data-driven and data is increasingly common in everyday conversation (e.g. talking sports everybody is talking stats now). I think by lowering the bar for what AI is (and allowing it to absorb a lot of relatively standard best practices in data collection, processing, analyzing etc.) we can actually get the whole spectrum of statistics, statistical programming, analytics, AI, ML, NLP, CV, etc. to become more popular and better translated. 

I think it'll be a positive when Excel has an add-on neural networks function and can better handle millions of rows. Bring AI to the people.

Looking at your e-commerce repo: 

1. The README is detailed which is great, although I would recommend making it less technical and more audience friendly. A recruiter is much more interested in the business potential of your skills rather than AUC curves. 
2. Your code is neat but your EDA plots are not clean. This is one of several reasons I don't like notebooks as a data science culture. They make it too easy to work linearly and not be presentation focused. You have black vertical lines on your plots that aren't explained (at first I thought they were box and whisker overlays but they're not) and you don't have titles on your plots telling me the main point. 

Don't publish (which is what including a visual in your notebook is) a halfway done visual. Either complete it as a standalone object so that it boosts your *narrative* or remove it. 

Otherwise I think the repo is good and I agree with your modeling choices (although they could be translated to the audience a little more easily. You tend to default to the most technical definition).

1) go back to people responsible for data collection  and verify its actually missing (I've reviewed code that used mean imputation inappropriately and went back and got the missing data from a different team). 
2) work with SMEs to identify if missing data is reasonable to impute - often it's not. In which case the amount of missingness and it's patterns may lead to dropping features. 
3) iterate on (2) and test out the changes in descriptive statistics over several imputation methods (MICE, zero, random value in range).

Ultimately we want imputation to be a value-add and if you look at imputation casually it's a major risk. 

My mentee and I are collabing on a project with lots of missing values and we're still working through the experiment design to take these into account.

I see a lot of errors caused by not erasing the environment and running scripts from the top. People will create temporary objects and then write functions that (accidentally) rely on those temporary objects in its lexical scoping. 

That's why I constantly refresh my environment. For large datasets, I take a sample and do my analysis as a template and once complete I run it on the full sample. I also make use of .rds to save objects for faster reproducible reading (i.e. don't re-read a big .csv, instead read it once, save a sample as an .rds and then read that while programming).

I'll quickly note that there is significant movement toward outcome based payments in Medicare. I know it's not the "good capitalist" in me, but I'm not sure I'd want private police that I then subscribe to, private mailpeople I subscribe to, or private food safety groups I subscribe to. I really would prefer to not have to subscribe to private health insurance either. 

Economists are already shifting to modeling employer healthcare costs as a tax, we should probably take this pandemic opportunity and disentangle employment and health insurance completely... 

Anyway not trying to jack your post, I hope you're feeling better, just wanted to note that people are seeing this and working on outcome based systems but they don't have widespread political support.

I appreciate this but monks are taken care of by deep connections to a society that has supported them (at great costs to themselves I'd add) because they value them as spiritual leaders. 

Also, some of the comments that seem to disagree may be misunderstanding the depth of capitalism obsession in the US. If you lose your job, nobody will help you. Our social services are overwhelmed, we have entire families living in cars, hiding because they're scared to admit they're down on their luck for fear of having their children taken from them. Our hospitals are expensive and byzantine, the least educated among us are thrown to the wolves and compete heavily with undocumented labor that has much better family and community support structures. 

We have I'd estimate 100-120M people (including children and dependents) who are a few bad luck situations away from complete and utter destitution and if that happens to them, our culture is to blame them for failing first and they have a ticking time bomb to get back on their feet because unemployment runs out, companies hate gaps, and landlords have all the power in most states.

Eh, I mean, I understand not wanting to get exposure to weird situations. But if a person drives to your office at your most convenient hours, especially multiple times, they probably do deserve more than a complete ignore and probably more than a template rejection email.

History is the context of business. I almost said Economics but really I mean history I think. History is how you understand a business in its customer context. What does it currently sell? What did it used to sell? Why did it stop selling that? Why isn't it selling something else? 

Appreciating that decisions are made under constrained information, history lets us reevaluate decisions with new information and understand if we should go back to something we threw away. 

I can't truly serve my clients unless I understand the history of their organization, the history of their funding, why they exist, how they've succeeded or failed before. 

It's like the stereotype of a 100 year old company hires a consulting firm and that firm sends 23 year old MBAs to fix the business when those people have never started a business, run a business, and sometimes even never worked at a business. They come in with just case studies and high level "frameworks". 

The young consultants that succeed are those that study the history of the business and industry so they know why other firms succeeded. History is the foundation of strategy consulting (in my opinion) and I see data science as a flavor of strategy consulting.

Exactly. I feel like people aren't hitting rock bottom early enough in life sometimes üòÇ. I'm not saying it needs to be a homeless level of rock bottom, but we need to acknowledge our lowest points, identify in what ways we got lucky to get through them, and make sure we never get put into those situations again. Whether it be better negotiating, more savings, constant upskilling, w/e.

I agree it's not everything, but "not important" is such a dangerous phrase. It implies that people who want to "do good" don't deserve or shouldn't desire to be well compensated. 

Take teachers for example. I've been one and it's way too little money for the amount of stress. 

I know some anti-teachers will say things like "they have a union", "they get summers off" [this is really not true anymore lol. Sooo much summer stress and the pay already is adjusted for this so don't double adjust], "the average teacher is less smart than the average professional [this uses some pretty biased studies like testing English teachers on high school math]. 

But for me, ultimately, you get what you pay for. If you want better education, you need to incentivize it, if you want better policing you need to incentivize it. 

We shouldn't be asking people to take pay cuts to do good, because we end up disincentivizing doing good. Like sure, hedge fund managers probably generate more short-term financial value for their clients than a school principal. But a good school principal can change the lives of hundreds across multiple generations. 

We need to start valuing non-financial contributions to society!

No, I mean, my best GitHub repos are all private. There's also the reality of people doing great work but within on-prem git like AzureDevOps or TFS or similar. 

I think more broadly though is that GitHub is becoming a LinkedIn competitor for developers, so it's a good idea for people to at least lightly keep it up to date with any side projects they've been up to . 

The issue i see with GitHub is when people have tons of repos and treat it like a portfolio (good) but their commit history is just like 1 date. 

That implies they weren't using git during the development process and that's bad. You want to make sure your GitHub is signaling that you understand version control, merge conflicts, branching, and ultimately the experimentation part of the projects and problems you work on. 

Again tho, not having one isn't bad at all, plenty of reasons you wouldn't have one. But I do think portfolios are useful in general and that GitHub is a good portfolio mechanism when done well.

Message: Less is more. That's my big point lol. If your audience is more technical than the general public, I understand why you would push back on this advice, but the general public is NOT the LinkedIn population. They are people who watch TV and get targeted by propaganda that uses fake Y axis labels and fake spacing to trick people into insights that aren't real. Data literacy is a fundamentally political topic.

(1) - sounds good, but be careful going too deep. Stick to stories as much as possible. This is a tricky convo. 
(2) I wouldn't frame collection --> visualization as a linear process. 

More generally, try to remind them that they use data products every day. Google maps traffic jams, their internet activity. The big thing about data is that the digital world is ALL collected.

(3) probably wouldn't bring this up. 
(4) would probably skip this too. 
(5) would probably skip. 
(6) I'd spend nearly 50+% of my time on this. And probably fuse it with (3), (4) and (5). So don't teach them directly that convenience sampling is a problem, show them visuals and tricks that USE errors to trick to teach them.  Show them how words like "average" can be used to confuse people's bias to this of average as "typical". There are multiple meanings of "typical"- most common, the middle ground, the most expected/likely. 

(6)(2) (you have 2 6s) sounds fine I guess. 
(7) sound cool but time concerns. 
(8) weave interspersed in the topics. 


Overall data literacy is about not getting fooled. So that should be your primary goal. Convert your audience into skeptics who don't get tricked. Everything else should be supporting this goal.

This chart tells its story poorly. There isn't a note on rounding errors leading to <100% and overall the only thing the user sees is that 64 became 61 over 40 years. 

A much better chart that is actively used in economics is the relationship between wages and productivity over time. 

Those chart show that (inflation adjusted) wages have stagnated while productivity has skyrocketed. 

The advent of the modern internet and personal computer area has completely changed the global economy but the working poor and working middle (*in OECD countries*) only have free apps and limitless amounts of low-cost content available for their effort. 

Some might argue that the value (positive externalities) society gets from FB, Google, and similar free at point of service mega-applications more than makes up for the lack of direct money-benefits of increased productivity (i.e. their productivity has resulted in large fringe benefits) but I'm not a fan of that philosophy. 

You can't Google food, water, shelter, clothing. There's a limit to what information can do for your daily life.
The point of using medians is to make nominal currency changes (i.e. inflation) not relevant.

Presumably a rounding issue? I honestly see this and wonder if these changes are significant. 3% shuffled around over nearly 40 years. Tough to extract a public policy out of this image. I much prefer wage vs productivity vs inflation charts that show the middle is getting squeezed inappropriately.

Just be objective and say what you actually want/need.

Very interesting. 

The rough idea is that if you have 5 red balls and 5 blue balls in a bag and you pick a random 3, you have 7 balls left. 

Even though you have 7 left, you cannot actually pick 7 balls at random. You can only really pick 6 at random. Because once you've removed 9 balls total, you've eliminated the final ball's ability to be random, because it can be deduced empirically by knowledge of 5 and 5 going in, and 4 and 5 coming out. 

Now of course, in a tweaked scenario you remove all 5 reds really really quickly, in which case you eliminate the randomness even sooner. 

The transfer of this idea to math using regression for example is, if you have a prediction (yhat) and you have a model (yhat = Ax+Bz + C) and your yhat is unbiased (correctly estimates y), then for any standard error calculations you would note that for any estimate of yhat, knowing A, x, z, and C, your estimate of B is not free to be any value except the value that ensures yhat is unbiased. 

Relatedly for A given the rest. 

This is why you see N-P in the denominator of some calculations (where P is the number of parameters in your model including intercept!).

I'd bucket that under IT governance but I can understand how it looks like data engineering would be foundational in that context. 

My experience is that those problems are much later. Typically data is being collected ad-hoc and decentralized just because humans tend to be hoarders üòÇ and THEN an effort is made to create data access portals, warehouses, etc. 

When I say ad-hoc, decentralized I mean that there are already going to be marketing, sales, business departments, etc. Collecting data for their micro-purposes (who last called this sales contact? When did they call them?), typically within paid software (Salesforce, or similar) or on their local machines (dozens, if not hundreds, of Excel files). 

At best, there's an ugly Access database lying around where poorly formatted Excel documents are dumped periodically. 

This is an environment where you can plug in an analyst to dive in, centralize crazy data, and start building questions and insights that inspire people to invest in proper data collection and management. 

You can't plug a data engineer into that environment without A LOT of political support for cleaning up your act, and companies OFTEN dump a data scientist / Statistician and get mad it fails...
Nothing wrong with being at step 0-3 of the maturity curve.

Consider the REPREX: 
Y = 3*x1 + 8*x2 + error. 

Y is *skewed*, the X's are *uniformly* distributed, and yet the residuals are normal :) . The model was identified quite easily.

Falconi Nicasio - Normality *of the residuals* is a fundamental assumption, but not normality of Y or the Xs. As long as the linear combination, consistent-variance, and minimal collinearity assumptions hold, you can combine non-normally distributed variables linearly to get non-normally distributed predictions and be a-OK if the residuals are normally distributed.

1. P values only matter when determined ahead of time as a threshold for a decision. Common misuse- using it as a feature selection tool in stepwise Regression (which is bad) or using it as a blind decision maker (above 0.05 = throw it away). 
2. Big sample is more good, makes your estimates better 
3. Fast way to choose data and know what the options are (I have essentially completely forgotten how to type SQL üòÇüôà but I know I love to do unique() and case_when in R). 
4. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è - what is this? 
5. Your dependent variable does NOT have to be normally distributed to use these, common misinterpretation that leads to bad things like log transforming your variables without a plan of how to interpret this new thing. 
6. Everything is the same except one tiny thing, that tiny thing is made to be either A or B. Then you see if there are differences. The important part is everything else being the same, don't run your website CTR experiment at 2AM on a Friday for A and then 6PM on a Monday for B... 
7. Lists are great, you can hold different classes of objects even if they have different lengths and then reference those objects by name (this is in R).
8. Resampling is dangerous but often useful.

General advice repost thread:

Where to start: --------------

Learn statistics and build up projects using Python or R and get them on your GitHub.

The thing people do wrong is they try and do things in pieces like school. Today I learn A, tomorrow I learn B, in a few weeks I learn Z.

That's not how people *do* data science.

People do data science by having a problem, having skills in statistics and programming and business, and using A LOT of Google. Then they use git for version control.

Start today by making sure everything you are practicing is problem-solution oriented. Then as you program the solution, use git (I use GitHub for desktop) and your GitHub to constantly update your answer as you learn more. That way your GitHub has a commit history.

Most people just code something then throw the final thing into GitHub. This shows they don't understand the tool and they think it's a portfolio site. That's not what GitHub is.

https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/your-resume-doesnt-excite-you-its-boring-recruiters-carlos-mercado-1e

It's very simple. You are trying to convince a company to pay for your services through a salary.

So you must prove to them you have the skills they need.

Everything must be focused on that 1 task.

Your resume is a SALES DOCUMENT. It is not a restaurant menu. The recruiter does not want the added labor of figuring out which of your 50 skills are good for the company.

Make their job easy and tell stories (career narratives & personal summary) that are targeted, industry specific, and align to your specific goals.

Makes sense. When I think of blockchain I think of (1) data security and (2) metadata analysis. 

(1) you can't contribute to the chain unless it's been validated (there are multiple validation schemas, e.g. majority crowd agreement). 

You could imagine like my podcast example, adding an appointment block which details which patient saw which doctor at what time and what results were, but if any of those factors don't align correctly and pass predefined checks, then the block fails to be accepted. Example: you can't add a chain detailing Bobby saw Dr. Susie and got X medication because Bobby doesn't have any details of disorders that align to that medication. 

(2) knowing when a block is added and to which ledger or chain and what the block details, and it's type, and the gap in time since a previous block was added, etc. Gives you some very useful metadata to improve your data collection process. You can understand the typical rejections, any slowdowns in processing, identifying bottlenecks, etc. 

The industry is changing and complicated and I'm oversimplifying a bit. There's of course the financial side of blockchain too.

Yeah, so I try to think in terms of APIs but in everyday work. If my client has a very specific process they do frequently and it involves pulling data, changing a SAS script to read a new file in a directory, and then running it, and then making a report out of the results in MS word by snipping images and typing boilerplate text, I try to break down each step into its inputs and outputs. 

What I find typically is, ok I'm not going to magically be able to pull the data you need however you need it, so go ahead and do that step how you're currently doing it. I won't be able to write the report for you in a parameterized way, so you'll still put it together.

But let's give you a web application that lets you upload files so you don't change your script to read new files programmatically. Then let's make sure to output visuals you need as nice, separated, pre-named PDFs or SVGs to make sure they scale well in your report and have high resolution. Then let's ensure that any boilerplate sentences, e.g. describing correlations or a table of top features or a confusion matrix, are pre-written for you too either as .txt you can paste or as a .xlsx you can open and copy/paste into a word table.

I know everyone's gut reaction is "what no!" But that's coming from some naivety. 

Yes, Facebook and Google bring eyes to publishers, but that's because they have consolidated the internet in ways that *might* violate anti-trust laws (FB CEO conversation disclosed to Congress THIS WEEK said they bought Instagram because it was a threat --they should have kept their mouth shut because that's textbook trust violation). 

In this anti-trust, illegal consolidation framework, you have to look at the downstream harm and say, these publishers were competing with each other for viewers (good). A platform came along that allowed publishers to advertise to people and people to view context within the platform (totally good, and a good argument against tech paying publishers). BUT what happened next is not good or fair. 

These companies started harvesting platform data (see related Congress conversation around Amazon and 3rd party sellers) and using that data to boost their position. Including summarizing that content and making it available to their users without the original party. 

This topic is very complicated.

TIOBE is skewed too! People need to understand that Python is a general programming language, so you can't compare R to Python head to head. You need to compare R for [insert target role/industry] vs Python for [insert target role/industry].

It turns out that for "general" data science, especially ML/DL, Python is ahead but it's surprisingly closer than you'd expect. And for some data science subsets (e.g. clinical research) it isn't close, R will be the only one or Python will be the only one (e.g. ESRI GIS products).

I see an outlier as a talking point and this is obviously worth talking cause it looks very strange. 

And to the answers bringing up regression to say no, outliers don't have to have any pattern differences to be an outlier. 

If I make $10/hr and work 20hrs / week. Then suddenly work 100 hours in a week, the chart of my hours worked vs revenue will maintain the $10/hr slope but it will very obviously be an outlier week simply because it's an anomaly on both axes. 

Two outliers (x axis and y axis) don't suddenly make a normal point just because it follows a known pattern.

Bootcamps work.    If you have domain knowledge and go to a well known bootcamp (flatiron, lambda,  springboard, etc.) and come out with the ability to connect to a database, pull in data, clean it, visualize it, and build a model. You're going to get hired. 

The problem people have is they go from different domain knowledge then do a Bootcamp but do the minimum and come out with projects irrelevant to their goals. 

If you're an English teacher and you do flatiron and your portfolio is all cancer detection and image processing in Python, you're lying to yourself to think you'll get a senior Data Science role at Walmart doing customer analytics. 

You've essentially done 2 career changes in one. Wouldn't recommend that.   You'd have better luck targeting roles that use your domain expertise (language and education). 

If your portfolio, your domain expertise, your target industry, and your skills are all pointed in the same direction, you'll be tripping over jobs. 

The problem is bootcamps aren't teaching this. Students come out with irrelevant portfolios for their goals or their goals don't involve their domain expertise, etc. There's a lot of mistakes to make but luckily they're easy to fix for the motivated.

Not following on "distribute wealth". It seeks to be stable in price by being flexible in quantity. Thus you don't have a consistent amount of the currency. One morning you wake up with 2 coins worth a total of $2 ($1 each). Another morning you wake up with 4 coins worth a total of $2 (0.50 each). What happens in between is chaotic and people capitalize on that and try and make money. In their arbitrage activities they essentially determine the desired market cap every day which results in a new quantity target for the coin. The pattern repeats until stability is reached.

Bonus: Well it turns out there's good #economics here. It's called Hayek money. 

The idea is private currency would be perfectly elastic in both supply and demand in an algorithmic way, avoiding the risks (and benefits) of our current discretionary money system. 

Because the US dollar is a world reserve currency, people want it to be stable. The best way to have a stable (fiat, centralized) currency is low and steady inflation. 

Bitcoin is the opposite, it's designed to be deflationary. Only 21M will ever exist and they have to be mined taking up immense costs that increase the price floor at every halving day. (Don't ask me too much more, my Economics specialty is spatial/urban economics, not financial LOL). 

Other coins work differently. AMPL's idea is simple algorithmic short-memory elastic supply is  purposefully chaotic but within some boundaries thus being uncorrelated to other crypto (which are often hilariously correlated with Bitcoin itself).

Finance loves stable chaos because uncorrelated assets are valuable. They add diversity to the portfolio and reduce risk. 

I read a few years ago that several hedge funds were deciding to put 0.5-1% of their portfolio in cryptocurrency exclusively because it's so uncorrelated.

This is an important point. I think many look at social media through a strictly negative lens (waste of time, fake highlight reel, damaging to self esteem) instead of the nuanced lense (connects you to others, keeps you informed, a forum for debate, but also risky for mental health, easily addictive, echo chamber / thought bubble, political awareness, viral conspiracy theories). 

To be honest I was bringing this up while excluding financial benefits that make NPV trivial to calculate, but I should have considered there are financial benefits to these services too. 

But however we value them, it does matter in terms of government policy (tax and otherwise) that we identify the value in some kind of way.

I agree and that's why I use and pay for LinkedIn. I get tons of benefits (e.g. lower stress LOL) from accessing big brained people to help me with my work problems. I think for this specific discussion it's biased toward determining the value of the service separate from calculable financial investments. Although I guess Facebook provides exposure value to some including customers for their small businesses, etc.

I agree, I think sometimes economists use averages as a shorthand too easily in opportunity costs calculations. People have a distribution of opportunity costs. I can't do more of my job for my money in a directly calculable way, but hypothetically I could make a fraction of it on the side doing teaching or consulting.   I think the benefit of using the average though is that whatever my side gig would be is probably already some else's job. So there's an argument to be made that side gigs in general have an average hourly value at some stable fraction of the prevailing average wage. So even if $10k is an overstatement I'd say it's closer to that number than $1k.

I'm not sure this is entirely true. Our team has grown during quarantine but the institutional knowledge and connections that lead to fuzzy growth are extremely difficult to replicate remotely. I think many companies are relying on institutional knowledge that hasn't decayed yet, but eventually it will decay. The people you knew who no longer work there will be replaced by people you never met. There's a threshold (industry variant) where a collection of strangers making up too high a % of the team impacts collaboration.

Having said that, I do think functions are critical, but it's not just about writing functions for functions sake, it's about coding and structuring products in a way that is modularized and problems can be isolated so bugs can be quickly found, understood, and solved.

Yes but that only solves the function overwrite conflict, there are more fundamental conflicts that namespaces don't solve. 

For example, some packages may claim to take tibbles or data frames, but then they can't evaluate reactives as tibbles or data frames ü§¶

So what works totally normally on a script completely doesn't work in Shiny. This is the kind of stuff that paired programming would really benefit, because under a time constraint the bias is to grab code and use packages that solve the problem, you often can't go back and audit your packages until the POC is done and you move to converting the final approved process into a production product.

Key word there is *teams*. You'd be shocked how many individuals are given a lump of data, no specific goal, and a deadline to make outputs. Under those conditions, functional programming gets put on the back burner especially if you're alone on the project. 

Sure you could write real functions and unit test and update them. But there's real time cost there, so you make the tough decision and build up technical debt by just sprinting to the next due date with no chance to pause and breathe. 

This is a technical debt and expectations management problem, not a "bad coder" problem.

But yes, data scientists are too often hired for their data + statistics = value skills instead of their data + statistics + business = product skills. 

Reports give you value 1 time, products give you value through their whole life span and can be improved and updated to extract even more value. 

Product oriented thinking needs to become commonplace in data science consulting and I think it's happening. I know at my firm we're making major investments in these cloud capabilities to create products for clients more often.

Bonus: This isn't the fault of the individual. I think there's this idea that if you can't lone-wolf your way into the best product ever then you're somehow bad at your job... 

It's the opposite. The ability to generate value in isolation under severe time constraints is typically *why* companies hire #datascientists.

They don't want to hire a full team to build software and they get what they pay for. 

Companies can get massive equity in terms of quality and timeliness by investing in software engineering processes. 

Paired Programming for example. There are *so many* benefits to having two people code 1 project. They catch bugs real time, they enforce code style, they anticipate errors (one on Google one on keyboard). 

But short-term brain says, 2 people in 1 job is twice the money. 

We need to make sure data scientists exist in an ecosystem that includes other data scientists whenever possible.

There may culture specific nuances, but it's totally normal to not know things. Just stay positive and acknowledge that you're a constant learner and you expect that with the standard resources (Google, GitHub, etc.) you'll be able to learn the topic well enough to make an impact quickly. 

Also, there's the reality that what they ask you about in the interview may be irrelevant to the actual role. If you're comfortable, you should verify to what extent the thing you don't know actually matters in the job. 

I once interviewed at a firm where I had to plan and make a presentation on the historical accuracy of the Phillips curve (the relationship between inflation and unemployment). 

I felt I did well and they were impressed. But then learned they do "constant" interviewing and didn't actually have a role for me at the time, but said I'd be front of the list for their next opening when it comes. 

That turned out to be true, as I was called about a role a few months later (I was already employed by then) but the role was completely irrelevant to economic theory or analytics presentations. 

So although I have a positive view of the org, their interview was generic and not relevant to the roles they actually hire for.

Given a prior belief about the probability of an event (e.g. I believe this coin is fair) and a set of data (e.g. 1,000 coin flips with 600 heads and 400 tails), what is the probability *my data* occurs given my prior belief, and what does that probability imply about how I should *change* my prior belief. 

Bayes theorem is that the prior distribution times the likelihood of your data is (proportional to) the posterior distribution; i.e. your updated belief distribution.

For example. I think tylenol is worthless for pain; I give 10000 random people a pain test and 100 say they are in pain. I give those 100 people tylenol and ask them how they feel. My prior belief is there is a 10% chance someone would have a noticeable change in their pain (I label this a placebo effect). The data comes back and only 80 are still in pain. 

What does the *likelihood of this result* imply about the correctness of my original belief? I expected 10 and got 20 with reduced pain.

"why am I wasting time by writing about the classic statistics, small data, SAS, frequentist inference, etc. if "it's old, nobody is uses it any more in the world of big data and Bayesian ML." 

Because we want our models to align to theoretical models that we use to explain reality. It's the same debate over and over- prediction vs explanation. You can predict tomorrow's stock price all you want and be very successful and very happy; but if you want to replicate that growth in your company stock, you need to understand the underlying mechanisms of stock growth which may not be as simple as no-brain big button push auto ML.

Honestly this whole 1% 2% thing is so strange to me. We know the cases are an undercount and yet we use confirmed deaths as our numerator? We know deaths are being undercounted too... 

It's very simple, 1600 humans die in the US from cancer each day; out of roughly 8000 deaths per day. Roughly 1/8 deaths in the US since February have been Covid-19 related. 

We are facing a virus with no vaccine that is duplicating cancer in its deaths. The idea that anything is overblown is just crazy to me. We know barely anything about herd immunity or re-infection (I've read the chimp studies that show 30+ day immunity), so again I'm not looking to cause panic I'm just pushing back on the idea that we should be "chill" because everybody dies and you'll probably survive unless your old or sick. It's an incredibly Spartan attitude.

I don't want any specific reaction. I want people to be given guidance by their government on best practices and for them to follow through. 

We *don't know* people's risk of dying, I never said 2% chance of dying, I'm saying that we have definitions and numbers attached to those definitions and in reality we don't want 300M individuals having to weigh a bunch of options and do the math on their own risk profiles and make individual decisions. 

The truth is, the chance of dying of Covid-19 probably is less than 1% for a random person who catches it- *but that isn't the debate we should be having*. 

Every Covid-19 patient who survives their 2 week ICU stay took a bed away from *multiple* cancer patient, a car accident victims, etc. 

I want a data driven government policy that looks holistically at the fact that if 1% of a state is known to have an infection and the hospital system is at capacity X out of Z. What are the odds that the hospitals get overwhelmed, who dies at the margins due to war-time health rationing? 

How many cancer patients are not getting their treatments? How many surgeries have been cancelled that would save lives?

3) we need to have millions of masks and doses of sanitizer & soap available for when kids inevitably make messes and need replacements. If you think a 7 year old is going to wear 1 mask all day you're kidding yourself. 5) we need to have continuity plans for when teachers eventually die and trained professionals ready to talk to the children who lose their teachers.
By a avoiding these conversations we erode trust more.

My personal opinion is that people consume animals due to misguided beliefs around nutrients (protein, iron, etc.) and of course taste, so we should seek to solve both of those through plants. 

Can we make plants taste like animals? Probably, we're learning a lot about hemoglobin and plant alternatives. What should a person who wants this to happen faster do? It'd be cool to get some resources. 

Can we make plants have nutrients? Well plants have insane nutrients, that's of course where animals get them from lol. But for the specific protein/iron, etc. argument: probably, there's some questions around whether adding nutrients post-growth actually gets ingested the same way by the body but I don't see why you couldn't just eat more protein plants.

Imputation is really dangerous and should probably not be done in real life unless it is overwhelming how necessary it is. 

My imputation steps are: 
1) identify missing values across features and do EDA to try and understand any patterns in missingness
2) go back to data source / collection / business people and try to fix them by asking for data reviews
3) repeat 1 and 2 a few times until I really start bothering people
4) mock up the experiment with rows with missing values or total missing features dropped. 
5) go to step 3 with step 4. 
6) coordinate with business people on what makes sense if imputation is critical. In many contexts last value makes sense before mean, median, or MICE even. 

Use MICE before you use mean and even then, you probably shouldn't be imputing in real life. 

All imputation does is destroy the accuracy of your confidence intervals (arbitrarily too small) similar to not doing adjustments to survey data, because now you've violated the simple random sampling assumptions of many statistics models.

Binning is cutting your continuous data into groups, called bins. You may for example notice your data has holes where certain values don't exist, in which case assuming continuity of your data would be inappropriate. You can make all kinds of bins: 

Binary (above or below a certain value) 
Decile/quintile/quartile (use percentiles then bucket them) 
custom cuts (in R the cut() function will turn your numeric into factor with your defined breaks). 

The appropriate bin size is an art too. I am biased toward using Jenks natural breaks (maximizes deviation of inter-categorical means while minimizes deviance from intra-categorical mean) and then I use that as a guideline and lightly push the numbers to be more even looking (e.g. 234-387 I'd make 200-400 accepting some arbitrariness there). 

The thing to be careful of is defaulting to equal intervals. 

Equal intervals doesn't assume your data is normal, but it implies certain things about distributions and can lead to distortions in visualizations when the distribution has skew (e.g. a map of 50 states and 35-40 of them are all the same color implying no deviation when deviation likely does exist even if it is small).

1) IDEs 

Take a big breathe and really think about the pros and cons of each IDE. Research them deeply. Understand that how you start is critical. Learn keyboard shortcuts, learn all the IDE features. If you're choosing #R (which I chose to start with, although I roughly know Python too) learn what each of the RStudio toolbar things do. 

2) READ CODE. 

It's open source for a reason, in R you can type any function and see it's body. You can see how professionals use whitespace, comments, commas, braces, etc. To make code readable and fast. 

Study up a style guide, look back at old code after a few weeks / months and optimize it. 

Again, if you use R, check out profvis, it's a package that lets you time code really easy. 

You can learn how to make faster loops and slowly get better about new classes of objects you may not naturally think about leveraging (e.g. lists, factors). 

3) Manage multiple processes 

Learn how to split things apart into their own scripts, the sooner you can think in terms of APIs and scoping and environments the better. 

4) Version Control matters 

Use git. At a minimum use GitHub for desktop the GUI version. It has less features but it has the all everything you need 99% of the time.

Eric Sims yeah CMPLT-BS is the next üåä after DL falls out of popularity. 

It's a mixed Bayesian approach, you start with a prior hypothesis, then you rotate, log transform, and blend (I use a magic bullet) your data, then spread it across two spheres.

Sphere 1 is the data that supports the prior, sphere 2 is the data better left in the appendix. 

Then you put sphere 2 in the trash saying it isn't representative of the population of data that you wanted. 

And voil√° you've distilled your data to the principle components that support your argument. 

This algorithm is very popular, I'd say it's the most common algorithm used in consulting üòÇ.

Bonus: Theories from data viz. 

1) Equity Over Table (EOT) 

All visuals should be tables unless the equity is so overwhelming that you feel it would be an injustice to only provide a table.

Let me repeat. If your visualization isn't *easier* to understand than a table equivalent, then it shouldn't exist, unless there is an overwhelming benefit to do so.

2) Colors have domain specific meaning. 

In finance black is profit, red is loss. In other domains green and red may have meanings. 

Use tools like iwanthue (my favorite color choosing tool üòâ giving you an industry secret here, use it wisely üòÇ) to generate palettes that meet your ideal progression of chroma, lightness, and hue. 

Understand the difference between RGB, HCL, etc. Take time to learn color theory. 

3) The point should be the title, the title should be the point. 

The Title is the most important part of a visualization. People will disagree with me on this one, but oh well. 

Look up the serial positioning effect. People remember the first and last thing they see / hear. 

So if you can state your conclusion upfront, it'll be more memorable. 

There's nothing worse than a title that says "plot of X vs Y"

Message:
Where to start: --------------

Learn statistics and build up projects using Python/R and get them on your GitHub.

The thing people do wrong is they try and do things in pieces like school. Today I learn A, tomorrow I learn B, in a few weeks I learn Z.

That's not how people *do* data science.

People do data science by having a problem, having skills in statistics and programming and business, and using A LOT of Google. Then they use git for version control.

Start today by making sure everything you are practicing is problem-solution oriented. Then as you program the solution, use git (I use GitHub for desktop) and your GitHub to constantly update your answer as you learn more. That way your GitHub has a commit history.

Most people just code something then throw the final thing into GitHub. This shows they don't understand the tool and they think it's a portfolio site. That's not what GitHub is.

Note: the reason I say to do steps 1 & 2 BEFORE stackoverflow, is because if you dont you put yourself at risk of curing the symptoms with more code. This is a recipe for spaghetti code. 

Instead of fixing the problem at the top, you layer on Band-Aids until it becomes impossible to debug later.

Step 3 continued: example- I have a problem with dates in my data, lubridate::mdy() outputs the date in a different format than I wanted and it breaks my later code.

Go to mtcars and make a date column of the same class as your real data column. 

Put the mtcars fake data column into your function. Are you getting the same error? If so, perfect, you just reproduced your error in an example everyone can run.

------


Now, anyone can recreate your error without needing your data or irrelevant code. 

This is what functions help so much too, because they *force* you to only provide the minimally needed inputs for your desired output. Making REPREX much simpler to identify.

Bonus: Let's talk REPRoducible EXample. 

Anytime you have a problem in your code take a breath and a break. Use these steps to solve your problem *before* you go to stackoverflow.

Step 1: status check 
What is currently in your environment? Is there anything non-reproducible that you coded but forgot to save that code in your script? Can you wipe your environment and get back to where you were? 

Step2: wipe your environment and start from the top. 
Run each line or chunk slowly, make sure you know what class each object is, it's length, etc. Is every process getting the input you expected? Is it giving you the out you expected? 

If you code without thinking of the inputs and outputs, you're too trusting lol. Trust but verify. Especially when we're using 3rd party packages for everything. 

Typically step 2 you find out something weird happens and that's why your later code breaks (hey this function coerced all my stuff into characters! I need them to be numbers). 

Step 3: ok everything works up to your latest part. 

Now you can go to stackoverflow and see if you just have the wrong function or something. But before you do, isolate the problem. Is 1 function not outputting what you expect?

History is real! Things come before things and affect things. 

Autoregression is being correlated to itself (ie. To it's past self). 

Monday may correlate to previous Mondays, AR(7) for days of the week. Or maybe today's sells can be modeled by yesterday's sales - AR(1). 

Funny enough, while time series is the most common domain for autoregression, you can actually test out autoregression in very funny ways, such as adding row # to your regression. You'd be surprised how much phenomenon can be partially explained by omitted variables that correlate with row number, e.g. if customer X is in row 1000 and customer C is in row 500, you may consider them unique entities. 

But consider that you were at row 500 when you were a smaller business and now that you're bigger your new customers are different but in correlated ways (e.g. they buy new products or they buy larger amounts). 

You can use autoregression to test if there is a history component you aren't capturing fully.
Love it!
Benefit of consulting, you do so many small things you know a little about a lot, but don't ask me how streamlit caching works or anything beyond surface level üòÇ.
Here's some more items:

Streamlit uses intelligent caching to essentially rerun entire scripts with a (somewhat basic) user interface and only recalculate the minimum items necessary. But it's not a full reactive programming backend. 

Even the phrase "interactive dashboard" is underselling shiny. Shiny is a full web application framework with 1 language that accepts JS, HTML, and CSS as needed. 

Shiny can automate processes (I do a lot of upload Excel get back a PDF and similar) in addition to classic backend/frontend support (connect to databases, perform calculations, provide inputs and parameters, get new calculations, etc.). 

The closest thing I've seen is Dash- but my understanding from overseeing (only 1) Dash development is that it doesn't handle things automatically the way shiny does. Especially sizing of objects, you have to really grind out the perfect layouts at a pixel level. 

Plotly is a cool API for getting interactive visuals in multiple languages, I'm not sure how much of shiny capabilities it can cover tho. 

I'm aware of Bokeh but haven't used it. 

Whenever we make web applications not with Shiny, it's because we intend to do a full application and deployment with like PHP, JS, SQL, Docker, Git, Python, etc. But shiny covers well.
Love to see it!

True- I think the problem could be better stated as,

In crunch time, you've got 150 hours left to do 80-100 hours worth of finishing and QAing your kia.

Client comes in requesting a Ferrari engine be swapped in. 

It would take 20 hours to even find out if it's possible, another 50 to scope the mods, another 50 to get everyone aligned to the new mods and get the schematics drawn up for each person's part and then 100 to do it and QA it. 

You can choose from: 

1) get them the original scope and let them know whether it's possible on version 2 (quality/delivery)

2) shove all the work in and sacrifice on QA (delivery/satisfaction)

3) plan for a delay (quality, satisfaction). 

I know many people are going to say - inform the client and work with them to see how THEY balance the 3 and work with that. But remember- information isn't free. To even entertain going to the client with the options takes hours of prep and discussion. There's no free lunch on closing information asymmetries.
Thank you for the comment, I totally agree!

True, I'm specifying the situation where resources are fixed because it's the final stretch. Although I agree, with planning and enough lead time, you don't have to sacrifice as much if you can be flexible with resources (more compute power, more developers, etc.)

Helpful note, in my consulting experience, satisfaction can be fixed, quality can't. If we give them something subpar, they'll ask a competitor to restart from scratch, not trusting us anymore. 

If we do an objectively excellent job, but they are unhappy about us and how we worked with them, we may still work with them again lol because the people who decide contracts try to be objective to avoid the principle-agent problem in procurement.

Not saying to ignore customers always, but in crunch time they are 3rd on my list.

Some would say it's better to be late as long as in the end what you deliver is good and makes everyone happy. 

Others would say focus on the MVP and sacrifice quality to meet deadlines. 

I personally think quality and delivery can fix client satisfaction long term.

I've been in tough situations where game theory says- "if you take this client call you'll lose somewhere between 4-24 hours of work given the reworks they'll request and you won't have time to actually incorporate all the reworks and also validate the numbers. It's better they have the quality numbers on time but with less aesthetics than to get the aesthetics right but the numbers wrong." 

So I dodged the client team and committed to the original plan as originally scoped.

I think for non-essential businesses (e.g. entertainment, retail, leisure), point & click autoML is totally fine and should be used. 

But when healthcare and global finance start using AutoML with intrinsic biases in the algorithms, critical regulation being ignored, biases in the training data, etc. We need to keep our hands directly on the process as much as possible to keep people safe.

I have, but typically get insulated from it for similar reasons- the data science team is the backup to the account team. 

What also helps is remembering proper product management principles. The client doesn't actually care about the minutae of what's happening and how and why. 

They just need to make progress toward a goal and have stresses related to the gap of understanding of that progress will occur or not. 

If you're in a situation where you have competing goals of product completion, product quality, and client satisfaction and you can only pick 2. You sometimes have to make the tough choice and pick product completion and product quality over client satisfaction. 

It sounds counterintuitive to many, but if our team is in the zone, a 30 minute phone call quickly becomes 2-24 hours of lost work. We have to prep for the phone call, have the phone call, hear distracting information that we then have to vet and iterate on whether we understand it, translate the new requirements, identify what conflicts now exist in our requirements, plan a new meeting to pick among conflicting requirements. 

In the end game when you're about to ship, pivoting can destroy the product. So we ship what was scoped and iterate later.

More fundamentally, sometimes you want a supervised learning problem but you don't want to go to every unit and manually label it. So you use a clustering algorithms to (hopefully) bundle up your data into easy to label items based on similarity. You still end up reviewing a lot manually, but it's nice to have somewhere to start and if you're lucky you find patterns that work for hilariously large amounts of your data, so you can feel confident labeling maybe 5-10% of your data as category X all in one swing because they turn out to be clustered really well and definitionally positive for a certain category. 

In practice, using these methods can make EDA really smooth too, because you learn about relationships that you expected exist but now you have data specific elements to describe your intuition.

You wouldn't use MC in that context is my understanding. And you've mixed up p values in your original analysis. 

The p value should be decided as part of the experiment design you can't just use 0.05 and then throw methods at it until you hit your target. 

Using MC doesn't really make sense here based on how I learned it and use it. I use MC when I'm working with combinations of different distributions (e.g. normal-gamma) to identify equilibrium estimates for when those distributions are harder to reason about. 

You're essentially using MC as a more complicated bootstrap / oversample. Again, this really just confuses the problem.   

N isn't large enough to be having problems with it's distributions. And the data probably isn't truly normal anyway. 

You can do small sample methods and tests to identify if differences are significant as defined in the experiment design. 

There's plenty of reasons that your significance threshold would *not* be 0.05. 

The whole 0.05 thing has done immeasurable damage to the field of data science in my opinion.

N is small, so Monte Carlo is just randomly oversampling some points more. 

You're treating the samples as a population when using MC, it's not surprising that MC at any arbitrary runs (even large) returns different results given how small N is. 

If you get a deck of cards and shuffle it 100,000 times, it'd be very rare to get the same exact arrangement more than once. 

Edit: I say very rare because people don't truly randomize when they shuffle, if it was truly random shuffling, the chances are at the 1/ 1e50+, so essentially impossible.

One of the teams I'm on wrote a white paper on this. 

I'd say you're generally right in terms of genomics and insurance getting the bulk of AI efforts. But this is slowly changing, major hospital systems including government and academic facilities are pushing the envelope on AI in ways that don't interfere but actually augment the day to day for nurses and doctors. 

AI fails when the stakeholders aren't included, so all the fancy stuff that actually just forces nurses and doctors onto computers instead of by patients is going to fail. We need to start by using existing systems (e.g. unstructured notes, EHR) and adding insights where the staff already exist. Don't add more software and navigation and clicks for them to use something...

To add detail: we did try some cool stuff. We generated training data by getting SMEs to label a subset of our data points (text classification), we used an ensemble method combining 3 different NLP models to parse the text and classify them. 

But we learned that this wasn't an NLP problem. Because the public health people expected 0 false classifications. They thought we were going to match their ability to ingest keywords and context and perfectly map these groups. 

Once I heard they expected 100% accuracy, I had to step back and go to the basics. We used tf-idf instead of ensemble methods and helped them identify *their patterns* for classifying. 

Without realizing it, they always put texts with 2-word phrase X-Y into group A, never group B,C, or D. 

So that allowed us to *augment* (not automate) their task by providing recommended classification for them to sort by and review in a way that was extremely interpretable. Instead of the black box methods saying group C and then they read the entire text to verify. We could say, consider group C because it contains this phrase X-Y. Then they could go directly to the sentence that contains that phrase, and agree immediately, OR read for context and overrule the simple model.

PCA is all about reducing the data size while retaining as much variability as possible.

Date: It works by taking your data in N dimensional space and rotating it so you can find a hyperplane(s) that can reduce the amount of dimensions while only losing a minimal amount of useful variation.
The simplest example is thinking about how OLS regression uses a line to connect 2 dimensions (x and y) down to 1 dimension (the slope!) While minimizing the loss (keep the residuals random).

Oh yes, this goes a long way back, I think the difference is that I'm trying to be pragmatic and accept pay changes may be in order. 

The 4 day workweek studies coming from the EU and similar are assuming no changes to pay - which is fine if productivity isn't dinged, but that's not very radical. 

What's radical is saying, I'll do less for less if it means there will be more for others. 

A big fan of NPR and I've studied some of this stuff extensively in labor economics, what the more theoretically inclined economists sometimes forget is that the substitution effect for people doing a job is extremely difficult to parse. Institutional knowledge is terribly hard to track and the idea that your best of the best will just not be available is hard to imagine. 

Mathematically, if someone is truly a 10X engineer (to use silicon valley phrasing) and you can get X out of their Y'th hour, businesses would be hard hit hiring 3 people to output X in 3 hours. 

So there's a productivity measurement problem here too.

Message:
4) is how do we identify the positives to keep the momentum going, how many parents and/or caretakers are we losing out on because of our 0 or 40 system. How do we maximize the value created by reengaging people into the workforce and into life! How much non monetary benefit will we see in people's engaging with their community, taking up hobbies, being a human being again, etc. 

At the same time, what should we do when this isn't a panacea, when the difficulties of managing more people impact earnings calls and stock values. When people start to consume less and enjoy more, what industries get hit? What industries boom? How do we smooth transitions across industries so we can re-skill, etc. 

There's a lot of complexity that I don't want to overshadow. This isn't going to save the world overnight.

1)  the more bureaucratic concerns of how much are you adding to your tax and healthcare expenditures by massively increasing your head count. The long term vision being that we can work around some of the tax stuff (if the labor costs and taxes work out to be marginal, so two people paying half is no different than 1 person paying full). 

2)  the more human management of a bunch more people, but hopefully we're scaling HR and operations, and mgmt, etc. too. Although I can understand the concerns of just literally managing a larger group that is less available. But we already do this, people work in teams, globally, at different hours, and more people is more ideas.

So let's try to be optimistic and flexible and comfortable with discomfort when we're talking about the livelihood of millions here. We may all need to sacrifice but I think it can work out long term if we make it work. 

If growth didn't work we wouldn't have so many companies with such big head counts. 

3) navigating expectations around what to do with that time. If you're salaried and you take the cut to work less, what culture change needs to happen to not bother you on your days off. How strict do we need to be on broadcasting when we're on or off.

So similar to the education "trap" (not a fan of this wording...) Where people with more income and education have fewer children -- this is because the opportunity cost of taking off work to have an Nth kid rises as your income does- 

Entrepreneurs also face a productivity trap. 

When worker productivity rises, their pay rises (this relationship has weakened significantly since the 1970s unfortunately), which increases the opportunity cost of trying to go solo. 

So not only do we have regulatory traps, e.g. the hurdles of organizing a 401k, healthcare, etc. As a self employed person or small business, but we also have the trap that the best people at their jobs are extremely well paid, making it even harder financially for them to quit working and start their own business because of how quickly the lost wages accumulate. 

Opportunity cost can feel very paradoxical, because income and substitution effects (to use economic vocabulary) can be additive or combative leading you to unexpected equilibriums.

I think individuals can be successful in breaking habits if they align to their personal life structure. 
This article makes a good point that we have tons of talent *not working* because of the 0 or 40 paradigm. 

I personally would take a paycut to do 30ish hours a week and i think I'd surprise myself with how little actually falls off. Between the meetings and emails and IMs that distract me from my deep work, I could recover dozens of hours a month if I had more control over when *others* wanted my attention. I'm trying to slowly change this for myself by condensing my weekly meetings to be mostly Fridays now.

My opinion: 

In reality, the entire medical system is a black box to me. A doctor explaining that my neurodeposits aren't absorbing my chemiproteins ( I don't know biology üòÇ sorry) causing me to feel terrible doesn't actually provide a value-add. 

The value-add is being able to stop or slow the disease through behavioral changes. 

If there are effective behavioral changes that I can make, another black box model trained on those with the disease predicting the factors that prolong survival could be available and I'd just do those things- as opposed to layering on more and more "explainable" models, e.g. doctors, that aren't doing things at massive scale. 

There's also the moral hazard problem. Does choosing XAI for myself lead to more popularity of XAI, does society as a whole suffer because the more accurate model is too scary to use and thus numerous false positives undergo unnecessary pain and treatment (using up resources) and numerous false negatives experience a terrible disease without help. 

Accuracy is real, these are human beings.

Trap of explainability: 

I think there's a small trap here on the explainability. A lot for these explainable AI are using marginal explainers. 

We gave you category A because on random sampling of your features we found retroactively that you being X tall was a class differentiator. We also found that if you were a woman you'd not be in this class given your other features. We also found if you were lower body fat % you'd not be in this class, etc. etc. 

Sure, you can maybe go down the list of class differentiators and pick out the ones that are changeable, but I'm not sure what you do with that information that wasn't obvious prior. 

Eat better? Exercise more? 

Maybe take some new vitamins or medicine, but if those worked at a societal level then a black box model that recommends things for the disease would've found those too lol.

"This decision will help slowdown... suicide in the US" 

This is boldly and in totality untrue.

If the intention was to do that, we'd block *tourist visas* - the ones individuals at risk of poverty can actually afford to get and then overstay. 

Those visas aren't affected. 

The affected visas are explicitly a business regulation forbidding the efficient movement of certain resources by US companies. It's a test to see how much the courts will allow interference into US labor marketplace at the "white collar" level.

A lot of people are going to look at this issue from the lenses of populism, immigration, xenophobia, unemployment, prioritization of citizens, and other lenses that are arguable in their accuracy. 

The simple truth is- this is an embargo. This is a massive new regulation that demands corporations "buy American" (talent). We haven't seen this level of interference into the free marketplace since possibly world war II.

Sure, ice cream and Nicholas Cage movies are a spurious correlation, but I'd note, we really shouldn't be generating features that dont make any sense in their correlations.     We shouldn't confuse an experiment design and feature selection problem with a spurious correlation problem. 

How often are these correlations both spurious AND not easily rationalized about? Having experts in the room should be an enhancement of the conversation around these correlations, not a blocker from using correlation to make decisions (unless the expertise was not used somewhere, e.g. feature engineering).

I mean for me, done is mostly determined by time constraints and specific user stories. Version 1 is done when the user can do X with file type Y and it returns Z. Version 2 will either optimize or add Xs or Ys to get new Zs. 

For more classic science, we try to define every part of the experiment (that we can) ahead of time. 

The data we haven't seen will be transformed into X shape. We'll do Y tests to make sure our sampling assumptions are valid. Then we'll investigate some set of predefined 10-15 questions that will essentially end the experiment early if any of them fail without sufficient rationale to continue. 

Then we'll run these cross folds with this seed ensuring this partitioning split. From there, we'll do X runs with Y burn in on each and we'll accept the feature selection output with the lowest [criteria X] in those runs. 

Those features will be passed forward for X survey adjustment modeling and the out that minimizes criteria Y under these specifications will be accepted to move forward with an expiration date of A or until model drift criteria Y happens, whichever occurs sooner. 

It's not a perfect system, but public health can be a tough field in my experience.

Specifically to #1 - as we were messaging about yesterday- It's super lazy and shows a fundamental misunderstanding of how useful correlations can be. 

Causal inference is for *explaining* something with the purpose of *intervening*. Otherwise, predictive inference with the purpose of prepping / *reacting* is a totally valid thing to do. 

If I predict the stocks go up tomorrow and I'm confident I can react to this prediction by investing today, then correlation totally worked! 

I don't actually need to know *why* they go up unless I intend to do something like push it to go higher via market moving or if I want to replicate the behavior in my stock or similar. 

They're different use cases. So yeah, huge agreement, these stats 101 "gotchas" are definitely overused. At best, they're a distraction and often they're just a means to ignore the results from an experiment and go to confirmation bias.

It's very simple. You are trying to convince a company to pay for your services through a salary.

So you must prove to them you have the skills they need.

Everything must be focused on that 1 task.

Your resume is a SALES DOCUMENT. It is not a restaurant menu. The recruiter does not want the added labor of figuring out which of your 50 skills are good for the company.

Make their job easy and tell stories (career narratives & personal summary) that are targeted, industry specific, and align to your specific goals.

Feel free to read my article, update your resume and send it over. 98% of people (I've done 200+ at this point) don't make updates before sending it to me, so the advice I give is just copy/pasting my article at them lol. PhDs are at best negligible relative to the same amount of time spent doing the job within a team and are at worst crystallizing bad data science practices- not research, I get that's it's great for research skills, but I rarely see PhDs with good programming principles. They're always great at the math but the business, communication, and software engineering tend to be lacking relative to a master's degree + 2-5 years in the field. 

Remember that the average PhD takes like 5-7 years now, so the opportunity cost over a master's is HUGE now. 

I actively discourage PhDs, especially considering the rate of ABDs. 

Funny enough, I work with a lot of great data scientists who dropped from PhD programs and just took the master's and went into industry. 

Before I get destroyed, yes I can see the value for novel ML algorithm creation and research scientists. But a master's + 2-4 years learning on the job > PhD + 0-1 year on the job in my opinion.

Note: I do realize tensorflow is a python/C application with primary support to python and that the R version is a 3rd party API layered on C with not all the available options. But, nonetheless, if you're using APIs to access your ML it's cool to know you can use R if you're already good at it.
T mobile uses R for millions of $$ in impacts.

Well what are the user stories- 

1) have one because it's expected so I post my resume but never engage (competition: resumes, personal websites)

2) have one to view content from people I follow (competition: Twitter, medium, Instagram, bookmarking others websites) 

3) have one to connect to industry leaders and engage with their stuff (competition: twitter, conferences, Instagram, email) 

4) have one to find jobs / talent (competition: resumes, indeed, conferences, icims)

5) have one to actively learn (competition: twitter, YouTube, Coursera, Udemy, medium, conferences)

6) have one to build a following (competition: twitter, personal websites, YouTube, medium)

7) have one to view current events from specific flavors eg. Business (competition: twitter, YouTube, news sites) 

People have multiple use cases, Linkedin needs to identify which it's prioritizing so it can scale. 

It's failed to be medium (weak articles), it fails to be YouTube (weak search), it fails to be conferences (weak groups), it's improving on learning (Lynda), it's excellent at resume dump, it's okay at follower building, it's improving on jobs but is top tier on finding talent. Its worsening on current events (used to have 1 general thread per event).

They need to invest better in search, then based on what people actually try and do (and inevitably fail to find b/c content isn't indexed well) they can upgrade their algorithms etc. 

I think they've struggled to avoid becoming Myspace so they've been hyper conservative on changes to UX, UI, etc. (Remember they splintered the jobs app then reintegrated it later... That was the most radical experiment I've seen them try).

 They want people to do the low effort join & resume dump so they can inflate user metrics. The next evolution is to judge based on user *use*. 

But overall I'm optimistic they'll figure it out. The stories idea is terrible, idk why they think they compete with Instagram. Their competition is email and conferences. I hope they see that and can focus on the core user stories.

False negatives are not always more dangerous than false positives in public health contexts. 

They need to be quantified. 

If the result of a false negative is 1 person getting ill (not the case here but just noting) it's possible that if the test specificity is low, that false positives are more harmful in net, if they lead to numerous people undergoing risky procedures and expensive follow-on tests. There are some examples of this in the cancer testing & imaging domain.

I love answering random questions, but like you say that's guidance not mentorship. 

And to some extent, I think people are doing themselves a disservice by going to random "experts" (I'm not an expert so the quotes are for me lol) and trying to get their life sorted out. If your goals are in finance and you ask me what to learn and I say something outdated due to my ignorance of the field, then I've harmed you but you also harmed yourself by not doing the work to ensure I'm the right person to ask. So I hesitate to give situation specific advice beyond standard resume review and resources on general topics. 

That's my biggest point I think, that a *great* mentorship is targeted and specific. 

If you just need guidance and some FAQs that's so more scalable but less investment. 

I'd note that when I say you might not need a mentor, I say so in the context of *a specific goal*. 

If you just need a job that pays X within 3 months that's not really a mentorship problem. Although a mentor could help. 

A mentorship problem is about moving up Maslow's hierarchy of needs, aligning to your goals of self actualization through fine-tuning goal definition, building up momentum long term, and catching you when you fall off the path.
