I think most people are just going through the motions and don't have particular goals or anything so I can't really help them. 

So for me, it's about how much effort are they putting in, because I can multiply effort, I can't substitute for it. 

If 1hr/week for 6 months puts then 2 years ahead in their career, then I'll do it because my marginal impact is insane there. 

The vast majority of resume review or other requests I get (what courses, what MOOCs, what degree, what company, what jobs) show less than 0 effort. They actually avoided obvious things like the articles and posts and videos readily available to them. 

They don't have the long term mindset to really benefit from the relationship. 

It's not an insult. I think it took me 8 or 9 years working full time in various jobs (I've been working like a dog since I was like 14 lol) for it to click.
But I have considered asking people I do resume reviews for to donate 1% of their marginal salary raise to charities of my choice if my resume advice helps them land a job.

Where people tend to make mistakes in looking for a mentor (I know I have, that's why I've never really had one lol) is: 

1) they just spam ask for one. They don't do the work nor respect the seriousness of what they're asking. "will you invest in me"- maybe! But I can't invest more than you invest in yourself. 

2) they don't know what they want. No one can coach you if you don't tell them what game it is. 

3) they think having a mentor is a shortcut. It's not, it's very possible the the fast way and the right way are totally different. You may be able to get a job paying X in 3 months or you can study for 6 months and land a job paying 2X. A mentor is there to help you find the balance based on your *specific* goals.

Tools matter!    I'm not interested in talking about r vs python for mature data scientists who have mastered 1 or the other, they've already seen dozens of problems and learned to think tool agnostically *because they've become proficient in the tool(s)*. 

But for someone at step 0, I think tools will literally alter the way their brain frames and solves problems, we naturally solve problems based on the context of our ability to solve them. 

So when I hear a problem about text, I think of R, tf-idf, n-grams, and more basic and interpretable methods *first*. I only bring up semantic embeddings and doc2vec and cosine blah blah if the problem proves to need those things. 

People from python backgrounds (that I've worked with) go direct to ensembled NLP methods leveraging pretrained models to do doc2vec and sentiment score, etc. That tool makes those things really easy and that's what they learned in their bootcamps and those models are very powerful. 

I'm not saying ones better than the other. But when you've learned an axe it's harder to solve knife problems and vice versa. 

This are real neurological and pedagogical stuff behind our tool usage.

Dude step 0 is not easy. I think there's a separate issue where I've just never been in a community that uses Python and like does knowledge sharing and best practices around it.

So I didn't have any ready resources to help me. 

In R, our company has a center of excellence in R, R best practice bookdowns, monthly R calls, multiple R groups, multiple asynchronous R courses, multiple R resource collections. 

Nobody who does or likes Python ever really started that at my job. I've never seen the community around Python, definitely not doubting it exists. It's too big not to exist, but this isn't rare. Friends at other firms and companies also note that R communities bubbled up at their jobs where python ones didn't. 

Could be that DC has a lot of academia types or something, or could be that R has RStudio backing it so there's shiny and markdown and shiny servers, etc. 

Even my clients tend to host shiny servers and use R and then python has to go through the virtual machines / docker teams to get used in production.

I think this is a bit of a meme take to be honest. 

You can't learn to build a house through understanding the intrinsic nature of the materials and the physics that hold up the walls and the philosophy of the drywall. 

You grab some tools and you start small. 

The tool you start with has HUGE implications for how you think about these problems including not just OOP and FP, it actually molds the way your brain frames problems based on your understanding of how *you* would solve it mechanically (i.e. tools). 

We're a tools species, the idea that we are a separate entity from our tools, that we're some higher being atheistically grabbing the sword or the axe in some purely rational goal-oriented way defies hundreds of years of psycho-anthropology. 

We are our tools. 

If you accept that experiment design is a tool and, so is logic and so is the scientific method, you quickly realize there is not some higher order homunculus choosing the sword or the axe. It's an embodied mind with a set of experiences and knowledge of the sword or the axe guessing and iterating on which tool solves which problems.

In layman's terms it's the table that counts your false positives and false negatives vs your correct answers. You use it to calculate accuracy, recall, precision, F1, and other metrics of model "accuracy". Although it's important to note some problems have bias toward false positives or false negatives due to cost implications. 

For rare diseases (or other unbalanced data üòâ) it's critical to actually assign your false cases a cost. It's very possible that a false negative that allows someone to live with a disease is actually less harmful than the false positives that put hundreds+ at risk from performing unnecessary treatments. 

A lot of ethical questions are hidden in this table, don't overlook it.

Think of it this way. You have to balance ATS and humans. 

You can bias toward ATS and double your through rate, but if it costs you a 51%+ drop in human through rate you've come out negative. 

Much better to focus at the top of the pipeline in making a sales document that convinces a person to talk to you. 

Good HR systems don't exclusively trust ATS and ignore all resumes that don't get through. 

And in reality, the best way to get a job is to go around the system and get in through specific people that will vouch for you.   Lots of articles on pain letters, finding HR emails, how to ask for referrals, etc.

I'll note that [[ behavior is actually more consistent with the fact that data frames are lists.  [ , i ] should return a dataframe, it's weird to me it doesn't! But I guess they wanted [i] to be the preserving subset...

Tibbles make data frames *behave like lists* which they're supposed to be. 

[[ i ]] works for both df and tibble.  

[ , i ] works for df but not tibble which I think is bad. It really *should* return a df (the way [ i ] does). 

That would make [[ subsetting more list-like.

Bonus for those looking for DS jobs. 

Your GitHub should not be 1 repo with a bunch of projects. That's not how GitHub works lol. 

1 project = 1 repo. 

You should be using git as you develop your projects, that way the repo *has a commit history*. 

You should make extensive READMEs that read like a blog post. You can insert images into your README, so put in those clean EDA plots and that nice model output tables. 

I promise you, no recruiter is going to read that homework2.ipynb and be excited to call you in for an interview. 

Projects are an example of how you *do the work* not showing off the finished product (although it's not really finished without a README). 

2nd Bonus: 

Know 1-2 sentences about a lot of technologies, while focusing nearly 90%+ of your time on only 2-4 technologies. 

What's the difference between Docker and Linux? (Not a trick question, if you know they're very different that's good). 

What's the difference between Jupyter Notebook and RStudio? 

What is Redshift? What is Lambda? What is EC2? What is S3? 

Can you describe a data pipeline in terms of tools, even if you don't know how to build one in terms of what you click and when? 

Would you believe I only know R, QGIS, Excel, and PowerBI?

I think your identification of outliers is a little off, you can identify outliers using the *standard deviation* (many do, sometimes 3+ standard deviations is considered an outlier) because it's in the same units. 

Average height of tree is 10m, this tree is 22m, the variance is 16m^2, so the standard deviation is 4m. That makes the 22m tree exactly 3 standard deviations above the mean. 

Note: height is actually a truncated normal, since trees have minimum heights and cannot be infinitely tall either.

I'll note tho that many irrational decisions are only irrational in the time-context being analyzed. Whether they be because of insanely high discount rates or misaligned incentives (e.g. stocks and the short term bias of quarterly reports) there are often methods to the madness detailing how what 1 model labels as irrational is actually an invitation for another model to contextualize the decision making process. 

This is how we convert things like principle agent problems, moral hazard, and game theory into quantifiable things.

I know, I feel like such a naysayer, so I replied to someone about pipes elsewhere: 

--------

I just think pipes lead newbies down a bad path of debugging, specifically overuse of comment out debugging (what I've called lvl 1 debugging elsewhere). 

I like that pipes don't store temporary objects which saves RAM and time, but I see so much like 5-15 layers of pipes and I just get anxious lol. Those are begging to be rewritten into a new function that is unit tested. 

So I'm not anti-pipes functionally, I just think people use them poorly and I'm not sure I'll follow my own advice if I start üòÇ.

It's open source- go read source code and pick up a style! You wouldn't read a book that was just 1 giant paragraph. You have to break things apart and think about how code review is a visual process as much as it is a reading process. 

Your layout and use of space actually boost your readability. 

Here's a picture of my R function style (not in roxygen2 format) in a REPREX on non standard evaluation. 

Keep every line < 80chars 
Use lots of vertical white space 
Every argument on its own line (and split content of arguments as needed)
Detail the function input and output 
Always put all your libraries at the top, not interspersed throughout your script 
Make REPRoducible EXamples, they will help you think through functional programming.

My answer: 

Random error is the best error. It is purely just bad (or good) luck that your data was that point instead of it's expected value. When I measure the weight of apples to buy, random error is the tiny fluctuations of the scale that add (or subtract) pennies just due to the standard difficulties of weighing objects and pricing them instantly. 

Systemic error is essentially, any non random error. It could be error because I've selected the wrong type of apple, it could be error because the scale is broken and consistently adds several ounces, or it could be error related to the machine not having the right price per pound. 

Systematic error is the error that is controllable through a process.

Why are our children growing up in chaos? Why is income inequality worse than all the surveys of the American people show is acceptable to them? Why are 80% of Americans not adequately invested in their future? Why do 80%+ of jobs created in the last decade demand credentials only 30% of us have?

You will see power law distributions a lot in real life.  Also, a key differentiator for a data scientist is being able to work in poisson and other non-normal distributions so you don't go straight to "I'll just log it". 

Logging your data impacts not only interpretability, but it can also impact all kinds of measures from R^2 to p value and others.

Statistically significant relationships for log transformed data *can be completely irrelevant* when trying to reverse course and make comments about the data in it original form.

Those numbers sound big, but is.X, as.X, and function arguments would count too in those big numbers. If you actually saw a list of 1000+ functions and methods and arguments and concepts you'd be like oh, I actually am familiar with so many of these / know what they do from reading the name / can understand the theory behind these functions so I'm not shocked they exist.

You shouldn't like explicitly make flashcards to memorize code, but you really should not have to Google every little thing. You want to build your access memory (knowing exactly which keywords will get you to that stackoverflow page you remember solved your problem 6 months ago) but also want to have your fundamentals. 
.

For me, base R is my fundamentals. I do probably 90%+ of my programming in base until I have a speed issue that requires me to move to data.table or other. Or, for very specific functions like group_by and summarize, but even then, split(), lapply() covers a lot of those bases too. 

I'm under unique constraints though, I can't just spam download every package under the sun and expect it to work in my clients production systems, I have to navigate their custom CRAN and the dependencies (including which versions of which packages are incompatible). 

You really should have around 2-300 functions (and concepts, i.e. error codes, classes, etc.) memorized within your first year or so, then another 500-1000+ you can confidently access via tuned keyword search. (don't just copy paste your entire error, actually follow the traceback and do some debugging and identify that X class and Y function aren't returning Z)

Link to day 3: random forest

General hints / answers. 

More trees = more complex = more processing time. 

Typically RF doesn't need training/test splits because of the way it resamples data with replacement (which someone once told me is fake data and I disagreed and it was a whole thing) although there are methods that test the trees based on data that tree hasn't seen. 

So let's accept overfitting isn't as much of a concern, which is a major plus of the model. 

You should be taking into account *how many features you have* and how much complexity you want the RF to allow, as it will inevitably generate all kinds of weird engineered features containing interactions of the input features that may be performative but impossible to explain to someone.  

You can look into iterative random forests for help on this one. 

Aaron Haskins, MS - you may have made a big jump between days 1,2, and 3 LOL. 1 was simple, 2 was medium, 3 is probably medium-hard. 

I'm not sure I am fully correct on my point about interactions.

This reminds me of a slide I saw at RStudio conference. Your loss function is the most important part of the user experience (this was from Google's AI team presentation at the conference)

It determines how many similar search results they get, it determines which results make the cutoff to be shown, the order they're shown in. 

The optimal number of trees needs to be a conversation with stakeholders on what their outcomes are. Do they want to use these ranked importance measures as a means for feature selection? What is there speed vs performance concern? How often can they realistically retrain? 

This is a tough question which is great. Excited to see other's more technical answers probably including some AUC stuff.
When was ARCH made? I know the nobel prize for creating it was given in 2003 probably decades later, but I don't follow finance much.
Just to specify- the mean of the sample estimates are normally distributed around the population estimate. You can use this to estimate several features from the population, not just its mean.

So whites test and visualizing your data (you can even do funny stuff like rolling variance calculations) are useful for identifying the issue. 

When your data has different variances you can transform it (log, weighted least squares) or you can use different techniques (e.g. ARCH / GARCH from time series domain).

You can use White's test (even for non normally distributed data). The important thing about differences in variance is that it makes comparison more difficult (more math) and less precise (try t.test in R with var.equal = TRUE vs FALSE). 

It also violates critical assumptions like the normality of residuals. 

But... Take it a step further, if your residuals are not normally distributed is it possible they are autocorrelating? This takes your analysis into a totally different direction. Are you missing time series features? Spatial features? Is there a structural issue in your data collection? 

Correlated residuals can also imply you shouldn't use basic linear models (visualize your data and identify if maybe incorporating splines into your line can help).

Here's my answer to (1) - Given a population you cant typically survey the entirety of, you take some number of samples (ideally independently and and identically distributed) and calculate an estimate of each sample. 

The average of those sample estimates will converge to the population estimate as the number of samples grows.

This framework makes it easier to talk about what is and *isn't* causal inference. We know that it is the weight of the car that causes lower miles per gallon *even if* mpg is highly predictive of weight with a highly interpretable set of coefficients.

I use a different set of spectrums. 

Predictive vs explainable. 

Predictive is biased to neural networks where you typically can't do a full audit of every part of the decision process, but it's highly predictive and you can use model agnostic explainers to understand the marginal decision making process - as in, what feature(s) (when removed) most quickly change the classification (e.g. LIME or SHAP)

Explainable is about *causality* - you model a phenomenon to explain reality in a way that allows you to *intervene*. 

If you cannot intervene, then explainability doesn't matter that much. If all I care about is if the stock market is going up or down tomorrow, then I just want the most predictive model, I don't care *why* it goes up or down tomorrow (maybe because I don't think the causes will have the same impact in the future). 

Interpretability is a third axis distinguishing why the model made its decision (in totality vs local explainers, which I wish were called local interpreters). 

Your regression picked 63 because Ax + By + Cz = 63 and this data point had a lot of z and the C coefficient is big. 

Your neural network picked 63.4 because the sigmoids and the hidden blah blahs... Well, who really knows.

A funny thing happening right now in urban economics / regional planning circles is the question about how we update models around location theory. 

We expect that people pay a premium to live closer to work and that work is typically located downtown in tall buildings with expensive real estate. The homes near here are typically small and expensive and also in tall buildings. 

Above a certain income level, people pay a premium to have larger homes farther away because the transportation cost is relatively small. 

But if people are working from home, then transportation stops losing its comparative advantage to home sizes. 

So will home sizes increase? Will people move farther? Or will they move closer because other people move farther? 

The balancing forces here are called income effect vs substitution effect.

Things shouldn't be valued at their cost-, they should be valued at their impact. 

A $10 pencil isn't worth $9 more than a $1 pencil, it's worth: 

The added happiness from smoothness + the value of the activity you get to do in the time gained from the smooth pencil (less mistakes, faster writing, etc.)  

These costs cannot be defined exogenously, they are defined at the individual level (this is "consumer surplus" - essentially individual profit).

It's pretty common for people who face scenarios to assume those scenarios share *equal* probability - because they accurately recognize that all probabilities sum to 1. 

The bias is to assume they are equal probability *until data tells us otherwise*. This is actually a natural Bayesian framework to have- with no data my prior assumption is 50/50. Then data changes your mind. 

"Is it going to rain or be sunny tomorrow? I want to go to the beach" 

"I'm not sure, but I'm willing to drive to the beach tomorrow even if there's a 50% chance we have to turn around for rain". 

The existence of 2 scenarios doesn't implicitly tell us anything about the probabilities of those scenarios. 

Having an informed prior (to continue the Bayesian reference) is dangerous (which is why many don't like informative priors) but it can be *useful* when that assumption is grounded in some history not caught in the data. 

Example of a prior actually making some sense: 

"... I'm willing to drive to the beach tomorrow even if there's a 50% chance I have to turn around, because last year in June, it only rained 13 days, so my odds might even be better than 50/50". 

The historical information informs our prior estimate and now 50/50 isn't so crazy.

I see it as a proxy for understanding the statistics behind our code. 

If I do a t test and my p value is 0.03 and I incorrectly say to a business person, "there's only a 3% chance that B is NOT better than A" - I could be negatively impacting their decision-making process that leads to hurt revenue. 

Whereas if I said the more accurate, "in our sample data, B performed better than A and the difference meets our decision making threshold to switch to B next quarter" they have the important info and no disinformation. 

That incorrect confusion of Frequentist and Bayesian relationships to probability could make them overconfident, it could poison their perception next quarter when they hear a different incorrect percentage and start looking into the difference between the p values as if they were exogenous things that exist outside of a model. 

I know I'm mixing "understanding philosophies" with "actually knowing statistics" but they're correlated and having Bayesian frameworks in your toolkit definitely doesn't hurt.

This is my best shot, might be a little wrong, happy to get feedback. 

You have a bunch of points in N dimensional space (e.g. 2). If you rotate that space you can identify some angle to put an N-1 dimensional plane (e.g. a line) into that space that minimizes some function (e.g. squared distance). You now have a reference to the points relative to that plane that is uncorrelated (e.g. The residuals of OLS)

You can repeatedly identify these uncorrelated components and boom you've reduced the dimensions of your data and created (somewhat) interpretable combinations of the features (the planes) for analysis on this smaller (but variance preserved) data.

Just to nuance this a little bit, you're using a Frequentist framework- data "representing" anything is Frequentist. 

The Bayesian framework is that you have an assumption and you have data. Your data doesn't come from or represent some magical place or population that is unmeasurable. Your data is fact and it is your assumptions that much be altered to fit the data. This is the *posterior* and it is fundamentally probabilistic. 

You aren't chasing an estimate of something you can't measure.
Adrian Olszewski -sounds like you're doing real science and we're just playing baking soda volcano.

Frequentist: accepting this data is representative sample of a true population I can't measure, how far off can my data estimate be from the population estimate that I change my opinion of the population estimate. 

Bayesian: given a prior understanding of the phenomenon, what is the probability that this data occurs and how low does that probability have to be before I update the prior understanding. 

P values are unfortunately used by Frequentists to incorrectly get the value from Bayesian analysis without doing the tough work of identifying a reasonable prior. 

Some even say that informative priors are definitionally *bad* because they are just arbitrary bias injected into your modeling. It is somehow lost on these people that p values are themselves arbitrary bias injected into your model, especially when you set a p value halfway through to analysis or worse change it in hindsight.

Yeah, so essentially all stats 101 courses (and thus a lot of people's exposure to business analytics) is fundamentally Frequentist. 

You have data, you make assumptions about that data representing a "true" population, and then you do things like t test to test hypothesis- accepting this data is representative, what estimate of the mean (or any other measure really) and interval around the mean would contain the true mean 95% of the time. 

It assumes you have one of infinite representative samples (technically not always infinite depending on the data*) and you want to make sure your sample estimate is not "random chance" extremely different from the population. 

This is the standard approach for nearly all statistical experiments and it leads to easy opportunities to misunderstand things like p values. 

P values don't actually tell you anything about the relationship between your data and the truth.

Truth comes from trust in your data and the experiment design. 

You can have a totally informative p value of 0.35 and a totally useless one at 0.00001. 

Bayesian inference uses priors (sometimes informed) to tell you the probability that this data occurs given an assumed truth.

Here's my general resume feedback that I give a lot, copy/pasted:

----------------------
Here's my guidance on resumes. 

https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/your-resume-doesnt-excite-you-its-boring-recruiters-carlos-mercado-1e

It's very simple. You are trying to convince a company to pay for your services through a salary. 

So you must prove to them you have the skills they need. 

Everything must be focused on that 1 task. 

So you: 

1) choose an industry (example: finance) 
2) take courses on data science for that industry 
3) create personal projects showing you understand how to get data and do science with it. 
4) write a resume that is *obvious* that you are a good fit for that role. 

Don't copy others. Don't watch videos all day. 

DO an industry specific data science process with industry specific data. 

It is very simple, but not easy.

1) do you understand data collection and common issues - the more understanding of survey design the better. 

2) can you articulate the fundamental differences in frequentist and Bayesian statistical philosophy. Bonus for understanding how p values are *actually meant to be used*. 

3) do you have fundamentals of statistical programming: cutting numerics into factors, releveling, OOP vs FP, understanding of O notation, understanding that memory allocation and garbage collection do matter (even if you can't necessarily allocate and schedule gc in your everyday code), can you debug without commenting out lines. 

4) if I give you visuals can you interpret them and add nuance unprompted.

5) can you manage a meeting and ensure the meeting (which probably cost $1000+ each) have measurable progress 

6) have you worked within a data science or product team, do you know how data science fits into puzzles as often only a single piece. 

Leetcode and OLS by hand are useless, so is trick questions, rabbit holes, gotchas, etc.

Data viz recommendation: 

1) you're using raw count, for full country list comparisons you may want to do % GDP and make it a map if you're going to have 100+ countries. 

2) since you probably don't want a map, it may make sense to only include countries with extreme values or countries with similarities to your target narrative countries (maybe 10-15 countries) of similar GDP/capita, population, total economy size, etc. 
3) consider weighted average comparisons like OECD, G7, EU, SEA, etc. This will add context while showing impact of individual countries affecting the group (e.g. G7 vs US vs G7-US). 

The narrative isn't that 100+ small countries have small trade balances in raw numbers (we already know that it's a consequence of being small). The narrative is that countries we often compare to each other and that have massive trade economies have different trade balances. 

But honestly, most economists don't worry about trade balance in the way you're describing could be a concern. There are so many services that cannot be traded (e.g. haircuts) that trade imbalances don't tell you *that* much about economy health. 

Of course *changes* in trade imbalances might üòú especially for countries with low GDP/Capita.

If you want a multiplication problem- just say what's 2/10ths of 70 million. 

If you want a survey design question, ask what they know about the risks of using simple random sampling on diverse populations and see if they bring up clustering, weighting, and stratification correctly. 

But even some of these answers from others are technically wrong. 

If you have several easily undersampled groups in a population, the confidence interval would not be a simple 0.5M each way around 14M. 

There's geographic correlation concerns around how the data could have been sampled as well. 

I'm leaning toward it's a bad question, what is there to gain by giving someone a rabbit hole and seeing how far they go down it? 

Very much not modern data science interview theory (if one exists).

Maybe I'm just hung up because you framed a multiplication problem as a survey problem, and surveys are by design complex. As soon as I read "survey" I'm like, ok this interview wants me to clarify that I understand stratification, clustering, problems with simple random sampling in the context of surveying online behaviors, and the context of the naive answer implying that this website is more popular than YouTube by multiple amounts (which is clearly insane).
A naive calculation would say your website is nearly 1/4th as popular as YouTube, the most visited website in the world, in *just* the UK. Lol. The trap doesn't end.

These always stress me out. A random sample of 10,000 /70,000,000 population and 2k *of your sample* visited the website? 

That would be an astoundingly popular website, likely Netflix level of popular. To even visit a website requires some ability to navigate the internet, including having internet in the first place, being, well you know not an infant which would inevitably be some % of your truly random sample. 

Without some kind of demographic information or understanding of what your website is there's no way to I'd be comfortable saying 14 million people visited your site. 

How was the sample captured? By telephone? Did you sample 10,000 internet users? Was there selection bias? 

Just feels like a trap question in so many ways.

If you define artificial intelligence as any system that lets a computer act like a person- machine learning, NLP, RPA, computer vision, spellcheck, auto-pilot, etc. all count. 

I personally like to use regression as like the foundational ML algorithm that everybody at least roughly understands. Once you understand OLS you can shift them to other GLMs and penalized regression, then you can tilt them to SVM, then start bringing up less interpretable stuff. 

I understand that many see it as a "sales" exaggeration, but I think including classic interpretable methods actually makes businesses less afraid of "real" AI because it gives them stepping stones to the fancy stuff. 

Plus, regression is really good at prediction for some problems.

Eric Weber - I know you said you had nothing to add, but any recommended nuance or context a recruiter borrowing this JD would benefit from?

How I would write a senior DS JD (with the expectation that they hit at least 70-80% of these with impact ready experience): 

*Talk about the team, the culture, the kind of problems solved, what piece of the puzzle you're hoping to replace or expand*. 


- production experience in Python, R, or Scala. Experience in X domain would be a bonus. 
- publication level data visualization experience in at least one of: Plotly, ggplot2, seaborn, power BI, Tableau, or similar. 
- experience working within Agile. 

["Back End" DS]: 
- experience in one of Azure, AWS, or GCP, specifically in the use of Docker or Kubernetes with Git for ML Engineering or CI/CD products would be preferred. Experience with the entire pipeline is preferred, but at a minimum should be able to contribute to production within 30-60 days.

["Front End" DS]:
- experience in business process improvement and managing stakeholders as it relates to creating ML applications. 
- client facing experience in 3+ of: scoping work, developing timelines, performing requirements analysis, data storytelling, ROI calcs.  

A manager DS would have experience with these + managing the contribution of 2-5+ data scientists in this work. 

A director, maybe 5-20+, or 2-5+ managers.

We are using MS Teams to great effect on our DS team. Screenshare, phone calls, IM, all work to keep us connected. Honestly to some extent the video chatting and casual clothes has made collaboration easier to some extent. Way less formality fluff. Message: Rahul Roy I know! That wasn't an attack on you or your skills, it's just important to caveat these imputation methods have major risks and people just starting in DS tend to forget nuance and just numpy/pandas without thinking.

By definition it is not making up data, it's duplicating your real data randomly. 

Benefits of doing this are that it *empirically* can improve prediction. 

Everything is relative. I probably wouldn't use resampling on a causal analysis problem, but I probably would use it on a weather forecasting problem. 

There are situations where "arbitrarily" (it's really not arbitrary, it's just random) reducing your variance through these methods actually improves your model.

I am very against most imputation methods. Best thing to do is revisit data collection process, 2nd best thing to do is possibly drop data or code it as missing (to verify missingness is not systemic), I would do bootstrapping or other resampling before I'd do mean imputation. 

If you really must impute, consider MICE or other more nuanced methods rather than averages.

Things I would describe as fundamental to understand about AI: 

1) examples of the subfields- ML, NLP, Computer Vision, Expert Systems 

Your spellcheck is AI, you're just used to it.

2) understanding prediction vs explanation as a spectrum so you can accurately definite problems and potential solutions. 

If understanding why doesn't affect your ability to *intervene* then all that matters is prediction. If you could predict the stock market with 99.999% accuracy for several weeks you wouldn't care why you were right, you'd be rich! 

3) understanding that interpretability is different from explainability. You can interpret highly predictive models without being able to fully explaining how the decision was made through a full audit trail. Check out LIME, SHAP, and similar model algorithms.

4) true explainability is fundamentally *a causal analysis*. 

Poverty is associated with pollution- but pollution doesn't directly affect your income (it can make worsen health, which affects income) - but poverty can cause you to live in a polluted area. 

5) prediction is a framework. 

Training/testing splits require domain expertise. Temporal or spatial correlations must be accounted for. Also, the bias vs variance trade-off is real!

They're all terrible, but I'm going to pick on the GDP one because those charts are unfortunately quite popular. 

1) understand what your point is ahead of time, it's clear they want to show the US "overspends" on healthcare. So keep that line. 

2) Identify a few key countries that "compete" with the US, e.g. countries with similar GDP/capita or sized economies or populations (e.g. Germany, Japan, China, UK, France, Spain, Italy, Russia, Brazil)

3) add aggregations line weighted average for EU, OECD average, etc. 

Data visualization is about storytelling, if a line isn't adding marginal value to the plot, then remove it.

I'm slowly learning the importance of *infrastructure*. 

Being tool agnostic truly requires you understand the client infrastructure. I've gotten a bit lucky sometimes on that and a bit burned on it sometimes. 

Otherwise the more I learn about product management the more I realize people don't know what they want - they know that there is a problem preventing them from being a better version of themselves - whether that means a more efficient or a less stressed or a promoted self is only partly relevant.

If they knew how to get from step A to step Z, *they wouldn't have brought you in*.

Everyone has done the titanic dataset ad nauseum. It's important to do projects that are novel, on new data (i.e. you found and merged disparate datasets with a plan to check a specific hypothesis). 

Even with major bootcamps, they do the same cancer detection computer vision problem on the same dataset for everyone. It's not original. 

The goal is get outside of academia style programming where everything is nice and orderly into the real world of "I have a hunch, my dream data is X, the best I can do is Y, if my hunch is true, this would be the result." Then you do the analysis and test your hunch. 

Don't do a cancer detection portfolio project if you're trying to get a job in finance...

Level 3 debugging is automated testing for those curious. Testthat package is useful for this, but I rarely need this level of debugging.

Commenting out is lvl 1 debugging, lvl 2 debugging is tracebacks and browsers. It's important to level up our debugging skills so we don't have stray commented out code. 

I once received a SAS macro (30+ pages in length printed out...) With essentially a decision tree handwritten on the side- if A then comment out lines 45 and 232, otherwise if B leave line 45 but comment out 113-115, and 202,.... 

Naturally we converted everything into an R Shiny application with checkboxes and sliders to ingest all that logic.

Yep, that's why I started with Excel first. I took Advanced Excel courses on Udemy before I ever learned R. 

Excel was (and is) the data program numbers wise. Everybody knows Excel - and I've said this before, you can really impress people when you go into their home court and show them you have advanced moves there too - find, mid, left, right, VLOOKUP, index-match, pivots, charts, buttons, mini-macros, shortcuts, etc. 

That's also why my updated internal R courses (possibly open source-ing the most beginner one) focus on *when you must graduate out of Excel* - there are plenty of times where you want to use Excel instead of R. 

But you choose R (or Python) over Excel for: 

Reproducibility first! 


Every other good reason to switch is secondary to the core function of reproducibility.

I would love a list of like 30-100 of these to share with people. 

 Everyone asks me, "how do I get into data science?" And I consistently reply, "why do you want to be in it? What industry or applications interest you?". 

The answer too often is money, prestige, working in a new country. It's never, "I'm obsessed with the food supply chain" or "I want to fight fraud and scammers that prey on the elderly" or "I think data science can help cure diseases". 

It is much harder to get a job when you don't care about the company's mission and just want to get paid to play with data. 

You have to bring purpose to the data too.

Having been in sales I'd like to remind the conversation - *there are only so many cold calls possible in a time period*. 

If you do 500 calls / week you burn 2k contacts a month. Presumably in an industry there are only 10s of thousands of potential customers. You really DONT want to hit them all too soon or too often, or you could get your whole company blacklisted for being too disturbing. 

We need to bring the Economics of scarcity back into sales and make sure every call is individually maximized as much as possible.

Ok ok, it is functionally overfitting- I accept it is not definitionally overfitting. 

I think we're on the same page though that seed-hacking is dangerous outside of specific contexts like ensuring your training sets are not crazy or making sure your k means initial points aren't like illogical (e.g. you have a truncated range of values but your initial k means point is just accidentally outside legal range).

?? This is semantics guys. 

If you use seeds to tune your in-sample accuracy, it will mess up your out of sample accuracy. 

This is classic bias-variance trade-off lol. 

It isn't just a cross-folds thing. 

If I only have 1 train set and 1 test set and I am hacking my seed to up my accuracy on my train set- the functional effect is overfitting. 

I can accept that the formal meaning of overfitting does not encompass seed-hacking, but it's not functionally different lol.

I mean- I can accept it is heavily context dependent. 

I could consider hypothetically setting a seed in a way that the cross folds are within some range of similarity to each other (i.e. so I don't just randomly get a cross fold with 90% of a column being the same) but that's such a niche case... 

The average Joe typing seed(1), run script, check F1 score, seed(2), run script, check F1 score, etc. Until their F1 score exceeds some ideal value is definitionally overfitting lol. 

K means initialization, eh, I guess I get what you mean in a small sense... 

The same way some industries think informative priors in Bayesian analysis are terrible while other industries pretty much require them... 

But I must be missing something, please expand if you can.

I can understand for demoing something you may want to give the algorithm some positive lighting (I'm not above hacking demo data just to prove an  obvious point) but when the time comes- I just use my same old seed just for my favorite number.

7,000+ resumes reviewed by 480+ recruiters and resume experts. 

2 pagers consistently ranked higher EVEN AT THE ENTRY LEVEL, even when they *self-admitted* that 1 page is best and 2 pages is only for the most experience. 

Again, never assume people truly know their own preferences. 

I like 1 page things cause it's less reading- but I like 2 page things when I want to have extra information to assess something. 

Another bias that might be hidden here is the mere exposure effect. Simply holding something (or seeing someone) for a longer period of time makes you biased towards liking it more. 

Now- naturally the counterpoint here is "Carlos- these people know they're in a study, they have all day to review these. It's not like they're at their job under a time constraint. When it counts they'll appreciate brevity".

That is a great counterpoint- one that you should seriously consider. 

The answer isn't to ignore this evidence and assume the evidence-less position. The answer is to make sure that if you do write 2 pages, it is actually engaging, informative, and a good sales document. 

https://www.resumego.net/research/one-or-two-page-resumes/

Here's my guidance on resumes. 

https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/your-resume-doesnt-excite-you-its-boring-recruiters-carlos-mercado-1e

It's very simple. You are trying to convince a company to pay for your services through a salary. 

So you must prove to them you have the skills they need. 

Everything must be focused on that 1 task. 

So you: 

1) choose an industry (example: finance) 
2) take courses on data science for that industry 
3) create personal projects showing you understand how to get data and do science with it *for that industry*
4) write a resume that is *obvious* that you are a good fit for that role. 

Don't copy others. Don't watch videos all day. 

DO an industry specific data science process with industry specific data. 

It is very simple, but not easy.

I'm gonna detract slightly only because in the actual process of getting a job you have to show proficiency in whichever language the rest of the org is actively using. 

If you know python in an R shop with RConnect and RStudio Server Pro, etc. You're going to stick out like a sore thumb. 

Also, you realistically are *learning programming* while learning one or the other language. This has a *huge* impact on how you think of computer science problems. 

Python users become wired for OOP, and I think R users become wired for FP. 

Ultimately, you hit a point where you become proficient in both OOP and FP in either language. But it makes noticeable impacts for all the projects you're on if you have certain biases at the time you're on it.

Message:
Data scientist: 
Python/R/SQL, git, business exp. 

Data engineer: 
Python/Scala, AWS, big-data / cloud exp.    Business experience less important, even some statistics exp may be less important (HIGHLY role/company dependent).  

(Edit: like David notes, engineers also use git and other overlapping tools). 

The dream scenario is DS works with Analytics & business teams to do EDA and work toward final model prototype and metrics for model drift based on usable sample of the big/flow of data. They translate the relevant business requirements into technical requirements for APIs and data pipeline design. 

Then they pass prototype and documentation to engineering team. This team details the pipeline into the specific architecture (i.e. actually choosing the database structure, identifying data validation steps), use Scala, C++, or other to get the final model up to near real time speeds, work out all the automated alerts for model drift, and put it in the production server for access to the other teams (e.g. sales, marketing). 


This is like super ideal scenario based on my reading of blog posts and books about FAANG and other major tech companies. I've never personally worked in this kind of system.

I had a few friends in undergrad doing IE. Most went into AutoCAD, design, process improvement, etc. The traditional engineering stuff. 

Now it seems like everyone in engineering is trying to switch to DS. 

As a final year student, I highly recommend you specify what you're interested in and go all in a specific domain. 

For me, it's urban economics. I love cities and am constantly reading about urban design. 

The sooner you can pick your niche and start building a consistent multi-year habit of just reading, reading, reading. The sooner you'll be able pivot into that field. 

It's totally ok if your first 1,2,3, 5 jobs aren't in your dream position. Just keep reading and studying- that way when the opportunity comes you'll be ready.
Thank you! And congrats on announcing your new role! (Glad to have played a miniscule part in your decision to take it üòâ lol)

Let me clarify my use of the word "saturated". 

When I said it's too late, I meant it's too late for people who just want to write good code quietly in the corner without talking to customers or being in an embedded product team. 

I used to be that person! Ijust wanted to get data, dig through it, make an app, and send it out the door. But that's not reality anymore. 

The options are: 

Front end- customer centric - statistics/business/management/sales 

Backend- engineering/scale centric - 
Statistics/IT/cloud/process engineering 

It's important to pick 1 and specialize. 

Individuals will always be able to generate millions in savings and profit using data- that will never go away. 

But the data is going to get huge and the problems are going to get *really* specific. 

You need to either get good at massive data or at aligning customers to the reality of what's possible. 

Personally- I can barely set up an EC2 instance, let alone write lambda code that will coordinate Sagemaker, dynamodb/Aurora, S3, and the billion other cloud programs out there. 

So data engineering is not a good fit for me. 

But I've been in sales, and I know enough about the technologies to identify what is and isn't possible. That's a whole job too.
I'll clarify that point in a comment
Thanks for sharing! And a reminder to everyone to definitely follow the hashtag #breakingintodatascience - it's not just for newbies. We're always learning.

Small recommendation as you keep learning:

Try to make all your renders a single line, where they are just calling a single reactive object. 

You want the reactive object to pass up it's errors and get cached and all the other benefits of reactives. 

If you stick everything in a render_() it's possible that you get errors related to the inability to render the correct type of object (as opposed to getting the error from the actual process you're doing). 


So instead of renderplot({ 

# a bunch of processes 

# plot

 }) 

You do: 

myplot <- reactive ({ 

# a bunch of processes

}) 

renderplot({ myplot() })

SAS can be really code intensive sometimes, e.g. generating hash tables.

R uses hash tables natively when generating environments which makes set comparison super easy. But my experience with hash tables is limited. 

But actually, if I'm being fair, I really like how SAS implements major machine learning fundamentals in 1-2 line. The partitions condition within glmselect is so easy to think about and explain to others. 

I would say a major weakness of SAS is the inability to cross over functionality. You can't do for example glmselect partitioning (e.g. for LASSO) while also working with Survey data (Survey reg). 

Overall, I think SAS is useful for scaling up specific algorithms, but it can be dangerous.

In R you would: 

Install R 
Install RStudio 
Read csv in base 
Make ugly plots in base

The console and the scripts and environment naturally make sense for anyone from a STATA, SAS, SPSS background. 

Maybe if I came from a C++ background it'd make more sense to me why all this overheard just to get started is so important.

Maybe y'all are telling noobies to learn python as a filter üòÇ they'd learn data science too fast if they started in R.

I think it's because there is so much support for Jupyter that it becomes the primary way people leanr python. Unlike R, where you learn RStudio as an IDE, so you get used to scripts and calling scripts across an R Project. 

I've noticed (as I still begrudgingly learn python lol) that the differences are noticeable. 

Even things like environments in anaconda vs personal libraries in R lead to very different understandings of the background computer science that supports your development. 

I asked a data scientist how he versions his packages in Python- his answer confused the hell out of me- "I'm using the latest anaconda".   I was like wait what, what about versioning your pypi stuff? All handled by environments in anaconda...
I think the knitr to word is great! I don't like markdown tables (hard to control width) so I inevitably re-do those in Word, but overall I'm increasing my use of markdown over scripts.

It's funny, I find R users have the opposite problem. They use scripts for everything and never use markdowns when appropriate. 

I'm still balancing this too, and am finding times where I rewrite scripts with tons of comments into markdowns but also rewrite markdowns with barely any narrative into multiple smaller scripts. 

Every sub-process you create should essentially be unit test-able. 

I'll post my R profile here, I use a custom function called refreshR() that detaches all my packages and erases my environments. It makes proofing reproducibility much easier.

A

Unfortunately very common. 

The two options are typically: 

1) end means-testing of programs like SNAP/WIC and Medicaid. 

The benefit is that it reduces bureaucracy and the poverty trap, the negative is that it may inappropriately crowd out private sector initiatives that lead to efficiency gains (personal opinion is that the negative is exaggerated). 

2) define explicit "wind-downs" of benefits to retain work incentives. 

Benefit here is that it's transparent and reduce problem incentives, negative is that it requires typically expanded bureaucracy to validate people are in the appropriate groupings (see: the $5/$100 wind down of income for the COVID-19 stimulus check) and that it requires transparency in services. 

Healthcare is hilariously lacking in price transparency, so doing this would imply block-granting Medicaid which makes wind-down easier but has derivative negative impacts in terms of distorting how people spend when forced to deal with essentially two currencies. 

Income / substitution effect stuff.

Not asking for more deaths, the opposite.

 I'm asking that we treat deaths seriously, invest in national databases for contact tracing of victims, surveillance of their contacts, and a single country policy that has explicit guidance on calculating things like IFR, calculating risks based on socio-geographic differences, develop re-opening guidance that is science-based. 

We could have been South Korea. 

Having 50 different state policies is the kind of decentralization that actually increases death because now we're going to have 50 different American experiments. Except they're not experiments because if one starts looking bad, people will cross into other states and evacuate and disturb the other experiments. 

Individual decision making can only happen with a consistent set of facts and rules. 

Diversity without structure is chaos. 

The truth is, we have organizations and rich individuals funding "diverse" (geographically) re-opening protests that are going to get people killed under the guise is individual freedom. 

The idea that we can have a conversation about individual decision making and risk tolerance without having a policy conversation is begging the question.

The laissez faire / anarcho-capitalism framework which I worry this interview is borrowing too much from, is outdated- we don't live in a society of individuals we live as individuals in a society. We need regulation, centralized systems (e.g. money printing), and mechanisms for negative externalities (pollution, public health, defense, food quality controls, etc). 

Obviously we do have to make tons of decisions as individuals, I'm a growing fan of decision science, discrete math, and things that are much more of your expertise. 

I think the big point I'm trying to make is that we don't have enough information on things like reinfection risks, IFR vs CFR, etc. to be saying that individual decision-making is a viable policy. This is a policy question. Can individuals purposefully get exposed to non-lethal loads of the virus, get a stamp, and go back to work and play? 

Maybe!!! 

The policy question is how do we balance deaths from despair correlated with weak economies, the millions of human-years lost to lockdown, and the not overwhelming the healthcare system. 

The language "certified non-lethals" implies we know anything about its immunity.

We don't know enough for individual decision making to be the national policy.

On reflection, I realize "continue to play" is an unfair characterization, people are unemployed and have real economic concerns. I don't want to dismiss those. 

I may be a bit biased being from Jacksonville Florida where the beaches reopened and people immediately went to go play, without masks, and without regards to others.

I've read that estimates are 8-12mo for reinfection possibilities but can't find primary source yet, looking for it. 

 Some estimates are 6 months - 60 years of immunity based on lower mutation rate. 

The primary study I am seeing cited are Monkeys re-infected without symptoms but that's just a test of 30 days later immunity. 

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41577-020-0316-3

Here's a chart showing similar viruses and where I am getting the 6 months - 60 years quote. 


https://www.wsj.com/articles/does-covid-19-infection-equal-immunity-11587314824

The point stands, a laissez faire approach that assumes a badge of immunity with no defined timeline for contagiousness isn't a real recommendation or worthwhile thought experiment. It's not an individual risk problem, it's a policy problem of balancing life, living, and death.

I did read it, I get it and will watch that movie recommendation. 

Coming from economics the laissez faire framework focused on individual decision making is kind of outdated to me. Negative externalities are real. There isn't really an ethical frame for ignoring these lol.  

This thought experiment takes away medical capacity from existing healthcare systems (which is already bring back retired professionals and pushing through students). 

The thought experiment kind of misses the forest for the trees, people would opt-in to getting infected because it'd give them a badge of freedom- but it's never been about individual choices. It's about protecting the weak- and the idea that these badged people would go work in a nursing home is naive. 

Pandemics are a policy problem. It's about the seemingly inhumane calculation of deaths from despair vs loss of human-years by having millions of people putting their life on hold adjusted for healthcare system management. 

Spain is going to reopen schools and recommend only the most vulnerable people continue isolation so that the young and lowest risk can "get back to normal". 

This is the 1990s CRISPR genetic discrimination worst nightmare. If you're weak go hide in a hole.

The assumption that people will be able to accurately gauge their individual risk and purchase this service at anything resembling it's "fair price" is a big assumption to make. 

We're terrible at pricing low elasticity goods like healthcare. 

I'm not saying the framework isn't legitimate or that there aren't people who would buy it. 

But what if organizations start requiring it? 

Who are the first wave guinea pigs to get the dosages right? 

What kind of societal pressure will there be to go through it for the right to not quarantine anymore? 

If it works perfectly, will only high income people be able to afford it?

Better to spend that money on a truly random sampling of several major cities to understand the IFR. Guaranteed infections at even very light viral loads could kill someone.  

Although I respect that I don't have the expertise here, I think the implication that we can chicken pox kid party our way out of this sounds weird at least to me.

The answer depends on the context. Sometimes you can top code outliers, sometimes you include them as legitimate, sometimes you do stratified resampling to reduce the impact of the outlier. There are other methods too.
Things I see that need more support:

Date: Why mean imputation is actually bad and rarely appropriate.
What to do with outliers (nuances of top/bottom coding) and how to read Cook's and leverage plots.
Understanding autocorrelation and random correlations (e.g. a value correlated highly with the row number may have implications for how the data was collected)
P values aren't feature selection.
Comparison of groups of different sizes (different types of t tests and their assumptions).
What to do if you find a distribution that isn't normal (e.g. inverse poisson).
How Log transformations affect interpretability
A lot here üòÇ

Message: I'm going to take credit for both

Continuing cash transfers without means testing (means testing saves cash, but it costs more because it adds a bureaucracy layer) including moratorium on rent. 

Expand internet based education (make community college classes free online, make them transferable to universities, offer and accreditate microdegrees through government funding tests / licensing),

 invest in major public transportation investments so that we can rely less on cars and complex global supply chains: regional and national public transportation interconnected with an expansion of USPS to include banking licensure and expanded (publicly funded but profit generating) commercial cargo shipping.

Work out at least a public health insurance option if not a single payer healthcare system, and require employers of a certain size make the option available to individuals (not deciding in bulk for everyone) who can retain that insurance across jobs.

Just like 2008 crunched talent, making the entry level market insanely hard for young graduates in the time frame, we'll be looking back at the structural gaps in wages that will persist for decades in this cohort.  Anyone in the early stages of their career (or just graduated) between July 2018 - July 2021 is going to lose hundreds of thousands in lifetime earnings (even if they maintain employment- low raises, less promotion opportunities, more competition from those delaying retirement).

I'm somewhat pessimistic that we'll learn anything from this long-term as a society. 

The ideal scenario here is 100% health insurance coverage, and possibly an employment guarantee. Similar to the works progress administration of 1930s. 

We have high-value things we can do. We can fix our infrastructure, we can clean up our streets, we can invest in public art, we can restructure our zoning to allow for urban infill and increase housing supply, we can boost local agriculture and local manufacturing to reduce reliance on global supply chains, etc. 

We have to make the hard choice and trust each other and invest in each other even if the return on investment may be decades away.

I think it's reasonable to question whether the intensity of the isolation orders were called for, but let's wait to do the data science post-mortem after the human mortems actually slow down. 

The entire concept of judging the pandemic in a context where: 

1) testing is not widespread due to supply chain issues with PCR chemicals
2) testing is actively rationed to the most severe cases where it is available
3) there are 50 different isolation regimes in the US instead of 1
4) we have not completed excess death analysis (countless elderly dying in isolation, not being tested...) 

Is wildly premature. 

The fundamental fact is, case data is not usable without testing data, which we don't have. 

Not a single person I know under 40 who showed significant symptoms (inability to smell, inability to taste, difficulty breathing) was provided a formal test explicitly because of their age and lack of comorbidities. 

I'm not saying the doctors made a mistake- they all survived- test rationing is valid in this context. 

I'm just saying any statistical modeling that lacks: 

- adjustments for testing regimes 
- adjustments for political divides over compliance with isolation rules 

Will get weird results. 

This post is premature.

Domain expertise is the gut check of EDA, it's the gut check for ML predictions, it's the reality of how a model will actually be used by a non- data person.

It's all about domain specific methods. 

Out of the box EDA tools make assumptions on normality and distributions when outputting p values, etc. 

Anytime you try and leverage automated analysis or data mining you must be careful with domain specific assumptions. 

For example on Covid-19, people are modeling without considering both the time series implications and the underlying disease model implications. 

There is a big limit to what a general methodology can do in terms of analysis and data mining. 

There are of course general methodologies for data science, that borrow heavily from business process improvement, Agile, etc.

I would clarify that methodologies for data mining or any specific analytics are very different from methodologies for data science- which fundamentally includes the overarching business context, data generation, collection, analysis, narratives, solution development, and deployment of these solutions.

Background vocabulary: 

Liquidity: ability to turn an asset into cash. Checking account: easy, savings account: less easy but still easy, real estate: quite hard. 

Elastic = reactive to prices; can gladly wait until something is cheap. 

Open Market activities: the fed "creates money" by creating a bond and putting it on the liabilities side of it's books (equity = assets - liabilities). For example, "this certificate is worth $150 in 10 years". Then the open market buys and sells the bond until it reaches a reasonable price like $120 or something. This is a simplification. 

The confusing thing here is the fed can greatly impact these prices because in parallel they can change the federal funds rate-  The overnight interest rates banks pay to close their day with the correct amount of reserves. 

"Correct amount of reserves" = however much the bank has out in loans (using their customers deposits) * the reserve ratio (e.g. 10%). So a bank with 1Mil in loans out must have $100k in cash on hand. If they coincidentally don't, they borrow from the fed at the federal funds rate for a few days (or hours). This trickles down into regular person loans.

Reserve ratio: % cash to ensure lquidity. Determined by the federal reserve too.

Copied from comment:

The federal reserve has been a massive success, so I want to be careful using words like "manipulate". 

US government debt is not like household debt, it's demanded. People want to store their money with the government even if it pays paltry interest because it's wildly safe. 

The fed doesn't print money in the traditional sense of the word, it creates liabilities (bonds) and opens them up for open market activities where institutions set the price through a free market. They "destroy" money too and it's good for financial liquidity. 

The fed can't do its job if it can't impact the interest rate. 

It can't affect the interest rate if private money is inappropriately cheap because hoarding isn't taxed appropriately. 

Low interest rates make money easier to spend, but *whose* money matters.

There's a delicate balance between 3 groups:

people who barely save disproportionately drive the economy through consumption of perishables, 

people who save disproportionately because their spending is highly elastic, 

The government that transfers value between the groups with taxes and subsidies.

Both worker subsidies and capital subsidies (infrastructure, education, public health, laws). 

Tax policy matters!

Forgive the pun, but the well goes deep here, we've created a system where we print money because we know most of it will be hoarded at extremely low interest rates, which will weaken the negative impact of printing money, but because the hoarding is happening while interest rates are extremely low, we need to print more money to move the needle in terms of spurring investment and consumption. 

It's a vicious feedback loop and the solution is to stop printing money and end hoarding. it's supposed to be the case that massive savings leads to lower interest rates which leads to savings being less attractive relative to consumption. But it's not happening. Interest rates are almost 0 and our economy has trillions of dollars parked, idle, with nothing to buy. 

If we don't get these interest rates back up, we won't have the tools we need to get out of the next non-pandemic recession. 

This is a once in a generation opportunity to actually leverage this parked money through tax & spend, relieving the supply pressure will also allow interest rates to go up.

This was just a quick first draft, here's a link to the code:

Again, the story isn't in the values, the story is the trend, so I added a simple best fit line (which is hilariously straight through the points). 

For a VERY technical audience I would add the slope and adjusted R^2 in a call-out box in the empty space.

Here's a first pass at how I would recommend showing this data to a *technical* audience. I would actually make this an SVG and use a formal software like Adobe Illustrator for a TV-ready version, but it meets the following best practices: 


1) All data could hypothetically be extracted from the visualization (all dates and values are available). 

2) domain-specific anomalies are noted - here I made weekends have pink backgrounds (in economic graphs recessions are typically backgrounded in grey or red) because depending on the locality, Monday may get a disproportionate amount of Saturday & Sunday reported cases. 

3) The axes are consistent in their reference. I use 0 for Y axis and instead of March 18-April 1 (which has no reference) I used Days Since March 18th. The context there is that March 18th was the first day that all 50 states had at least 1 reported case. 

4) The point of this graph is simple, if daily new cases grows linearly, then total cases will grow exponentially. So I made the point the graph title and sized by new cases daily. I removed the legend because it would only be appropriate if I had used a discrete set of circles, but the size here is equivalent to the height so I didn't want to waste the space.

A few tips to remember: 

1) your visualization must be not just better than a table, but *so much better* than a table that is worth asking readers to ingest the visualization. This is a relatively low bar, but some visuals (like this one) do fail to meet it. 

2) Less is more, instead of labeling each value (visual noise), consider a scatter plot, maybe even unlabeled, with a simple linear model (this is a special case where intercept may need to be 0) to provide the viewer a trend and a simple number (every day we find the same number of cases as the previous day, plus 50 more!). 

3) understand quirks from the domain. The dips in this graph seem to be on weekends, this makes sense in context of Monday getting a disproportionate amount of cases if Saturday and Sunday reporting is limited. Or vice versa, if people are waiting until the weekend to go to the hospital. 

Borrowing from time series, you can do things like moving averages to smooth out known spike factors.

When we won the ascend hackathon last year (a professional group supporting Asian representation in leadership) we got the chance to meet and hear Indra Nooyi on a panel. 

She said that no matter the penalties she faced for being a woman on her way to the top or being a person of color on her way to the top- she was ALWAYS able to overcome that penalty by being the *most prepared* person in every meeting. 

She said "sure -25 for being a woman and another -15 for being Indian. But +100 for preparation". 

She read everything that was sent to her and had dozens of questions, notes, and citations ready no matter how the meeting went. 

The obvious result of this preparation is that she clearly became the de facto leader - until eventually she became the CEO (recently stepped down as CEO of Pepsi).

Microbenchmark is cool, I just sometimes have memory restrictions so I try to balance memory and speed. Even packages like feather that allow for very fast object reads I sometimes avoid because of the memory bloat.

Just a general fyi, profvis is better than system.time for these tests. It includes memory allocation too and measures time in microseconds. 

library(profvis) 
p <- profvis({
x1 <- read.csv(...) 
x2 <- fread(...) 

 })

p 

A JavaScript output with open and you can see the tracebacks and allocations of each command within the profvis it also works with entire shiny apps! It's very good for profiling sections of functions too to rewrite only pieces of them for speed.

Um, it shouldn't be that hard to get, you can look up income per capita data over time, that is typically pegged to PPP and nominal. From there you get a ratio. 

Using gold is just going to increase your variance around recession points, it won't make it easier to read.

Inflation is not typically shown the way you have it, inflation is typically shown by pegging a value to a year of dollar. 

So for example, many economics charts show spending from 1990 - 2010 using 2000 constant dollar values. 

The nominal values don't reference exogenously to any particular receipts but it makes the internal visualization consistent by allowing someone to say "we are spending more relative to our revenues" over time.

You should look into historic purchase price parity values. It's much more interesting to see changes in what the currencies can buy you, as opposed to their forex values alone. Makes comparisons between typical wages more honest as well.

Oh man, I'd honestly just recommend not using unlist. 

It has so many unexpected derivative effects. Your vector could have names which explodes their memory, it could coerce your numbers into character classes, who knows. 

Much easier to just skip this step and do either an lapply to get outputs using items from your list, or use dplyr bind_rows and turn your list into a specific data frame or anything else. 

I've used it, but if you unlist() you are begging for unit test hell.

I may be misinterpreting your question but if you do: 


set.seed(4)

x = runif(5) 
y = runif(5) 

x != y 

This is purposeful behavior. 

But 

set.seed(4) 
x = runif(5) 

set.seed(4) 
y = runif(5) 

x == y 

This is also purposeful behavior. 

You set a seed so that an entire instance of code (i.e. a whole script or a whole function) can be reproduced. 

You can't set a seed, do 4 random things, then the 5th random thing be reproducible in isolation. 

That 5th random thing is only reproducible in context of having set that seed *and also* having done the exact same 4 random things (in the same order!) prior to the 5th thing.


I used to play a lot of video games as a kid that used RNG so I've built a bit of a sense for it. 

Example: "ok, to catch this Pokemon you have to enter the city and walk in this exact pattern to trigger the RNG on your 4th step in this exact patch of grass".

Rhea Trupe that's awesome! I think the key takeaways are that with this knowledge you'll be better able to act as the intermediary between the DS managers and the DS recruits. You'll be able to ask the tough questions that make a huge impact on whether or not someone is the right fit for your organization. 

Often data scientists try to get into a specific company for prestige or money, without knowing if they're a good technical culture fit- when they ask recruiters for feedback all they get is- we chose someone else. 

That's super deflating. If a recruiter can say, " we think your experience won't translate to the way we do X because you haven't had experience in Z which we need day 1 skills in. If we overlap in the future I'll definitely reach back out!". 

If you say youre a python shop that uses GCP focusing on computer vision and I know I'm not a good fit. 

But recruiters don't get the important vocabulary they need to explain this. 

I know because I have to ask almost every recruiter who inmails me what their tech stack is and they act like that is an afterthought. It is literally the #1 reason to not hire someone- if they can't do your stack they can't contribute day 1. They could still be worth training of course.

The people I personally know who've taken this course are flying up the ranks. They were data scientists specifically trying to be data science managers. 

Their teams are consistently some of the best performing to my knowledge, but I don't know of any recruiters who have completed it (I mention it, they say interesting, I link it to them, then I don't hear anything).

Yeah, so one of my government clients is working on national risk modeling for various toxic substances (we are doing multiple in parallel) to inform both targeted testing (should a child be tested based on where they live) and benchmarks for progress around their grant recipients. 

Can't get too much into the details, but it's definitely high visibility work that we're proud to be helping with. We're incorporating machine learning to make the model more robust and are even coordinating similar risk modeling at non-national levels.

Those marketplaces didn't have massive 2-way subsidies to keep them afloat while they try to monopolize. 

Subsidy 1) VCs willing to burn ignorant amounts of money when even a duopoly with Lyft isn't profitable. 

Subsidy 2) Destitute drivers willing to trade long-term losses for short-term gains. It's extremely predatory. Uber's most profitable sector is coordinating the leasing of vehicles between high-interest car dealerships and poor people with terrible credit who need a job and Uber is the easiest way to get money. 

The problem is, the IRS estimates that maintenance for a car in commercial use is roughly 46-55¬¢/mile. 

These drivers are doing multiple miles deadhead (non paid driving between paid trips) and relying on tips to cover their minimum wage (the 60-70% of trip cost they keep covers some of the car expenses). 

Eventually these drivers who are making $5-$13/hour (in the best, densest cities with perfect driving scheduling, i.e. late nights, rush hour, surge pricing) get hit with a real maintenance bill that they couldn't have planned for, default on the car, drop out of Uber entirely (check driver turnover rates, barely any drivers last a year), and go broke. 


Walking dogs doesn't have these subsidies.

I'm rebuilding a giant shiny app of a risk model we've developed for toxic substances in the US. The original was ok, but too slow to put into use. It has all kinds of levers for adjusting coefficients so outputs from a separate analysis can be quickly mapped.

Fair enough, my goal wasn't to really even think about my acceptance rate, I just wanted to know how many people were (1) active and (2) not engaging. I think that population is interesting in a lot of mediums. 

For example, I think one of the most dangerous things in social media analytics is Twitter. Because twitter is so easy to access and analyze, it's analyzed with a 1000% incorrect framework. 

Twitter is NOT representative of society, and it rewards highly engaging content- the things that make people angry and happy enough pick a fight or retweet. 

Journalism is so warped by the idea that twitter can be resampled in some magical way to tell us something about society as whole but it fundamentally can't. 

Marketing too, and government as well. The entire field of open source analytics is predicated on methods to adjust voluntary high-emotion data into representative data- but the experts are expensive so people just do it themselves and don't make adjustments.

The basics: 
Master - the code / repo
Push - code goes from local to the cloud 
Pull - code goes from the cloud to local
Pull request - "please incorporate the changes to the code I pulled". It's for when you are participating on a team project. 
Commit - make a save point 

That will get you 80% of the way there. 

The harder stuff: 
Fork- make a copy of others code that you may pull request later. 
Clone- make a copy that you will not pull request, mostly for personal fun or for production where your code is one-way.
Branch- a mini-fork, where you test a new feature knowing that you will incorporate it if it succeeds. 
Revert- oops made a mistake, go back to a previous commit. 
Checkout- scrap this whole session, go back a lot, a super-revert. 
Cherry pick- a surgical revert, you are taking an old old commit and trying to recommit it. Relatively rare. 
Merge - the act of combining branches 
Merge conflict - the plural of developers LOL. When branches want to fight.
