Unfortunately there are 2 major fake job posts: 

1) continuous posting of a role when there isn't explicit funding for a new hire. Very common for entry level roles where they hire a few a year, but if you randomly picked a day in that year, they wouldn't be ready to hire within a month. 

2) posting to gather resumes and meet internal KPIs for applications. The nefarious thing is to take resumes and then use them to pitch to clients "look at all these data scientists in our recruiting network" when there isn't a relationship with the actual job and misrepresenting the relationship with the potential hires.

I dont blame individual recruiters who are just trying to hit their numbers and do a good job. It's a corporate culture, that taking from your competitors is critical. I had a great conversation with a partner at our firm about this recently. Companies will chase people from competitors offering 20-30k raises, but would never give that much to their own employees!
Good to know that recruiters consider you complete trash with no skills if you ever have bad luck lol.

Maybe that's borrowing from the (maybe fake?) Bill Gates quote. Give the laziest person the hardest task and they'll find a way to do it twice as fast.

Of course, but I think many people are pushing "side hustle" culture as critical for growth and income, and many are incorrectly falling for it. 

Companies also want long-term employees with strong institutional knowledge. I agree roles and responsibilities should be explicitly defined (so that excellence can be measured and rewarded), but I think given a limited amount of time in a workday, going all-in on one business impact (doing your defined role) seems risky. Like investing in stocks, it's good to diversify. 

By accepting not being in first place at your normal job and investing in improving other parts of the company, you are diversifying your network, your resume, and your raise/promotion worthiness.

"Pain is inevitable, suffering is a choice."

Buddhism saved my life. I think everything you've said fits totally within that framework and I think people, especially in business, need to hear that more can't solve their problems. 

They say that humans are happiest when they are slightly above average relative to their community. That's why happiness and country wealth are so weakly correlated. The easiest way to feel that happiness is to identify ways in which you *are* doing slightly above average. 

Maybe you have a really easy commute, or you live near family and have weekly dinners, or you own your own land and have the freedom to do what you want, or you have the time to read books that don't advance your career. 

There's always some metric that you're doing very well in, appreciate that and realize it is desire and expectation that cause suffering.

While we're here, good data science requires good software development principles. 

Shiny apps are best when structured like packages (see golem package). 

Big analyses are most portable and reproducible as a package (see renv). 

You should probably be making libraries and versioning the packages you use if you're trying to be serious about production level R (renv, packrat, checkpoint, devtools::install_version(), etc). 

Making things into packages gives you control over your functions (EAAF - everything as a function) including whether they export. roxygen2 is fully embedded in RStudio so you can do all your build and unit tests (testthat) the same places you do documentation. 

I used to just open R, setwd(), and get right to it. Now I've learned (the hard way!) how important software development principles are to doing *science*, I was doing data play before...

It's a weird situation, the best candidates are the ones doing similar work at a competitor lol. They aren't fun to read. There's too many holes, you can't piece together what they actually want to be doing and if your role fits their goals, and they never tell you explicitly so you can bucket them quickly lol.

I'll note, I take issue with HBR's statement of "younger employees". It's not about age. 

It's about knowing so much, that you can quickly bucket ideas into {no chance} {small chance} {worth pursuing with X resources} {worth pushing to get more resources}. 

Innovation can't happen at an individual level. So when experienced people have all these ideas but are pre-bucketing them before they leave their heads, they have a very low false positive rate (they don't invest in things that risk too much money) but they also have a significant false negative rate. 

There's a nugget of gold in there. 

Having inexperienced people to (1) act as a non-judgemental soundboard and (2) provide their own crazy ideas that you wouldn't even finish thinking before putting into the {no chance} bucket (but are forced to finish thinking because now you have to explain why it won't work) is printing money. 

Innovation is wild ideas/new ways of thinking + experience. We worship the young tech entrepreneur and forget the army of experience they hire / who invest in them. 

It's a team effort.

Can vs should is important. 

There is software out there for analysis that is point & click & reproducible. Tableau is not one (unless you do the complex coding behind the scenes). 

When I work in QGIS/ArcGIS (tableau for real mapping) I have to meticulously record every step and every join and try to do everything I can in R before I get to the software. Because once it's in there I'm doing a LOT of point/click/didn't work/try something else/click/unclick/repeat. 

This is not science! 

In R, I am constantly wiping my environment (restarting my session is the better way I learned) and starting my scripts from scratch to make sure it's all modular and reproducible (and I didn't leave a library attachment out of a script). 

Most GUI software have only narrow areas where they do this kind of reproducible cleaning (power BI has power query which records steps, but that's mostly for data import reproducibility which is not the same thing).
Public undergrad + the bougiest grad school you can afford is the secret. People only care about your latest education, and master's are the new bachelor's unfortunately...

Power BI has a 150k row limit on r scripts and does some reallly ugly stuff like saving temporary csvs all over the place, even power BI service you have to integrate power apps to do what you need. Which I've avoided learning at all costs lol.

Tableau is the more powerful Power BI. The better comparison is Shiny+Plotly+ggplot2 vs Tableau. Which is a reactive framework, a (finnicky) JavaScript API, and a very advanced plotting grammar structure/language vs point/click pretty pictures that filter well and work for 90% of the dadhboarding business intelligence needs.

Require is useful for managing libpaths. For example, if I have multiple R versions and multiple package versions in separate libraries (which I do lol) I have multiple checkpoint libraries to manage different packages. So if I call require and it returns false, it means that I'm in the wrong library (I keep my default library empty) and I can then change the libpath for when my shiny app opens.

Just to add, attachment is about scoping, so it loads the package as an environment as a parent of your current environment. 

So what happens is you type filter(), and it checks for it in the current environment, then goes up environments until it finds it. 

This is why loading packages in different orders can also make an impact. Because it stops where it finds the function.

Everyone should be allowed to accurately purchase the goods and services they want to consume. Unfortunately the private cost of cars does not reflect the social cost of cars- congestion, pollution, subsidized parking, subsidized roadways, etc. 

We're in a catch-22 situation. Millions of people live in sprawled, auto-centric environments that have subsidized an unsustainable lifestyle. 

DC didn't get it's metro until the late 1970s and now 40 years later it is becoming a huge hub for educated, high income, people who value public transportation. (Gentrification being worth discussing as well). 

It will take decades to build the infrastructure to give people enough options to where pricing cars effectively (direct pollution, congestion, parking, storage, manufacturing pollution) is moral.

I agree that banning cars with buses being 2hrs one way to anywhere worth going to is both infeasible and unethical. But we have to start somewhere. Yet, there are forces and money keeping us going down the wrong path.

Today's average home would be a mansion 50 years ago. I don't even think they build new (detached) homes with less than 2 bathrooms either. 

40% of Americans live below 2x the poverty line (metric for "in poverty" changes sometimes, but I think that is the current measure for that 40% number). 

I'm not too quick to blame student loans though; inflation is not quality adjusted. Today's education is on laptops using the internet regularly. The technology requirements of a university have skyrocketed, although not at 4000%+ like tuition.

I think the quantification is key as well. Coming from an education background and working with psychiatrists and therapists, we often talked about defeatism and learned helplessness. 

The way we speak is the way we think and that's powerful. So absolutes like "always" and "never" breed contempt and can make medium sized problems feel huge, especially in social contexts.

I think we're splitting hairs a bit, there is definitely a group of leaders who irrationally expect every problem to have a well thought out answer to the point where all they do is approve the funding & hours. I was acting this way, and I was wrong. 

Then there is the (big) middle where problems could at least be expanded upon to have 3-5 first steps. I agree that if you have a problem and it is reasonable for you to research a few first steps- you should do so. But there are definitely problems where it is completely unreasonable for the person who found the problem to really make any progress at all. They don't even know what they don't know. 

And of course, at the bottom is just complaining to complain. I think this is especially small, so many companies are hiring for cultural fits (I don't say this explicitly in a positive way), that they can end up with either only complainers or only the article's CEO types. 

It requires a cultural shift to have difficult, maybe not solvable, problems spoken about publicly because maybe the solution is to work around the problem and minimize it's growth until a solution can be found. This is often the case with technical debt problems. Where IT migrations could take years to finish.

Interested to hear about changes in the tech scene. I left Orlando in 2016, after living there for 6 years. The tech jobs were terrible. All copy/paste SAS code for an insurance company or do basic Excel for Disney or a company with Disney or Lockheed as their biggest client. 

The most successful tech people I knew from Orlando moved to Tampa, Miami, or left Florida (most left).

Manhattan easy. 

No car needed. 
Better quality of life. 
Much better advancement opportunities. 
Much better networking opportunities. 

You make 40k in Orlando, in 5 years you're making 55k. 
You make 85k in Manhattan, in 5 years you're making 150k.

Orlando is where I saw ads like this (not exaggerating): 

Data Analyst (contract to hire) 
3+ years experience in Python, AWS, machine learning. 
Master's degree preferred. 
Pay: $14/hr 

And there's no growth potential. Because there isn't enough shuffle and growth to cause higher up jobs to ever open. Everytime I go to Orlando I hear friends getting $0.25 raises per hour working as community managers for well known companies. People with 5+ years experience happy to move from $13/hr to a salaried 40k role.

Orlando is the least affordable city in the country in terms of median income : median rent. Only 14 affordable homes per 100 people. 

Living in Orlando means making 30-40k while being overqualified, driving 10hrs/week in I4 and 408 traffic (which also requires paying tolls in addition to all the terrible car costs and risks). 

Living in DC or NYC you can make 20-100% more (obviously depends on industry), trade all car expenses for a walkable lifestyle and metro pass. Of course, rent and taxes are higher, but entertainment and quality of life skyrocket. 

I lived this exact life and had to leave Orlando. There is no viable tech sector, it's all Lockheed or Disney. Sure, there are some startups (Robinhood is in lake mary) but it's not a real market for data science, software development, etc.

I explicitly said institutional MNCs use forex for legitimate arbitrage.

The issue is that insiders know when these moves will actually affect the market and then will sell this information ahead of time to people with large downstreams. Who then resell this information to their downstreams, etc. So a JP Morgan Chase rebalance of USD and Remnibi which is estimated to have a 5 pip impact on Remnibi for a short period of time, will have millions of unrelated dollars follow the move- multiplying it's impact. By the time low level random people get the information they'll be either too late and invest after the swing back to equilibrium has started; or their unscrupulous upstream will offer them a 10x and purposefully delay the info, getting someone who committed $1000 into a $10,000 debt.

Comment 1: Newspapers

Newspapers have high fixed cost: buildings, ongoing reporting, non-writing staff, broadcasting channels, application maintenance, etc.

 Their primary product is knowledge. You can't sell knowledge piece by piece, because anyone can copy knowledge by telling it to others and they don't lose it. 

So high fixed cost, with low marginal cost (cost for 1 article) and no means of blocking people from copying and giving away their good means they can only extract value by forming a "club" and selling access to the entire product base. 

This is how theme parks work- with 1 caveat. 

Theme parks are 2 tiered goods. Once you're inside the theme park, they have a monopoly on all goods and services inside. So they can afford to do both club pricing (annual passes) and 1-time pricing (1 day tickets). You'll notice- nearly all theme parks have these at hilariously close prices. It's like 20% more to go from 1 day to 300+ days of access. 

Newspapers would have to sell individual articles at almost their subscription cost; and to do so, they'd have to similarly monopolize secondary products. Like writer meet & greets, tote bags, gift shop items, etc. Which is not closely related enough to the primary good to make sense.

Comment 2: 4 types of goods. 

Exclusive means there is a barrier to buying it, pretty much everything has a barrier except for like air, water, nature, national defense, etc. You can't discern how much value I get from having a US army, so you can't charge me directly for it. (US army is a public good). You can't prevent me from breathing the air thats all around us (common good). 

Rivalrous means that if I have it, you by definition don't have it. So a toy in my hand is not in your hand (private good). But also, air in my lungs is not in your lungs (common good). Radio stations aren't affected by how many people tune in, so they are non-rivalrous. Similar to newspapers, once an article is written, it doesn't matter how many people read it or talk about it anymore. It's non-rivalrous. 

Non-rivalrous goods cannot be priced at their marginal cost. Writers write hundreds of articles a year, their marginal salary split among millions of readers is not a realistic way of pricing news.

I do understand that if you take the argument to the extreme, you'd expect things to be like theme park style pricing- where annual pass is only marginally more than 2-3 visits, but theme parks have a monopoly on other priced goods inside the park to extract differences in budget. 

Newspapers don't make enough money off their differential products (totes, gift shop, hoodies, books) for that pricing strategy to work.

The theme_economist() (in ggthemes package) uses thick reference lines and stark color contrasts to make following lines to dots easier; essentially using the background to get the benefits of lollipop without cutting back to a different background after the point. 

Ggthemes() is great for playing around with well known styles (wall street journal, 538, etc.)

Well it depends on how they are presented as areas. Squares and Circles are bad for discerning area; but rectangles are generally good. 

Lines have an array (no pun intended) of problems including length distortion, assimilation, and angular references. 

Here's a good overview on perception from a Washington Post graphics editor. 

https://medium.com/@kennelliott/39-studies-about-human-perception-in-30-minutes-4728f9e31a73

Bar chart is the most technically sound, because the human eye is very good at understanding differences in area; but terrible at understanding differences in 1 (and often 3) dimension(s). 

That being said, I think lollipop is the most aesthetic. The problem with just dots is you rely on the grey background lines to follow along a single company, so it becomes harder to compare companies that are not next to each other. 

Like if you polled 1000 people and asked them which company had closest to 1/2 the revenue of Pfizer, I think the barchart would be fastest for (1) finding Pfizer's revenue, (2) identifying it as between 50-55, (3) visually cutting it in half, and (4) realizing AbbVie is noticeably more than half of Pfizer so it must be Abbot.

There are measures for "discouraged" workers (the BLS has several definitions for marginally attached to labor force as well) and the labor force participation rate has plummeted in excess of changing demographics. 

Other countries are formally tracking NEETs (not in education, employment, or training) as they typically overlap with the 18-29yr old male group that commit a disproportionate amount of crime. (comment 4: a personal opinion) 

In a democracy, people (or their representatives) should vote on nearly everything. The acceptable income and wealth distribution included. 

If you poll Americans nearly 0 of them are actual communists who want everyone to have exactly the same amount of money. They all want hard work rewarded. They just also have common sense limits that billionaires are a policy failure. 

The problem is, there are people who cannot produce the value required to pay them high minimum wages. The people with disproportionate profits use these people as cover to keep wages low. And of course, wages = survival breaks our concept of "free market" (the free means without coercion, both from government and from death). 

So the only sensible thing to do, is subsidize the education and training (and as a last resort, the wages) of those who for some reason cannot produce minimum wage value (whether for physical, mental, or talent reasons). 

Then raise minimum wages according to reasonable inflation estimates (putting upward pressure on non-minimum wages) and ensuring that profit grows at the appropriate rate (inflation + the fair benefits from innovative and valuable efficiency gains); not from exploiting labor.

(comment 3) 

Vocab again: 

- Profit:    revenue (items sold * avg price sold at) -
 capital costs (amortized building cost, loan interest,  amortized machine cost, etc.) -
 labor cost (hours of labor purchased * avg. wage). 

Inflation implies that profits also go up (because profits will buy less things over time);

 revenue rises because what you sell increases in price; 

capital costs rise because buildings, machines, etc. go up in price. 

The question becomes: what happens if labor costs don't go up? 

Well: consider a 2% inflation in everything but labor. 

P = R - C - L  -> 
XP = (1.02*R) - (1.02*C) - L 

X must be greater than 1.02. So if labor doesn't rise, profits will rise faster than inflation. (This is essentially the history of the US from 1970 to present). 

Minimum wage is a floor on labor price. When you raise it, 2 things happen: 

1) other jobs that are more difficult or dangerous or dirty (the 3 D's) must raise their wages  
2) people must produce value at least as high as the minimum to be worth hiring. 

who benefits when wages stay low? 

- the people who disproportionately get profit 
- the people who have an inability to produce higher value. 

All labor policy is about those 2 groups of people.

(Comment 2)
Fast forward to industrialization and Karl Marx, people now live in cities and trade their labor for wages which is then used to purchase necessities. These people are nearly entirely without land (will be important soon). Marx labels these people inherently alienated from the outputs of their labor and are thus "exploited". 

The minimum wage is the mechanism for which labor is minimally priced; why is this fair? 

Combine all the previous points: 

1) land is fixed 
2) land is the only fair tax 
3) the country was founded on the principle of everyone farming 
4) free markets were considered only in context of "surplus" goods (survival was not tied to the sell/buy/trade of goods) 
5) wages replaced farming 
6) cities tend to locate on replaced farming land (reducing supply more) 
7) wages are now tied to survival (alienation from the output of labor) 
8) the minimum wage must include a fraction of the labor production and a fraction of the value lost from privatized land (essentially, funded via property tax). 

One last vocabulary (comment 3).

(comment 1) 
-Minimum wage: deserves a big comment block. I could talk about this for probably an hour straight. 

The hobbsian view is that nature is the property of all man; and thus privatized property is inherently stealing value from the many to provide for the few. It follows that owning property is the truest and possibly only fair thing to tax. (They don't make more of it). 

The Jeffersonian vision of America was an agrarian democratic people; an acre of land has pretty consistently in human history fed about 1 person when it is not industrialized. 

The value of land is inherently tied to it's agricultural value, because that is lands fundamental use. We see this today where cities on good arable land are smaller in radius, with taller buildings, and less sprawl (Chicago vs Phoenix for example). 

Adam Smith's free market was the ideas that people independently selling *their surplus goods* (i.e. excess stuff they made that they didn't need to survive) would create the perfect price because surplus markets are inherently fair (everyone is selling and buying and trading with only minimal connection to if they survive or die). 

Fast forward to industrialization and Karl Marx. (comment 2).

Message:
Random advice I just gave earlier today by email: 

- remove address; city & state is plenty 
- add objective, what are you trying to do & where (if open to relocation, say so). Say what you are interested in:. Marketing, Public health, finance; pick something. 
- if your undergrad is not from the US, say your citizenship status / sponsorship needs. 
- Pick your best skills (e.g. python) and be specific how & where you used it. 
- data science is quantitative; your resume points have no numbers in them. What was the problem? why deep learning?  What was the impact (in $ # or %) 

 Making your resume simple will show you're a good communicator. 

If I say, "i developed an r shiny application using rvest and html to scrape websites for business development" you wouldn't be impressed. 

If I tell you, "I developed an R shiny app that  replaced an Excel database to improve partner selection on government RFPs. This automates a check of over 400+ keywords on 100+ of partner websites and provides an jnterface to search keywords and get the top 20 partners to consider for teaming on a government proposal." 

That is more impressive because it explains the problem and shows how the tool solves that problem

Hopefully this stimulates debate, I think the whole discussion is hidden behind obscurity. 

From MIT: 
" [Extended job vacancies] ... reflect inadequate compensation for difficult working conditions, not a structural skill deficiency."

Computer science grads don't have a significantly smaller unemployment rate than other grads; there are key markers of a skills gap that just aren't present. 

It looks more like employers are asking for more, are willing to train on the job less, and college can't pick up the slack. That's not really a skills gap, that's a reasonable ask gap. 

Plus, there are moral hazard concerns in surveying companies who want looser immigration laws and subsidized training from gov agencies so it's easier and cheaper to hire people with the skills they want.  

If you actually try and drill down to which skills companies are lacking, suddenly the list becomes a lot less technical and more people oriented (computer scientists who can give a presentation, IT that can talk to people). 


https://www.technologyreview.com/s/608707/the-myth-of-the-skills-gap/

That's the question though; how do we (1) split the hype from the truth and (2) measure these innovations as being worth their cost relative to the innovation we lost by hyperfocusing on tech. 

Reusable rocket - super innovative, great example of manufacturing and tech changing how we think of how we do space travel and commerce. 

Solar panel roofs - still pending scale and cost compared to traditional. But big potential in developing nations without high fixed cost infrastructure like electric grids, where individual electric generation is critical. 

Tesla vehicles- very high tech, but still uses a driver, outsold Mercedes and turned a profit recently. But Im not sold on self-driving if it still moves 1.3 people per 50 sqft of space. There are fundamental geometry laws we're ignoring.  Now self driving busses with crowdsourced dynamic routing based on an app w/ AI and ML etc. That'll convince me.

Probably not felonies, but anyone who has ever webscraped has violated God knows how many terms of service. 

Even formal software that lets you scrape twitter beyond the 7 day API period is breaking some kind of agreement. It's just not feasible to enforce these agreements, and since no one enforces them we can't get the courts to rule on which sections of agreements are actually illegal contracts vs breach of contract vs anti-trust vs IP theft. 

We're still in the wild west! And your reference to 2003 (i.e. pre-youtube era internet, where I remember buying extra internet hours via CD!!) Only further shows our laws are not catching up.

Anyone who tells you not to worry about money, is trying to trick you so they can have more of it for themselves. They have a fixed pie mentality and are dangerous to associate with. 

Money is freedom. It is the #1 most defining problem in the lives of 80%+ of the world. 

Seriously, anyone who says anything bad about chasing money wants you to be poor so they stay relatively rich. 

Global poverty still exists. Maybe when no one is hungry and no one is homeless, then we can talk about money not mattering. Otherwise the notion is prima facie ridiculous.

I don't want to name names. But I recently saw a white paper we were putting out which required data simulation. I have like, minimal experience with this, but somehow I was the expert in the room. 

People are enamored with model building and it is not data science!!! 

GANs is not a simulation tool. ABM is not a simulation tool! Not only is not everything neural networks- almost nothing is neural networks!! 

Model building is the part that WILL be automated, so DO NOT make it your specialty. 

Math Phds, maybe excepted...

They need citizen data scientists, can they scrub the text and maybe put out datasets? People can build bots to scale the conversation, evidence gathering, evidence packaging, etc. 

I don't want to inundate the courts, but it sounds like there's real potential to get thousands off the street without having actual people do all the emotional work for each one.

People are used to buying something and it being the exact quality and specification they insist on. The idea that signing up for a platform is somehow doing the platform a service, and thus the platform owes you quality is probably not actually a bad way of thinking of things. 

It's just that these platforms don't care about individuals lol. The marginal cost of a Facebook user is in the pennies, and the marginal gain is like $1-2. So the amount of person-time-dollars a platform can spend tailoring to an individual is what, $0.25-$0.75 a person to keep the profit margin? 

So they use algorithms to scale the customization, but people don't know how the algorithms work and how to leverage them into getting the experience they want, but no person is available to help them. 

This is another area where explainable AI (sometimes shortened to XAI) becomes really important. Because people are used to be engaged with personally, and you're offloading that responsibility back to the user by expecting them to own their own experience. This is not easy to do.

I notice it's used as a way to get connections & followers. Which is like buying bots for your Instagram lol. 

But I think people have this idea that if the chance is non-zero, and the cost is almost zero, that a just shooting their shot will work. 

The problem is that any opportunity worth doing is going to have a filter that makes low effort into 0%.  So by even engaging in the behavior you're like mentally setting yourself up with a scarcity mindset, that any old job will do. 

Sure there are times where that's actually true (Lord knows I've taken some rough contracts lol...), But it's dangerous to even think of yourself as so generic that any old job will do, because you're any old laborer.

In the US on black Friday they sell TVs with damaged & rejected parts for 70-90% off. It keeps being buying new (bigger) ones every year. I'd assume similar for laptops. 

I spent 1.3k on my laptop for grad school (it's a behemoth, matched only by my work laptop) while people in my family spend  200-400/yr on laptops that inexplicably die or become too slow to be usable. They barely even use them either. Some people just can't be convinced to invest üòÇ.

The US should do this. Huawei has installed spy tech in Apple devices and who knows how much military hardware for years. Some systems are too critical to involve parts from an adversary. 

The tech is terrifyingly sophisticated, like smaller than a grain of rice and intelligent enough to not turn on (and become detectable) until certain conditions are met.

The vast majority (and hardest) steps involve getting people on the same page and ensuring that it's all explainable and in line with how people think about the problem. Otherwise the risk of bias is too big, or worse, your buy in has an expiration date.

Data science pipelines in reality:

1. Identify problem(s)
2. Brainstorm with stakeholders 
3. Identify dream data 
4. Narrow problems to the solvable ones
5. Identify available data 
6. Verify data can answer narrow problems 
7  Generate buy-in that the narrow problems are worth solving
8. Work with stakeholders to prioritize efficiently
9. Create a research plan to flowchart  expected pitfalls and checkpoints 
10. Develop metrics for success 
11. Begin data gathering 
12. Begin data cleaning 
13. exploratory data analysis
14. Check in with stakeholders that EDA outputs align with their domain expertise, the literature, etc. 
15. Begin formal modeling
16. Tune to defined success metrics 
17. Verify model insights align with stakeholder expectations and is appropriate in terms of bias and interpretability. 
18. Develop model health metrics. 
19. Push the model into appropriate production environment. 
20. Continue tracking insights, complete relevant documentation, and pass containerized version to relevant maintenance team.

Don't doubt the value of structure. My firm hires a lot of DS and it can take several weeks, even months, to get integrated into client sites. Structureless self-learning (even when paid to do it!) can get old and rudderless after awhile. Recently we've been working on finding certificates and classes with more structure to make it easier for these hires.

I picked on Sagemaker, but redshift, ec2, S3, and numerous AWS and other cloud technologies can help at various stages of the pipeline. I'd argue Microsoft has the Monopoly on the all the steps given outlook, SharePoint, PPT, word, Excel, docker (windows version), GitHub, Azure, etc etc etc lol.

Data science pipelines in reality:

1. Identify problem(s)
2. Brainstorm with stakeholders 
3. Identify dream data 
4. Narrow problems to those that are solvable
5. Identify available data 
6. Verify available data can answer narrow problems 
7  Generate buy-in that the narrow problems you've determined to be solvable are worth solving
8. Work with stakeholders to prioritize efficiently
9. Create a research plan that acts as a flowchart for expected pitfalls and checkpoints 
10. Develop your metrics for success 
11. Begin formal data gathering 
12. Begin formal data cleaning 
13. Perform exploratory data analysis
14. Check in with stakeholders that EDA outputs align with their domain expertise, the literature, etc. 
15. Begin formal modeling (Sagemaker starts here)
16. Tune to defined success metrics (AutoML excels here)
17. Verify model insights align with stakeholder expectations and is appropriate in terms of bias and interpretability. 
18. Develop model health metrics. 
19. Push the model into appropriate production environment. 
20. Continue tracking insights, complete relevant documentation, and pass containerized version to relevant maintenance people. 

For some projects, tweak 11-13, 15,16,19.

Fair enough, I think my experience with R is not representative and I forget that. I pretty much exclusively build shiny applications where all the stuff matters a lot. 

There's a whole world where people are doing ad hoc analyses or markdown reports or using R as an intermediary (via API) for some larger application where a lot of what I said doesn't matter as much (or at all).

Tidyverse is a great mechanism for all kinds of important data needs: reshaping, grouping, summarizing, imputing, functional programming, self documenting code, readable code, integration with data.table for speed, etc. I'm not trying to make "soul of the language" argument. But it does make important things like controlling environments, package versioning, backwards compatibility, etc. harder when it's assumed tidyverse (or pandas!) is all you need to use to do anything lol.

Because people are making money pumping out "R experts" (and Python experts) in 30-80hrs of copy/pasting tidyverse or pandas template code and calling them data scientists. 

I'm not against the practice of boot camps, I support all alternatives to expensive universities, but they're overpromising and people are getting lost in the job market when they realize they missed key software dev, data mgmt, programming, compsci, etc. skills because they were told they just gotta do 3 months of work and they're ready to make million dollar impacts. 

Python is having the same conversations too around everyone learning it, the bar getting lowered, titles getting diluted, and the market not being able to clear at reasonable rates, so people hear "data scientists make 140k" and then start feeling bad when they're nowhere near good enough to earn that much after 3 months lol.

Tidyverse is a philosophy encapsulated into a popular package (or more accurately set of packages). Of course some of the philosophy is so general as to be obvious, but to say tidyverse doesn't exist or that bootcamps aren't overteaching it while leaving out key computer science fundamentals would be inaccurate. 

It's a systematic way of doing data science that of course you should take bits and pieces of. I use dplyr for summarise_at and group_by all the time. 

I use lubridate for dates. I use ggplot2. 

You're missing the forest for the trees here.

Just to pile on while I have the chance, I think tidyverse has become like its own language. People spend 10k+ on bootcamps to drill tidyverse functions and templated cleaning, processing, analyzing of nice orderly datasets and they don't actually learn R. Like, can't even debug tidyverse errors related to date, char, numeric, factor classes.
Calvin de Wilde. You don't write nested functions in production code. You write custom functions carefully crafted and unit tested that themselves contain the nested items.

I would say yes, it's a different relationship. 

I think the key is, and I hate to even use this dichotomy, to predict and to explain are different frameworks. So in explaining why one series would affect another you look into the relationships of the residuals over time, try to find some discontinuities that perform well, etc. 

In prediction, I think you take a similar route, but you underemphasize the discontinuities interpretation and shoot for the lags that are most performative under various cross folds (of windows). 

I'm in a Lyft, so this answer doesn't do your question justice. Kevin Gray is my go to resource for literature recommendations on time series. Check out his past posts for more insight. I think he'd have better ideas on how to think about residual assumptions (e.g. can you use Kriging and covariance matrices to consider the time series model as a spatial model?).

There's this story of this German guy who made hundreds of millions betting on German financial derivatives based on modeling the economy of Facebook Farmville crops. I'll have to find it. 

Turns out, when everything goes up it's easy to bet that it'll keep going up. 

I will make a slight disagreement tho, the difference between a good correlating assumption and a bad one (given the same length of time and amount of data, etc) is domain expertise; which is really just code for instinct for causality. There very well could be a causal relationship between two very unexpected phenomenon overtime. 

The answer isn't to throw out every relationship we can't explain, it's to use it cautiously and develop markers for model health so that we can ditch it once it stops being useful. 

Production isn't a fanciful land where everything goes in perpetuity, all models break. I think I didn't fully understand this until I heard Ben Taylor's talk at DSGO19.

Still working on collaboration; it's so obviously good, but it takes work. I also fall back into bad stereotypes, "what takes 1 programmer 1 day will take 2 programmers 2 days". With good planning, modularization, and environment control, there's no reason more staff shouldn't be more efficient.

I love bookmarking in R scripts (I underuse R markdown b/c I mostly build apps, not reports) but I get caught fiddling with things and losing track of what's in script and in my console history. 

Version control has also perversely rewarded this bad practice of mine, since I can just branch away and sort out bugs later. It's part of learning though!! There isn't a single application I wouldn't build entirely differently if I were to start from scratch.
FOMO = fear of missing out.

Saw a meme on Instagram (a great place to follow data scientists and consulting pages just fyi) and saw- 

"What do you mean I have to have a 'research question' and a 'hypothesis', isn't it enough to be cute and collect random data until I stumble across a  discovery?" 

This was how I always thought about data my first year (or two üôà). So my first #worstpractice is: 

FOMO data collection. 

While it is related to the more well known garbage in, garbage out; I would call that a different worst practice. 

FOMO data collection uses up resources that could better be spent: combing the literature, developing hypotheses, developing a research, and of course- costs money in storage that only makes cleaning and processing even harder.

It's a weird concept, I feel like they didn't have the right people in the room. AI predicts injuries based on previous injuries, so that in similar scenarios you can identify if you'll get a similar result. 

But what did they define as a similar scenario? The players on the field change. The plays evolve. Is the AI going to tell you be careful when a players old, or be careful when a player is injury prone? Isn't that a bit obvious? 

Is the goal to avoid plays that disproportionately lead to injury? That's not really prediction. 

Of all your points I think (C) is the most important. Have your questions, then identify the process that will get you an answer. 

I disagree a little on waiting to collect data.

So, nearly all shiny outputs are themselves HTML. For example, just run: 

library (shiny) 
selectNumericInput('a',"A",min=1,max=5) 

And it'll spit out what looks like HTML. 

CSS allows you to specify the borders, margins, and a few other layers of an HTML object (color, front, etc.) As a 'style sheet' that is applied to objects based on their 'div class'. 

It's hard to provide a specific example from mobile, but Matt Dancho has several r shiny courses and I believe the 3rd one covers CSS for UI. Otherwise Udemy has some cheap courses as well.
Really, you should just use CSS and give the plot a div class; alternatively, save the plot as an image of w/e size you want then render that image on the screen.

There are limitations to outputs that you probably can't get around just due to inate limits in how the device the plot prints to works. Sometimes I will make things output on screen and also output them to a PDF and the sizes are totally different (PDF being consistently better).

That's not how shorting works. When you short, you are borrowing stock and selling it, so every gain is a loss for you, it's the same amount of skin, just in the opposite direction. It's actually more risky than a long position. Shorting also allows for hedging. If you are exclusively long on an industry, such as all the biotech companies in Boston for example, then a structural issue - such as an overinvested technology (e.g. Theranos) causing an industry wide downswing will wipe you out. Strategically shorting reduces the variance of your gains in exchange for reducing the max possible gains. 

We actually know what markets without structured shorting look like: crypto currency. An extremely volatile market. 

Also your example doesn't make that much sense, stock is only sold once; people reselling stock shouldn't have a noticeable impact on already funded R&D. If they were issuing stock explicitly for R&D funding, they don't have to go public and risk competitors betting against them (although that is a perfectly valid strategy, just like coca cola probably has investments in other drink makers - it reduces variance), they can issue bonds, nonvoting stock, lower class stock, or simply take out corporate loans.

I think you should learn as much of base R as possible. Ultimately packages are just rewriting base R or other package's rewritings of base R to make a specific task easier. (And of course introducing C occasionally). 

Errors typically pass up from base R and sometimes package specific errors can overwrite these which can actually increase confusion on traceback. 

Also learning base can let you reduce layers of packages. Loading tidyverse and datatable in different orders for example can mask several common functions. If you can use base to avoid using one of those then that makes error handling easier. 

There are also client environments where packages are a security concern, so the more you can do in base the better you can serve those clients. 

I only use tidyverse for specific summarization functions, I don't even %>% lol.

A lot of times we use normal distributions for simplicity, but technically normal distributions go on infinitely at both ends. For a metric that can't be negative the assumption occasionally breaks down if the mean isn't large. 

Your idea of applying log to it can help make it normal (negatives are now allowed, so normal distribution assumptions are safer) at the price of interpretability and critically, could violate some derivative assumption down the line of your analysis. 

Here's a paper detailing why the use of logs to reduce variance (you can technically always variance hack, there are numerous methods for it) and normalize data can be dangerous. Log normal data can return significant results that are irrelevant in reality or violate assumptions of models you're using, such as normally distributed residuals in ols. 

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4120293/

This is a prime opportunity to do classic techniques like randomizing the Segment column and testing changes to recall and accuracy across multiple cross folds. 

The philosophical question is does imputing Segment ultimately reduce noise and lead to better predictions. Imputation is essentially adding weight to the variables used to make it, pulling the distribution closer to the mean (your imputation by definition absorbs some amount of variance from the other variables unless it is a perfect linear combination; note many model choices ignore these perfect relationships algorithmically, so take care when imputing!).

 If this leads to a better overlap between the true distribution and your model's distribution, then there is probably a more advanced method that would more appropriately weight your non-segment columns instead of doing it yourself (unless you're able to access the true value, which it seems you can do occasionally).

One of the many rules of visualization broken here. The bars are disproportionate, which means the axis would have to be interpreted as not starting at 0. 

Not a law of data viz but very frowned up outside of specific contexts like stock charts and GDP charts where the unit of interest is often 1000ths of a point.

Two axes charts aren't too hard in ggplot2 but they are frowned upon. 

The issue is you're trying to see 3+ things in the space of 1-2 thing. Typically you do that with dimensions like size, color, and facets. You have 6 things on your plot: 

Time 
Value 
Metrics 
The trend of metrics (the reason you have a line instead of just the points) 
Category 
The correlation between value & metrics (the reason you put overlapping axes in the first place). 

That's a lot to keep track of and you've made it *more* difficult to read the insights by having not only all these variables, but in two different forms (bar and plot). 

Alternatives could be: 

- facet the categories 
- state the correlation between total value and the metrics. 
- make a new feature that details the relationship between value and metric and show that over time, with points sized as value and colored by category. 


The color scheme also doesn't help but those just seem to be the defaults. The main insight I get from this graph is that there are categories that are much rarer than others. That'd be my first question

The graphic is good, I'm only discussing why the graphic would be shocking to people- they grow up with the Mercator as default. Hundreds of years of racism were validated by the Europe/US big and on top vs small third world on bottom paradigm. North and South as top and bottom is dangerous, and incorrectly viewing continents makes us homogenize gigantic places like "Africa" the land with the most diversity on the planet by far.

(1) Some people argue normalization makes any projection fine since the color scheme is still correct; but this ignores a fundamental 'rule' of data visualization - that the data itself should be able to hypothetically get re-calculated if you knew everything in the visual (i.e. the radius of the circles + the legend scale going back to the raw data). 

(2) 3D projections have a similar problem as projections because they have to viewed at specific angles (at least 3D maps) and there are distance/horizon effects. 

(3) The Peterson and Albers projections have equal area versions; but they aren't perfect maps (there's no such thing), they distort the poles instead of distorting the equator (like the Mercator does).
The Mercator projection is wrong and we don't talk about it enough.

Phillip Johnson. That's a fair point. There was an update to dplyr within the last few months that made tibbles unable to be passed as data.frames when being subsetted for certain simple stats methods. 

I don't quite remember a reproducible example, but essentially: 

M <- as.tibble( mtcars )
mean( M[ , "mpg"] ) #returns error 
mean( M[[ "mpg" ]] ) # returns numeric 
mean( as.data.frame(M)[ , "mpg"] )
 # returns numeric 

You have to either constantly revert your object back to a data frame (because the as.matrix() portion of the mean method has an exception for non data frames) or do vector selection of columns instead of data frame selection. 

It's a small issue and quick fix and because the base R code was well documented and the error handle was clear. Comments should seek to clarify these kinds of things whenever the code itself can't.

I must admit I often use SAS documentation for stats models that I then tweak in R. Quality control models, constrained time series, etc. SAS documentation itself is almost worth paying for.

My only concern about SAS in the DS context is it's lack of transferability in terms of programming techniques. The row by row structure makes you have to think in a for loop. Things like creating lags (instead of being able to positionally reference) is counterintuitive. 

Macros are also, in my opinion, insanely complicated compared to functions in a program like R. I'm not sure where most people fall on the functional vs object oriented debate, I'm a pretty big fan of functional (I know... Inheritance, polymorphism, blah blah...) And I don't feel like SAS made my transfer into "real" programming any easier. Maybe even harder.

Direct links to the issues around cross validation in scikit learn - they are ancient by programming standards (3 - 5 years) and should be resolved by now. But still illuminating:  

https://scikit-learn-general.narkive.com/CcCsycWg/bootstrap-depracation-warning

and also logistic regression (uses Ridge by default and it isn't obvious! limited support for unpenalized logistic regression).  

https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/6738#issuecomment-252798270

I would bet that 95%+ of python machine learning implementations don't actually need the math to be perfect anyway, so the one-line unoptimized 'deep learning' do good enough. Python's flexibility is a huge strength, but I think it's speed & scalability are overrated compared to R. It's trustworthiness is definitely overrated. 

 R (stats) packages are typically built by individuals and tight groups that are actually stats experts. The documentation often almost as good as SAS's. 

Look into the documentation for scikit learn cross validation or the pandas API under the hood and you'll find that tons of methods were developed by the community in a hodge-podge fashion by non experts taking a guess at the stats algorithms. The same code doesn't necessarily get the same process done to it even across just a few weeks of updates.  The assumption that it does puts reproducibility at huge risk. 

In the micro business scale, R Shiny is still yet to be replicated well in Python too. I've never seen a Python Dash implemented in practice. I've seen some great python products but they always seem to be at the very top of the market or the individual computer level. I like R and R Shiny's ability to perform well in that middle ground.

Masoud, this is car blindness. Obviously scooters and bikes should be separated from pedestrians. But you must realize cars are boxes where a single individual gets to use 10+ times the space of a pedestrian walking. 

Until we make public space equitable to all modes of transportation: 

1) reduce real estate loss to road width and parking. 

2) improve public transit to reduce reliance on cars. 

3) implement guarded/separated bike paths for bikes and scooters on every road above a certain amount of use & speed limit. 

4) provide a full network of sidewalks. I grew up in top 100 US cities (population) where sidewalks where rare. It was assumed in the landscape that people don't walk certain section of road, including neighborhoods even! 

Then this whole debate on "why do scooters go on the sidewalk, they could hurt someone's ankle or crash into someone at 8-10mph"  is out of context. Scooters are on sidewalks because car society refuses to share the road. Because local governments refuse to create cities where not having a car is a real option. 

On that note, the safest and easiest thing a city can do to protect pedestrians is reduce speed limits and introduce speed bumps. A car at 15mph hurts, a car at 25mph will kill you.

To the point of vehicular homicides. Here's a study detailing how a car bias does exist, as sentences for vehicular homicides are shorter than comparable homicides not involving a vehicle. I admit my "separate legal system" was a bit of hyperbole, but the point stands that we *treat* car crimes as less serious crimes simply because a car is involved.

4% is taken from the Trinity study on every possible 30 year stock market sequence dating back to the early 1900s. It survived over 90% of 30yr sequences; while 3.5% lasted over 95%. 

Being willing to withdraw less in bad years (flexible withdrawal between 2-4%) boosts it to over 98%. 

If you intend to live beyond 30 years of retirement and/or are uncomfortable with a 5% chance of running out of money and/or are unable to withdraw less in bad years then your math would need to change. 

The arguments for raising the withdrawal rate typically mention more stable inflation than historical (the goal being to not work more than needed to survive retirement with low bankruptcy risk),

 while arguments for lowering it mention healthcare costs being disproportionate for the elderly even after medicare, SSN, etc, which is my #1 reason for moving out of the US if we don't fix our system by the time I am considering retirement. I need to pay into a better system long enough to earn access for retirement.

In short, "feel rich" on 200k is only true if you plan on dying within 5-10yrs of retiring and not having any serious medical issues or wanting to travel or engage in expat activities. It's not easy to just move your whole life to a new place that doesn't speak your language or act like you.

read reddit FIRE before getting too involved in your dream search. Inflation is less stable in other countries and 200k is probably not going to be enough when you take into account the ongoing growth rates and development of these places (especially SE Asia). 24k/yr in 2018 $ would be the minimum I would recommend retiring on, which requires a 600k nest egg for a 4% "safe" withdrawal rate.

The salary range should be included in the JD, which means it should be included in the first email. 

Would you go to buy a car and wait until the test ride to find out the car is too expensive? No, they put the price on the car. 

Would you tour a house and apply for a mortgage before getting the price? No, they include the price on the MLS. 

The sooner everyone is upfront with salaries, the better everyone will be.

I get a decent amount of recruiter in-mail. I'm not looking (and my profile says as much), so I try to be upfront and no BS. 

This is my default reply: 

"Thanks for reaching out, I'm not currently looking, but if you think this is a can't miss opportunity, feel free to send the JD, location, salary range, and security clearance requirements for my consideration". 

This weeds out: 

Contract roles that pretend to be FTE until the very end (they'll say things like well it's a W2 role - which is barely different than hourly). 

Recruiters who don't actually have a real professional relationship with their clients, they just get lists of roles and send back resumes. They won't always be able to answer those questions. This is similar to the next group. 

Phishers. They just collect resumes to reformat them and send you barely relevant roles always asking for you to also send in referrals for a few hundred $, which is more trouble than it's worth. Some even send your resume to companies you're not interested in, just to show they have a "good network" the company can tap into. 


You should do this immediately because you don't actually know the depth of the relationship the recruiter has to the role.

In javascript there is a lot of discussion on the differences on the .call and .apply methods that are similar to the discussion in R. Typically in R there is some confusion over do.call vs lapply (I typically stick to sapply, or apply, I don't work with lists often). 

The key difference is that apply literally applies a single function over an array of objects, whereas do.call applies an array of objects to a single function. 

There is a ton of overlap in these situations, but in instances where you don't know the objects well enough to apply the same function over all of them, it may make sense to instead send them all to a function that contains different situations for different types of objects and provides a set schema of outputs. 

Again, you could probably go years without running into a situation where this matters.

Have you read the pop-news of the Bezos meeting method. All meetings require print outs of a deep agenda (typically 1000+ words), all meetings begin with 10 minutes of silent reading of the deep agenda; and all those who feel the deep agenda is all they needed can just walk out of the room at that time. It's a stronger version of the two-pizza rule. The idea being, that a meeting isn't worth having if you can't write 1000 words that everyone needs to read; because any less could probably be done in a few emails.¬†

Unfortunately even the top universities can be lacking in class availability. Especially when a curriculum is built for the beginner. 

I've taken classes where the language was an afterthought. I actually disagree with that approach. A lot of DS is efficiently transforming variables into useful features and fine tuning popular algorithms.  

I learned so much useless stuff like OpenBugs, SAS (yeah I said it lol), STATA, and ugly-looping (O^2 run time) in R b/c the professor treated the languages as an afterthought and didn't really know the production side of their domain. 

Deep diving in R or Python would teach students the importance of vectorization, modularization, effective commenting, the nuances of subsetting the same data.frame into different classes of objects by subset syntax, a million other things. 

We all can't minor in computer science (although arguably, high schools should drop half their curriculum and becomr computer science minors) so it's critical that this education is found in the applications of a domain (I'm speaking from economics) and because it's not- MOOCs (and self-learning) become a must.

Message: A classmate of mine at the AAF (William Rinehart) wrote the following and I learned a lot from their panel on data & privacy a few months ago.

Date: https://www.americanactionforum.org/insight/law-economics-owning-data/

Message:
I think the article is an ok primer on the subject. The economics of objects with 0 marginal cost is pretty tough, but there is a lot to gain from the contract law theory around this issue. 

That point about Amazon's hard drives being primarily useful to Amazon is a good and severely underdeveloped point. Why would that data be useless to Google? Because google can't use it. 

There are 3 types of data in the typical internet interaction. 

Profile data (my name, demographic, interest, hobbies)

interaction data (I clicked X, typed Y, bought Z). 

Metadata (time/date, location, user history). 

Monetizing the profile data is barely useful, as I gave it away for free for other reasons (filling out my interests allows me to find others with similar interests, and I don't have to do it to use the service). 

The metadata needs to be highly regulated, as the article said, as location can be used to hurt someone. 

The interaction data is where the $$ is, but that data is only useful in an ecosystem designed for it. My facebook interactions won't help airbnb, my amazon shopping views won't help apple, etc. The companies spend billions creating ecosystems fine tuned to handle this data. 

I'll provide some links in the comments.

There's a great mentor/mentee group I'm in and this question came up: What motivates you in your career? 

A lot of fluff was said. Wanting to do your best, solving problems, fulfilling work, etc. 

I had to be the one to ruin the party - uhhh money!

If I had unlimited money I would do my job for free for non profits and startups that were improving the world. But I don't. Where's the money?

The best part about admitting the value of money is that it becomes the framework for all other decisions in your career. I'm a government consultant, my work is actually really cool and helpful to people throughout the country, especially vulnerable children. I would have never gotten this far if I didn't chase money and build up my skills (for $$).   

By having these skills, I can apply numbers to life decisions.  "Oh actually I don't want to change industries for only a $10k raise, or move my whole life for only 20k raise". 

When you devalue money's impact, you actually end up in situations where money is more limiting and overbearing in your life.

105k in a top 10 expensive place is like 60-70k in a medium place. I compare DC and Jacksonville, FL personally. 

Definitely above the median income, but it's not going to pay for: 

2 cars
4+ bedroom 2,000sq ft house in a good school district 
private tutoring for 2 kids
1-2+ weekly activities for 2 kids
2 kids college prepayments
2 adults 401k + HSA
1-2  vacations a year 
Good Elderly care for aging parents
Uncovered medical emergencies (supplemental insurance). 

The issue comes down to wants. Reframe success and identify what you actually care about and a 70th-80th percentile income should be enough for a household. 
Although I think the bigger conversation to have is that a median income doesn't afford a median lifestyle anymore.

We need to equalize talent by equalizing opportunity. To do this, more cities need to become top tier livable places with specializations in specific 21st century industries. 

Nashville comes to mind for its growth in the marketing analytics realm and its leverage of its music history to become a "next denver". Unfortunate that the state refuses to allow it to build mass transit and really hit the map.

Once more cities hit critical mass, the housing market woes will even out, and mass transit + upzoning + rezoning will have a much better impact.

Unfortunately most rezoning is just upzoning. It just creates luxury condos that sell for the same expensive rates that the median income can't afford. 

I try not to blame people for circumstances out of their control, but the problem with city housing is a problem in city inequality. As a personal example, as a data scientist there are about 10 cities in the US I would feel comfortable living in. 5 of which are desirable to me as walkable places:  NYC, SF, DC, Boston, Chicago. 

5 of them I'd likely have to get a car to live in comfortably:
Miami, Austin, LA, Denver, SLC. 

Now, obviously, these are not the only cities with data science jobs or large companies. But knowledge workers go to where there is: 

1) a community of data science - this includes access to knowledge spillovers 

2) knowledge spillovers happen where there are a *critical mass* of jobs within an industry. A city like Orlando, while awesome, just doesn't have this critical mass. there aren't industry jobs just lying around, the throw a rock in a direction hit a data scientist kind of critical mass. This means that theres less competition for your service (lower relative wages) and less competitors to compete and learn from. 

cont'd in reply.

Remote work is a separate thing worth talking about. As for companies moving out of city centers, there's some great research on agricultural land rents, and the relationship between capital and land costs for buildings. Knowledge work has economic pull factors keeping it toward city centers, agglomerations and spillovers being two of them.
My point was that both numbers are > 4x. I agree that more income can afford more house nonlinearly.

On a related note, I asked my bank how much they would allow me to borrow for a mortgage. Taking into account my income and student loans their number was 5.2x my income. Combining mine and my partner's incomes (and our student loans), their number for us as co-applicants was 5.6x our combined income. 

So, clearly 4x is no longer "aggressive" by bank standards.

3) related to 2, land is generally fixed, so we would expect home prices in a large closed market (i.e. at the country level) to be nearly a zero-sum game. This pans out when you adjust for lack of building relative to the population growth. Homes in the cities are (in my opinion, appropriately) rising in price due to the desirability of living near walkability. Exurbs are going to fail (no, self driving cars will not be a panacea here) and suburbs will splinter into desirable and undesirable. This is already occuring. walkability by design is key to making a desirable suburb and planners know it. 

4) foreign "investment" in the US housing market. Estimates for seattle square footage owned by foreigners exceed 30%, I will look into the source on this, as it may be outdated. In general, housing cannot be both affordable and an investment. There's a city in the US where housing prices grew an average of ~2.5% net inflation annually for 30 years. A modest "investment" return. That city is San Francisco.
 If housing is an investment that expects to pay dividends (rent) and increase in value (price) then it cannot be affordable (unless wages grow in excess of that rate).

- you should use median price. anyway, 

The literature here is expansive and interesting.    New metrics include bundling housing+transportation (should be <40% gross income),    others are based on %of mortgage as monthly rent (< 1% in the expensive markets). 

The primary conclusions to make are: 

1) housing prices are capitalizing future equity, this is a somewhat nonsensical feedback loop (i.e. bubble behavior)   a house shouldnt cost more simply because it will cost more in the future. 

2) the "gray tsunami" of boomers selling their homes. Some (in my opinion, incorrectly) believe home prices will fall as boomers pass away / sell their homes. the more nuanced framework is that top end homes (3000+ sqft, 5+ bedroom, SFH, aka McMansions) will crash, but mostly because of their isolated location.   The future is cities and density. Boomers are downsizing into the homes millenials (with student loans) can't compete on. We don't have 20% down or all cash offers. So the middle market will continue to rise disproportionately.

This should be an Albers Equal Area Conic Projection, not a Mercator. Also, there's a lot of empty space. The whole world could fit in Texas, USA. 

The world could handle 50 billion humans, it just can't handle 50 billion modern-consumers who waste 30-50% of the energy they access (accounting for food, fuel, heat, etc.). 

Really, the entire concept of Earth being overpopulated is lazily Malthusian. All projections incorporating the tapering of birth rates with education show peak human around 10-12 billion anyway. 

It's the unsustainable use of our environment (we use 1 year worth of Earth's renewable resources by August, it used to be by October until recently). That is the core metric we should be using. When we take more than the Earth gives it's a problem. Population is a terrible proxy, considering how uneven resource use is geographically.

Twofold issue here. 

1) The experience of a few sources of trusted information (the 3 news channel era) was actually an anomaly. The US functioned for most of its history with multiple biased news outlets spewing their perspective and people flocking to the ones they agreed with. The 1880's - 1930's was a crazy period of growth that ended in both the worst and then best period of world growth ever. We're in 1919 again. Although some may say 1909. 

2) I agree, I think there is a split between the educated skeptics who can accurately assess the fakeness of news and don't go on fake sites like infowars (right wing) or mindunleashed (left wing). And then the uneducated hopeful who believe and trust whatever tells them what they like to hear.

Rarely does the interpretation of a prediction or parameter estimate actually *need* to be in terms of probability. Frequentist interpretations of p-values, power, type 1, type 2, specificity, sensitivity, confidence intervals, prediction intervals etc. - cover 90-95% of your typical analytics framework. Bayesian methods that incorporate informative priors, develop methods for sampling from insane multi-dimensional distributions (that I barely understand from taking Bayesian Econometrics and grinding several textbooks on the subject), etc. are, as described by another commenter above, insanely computationally intensive. For rarely good marginal value.
The question is, as it always is, how much privacy will we give up for convenience. E.g., Airlines are scanning faces instead of boarding passes, those will be anonymized and sold too.

At a fundamental level these are just distortions and fusions of the training data (real people) who probably didn't consent to their image being used for this purpose. 

If this got too far I think we'd see big modeling agencies and those in the industry push back on their copyright infringement (presumably, people own like their likeness, and this would fall under commercial use of their image, even for stock photos and photographer owned photos). 

Any players in the AI-generated modeling industry will have to be transparent on who's images they used to develop these models (both the math and human models)- which will inevitably lead to pushback when people find out their Facebook and instagram photos were sold to 3rd parties. Which is of course what will happen. They'll intelligently anonymize your photos (noses in this database, eyes in that database). That way they can cover a full range of body types and facial structures and begin selling perfect fit clothes based on the interests advertisers learn about you. Estimated height, weight, waist circumference, etc, all from your online interactions.

Again, if you poll Americans, they do not support communism, they have their current estimates of inequality by quintile and their ideal inequality. This black or white fallacy is disingenuous. You can want a 40 hour workweek to pay a living wage and have single payer healthcare while still reducing business regulation and supporting entrepreneurship and capitalism. Denmark is the #1 country for business competitiveness for this reason.  Inequality matters because the current inequality is different from Americans acceptable inequality. Not talking about it doesn't make it go away.

And I'm aware that Dan's philosophy is, inequality doesn't matter as long as everyone is getter richer and to a certain extent that makes sense. Don't compare yourself to your neighbors. But, I'm not sure that philosophy is politically stable. Poll Americans on what they think the current income distribution is and what they think a fair distribution is and both are nowhere close to what the reality is. If the American experiment is going to continue, we have to address inequality's effect on political stability.

He hit top 1% in 2 tax years but he's below the estate tax on wealth. 

In fact nearly everyone you or I will ever meet in our lives will be below the estate tax on wealth. It's insanely rare for two people to be combined worth more than 22 million dollars. 

As for "massive", we can have a separate conversation on what our society actually values. Poll Americans and they say the system isn't fair, they want better schools, better roads, better healthcare and would rather pay for that than $700,000,000,000 in defense per year and nearly $1,000,000,000 a day on regime change in countries they'll never go to. 

Americans know things cost money, they're living paycheck to paycheck. Now I agree, if you want the middle class to make more money you can stop taxing them into poverty - but these are narrow tax recommendations:  0.1% tax on stock trades, keeping the estate tax where it is, increase marginal tax rates on the millionth dollar of income, closing the gap between taxes on labor and capital. 

I'm well versed on the distortions different tax structures have, so that's worth talking about too.

In R, I did the following (verrrry not optimized method) 

months <- c(01,02,03,04,05,06,07,08,09,10,12) # no november 
days <- c(01,02,03,04,05,06,07,08,09,10:31)[-c(11,22)] # take out 11 and 22
years <- 2019:2987 # got lazy here 

from there I used expand.grid to get all possible combinations of month, day, and year. 

Then made an ugly function: 

if length(x) != length(unique(unlist(strsplit(x,"")))   
#if the number of characters in the year (always 8, but kept it generalizable) is not the same as the number of unique characters (i.e. no duplicates)  then I exclude that row. 


by keeping everything as characters and using 0, once I excluded items with duplicate characters, I could just sort the table and have all legal dates between now and 3000. 

I'm sure there are tons of better ways to do it, but this was my immediate attempt with only base R. ‚ò∫

And it was Wednesday at 6pm EST. The optimal post time. 

 possible explanations:

1) Algorithm bias against content length
2) Quoted content treated differently (similar to plagiarism detection doesn't hold quoted content against you) 
3) no hashtags. 
4) comment engagement treated higher than like engagement. 
5) the people who liked it themselves have low follower counts (not all likes are equal - low 2nd connection viewership). 

We know there is a purposeful reduction in top creator engagement, but linkedin claims that network growth should still lead to YoY growth in post views for top creators. 

Linkedin, being a professional site, should be much more transparent on how this system works. Or alternatively, allow users to better customize their followers. My feed is a honestly a mess. I probably view less than 5% of my feed for any measurable amount of time. 5% is probably an overestimate.

My short research on the subject states that the top 0.1% of creators are getting 8% less exposure in order to boost exposure to the median creator. (LinkedIn notes YoY network growth > 8%).
Instead of not posting, can you get a social media management app so you to write when you are able, schedule posts at linkedin optimal hours: 

Tues, Wed, Thurs  8am, 12pm, 5-6pm. 

Then see if that improves your viewership.

Personally, I noticed a huge dropoff in how often I saw your posts and had to manually find your profile and see if you stopped posting on purpose (similar to Vin Vashishta, who I noticed a large dropoff in posts, you two are some of my most purposefully followed connections). 


I found that you did not stop posting, I was just not being shown your content. We were 2nd degree connections. Now that we are 1st degree connections I have seen your posts much more consistently. 


I think the algorithm is also showing people content they engage with more specifically. The more I comment and like peoples posts the more of their posts I see - separate from any change in their post frequency. 

That would be contradictory to linkedin's statement that it is general engagement that determines if a N'th connection will be shown.

Just to add: 

Your first data science job, shouldn't be the first time you're doing data science at a job. 

Find ways to automate your current work, document your processes, do *science* - hypothesize, experiment, review results. Test different methods to your little analytics, try out the models you understand on the data you can access. 

Sure, it's not some giant ETL python pipeline using DRAIN with Hadoop or w/e, but show you have good fundamentals: modularization, packaging, documentation, math, regexpr, etc. Build an authentic portfolio and the recruiters will come knocking.

The #1 way to identify someone just fundamentally not suited for data science / statistical programming in general: the lack of the hacker mindset. 

All solutions exist, most of them are on the internet, if they're not, the knowledge to make your own solution is there. 

I see this in the most basic scenarios and its baffling. Here are just a few examples I've seen on LinkedIn that show this:

1) A resource won't download correctly from linkedin viewer:  they type "doesnt download" instead of reading through the resource and finding the original source.   

2) A post offers DS internships and defines who to contact and what to provide. They just type "interested, check profile" instead of following the instructions - their profile isn't even complete. 

3) They blind message data scientists, "can i wrk 4 u". They don't check the company website of that person, identify specific opportunities, and ask for the chance to be a worthy referral. 

4) More specific to this post: They use thing like auto.arima() and accept the lowest AIC model without context. 

Playing the numbers games doesn't work. "Eventually someone will hire me, eventually 1 of the default models will work". No, 1/3rd of DS is hacking.

A much simpler explanation that doesn't try to psychoanalyze 100+ million people is that there are more local brands that appeal to niches like organic, green, etc. Generics from the same stores (grocery store brand paper towels, grocery store brand detergent, etc) are just as good (thank pharma for telling us generics are the same chemical). 

As for brand loyalty, this completely misses the mark for what loyalty means today. Sure, maybe in the past, people were loyal to a brand out of ignorance (didn't have a smart phone with every single item ever made reviewed by others with stars), but today people are loyal in their own way - it's called being the "default". If you prescribe to the belief that making decisions takes energy and you should not waste time and energy on negligible decisions - then brands need to learn to become default decisions. 

for example, I always get the same litter and cat food for my cat. It's a decision I don't want to spend energy making periodically, so i go to the same store (in person) and get the exact same items on the exact same shelf for w/e price it is. That's not loyalty, it's just a default. 

You become a default through investing in the nudge-factor. See Nudge, the book.
