Coding proves ability to think logically from another perspective. It teaches that all answers are out there if you persist and look for it (e.g. stackoverflow haha). It allows for customization that the auto-ML tools cannot handle yet. For many places, auto-ML tools and knowledge of algorithms will be enough, but it is more true that simple, customized regression and unique data processing will be required when auto-ML is premature. Don't switch to DS because you took some DL/ML/AI certs online. You need to already be doing DS in some way - creating business value from data - before you jump into the deep stuff.

We have an industrial state capitalist economy. 

What that means is the government heavily subsidizes the research costs for industries that would be (are) critical for war. Metals manufacturing, transportation, energy, weapons, aerospace, communications,  etc. This works because the government stays in the loop on technological advancements without having to do the hard job of managing the workers and navigating a profit motive. 

But this is without any doubt, a form of socialism, in that there is a revolving door of people between government and industry, and there are lofty benefits, pensions, insurances, for those in the in-group *even when they are no longer needed*. 

Shifting the subsidizes (and tax incentives are a form of subsidy) of this industry into industries with a larger in-group (i.e. the poor, the old, the historically disenfranchised, the young & vulnerable) is called socialism as a bad word. But we already have state sponsored industry! we already have state subsidized insurance and state ownership, when it's deemed critical. 

AOC wanting to add medicare for all (when it exists for the in-group as tri-care) and subsidized education (which exists for the in-group as research grants, GI bill, etc.) is not new.

New York doesn't need Amazon, and Amazon doesn't need New York. 
The "billions in net gain" is dubious, cities and states live on fixed budgets (don't print $s), so every dollar of that 3 billion tax break was coming out of current New Yorkers pockets on that hope that new residents pay it back without kicking old NYers from their neighborhoods. None of us believe housing creation would match the marginal population growth of Amazon. 

New York doesn't have a high tech unemployment problem; they have a trashed metro and NIMBYism problem. In fact, if Amazon actually wanted to be in New York, they could have declined the tax breaks and offered to subsidize transportation and invest in local housing. This is the crux of why regional economic incentives make no sense. States and cities cough up $90Bil a year just to musical chairs companies across borders. See Kansas Cities KS & MO for informative case studies.

unit of account - yes, very divisible
store of value - yes (volatile, but yes)
medium of exchange - yes, but limited use cases. 2011 pizza purchases not withstanding. 

The end result of bitcoin's computational peak isn't the collapse of the coin, it's the increased divisibility of each unit. it's an entirely new inflationary mechanism (through deflation). To increase the amount of bitcoins, just allow them to be broken into smaller pieces. Those pieces will be worth marginally more than the sum of their parts (owing to the marginal value of divisibility), and boom a usable currency with a set schedule. Ripple is pre-mined for this reason.

Really? What would you recommend? 

example 1) To prevent functions from checking their parent environment for objects not in their own environments, I regularly wipe the parent environment while testing. This is mostly to protect from coding errors, such as creating an object in console but not making it in the function environment, then the function works accidentally and I get confused later when the function doesn't work later. 

 2) This also helps remove all the intermediary fake/test objects I make when verifying that loops are working as expected, that functions are returning the expected classes, etc. And saves time when I want to retain specific objects when debugging. Such as when only a subset of a list returns errors when using lapply. 

3) saves RAM (see (2)).

I started in logistics sales, just picking up domain knowledge and grinding out the few sql commands and data visualizations I could come up with that made me just marginally better at pricing and booking loads. 

After a few years of unrelated work, I got on the startup circuit, just working with whatever startup's data & problems I could find, which exposed me to a variety of industries (big data, ML included). As you could guess, this type of freelance wasn't stable financially. 

Then I started from the bottom at a consulting firm, finding ways to improve anything and everything I was allowed to put into an R shiny app - numbers were less common here, it was nearly all NLP, dirty excel files, websites, html, ppt, etc.

Having the business experience, the wide range of (not too difficult) math experience, and the niche of R shiny apps that could do things I didn't know R could do - I finally got into analytics full time. 

I've never used CNN, adaboost, deep learning...  just a track record of making more money, more quickly, in all types of environments. 

The key takeaway being it's better to have a wide range of loosely related experience than to try and become a master of niche modeling that isnt used in 80% of practice.

Plants can: 
react to small changes in light (including lack of light, i.e. shadows) to reach objects

react to small changes in chemical composition (nice voices vs mean voices have different CO2 composition, separate from the confounding variable of if the two plants were treated the same, if anything that was an experiment on the person lol)

react to chemicals given off by other plants (fresh cut grass smell is a chemical that other plants respond to, similar to what was likely on the plant-killer man's shirt)

Anthropomorphizing them isn't really that interesting, plants are already interesting without all that.

I think someone complaining of an inability to find data is a huge red flag. The ability to google is the #1 skill in data science, (although we try focus on skills #2-#5 haha)
hundreds of cities and counties post open data 
kaggle has data
github has data
yahoo finance has data 
google analytics has data
google web searching can find you data 

and most importantly YOU CAN MAKE YOUR OWN DATA. The ability to simulate fake data specifically constructed to the benefit of certain models over others is a critical skill. 
Especially when you need to test the code is flexible. 

Personal example:   making an app that accepts time series sas datasets, excel files, and csv files, it is critical to have flexible and accurate readings of dates (especially if you are using less robust plotting methods like plotly) that is tuned to each file type.

I actively make fake data with different date formats, different seasonalities, different time trends, etc. to make sure the app performs as expected when given inputs that are realistic to the end users skill sets.

If you get deeper than that, it's a monetary phenomenon because over time more currency is needed and marginal costs generally rise. It's not morally hazardous seigniorage, at least in developed economies. 

Production functions are not linear, and as demand for goods rise (even just population growth) the costs for inputs rise accordingly. My only point is that arbitrarily keeping labor costs down (by abusing the fact that people are not selling their surplus labor, but the labor required to survive) is going to artificially raise profits.

A really interesting idea i've heard is the 33% flat capitalization "tax". Instead of taxing corportations, public corportations turn over 33% of their stock to an impartial government agency whose sole purpose is to use the dividends to fund public projects.

pro-   better workers, probably better suited for navigating these jobs as automation inevitably takes over the rudimentary aspects. 
Wages for jobs in similar clusters will need to rise as people look at their relative choices and make updated decisions  (CNAs, EMTs -needed positions, that dont have long education periods may need to especially raise wages). 

anti -  it increases the validity of automation, leading to fewer # of workers (an argument for basic income?)
all stock values and investments are based intrinsically on the extraction of value from labor, so as wages and productivity converge, the real return rate of capital could fall.

inflation occurs separately from wage prices - of course as a fraction of input costs labor can cause some inflation, but consider the painfully simple formula. 

profit = revenue - laborcosts - nonlabor costs

raise revenue and nonlabor by 2% and keep laborcosts (i.e. minimum wage) the same. 

Xprofit = 1.02R - 1L - 1.02NL 

profit has now risen by more 2%. Because profit has been extracted from the wages not rising with inflation - i.e. labor has experienced a pay cut. 


This is the fundamental mechanism that requires us to raise minimum wages at least by inflation. 

As for raising it in general. In economics we say that people are paid their marginal product of labor - that is, they are paid for their productivity. 

The research is still out, but often we find the opposite relationship - that people produce to their pay. When you pay people more, (in general, for people who arent scumbags) it induces them to try harder, it validates their hard work, and proves that their effort will be rewarded with increasing pay, status, etc. 

In this case, while the data possibly could've been normalized for population growth & compared to growth of jobs in other sectors, I think there's both pro- and anti- arguments... (cont'd)

img of references you may find relevant

There are some interesting papers on Bayesian methods for verifying randomness in lotteries (which are also mechnical processes) , but typically not in Casinos (as they would keep it private). 

Roulette spins are mechanical, deterministic processes and computers (when given sample spins, data on the ball density, and the ability to track speeds) can predict specific ranges of probable results. One key book I would recommend: 
Beating the Wheel

It's a really interesting algorithm, locally weighted breadth search. Unlike StockFish that analyzing 7,000,000 paths a second, AlphaZero studies 70,000 and weights them by their probabilities of leading to future paths of high win %. All learned from playing against itself and discovering strategies. 

Agadmator (spelling?) on Youtube does fascinating analysis of AlphaZero's chess and shows that AlphaZero plays more humanlike than modern players (often, AlphaZero validates insights that grandmasters from 100+ years ago had committed too, but were never able to fully defend the optimality of). 

Funny enough, engines will struggle to match alphaZero's move finding, but will inevitably agree afterwards that it was the best move. AlphaZero's (apparent) understanding of space trumps other algorithms reliance of piece point values.

Yes actually, roulette is a shockingly simple game for computer vision. I just did my Bayesian Econometrics paper on it. 

Roulette wheels suffer from a variety of manufacturing defects that create wheel bias, and casinos spend thousands of dollars keeping track of non-random results. Check out roulette-physics for more info.

Sometimes I see this in coding interviews, with trick questions. A really famous one I've seen 2 times in my career is the "explain proc merge in SAS". 

It's such a dumb question, like all trick questions are:: 
1) you don't know if the interviewer is making a mistake or trying to trick you. 
2) if you assume they are making a mistake, your options are rock & hard place. You can either confront them and come off as rude, or try to get to the essence of the question and end up "losing"  (I think Liz would call this getting lucky). 
3) if you assume theyre tricking you, then what does that say for the rest of the interview. You're going to be stressed about your responses on top of wondering if you actually want to work for this trickster. 


(for the curious there is no merge SAS procedure, but there are 100+ different ways to merge in SAS, so the question could be easily interpreted to "how do you merge in SAS" which is not a terrible question).

This is critically absent of any nuance regarding the structural issues that push women out of the labor force, away from high paying STEM degrees, and the historical facts that women's work is undervalued (when an industry changes from predominantly women to predominantly men, wages rise, when the reverse happens the wages also reverse - you can read the history of computer science as a great example - this in economics would be called a "natural experiment" since there would not be any way to say men magically had more experience or qualifications in aggregate when moving to that industry). 

And even when you do "apples to apples" (which is intrinsically unfair, since there are structural issues that lead to 25-40 year old women to being statistically significantly out of the labor force in prime promotion years - i.e. weak parental leave) there still exists the discrimination from the negotiations gap (estimates for this range from 3-10%, but remember this compounds over time AND feedbacks to the structural issue stated above).

Also critical - the job seeker *doesn't know the job*. Posting a salary range shows key information about the depth of a role. A 50k Data Analyst doing sql, excel, and basic dashboards is very different from an 80k Data Analyst doing R, Python, and advanced statistical modeling. Both job descriptions are going to sound similar, they might even both have overlap on appropriate experience levels. 

Posting salary clarifies the company's goal with the role, often much more clearly than the copy/paste JD will. And spending countless 30 min blocks doing phone screens just to find out you have overqualified or underqualified people who would have self-selected out is a big time waste for everyone.

Emphasis on reaching out to HR- I would actually say try to flip this entirely. Contact first, then apply. 
In sales, beginners make the "email mistake". They get a potential client on the phone [we rarely answer our phones, so this is a very special opportunity] and then they either ask for (or quickly accept) an email address. Then they stop the convo and try to pursue the sale through a less effective medium (email). 

By calling first you get to: 
A)  save time (maybe it is a perpetual posting, i.e. just resume gathering but no specific position, or maybe the position is almost filled and theres no benefit to putting 1-2hrs into a full online application). 
B) possibly have an on spot mini phone interview (if you are an experienced 80%+ fit, this is the ideal scenario) 
C) get direct contact  (preferred emails, preferred phone numbers) 
D) application priority (they give you a sneak peek of what their ATS is looking for, tell you to add in a specific phrase, or put them as a referral).

Sometimes they don't even know what they want; or they got lucky and found more than 1 great fit. It's their job to keep engaged with the 2nd best and find ways in add them in -even if the work isn't there yet- in this market, it pays to horde talent.

This isn't easy! Building a network, keeping your rejected candidates engaged, writing white papers, giving away trade secrets. It's stressful, really stressful. But consistency is rewarded. I promise.

As someone who studies economics heavily, I think there's a big misconception on the meaning of competition. Competition is about creating value, especially if the value / resource ratio is high. I encourage businesses to engage in LinkedIn, Facebook, Yelp, Google reviews, relevant Journals, etc. to share their knowledge and boost the efficiency of the industry as a whole. 

This means posting quality content, building a *purposeful* network, keeping heavily in touch with candidates who made it 90% but didnt get hired   (2nd best in 1 hiring cycle may be clearly the best in another). To keep that contact you need to provide value. 

In government contracting that would mean congratulating opposing firms when they win big contracts, keeping connected to their employees, not stressing when your employees leave to competitors, never burning bridges, happily providing references, providing great referall bonuses, being a human being when it comes to bereavement, parental leave, flexibility, etc. 

For me, I know several firms where if I needed a job (aka I had a new opportunity to provide value) I could reach out to them, learn about their current opportunities, and find a way to add value. They do the same and keep me in mind.

Poor people spend most of their money on non-taxables like food. Of course their income tax bill is so low. The standard deduction and EITC put, what 47%?, of them out of the running to pay any federal income tax at all.
They still pay disproportionate sales, gas, utility, and sin taxes. 

I'm in the top 50% that does pay income tax and my complaint is that the money doesn't even feel like it's benefiting me. Schools are expensive and outdated [in the literal sense, old buildings with lead and asbestos are poisoning children], roads are impossible to ride a bike on -full of potholes-, non air transport isn't viable for the holidays -massive cuts in public train and bus systems;  entitlements are a bankruptcy risk by the time I retire;, my share of the public debt is going to cross 40k with the new 900 B$ deficits.

Yes - I don't disagree. But I have to ask - was that ever actually the optimal way? Or did it just happen to work out okay?¬†

The thing about optimal strategies is that they should be robust to a wide range of situations and markets. The benefits of outreach and being human possibly work !even better! in employer-biased markets - they are just absolutely necessary in today's market.

Outreach is the missing ingredient in both, great post Liz. 

Your own interview pipeline is a talent pool waiting to be used. Tell candidates how many jobs you're looking to fill [including salary ranges!!], invite them to recommend their friends, classmates, and coworkers to apply too. 

It sounds crazy - but that's what interviewing is supposed to be. Is this a good fit for me? no, but it's a good fit for someone else. It's not always a competition to see who "wins" the job. Wins only happen when good matches happen.

Start doing the same with your own competitors - you're not a good fit for us, but an HR colleague at a different firm may be interested in your profile. We've spent 3 hours interviewing by phone and in person, I'm comfortable recommending you to them.

Be a human being and reap the rewards.

"The best time to plant a tree was 20 years ago, the second best time is today." 

"humans overestimate what can be done in a week, and underestimate what can be done in a year"

Interesting note Craig. My career began in the freight brokerage space (2014) where I noticed a severe lack of tech. I mean, even doing things like SQL queries on past lanes to provide quotes taking into account seasonality was difficult to do at the individual level and was considered innovative. I was getting the occasional descriptive statistics & data visualizations, but limited modeling. Gut was maybe 80% of how we priced. Forward 3 years and I was working with freight brokerage platform SaaS to develop pricing models for automated brokerage (high volume, low margin, low overhead stuff) with venture funding. 

We talk a big game about self driving trucks fixing the driver shortage - but there's a lot of efficiency gains to be made before taking the driver out of driving. Warehousing, dredging, drop shipping, route optimization, LTL/partial optimization on Near FTL, packaging, etc. A more experienced supply chain person could definitely expand on that list...

What do you recommend HR departments do to make candidates comfortable asking the tough questions? Or is asking those tough questions a sign of a good hire itself? 
What I'm hearing is that plenty of HR professionals are prepared and willing to answer them, but they're not being asked, and it's often too out of flow to bring it up unprompted.

LinkedIn does charge for posting jobs actually. That is why it is less spam filled than monster and careerbuilder [the 2 sites I will never return to, as they sell your contact info to known spammers and scammers].

Employees are generally looking for a comfortable paycheck with a positive impact to make them feel proud of how they spend 40-50hrs a week. 
HR isn't involved in emotional counseling, psychological growth, etc. I don't say that to be rude or downplay HR- it's just not their job to be therapist. 

Ask about past mistakes and their resolutions (and most importantly reveal company mistakes and their resolution!). You'll get more honest answers. 

These questions are fundamentally about emotionally manipulating an employee to see the negatives about themselves and do worse in a negotiation.

 Yes, I know, that's not the goal- HR wants confident, self aware, self-learning, innovative employees; but this question (without an equal disclosure of the company's weaknesses and failures) is manipulative. 

Do you disclose company failures, weaknesses, etc on interviews? Are they prominently on your website? If the company doesn't embrace failure, then I think it is strange to ask candidates how they have.

So why not ask what you actually want to know? 
This position often faces X, Y,Z situations -how does your experience lead you to deal with them? 

The issue I see is that a lot of departments are still behind on getting technical recruiters with industry specific experience. The big firms and the startups have that settled with having directly involved people doing the interviewing - but small/medium firms may not be able to get the technical team into the interviews for everyone - so we get this situation where the interviewer really doesn't know the job description in context of the future role (aka keyword & technology dumps) and actually needs someone (which should not be the candidate-since they don't know the company) to explain what the role is really like and how they would succeed in that role. 

It's an impossible question, for more reasons than Liz stated. Ask better questions, get better answers.

Yes, it was covered extensively. My curiosity is on how this will be covered more personally. Khashoggi's death had speculation, facts, narratives, running wild - especially in DC where his writing in WaPo was discussed extensively. This story leads itself to being discussed very personally - experiences of being in the white house, in their shoes, dealing with presidents, concerns about freedom of the press, etc. The discussion around Saudi Arabia and Khashoggi stuck to a lot of oversimplified preconceptions - "Saudi Arabia's human rights record" , "Saudia Arabia limits to press freedom" etc. As if nothing similar has or could ever happen in the US.¬†
I didn't mean to come off as downplaying the seriousness of Khashoggi's murder - only that it was easy for the media to retain a certain alienation from the topic because of our preconceptions of Saudi Arabia - and the fact that the President was so quick to note, he was not a citizen.

Sessions was a done story. My curiosity is in the difference between the US pop-media's reactions to Acosta losing his press credentials on a complete fabrication vs khashoggi being literally disappeared like a Godfather movie inside an embassy. 

It's easy to worry that the personal comparison [I could get silenced by the WH, but i'll never get disappeared by MbS] would affect the DC coverage at least.

Learn something enough to where you are comfortable debugging and researching new answers quickly- to the point where you are comfortable leading people in the technology at a team level. 

This is a big reason I like government consulting, getting new projects forces us into different technologies and someone has to step up and lead and make the SOPs and read the forums and become the local-expert in just 40-120 hours (1-3 weeks). 

You will be shocked how fast you can learn in 100 hours when you have the problem, the data, the internet, and a good mental-framework for solving similar data problems with other tools.

Am I professional in Tableau? Lectora? SQL?   no, they are only part of my job - but I am comfortable solving specific ranges of problems with those tools. 
The 80/20 principle applies too.  Learn the 20% that will result in 80% of success then google for the rest.
As for the complaints of certificate and skills inflation. Thats why portfolios and industry specific recruiters exist. A good HR system isn't fooled by a bunch of MOOCs with no back up.

The fundamental theory of stock value, is that stocks are valued as the net present value of their dividend flows. But, then how are values of stocks derived from companies that don't give dividends?
Is it a controlled bubble?
 A multi-period game of asymmetric information? 
Why would someone buy when someone is selling? well, why do people buy? why do people sell? 


It's interesting that especially in the last 20 years algorithm trading and indexing have taken over as essentially the only way the average person interacts with the stock market. This makes it, in my opinion, actually less philosophical, in that now we just need to study the aggregate trends of stocks by category. This is much easier to apply statistics to. 

Unless your goal is to "time the market" which nearly nobody should be trying to do. Then you get into the philosophy of consumer confidence and heuristics. That's where math tends to fail.

You should really just sneak around the whole system and get directly to an HR person. Then you could email them your nice inDesign resume and worry about the application and ATS later.   Applying for a job by the traditional methods is so rough and demoralizing.

My background isnt graphic design, but our team uses inDesign for all of our graphics (including text, charts, etc). 

My understanding is that inDesign supports alt text metadata and hidden alt text (ie text boxes not visible to a person but visible to a computer)  for 508 compliance (i.e. a screenreader for a visually impaired person can read your inDesign creation)

My assumption is that your CV was not passing through the ATS because either A) the ATS was not parsing your text boxes / pdf images correctly  (it doesnt accept the file type)  or B) it accepts the file type but was expecting metadata of some sort similar to a screenreader. 

I don't work with ATS or inDesign, so this advice may not actually apply to your situation, but hopefully this link could help?

More construction is only a surface level solution - it's true we're not building housing as fast as we were in the early 2000s and the recession and boom heavily affected the construction industry -but cities across the country (Nashville (i think this one got vetoed), Denver, Seattle) are investing billions more in transportation than they are in housing. If you build the transportation - the housing will come.

Something I often see missing from this conversation is that homes need to be built where people want to live. 

Unfortunately, the places people want to live, are hundreds of years old and full of houses, businesses, construction, schools, etc - a lot of it unplanned. 

So its natural to build around that core so that people can afford to be near the action. 

But how do you get to the action? 

driving a car, alone, for several hours a day? That's a clown car habit for clowns. 
Bike around? No way, it's too dangerous, there are clowns out there in 2-4000 lbs metal speedsters with road rage. 

Transportation is a key solution to making more space a viable option, but if all we talk about is housing, then we're gonna get exactly what we see: 
lots torn down for luxury apartments (that lot was expensive! that demolition was expensive!) 
pockets of affordability closing as those who want the tier 2 housing gentrify anything able to access existing transportation networks. 
Extremely high commute times for the REAL middle class (hint: if you're in the top 5-10% of local income -youre NOT the middle...) 
Unplanned sprawl, only loosely connected to highways and individual-based transit (more clown cars). 

Mass transit! Planned cities!

Nationalism =/= Patriotism. 

Patriotism is respect for the Constitution and principles of the USA and the belief that we are a net positive on the world when people engage with their political system and seek to make it better. It's the belief that people choose to be American and that it's a great choice to make. 

Nationalism is respect for blood and soil, literally, that only those from a specific place (USA) and with certain blood are deserving of the highest rights and citizenship. Nationalism is putting your nation above the constitution, legal agreements, etc. It's the weakest form of patriotism, unable to self-criticize and improve and critique ones country because to do so is treason - "if you dont like america, why are you here?". 

I'm a patriot because America can and should do and be better. Criticizing, speaking, protesting, voting - that's how America gets better.

Look in the mirror and make sure you know what you are and want to be, with specific details, and then cultivate a network of people in that field. The literature on spatial economics generally states that increases in home values that are not driven from exogenous supply problems are relative. That is, increased value in property of one place is roughly offset by a decrease in value somewhere else. So the idea of "timing the market", in my opinion is better stated as locating the market - which is what I meant by picking a well-run good city. Of course, people contribute to the cities they live in, so to a certain extent people should also maximize their influence on their place.

1) generally, children of rich people are the ones getting the "basket weaving" degrees -¬†https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/students-at-most-colleges-dont-pick-useless-majors/

But college is also higher quality today than 20-30 years ago. A lot of these comments are not understanding that you eventually pay off a home, contributing immensely to intergenerational transfer. If you're lucky enough to purchase a home in a "good" well-run city with long-term growth prospects (i.e. you bought in Pittsburgh not Cleveland/Detroit) then you're setting your descendants for success.¬†
Yes, it's not the optimal investment, but given that you have to live somewhere, if you're able to stay in one place for multiple decades (this is the fundamental premise that negates the homeownership benefits- lost equity from having labor mobility) you can really set up and participate in your community with a home. Not to mention the benefits of having fully customizable space that you can modify with renovations that have a high terminal value once you're done with them.¬†

How people perceive the FIRE movement: "why would I want to eat PB&J and cut coupons just to quit contributing to society at 35. I want my career to matter and to grow as a person through my career. Those lazy people just want to go live in a van for $500 a month forever"

How the FIRE movement actually is: "To have full control of my life I need to separate survival and labor. Once I have saved enough money to where my minimal living expenses can be covered from 3-5% annual withdrawal of my net worth, I'll be able to perform actions that align with my values and not have to worry if they pay enough and I'll never be stuck doing something I don't want to do for people who don't actually care about me, ever again." 

Understand before you criticize.

Hey Cameron, I went through your profile and resume (I do speak spanish so that's fine that it's in spanish), but i felt there was 2 issues: 
title inflation -  my understanding is you started a website and you run it yourself; I mistake I made after founding my LLC to do consulting work was that "founder | ceo" wasnt really as relevant as I had hoped it would be. Focus more in what you would title yourself if you did that exact work at a company. Data analyst/research analyst/ economist etc. 
school focus -   its great that you took interesting, relevant coursework and had honors. But in DC, its masters degree or bust with wayyy too many jobs. In a recently completed project of mine we struggled with single sourcing when derivative products were developed; we worked with text, so the original source was kept alone, but derivatives were often cleaned in very specific ways that were repeatable, but not applicable to the source itself. It ended up being that the team was combining derivatives instead of returning to the single source because it was faster/easier; this led to unexpected consequences when the derivatives were actually of objectively higher quality than the original source but unusable for different tasks [due to having been overcleaned and certain metadata removed].

5. python, d3.js, javascript  - more visualizations

7. statistics again + linear algebra

9. more communication skills especially in your domain knowledge

I put visualization so early and often because the ultimate goal of data science is convincing the business decision makers that their gut is not enough to make million dollar decisions. No amount of data tables and advanced math and great communication skills will beat the right visual. 
Great communication is important one two fronts: interpersonal & domain. 

Domain knowledge is more important than machine learning, since its the knowledge that contextualizes model comparison. 

Machine Learning is last because, well, the most common tools in data science are log regression, clustering, random forest;  
NN, SVM, PCA, and the rest of the long acronyms come later and in specific uses

These cities are starting from a disadvantage- that the 60s and 70s and 80s left many of them with decaying segregated central cores with inequality in education and infrastructure. I don't know enough about PA to get too specific. But infrastructure, inequality/inequity, inclusive urban design, planned walkable communities, affordability,    those are the things that make young people say "its not a big place, but its the right place". 

loose zoning laws, an agile city government invested in its startup community, partnerships with colleges to host interesting events, maximizing natural resources sustainably, promoting sustainable tourism, etc.

Traditionally, what pulled young people back into their original hometowns or smaller cities was the need for affordable space for having children and making families and of course - the desire to have real influence in their community.

Whether we want to blame wage stagnation, student loan debt crises, or austerity government - that mechanism is broken. 

Small cities can still attract young people using some of what you mentioned - startup funds, strong community ties, etc. But the effect will be limited (Vermont is going as far as to pay people to live there while working remote). 

When you look at the "rise of the rest" what you see is: 
Infrastructure - look at OKC, tulsa, kansas city, nashville, colorado springs. These places now that young people arent going to just move somewhere small to live the exact same  wake up drive to work  drive home lifestyle. They want public transportation, a vibrant city life (even if its small! even if its just 1 riverside, or 1 downtown!  walkability, good urban design, inclusive design - look at vienna, austria and its immensely successful design for women initiative)  
culture - small places get a bad rap as "backwater" "flyover"  essentially, that these places are full of old racists.

In my opinion (and after reading other comment threads)

Analyst - is given tasks, data, and tools. Not to make this sound easy - there may be a lot of valuable exploration, scripting, and creativity in this role - but it is by definition limited in its scale. 

Data scientist - creates tasks based on business value, compiles data and works with engineers (if applicable) to create/design architecture required to get data in the correct form, creates the tools that they or analysts will use (ML models, Shiny Apps, and similar), passes down tasks to analyst and trains them up to DS. 

I would find it disappointing and shortsighted to hear a company want an analyst and not take a want-to-be data scientist. It's just like a research assistant that wants to be a chemist, economist, etc. It's the natural first step - even if often the titles are not "analyst" the role makes sense. 


I'm a DS because I independently find ways to make business value through automation, EDA, NLP, etc and use R, tableau, excel, sql, html, whatever I can find, to do it. If I was told exactly how to best do what I do and given the tools and the data then that'd make me an analyst.
Do most companies even know the difference between a data analyst and a data scientist?

They don't, but AI and computer programming in general gets this perception of objectivity that I think is dangerous. All any algorithm can do is hard-code bias. But, I do agree that AI in hiring would at least be done in an iterative process that examines bias, unlike most HR. 

If the question is can AI do better than HR - I think we'll find the answer depends on specific targets - i'm sure AI would be an amazing job hiring for: 
culture fit (this is a somewhat loaded word phrase given the studies on racism in hiring.)
soft skills (analyzing text and speech - but again if it were based on unstructured public social media we get into issues of bias against certain dialects) 
technical skills (coding challenges or similar). 

But I hesitate to say it can do all 3 at once, and hesitate more to say that beating HR as it currently stands is enough. I do understand theres minimally viable considerations.

NYC has so many people that average traffic speeds in the central cbd is low enough that even if bikers get hit more, they die less. Also, they're used to sharing the roads with tourists, bicyclists, scooters, buses, etc. Not so much in the FL places i've lived.

This is of course separate from the public perceptions that the only 2 kinds of bikers are poor (transport riders) and rich tour-de-france dressed (sport/exercise riders) that keeps a huge range of people thinking biking for transport isn't for them.

I would worry less about prediction granularity and focus more on your inputs. Soccer match attendance is going to have a lot of collinearity   - the best teams get the best time slots   and both lead to higher attendance. So they may receive a disproportionate number of attendees and your data may not be large or varied enough to accurately split those two measures.     As for prediction, are you just testing with a confusion matrix or are you using other model accuracy criteria (AIC?, R^2)        I would look at attendance normalized and try to determine which factors most strongly lead to attendance beyond some interval.  Low can be < 1 standard deviations, high can be > 1.   So ~70% of games are medium attendance.    Of course,  since soccer games have a fixed cost component there's also the survivor bias since games with low attendance predicted are canceled or rescheduled.
I would reply differently if you were using cuts of the data as a specific measurement like "high" attendance or "low" attendance - that's not arbitrary.
don't introduce arbitrary classes, just use continuous data and allow an intercept.

Carlos N. Velez     I don't blame the politicians, all they can do is be representatives of their constituents. 

The ones who most need long term structural investment (the working poor, within 3 paychecks of poverty - those without health insurance or on the fringes of the labor force) don't vote and don't move. Theyre the ones who make a city into a community by taking care of each other as neighbors, volunteering at their churches, having multigenerational roots in a place, and physically traversing the city using its services (public schools, busses, walking on its sidewalks, going to its parks).

The ones in the power structure are the landlords, the business owners, the country clubbers who have only a tertiary investment in the city as a whole, since they navigate a very narrow section of a city (usually driving directly from their large homes on the exurb to the CBD, then returning promptly) and are better able to navigate BIE (bureaucracy in everything). They want low taxes, narrow investment (fix potholes, hide poverty), and most importantly the status quo. 

I would recommend researching the Tiebout model for more discussion on how these power structures are political equilibriums.

This has been known since the 1800s. But local government is cyclical - and a press release saying you convinced a household name of a company to bring 1,000 jobs to your city gets you re-elected. Actually investing in your community (and what makes a city desirable: strong public services, appropriate density, reasonable zoning and regulation, etc) is time-consuming and puts you at odds with your (voting) constituents (i.e. the business community and NIMBYs that are intimately tied to the power structures of your city).¬†
If people voted in their local elections and took part in local politics you'd see local governments make the kind of broad investments that the average person would benefit from (read up on Elite Projection from HumanTransit for a great example).¬†

*why* agricultural subsidies exist: 

1. Land is different than all other capital - it is in fixed supply and is endowed by nature. The supply curve is completely vertical;  there is no shock can increase or decrease its supply; only change its optimal use/price.  

2. Food is different from all other commodities. Yes of course, when hot dogs are expensive people by hamburgers instead, but food as a category is a must-buy. 

This means a) in a free market it's price is highly volatile and b) there are political reasons to keep food affordable (the french revolution, the arab spring, were are highly correlated to bread price shocks). 

3. For political purposes, the price of food must be affordable to *the entire population*. 

4. Affordable/cheap products are not necessarily the most profitable. 

5. It is profit that is reinvested into the company spur innovation and lower marginal costs (and thus lower price + increase quantity sold). 

The paradox: high food prices allow for profit and innovation; but food can't be priced high politically. So the equilibrium in the real world is that the government subsidizes the profit needed to spur innovation in food. There is also sequential game theory involved, but i'm out of characters.

Kevin Wilkins monopolies are powerful, and duopolies are at least theoretically possible of performiglng equivalent to perfect competition, although thats very industry specific. 

I think what people fail to understand is that we're dealing with industries that have near zero marginal cost, thats essentially unprecedented. What happened when music became available online where copies could be made at negligible time and electricity?  records and CD sales plummeted and the music industry became about *access*  instead of products.  now obviously memberships didnt just get invented; but our entire economy is shifting to service and what that does is it flips our understanding of what competition and efficiency look like.  I dont support Amazon owning everything, but you cant tell me they're not efficient; maybe we lose out on 1000s of small retailers and instead get WalMart vs Amazon dominating retail. my point is only that it is still possible for that setup to act as innovative as the alternative, price competitively like the alternative, etc. 
The EU isnt really making these anti-trust decisions around how many competitors are in the market, the prices consumers are paying, etc. Theyre making cultural choices against mega corps.

Ryan Mills    of course, but we're talking about differences in regulations (or lack thereof for multinational conglomerates) affecting how well businesses can grow to massive size. We do see that the EU succeeds in regulating down industries; they have lower small business death rates (local grocers and similar). They've shown that they are stronger on anti-trust than us and I think that's indicative of their government culture.  They want 5 homegrown mini-googles whereas we just want the best service regardless of if it comes from a duopoly. see: the bertrand model on duopolies converging to perfect competition prices.

Google has built up arguably the greatest branding since the robber baron days. I've read that 60% of searches in the EU go through google (same source says it is 90% in the USA). Google decided to get into cell phones and now we have the duopoly - apple and android. Google decided to get into enterprise business services - now we have cloud storage, gmail suite, the google drive suite, etc. Google is the backbone of so much in the USA (analytics, ads, APIs, mapping, the list in insanely long). 

Can we really fault the EU for being scared of them? We view them as an american success story along with microsoft - nerds in a garage become billionaires. The EU wants to cultivate its own googles, apples, microsofts, facebooks, netflixes, amazons, - but theyre starting from behind. 

I see this as a proxy for the EU's struggle to compete at the level that the US (and China and India) are at in tech. We can look at GDPs (India recently took over France at #6), regulations affecting business births (still very low OECD countries since 2008, and barely stable/possibly falling according to the BLS's ARIMA model for birth/deaths), etc and it's clear that tech is the real trade war.

I've never seen an MLM that wasn't based on lies ("business owner" just by paying $300 and then buying our stuff - no that makes you a customer), predatory, or simply a pyramid scheme. 

MLM is banned in China and many of the companies simply switch to standard retail model and do well, they cant compete on that model in the US so they resort to distributed wholesalers. 

I'm willing to be convinced that I'm wrong to characterize all MLM this way, but if the business is in the side products ("how to sell X" books, access to conferences or VIPs who are really just early pyramid scheme enterers, discounts on product volumes that just sit in peoples houses, lack of choice in inventory) and not the primary product (membership, tea, yoga pants, STUFF, knives...) then it's a scam. If the MLM on their resume isn't a scam, then I would consider it resume-worthy. But thats a case by case basis. 

Probably worse, if they did really well in an MLM and duped hundreds of people in buying items they can't ever hope to sell off their limited networks, then i'd hold that kind of dishonesty against them.

geo.mapper<- function (map = USA, 
                             data = home.prices){
# this function maps data with lat long
# and 1 other column onto a relevant map 
# 
the.map <- get_map (map)
heat. <- qmap (the.map, 
                          data, 
                           x = long,
                           y = lat,
                           color = value) 
return (heat.)
}

Wow!! Brings me back. I just moved back to the US from south Incheon (5  minute bike ride from Songdo). 

Songdo is great - canals designed to simulate Italy, Central Park designed to simulate NYC's central park. Massive investment in transit and biking. 

Another fun factoid - ALL the apartments in Songdo have built-in waste and recycling receptacles. You just stick it in the hole and everything goes to the processing center where recyclables are separated and the trash is incinerated w/carbon capture. 

The only problem is that Songdo is jokingly called a ghost-town. Created literally out of water in 2011 (they dumped millions of tons of dirt/sand to create a brand new island) the Economic Zone has successfully brought businesses, schools, hospitals, entertainment, etc. But it's still working on bringing people. 

There are families, business tourists/immigrants, and even partner universities of NY, Utah, and Colorado. It will take more time before young "millennials" really get pulled away from the more vibrant, epic, engaging Seoul just a few hours NE. 

I think if that happens, we'll have to re-assess a little bit of the Songdo optimism- no congestion is easy when there's no density.

The calculus of renting vs owning is much more complex than these comments. 

it's not just 5 yrs stationary vs salary increases from labor mobility. it's not just equity (which a few people are apparently forgetting can also be negative) and risk. 

If you want to make returns on real estate there are plenty of REITs. If you want a tax-friendly liability (turned asset after 30yrs) that you can cheaply pass down to the next generation  - consider stocks haha. 

The historical return on real estate in the vast majority of the country is low. Yes, if you can predict the next portland or denver and get in early then a home sounds viable. Yes, if you're good at repairs and can turn your own labor into value then fixing up homes to rent them is an option. But that is all separate from the idea that home = rent to self = free equity.  We should have learned that lesson 10 years ago.

The inflation metrics are probably wrong.   There I said it. 

With the abundance of non-physical goods- especially FREE ones (google searches? online profiles? online advice? DIY guides? open software? youtube entertainment?...) not being priced into GDP when priced substitutes exist but arent being demanded OF COURSE INFLATION LOOKS LOW. 

As another commenter said, the information asymmetry in pricing is so low, firms can't differentiate and raise prices as well. Plus, honestly,let's be real, the quality of products (i.e. their productivity) isn't necessarily up. Electronics have planned obselescence built in now. 

As for technological growth-  we hype a lot about worldchanging technological progress but what changed the world more:

The toilet  or  the newest galaxy S# 
the green revolution  or  terabyte hard drives. 

Yes yes of course cloud computing, localized machine learning, self driving cars, modern telecoms are all insanely amazing. but will they have to same impact *on the margins* as earlier world changing inventions. Maybe,  I'm excited for AI advancements but let's not pretend that these are all new. Many of the most fundamental computer algorithms were created in the 70s- we just have more and better data now.

Every wells fargo security breach or mass scam pushes bitcoin up a little bit, but I think we should hesitate before claiming to predict the deflationary pressure on bitcoins. They're currently only divisible to the .00000001 I believe. But if that changes we'll see some fundamentals shift.    I think of it like an economy- just because GDP grows doesn't mean the dollar rises.    We can see bitcoin get closer and closer to it's 21 million cap without necessarily seeing any related price changes.   This isnt even bringing up ICOs (the next .com bubble) or catchup coins (ethereum; litecoin, dogecoin, hibbertcoin haha). 

I'm bullish too, but I probably couldnt articulate why if someone really grilled me on it.

It's simple really. Do you love cable? Do you love not being entirely sure which channels are included in your packages? Do you like certain game-day blackouts (for sports fans)? Did you love your 500 hours AOL CD? 

Are you willing to add the calculus of your internet usage to your billing system? 

Do you like data caps? 

If you bought a pencil - would you want discounts and surcharges depending on if you draw "partner-pictures" or write "out-of-network"- sentences. 

Do you want ISPs to make their content fast and their competitor's content slower? 

In economic terms, 
Do you want to give up all the consumer surplus in this market so that the producers can perfectly price discriminate? 

$10 for 100 GB: FOX news, Hulu, reddit, and twitter data are waived. Reddit, CNN, and Netflix are charged 2x data usage from 9pm-12am M-Thurs.  Facebook is loaded 1/2 speed. 

$30 for 150 GB, Facebook data is waived 50%, adult sites are charged 25% data surcharge  from 10pm-2am, Netflix is only charged at 1.5x data. 

They already study your browsing habits. They'll find the exact price and combination that you'll pay for. How does any of this sound like innovation? 

Innovative pricing i guess...

i like this a lot, but it's just not the past-future assumption that's the problem (although the people pointing that out are right). There's unmodelable crisis events that limit our forecasting ability. The 5% in that 95% CI. 

It's like trying to model population growth in the 1910s. An amazing model may predict WWI. But could it also predict the spanish flu? 

The loss of a major exchange (this happened before, forgot the name), a government adding (or removing) legitimacy (SEC labeling it property or China making it illegal), or information shocks - we cant assume everyone in the market really understands the economics of having a 21 million bitcoin limit with a finite divisibility of each coin, let alone understanding the changing rate of difficulty in mining coins). 

Of course oil, foreign exchanges, and other commodities have their own chaotic (but small) risks too- cold fusion making oil worthless overnight maybe- but they've built up some inherent resistance to smaller shocks.  Many players in the market, barriers of entry (information/licenses), broad trust in solvency, etc. 

I guess, to say it shortly, bitcoins have inherent deflationary pressures and information asymmetries that make it  harder to model.

I did a year in Korea - some friendly advice: 

If you don't speak french, take language classes starting on day 1 - Although it's true many french people speak 2-3 languages including English and, generally, won't make you labor in French, it's the polite thing to do and allows you to get more into their culture, history, and literature. 

Take more pictures and write more than you think you should. A year will fly by. You'll be shocked at how many memories you can make. 

Don't make only English friends, it'll hurt a lot when you separate and it's easier to convince French friends to visit you in randomtown, USA.

Have FUN!!!  Make sure to get your family involved in the society too and get their own friends, etc. It'll be hard on everyone, but it sounds like you have a good head start!

There's institutional knowledge to be gained by just being around people, seeing how they work, learning how they want to be communicated with, what rewards work for them, and what their niche is.

Honestly, I did it for the politics. Which seems to be what all these comments are arguing. Are you setting examples that weaker employees will follow? (-my question- why do you have weak employees?) Do you not respect your boss? etc etc. 

I think forward facing companies are going to learn to drop the politics. Respect the Work. 

client meetings, availability needs, deadlines, those are objective measures that require timeliness. 

But if  your work has autonomy and responsibility than you need to respect the work and do it when *you're at your peak*.  

If prepping for 9am makes me a zombie and I have no objective reason to prep that early than it would be more respectful to the work for me to prep later and of course work until later. 

This isnt about laziness or entitlement. It's raw efficiency.

Bosses-don't ask for hours. Ask for productivity. Find measures for it and throw away the politics.

If you need more than 40 hours to do the job you're either incompetent OR invaluable. 
Incompetent if there's things your missing and ways of doing that you haven't saught to learn. 
Invaluable if the company is in a pinch and needs people to do more than their fair share. 

In both situations the answer is to learn. 

always stay learning to be better, faster, smarter

 and/or 

Learn to ask for what you deserve.

 Whether it be extra time off at the end of the rush, flexibility to work from home and put that commute time into your work, or a pay raise to hire a cleaning company so you can get those hours back! haha

why should every business invest in data science? 
1) your competitors probably make more data than you. Data is unreasonably effective. 

All the fancy AI stuff you hear about at workshops? those algorithms are from the 70s. We just finally have more data and fast computers. (i include this, but wouldn't say this if i were actually selling data science as an investment)

2) your competitors definitely make better data than you, since you haven't invested in data science. So you're even further behind than day 1. Their first 100 days was probably all spent on data architecture. 

3)  the fundamentals of business -pricing, quantities to buy, inventory, sellers, supply chain. Without data science, you're making gut science decisions. "I think we should buy more of these, they seem to sell well", "we should get her more hours; she gets tons of revenue". data science is gut science + statistics. Data tells you when you're wrong- people often don't.

hello to everyone at X company- 
1) how you came across the job (a referral would be best) 
2) a little bit about yourself 
3) why you feel like a good fit (show you understand the job description) 
4) example/story connecting parts 2 & 3 
5) thank you and contact. 

the hello isn't given a number because its the least important part. if you can get someone to refer you, or at least name a person you have a connection with (Sally Smith and I went to the same grad school and she emailed our cohort that ___ was hiring).  better than nothing.

personally, I've had my best resume success this last 2 weeks. my entirely new resume is: 
name
contact
links to website+portfolio+linkedin
career: 
title, company, location, time 
key skills (ATS list) used at that job
2 or 3 job highlights  
repeat as needed
page2: education 
place, degree, relevant classwork
2 or 3 relevant projects 

i have 5 jobs, 4 educations (BA, coursera spec, MS, relevant cerificates)  all organized in tables in Word.

I'm beating ATS, giving HR enough stories to craft a real person in their minds, and then in interviews I can bounce around the resume and answer a wider range of questions.

I don't know if you can train people skills in an authentic way, except for putting people in situations where it benefits them to practice those skills. This is where corporate social responsibility becomes a factor. When companies provide volunteer time off, take corporate trips together to help their community, network with community partners and otherwise engage people they don't get direct business value from. 

Corporate authenticity is a buzzword, but it's rooted in a real, but difficult, and sometimes costly cultural adjustment. Companies that think in the short-term (quarterly stock prices, raising funds for buybacks, flashy new offices to impress clients, raising expense account limits to keep the C-levels happy)  will struggle with validating these activities to the entire decision-system. This doesn't mean they'll go bankrupt or fail to profit or innovate. It's just that they won't be considered leaders.

Employers training their current employees is alive and well, I am just specifying that training new employees and being willing to find candidates that learn quickly instead of know many ______ is a competitive edge that many companies are slow to taking. This is possibly just a relic from the great recession, where amazing overqualified candidates were insanely cheap. Companies were quick to adapt to that. 

But if we accept the premise that it's a candidate's market (I don't accept this premise because it's really just a few narrow fields in my opinion) then eventually companies would have to adapt again and start selling themselves to clients instead of stoically demanding candidates bend to their whims and grovel for jobs.

Employees are crunched, the numbers say unemployment is low, but underemployment is high. People graduating from 2008-2011 who didnt get entry level jobs or struggled with unemployment are competing with more new graduates every year. Also, over 80% of jobs created since 2011 have gone to people with at least *some* college. And only 30% of 29 year olds have a bachelors degree. 

Because the responsibility (and cost) of education and certification has been moved to the candidate- we have this "skills gap". But for comparable positions a generation ago- the minimum viable candidate rarely included last-mile skills. This gives employers more leverage and lower costs. They can overwork employees scared to be unemployed (again). While waiting for candidates to pay for their own last-mile education before hiring them. 
This has numerous sociological consequences, see "unpaid internship" privilege and similar writings. The #1 predictor of career success is parent's wealth.

If you are ever in an interview and they try to give you a 20th century "through the wringer" interrogation style. Cut that off early. They ask 2-3 questions then you ask 1-2 questions.  Alternate.

Eventually text to speech (see google translate's LIVE visual translate through the camera) and speech to speech will advance to the point where learning another language is primary for high level negotiating, business conversations, diplomacy, etc. 
Computational linguistics are still limited by their inputs.  Languages have imbedded grammar "errors" (exceptions), idioms, flexibility in nouns/verbs (let's bounce = let's leave), historic phrases/structures, etc. 

You would need native speakers to handcode these edge cases if you really wanted to compete with a fluent translator. Also, that's not even getting into the use of slang in business (marketing especially)

I think step 1 is determine the relation of NAs to other features. For example, in weather and pollution data, do certain areas have disproportionate numbers NAs? What would cause an NA?  Are there actually other types of values (1, -1, 999) that should have been coded as NA? For example, having PM2.5 levels of -.5 ppm  which is technically impossible. 

I'm not a professional on imputation, but I've read a lot of criticisms on imputation as a whole, specifically the assumptions like normality  which are essentially doubled down when you use mean imputation. 

I would also worry about what imputation would do to residual diagnostics- could it artifically lower the leverage of important outliers? 

I'm biased toward removing NAs, especially when they're a small percentage of the data.

I support licensure in general. I support it fully for doctors and lawyers. I think the main argument against considering data science in the same pool is that there isn't a set list of requirements and abilities and roles for data scientists. 

I think there *should* be though. If licensure gets us closer to defining what a data scientist is and how to become one I think that's a good thing for the field as a whole. 

Accountants, lawyers, and doctors go through ethical training (as I believe more fields should). 
You go to specialized education centers and learn best practice, and then train with masters (apprenticeships should be in more than just manufacturing). 

As for what your masters or PhD is in, I think that should stay flexible. 

Astronomers and physicists make great data scientists, just as philosophy majors are some of the best prepped to enter med school (see Harvard's review of chemistry vs philosophy majors in med school).

UBI is a sustainable means of ensuring a stable velocity of money. Economic growth stagnates in a low interest rate environment when loans aren't being made. We've developed "socialism" for the rich (giving the largest companies and banks essentially free money with negative real interest rates) and ignored the bottom 99% of us. 

I've used U.S. Census data to identify tax rates for median income levels in the US, even assuming that the top 1% of US incomes only have a median taxable income of 250,000 (this is insanely conservative) a 19% basic income tax (after giving ALL american adults a basic income of $1,200 a month) pays for itself. This is cheaper than SNAP and other non-healthcare programs when administrative costs are included (you can actually see Heritage and other conservative think-tank estimates for welfare programs total costs) and because the basic income is taxed itself, effective tax rates are even lower. 

https://goo.gl/sQ3fcp

see pages 5-9. 

In addition, there is NO POVERTY TRAP. The incentive to work is preserved completely. The program is a negative effective tax rate all the way up to $70,000 per year, when you become a net payer of BI, at 0 effective tax.

Oh really, I thought it was not having enough money, connections, time, and fallbacks to take the risks necessary to grow. Good thing to know, all you need is the desire. 

Funny enough, this desire to be rich is paradoxically why the desperation hypothesis for buying lottery tickets holds so well.

Economists who study matching systems (most popularly behavioral economics of dating "markets") find a consistent bias to look for the "best" instead of accepting the most sufficient candidate under a time constraint. 

A famous "formula" (I'll find the article but its easily googleable)  in dating market analysis finds that assuming the chance of finding the perfect candidate is evenly distributed over time, and you know roughly how many potential candidates there are:  interview the first 37% of potential candidates. Then either pick the best youve seen or pick the first candidate (in the latter 63%) that matches or exceeds your best candidate. 

This formula (due to properties on the natural log function and our assumptions) gives you a 50% chance of getting a "best" candidate and a 50% of complete failure.

This is a good point. In my short time working with psychiatrists in education we found that the best methods were those that focused on what the child had control over (or at least felt they had control over). 

The positive reinforcement didn't come from the results - "you got a 100, you got a 98, you got a 50 what happened" - not because those things aren't valuable (they clearly are) but it was outside of what the child feels they have control over.  They do their assignment it goes to the "grading gods" and it is returned with a number that is essentially random for children under a certain maturity level (i.e. old enough to where they could independently identify their mistakes given notes and some time). 

Instead we focused on reinforcing processes like effort. Some proxies like total time spent practicing, total practice worksheets willingly added  to their work, time they were able to spend focused on one task - for example, sustained writing,. Not feeling done on the first attempt, asking for chances to submit 2 or even 3 versions of an assignment. 

When you focus on what they feel in control of, you can positively reinforce effort and (almost secretly) the idea that effort --> results.  TNWC (The numbers will come).

To respond to Mr. Grinberg, I am struggling to identify what criteria they used to get these top 90. LinkedIn says it is based on "readers" "linkedIn Data" "and More..." and all current and former LinkedIn employees are exempt. If it were all perfectly average you'd expect about 8-9 of these writers to be black. But given LinkedIn is <10% black and less than 10% of contributors are black and this list is pulled from the top 10 from 9 different subjects (where each of those top ten are statistically 90+% white) It seems to be unfortunate math that the writers don't represent the English Speaking Population.

Teachers don't "get" summers off. They are laid off with the expectation of re-hire. 

If you want quality teachers make it pay like a profession - like Engineering. 
If you want teachers to grow and use new teaching techniques - make it a defined SMART goal; conferences right now are all content, no knowledge; and we need to have reasonable expectations about what implementing a new technique would look like. 

Also, at the end of the day, you might just need to build more schools and support a system where school is actually a choice again. Our schools are more segregated than ever before  -by race, economics, anything - and kids still go to whichever school is closest. 

I don't mean to stand against your article, I think the premise is sound, innovation is growth; but there are so many structural issues in education - students with nutritional, psychological, and economic needs not being met; classrooms filled to the brim with students often not prepared for the grade/class they are in; teachers being asked to be a soundboard, a counselor, a parent, an instructor, a friend to dozens of students at a time. Asking them to also teach proper use of technology while incorporating technology that is often haphazard won't be some magic fix.
